PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr ACTING SPEAKER (Mr Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.PRESENTERS: ALDRED; BEALE; BOWEN; BROWN; CAMERON; CARLTON; CHARLES; CLEELAND; COBB; COHEN; CROSS; DUFFY; EDWARDS; FISCHER; FISHER; GRIFFITHS; HEWSON; HICKS; HOLDING; HUMPHREYS; LEE; MILDREN; MILLAR; MOORE; MORRIS; NEHL; PEACOCK; SCHOLES; SCOTT; SHARP; SIMMONS; SNOWDON; SULLIVAN; WEST
PETITION.NAMEIDS: KD4; OE4; ZE4; PD4; 9F4; DF4; GF4; KF4; MF4; NF4; YF4; 6G4; 9G4; DG4; EG4; 0H4; 9H4; AH4; CH4; FH4; MG4; AI4; CI4; EI4; FI4; AE4; MI4; 5J4; 8J4; AJ4; FJ4; IJ4; 3E4; XJ4
PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
If open not-for-profit health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
Some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Aldred (from 356 citizens), Mr Beale (from 185 citizens), Mr Lionel Bowen (from 12 citizens), Mr N.A. Brown (from 96 citizens), Mr Donald Cameron (from 849 citizens), Mr Carlton (from 48 citizens), Mr Charles (from 273 citizens), Mr Cleeland (from 257 citizens), Mr Cobb (from 196 citizens), Mr Cohen (from 131 citizens), Mr Cross (from 474 citizens), Mr Duffy (from 357 citizens), Dr Harry Edwards (from 42 citizens), Mr Tim Fischer (from 109 citizens), Mr Peter Fisher (from 38 citizens), Mr Griffiths (from 36 citizens), Dr Hewson (from 98 citizens), Mr Hicks (from 76 citizens), Mr Holding (from 572 citizens), Mr Humphreys (from 2,401 citizens), Mr Lee (from 89 citizens), Mr Mildren (from 40 citizens), Mr Millar (from 263 citizens), Mr Moore (from 139 citizens), Mr Allan Morris (from 213 citizens), Mr Nehl (from 288 citizens), Mr Peacock (from 340 citizens), Mr Scholes (from 49 citizens), Mr Les Scott (from 136 citizens), Mr Sharp (from 93 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 61 citizens), Mr Snowdon (from 70 citizens), Mrs Sullivan (from 444 citizens) and Mr West (from 190 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CAMERON; DARLING; FATIN; JENKINS; KATTER; MILES; SCIACCA; TUCKEY; WOODS
PETITION.TITLE: Pornography in Videos, Films and Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE videos, films and publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian Community.
Because Parliament has a direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the house:
to ban the importation, and availability of pornography in videos, films and publications,
to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material,
vote against any recommendation to extend video and theatre film classifications and guidelines into television standards,
ensure that pay television does not exceed the program limits of television standards,
control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation,

give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron (from 16 citizens), Mrs Darling (from eight citizens), Ms Fatin (from 24 citizens), Mr Jenkins (from five citizens), Mr Katter (from 62 citizens), Mr Miles (from 48 citizens), Mr Sciacca (from 13 citizens), Mr Tuckey (from 289 citizens) and Dr Woods (from 46 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CARLTON; HEWSON; MORRIS; SCOTT; SNOWDON; WOOLDRIDGE
PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available for the treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Carlton (from 27 citizens), Dr Hewson (from 54 citizens), Mr Allan Morris (from 31 citizens), Mr Les Scott (from 21 citizens), Mr Snowdon (from 44 citizens) and Dr Wooldridge (from five citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that major reforms be made to Australia's Retirement Income System. These reforms are earnestly sought by retired Australians and those facing retirement.
The reforms are:
That the pension be increased to 30% of average weekly earnings (i.e. increasing the basic pension to $146 p.w.).
That the pension become tax exempt.
That the pension be adjusted so that it keeps pace with price rises rather than falling up to 12 months behind.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray that your House/Parliament will see that our requested reforms are implemented.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann (from 15 citizens), Mr Charles (from 102 citizens), Mr Humphreys (from 78 citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 1,134 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families;

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the House require the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force most Australian home-seekers out of the housing market=mand many Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Fife (from 12 citizens), Mr Jull (from 135 citizens) and Mr Shack (from 142 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
Recent huge rises in mortgage interest rates have pushed the cost of buying their own home beyond the reach of most Australian families;

Those Australians already paying off home mortgages are now suffering severely and unfairly through increased mortgage payments or longer repayment times so that many will never pay off their mortgage and go further and further into debt unless interest rates fall substantially.

Now, therefore, your petitioners request that the House require the Hawke-Keating Government to cease its excessive reliance on high interest rates as its major economic policy weapon and instead to use other measures which would allow interest rates to return to levels that do not force Australians out of their homes-so that the traditional right of home ownership is returned to average Australian families.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Ewen Cameron (from 33 citizens) and Dr Harry Edwards (from eight citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Madam Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the Pharmaceutical benefits scheme which has severely affected the viability of our community pharmacies and their ability to provide the quality and quantity of services to which we as Australians have a right.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which ensures the availability of Pharmaceutical Benefits through Local Community Pharmacies.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett (from 18 citizens) and Mr Snow (from 673 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Madam Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the continued Government interference in the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which is causing hardship and confusion amongst the sick and elderly.

Your petitioners therefore request the House to guarantee the provision of an adequately funded Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme which is free from Government tampering and provides for the public of Australia a comprehensive range of modern therapeutic products.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Post
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and all members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House proposals by Australia Post to close down hundreds of post offices in rural and regional areas.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the House request the Government to ensure that any restructuring of Australia Post's operations does not result in any reduction of postal services to customers.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Cobb (from 189 citizens) and Mr Nehl (from 78 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Chlorofluorocarbons
PETITION.PARA: To: The Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are concerned at the threat to the environment that may result from an acceleration of the Greenhouse Effect.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government:
1. To ban immediately both the exporting and the importing of Chlorofluorocarbons (CFC's) with the same exceptions as those specified in the Ozone Protection Bill.
2. To introduce tax deductibility of-
(a) cost and installation of solar heating systems; and
(b) cost and installation of home insulation.
3. To introduce tax incentives for-
(a) research and development of renewable energy alternatives;
(b) manufacturing and marketing of renew- able energy alternatives; and
(c) development of new technology to reduce or avoid the use of environmental pollutants.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will legislate to provide these facilities.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Tim Fischer (from 83 citizens) and Mr Nehl (from 502 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) the Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) the large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Jenkins (from 11 citizens) and Dr Wooldridge (from 43 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Star of the Sea Home for Aged at Wallaroo, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House-
That the Star of the Sea Home for Aged at Wallaroo, South Australia, has operated very successfully with 21 Hostel Beds since 1978 and its associated Nursing Home of 10 beds since 1985.

The Department of Community Services and Health has advised, that as from the 31st of December, 1989 the present level of financial subsidy for the Nursing Home will be substantially reduced making it impossible for the Nursing Home to continue operating at its present numbers.

As the District, in which the Nursing Home is situated, has the highest ratio of aged persons, per head of population in South Australia, there is an ever increasing and definite need for the Nursing Home to continue providing this essential service.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House:

Will ensure that a financially viable Nursing Home, as an adjunct to the Star of the Sea Home for Aged at Wallaroo, South Australia will be maintained, by either a continuation of the present level of Funding or approval for additional beds to be allocated.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism.
Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including: cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness.
Alcohol causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.
Television and radio have a persuasive effect on children and young people.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectively showeth-
That there is a general dissatisfaction in the community at the levels of road funding made available by the Federal Government.
While noting the commitment of the Government to maintain a high standard of roads in Australia, we are specifically concerned at the real cutbacks for roadfunding in the Local Government area.
We especially note that roadworks are a labour intensive industry and cutbacks will create unemployment and hardship in rural areas.
Your petitioners request that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled give due consideration to increasing the amount of funds available to Local Government authorities for roadworks.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy and Isolated Children's Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the introduction of an Assets Test for Austudy and Isolated Children's Allowance for students, particularly in country areas, is unfair and excludes many students from financial help where parents do not have a substantial income.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House abolish the Assets Test and use an Income Test to determine eligibility for the payment of Austudy or the Isolated Children's Allowance.

PETITION.TITLE: Smoking Sections on Qantas International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that they are opposed to the removal of smoking sections on Qantas International Flights.

To do so would jeopardize our fledgling Tourist Industry and would discriminate against thirty percent of Australians who wish to smoke. This proposal would also harm Qantas profits and good public image and would cause the International Traveller to use Overseas Airlines who are prepared to provide services which are required by ALL passengers.
The argument of so called Passive Smoking does not apply if the aircraft's air-conditioning system is operating to its optimum.
Your petitioners therefore request the parliament to totally ignore any such demands made upon Qantas.
Your Petitioners, in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament: The petition of certain electors of the Division of Indi.

Draws to the attention of the House the current inadequate level of funding for road construction and maintenance and express concern that the House may have placed before it, as part of the government economic strategy, options to further reduce such expenditure, and in so doing placing an increased financial burden upon local government ratepayers.

Your petitioners therefore respectfully call upon the House to ensure an increase over current road funding levels through a clear dedication of a proportion of fuel excise collected, indexed for inflation, towards roadworks and that such funding arrangements provide for a clear and reliable method of distribution to local government.

PETITION.TITLE: Moratorium on Mining of the Antarctic
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by proposed mining activity to the ecological integrity and wilderness values of the Antarctic continent.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government to:
withdraw from the signing of the Convention for the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activity (CRAMRA) and extend the moratorium on mining;
take a leading role in preparing a Conservation Convention, that will preserve Antarctica as a World Park and the last wilderness continent on Earth untouched by human exploitative activities;
continue its high emphasis on environmental protection for the Australian Antarctic Territory.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation Rural Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that
Listeners to ABC in country regions are dependent on advice and information provided in farming segments of ABC programs, particularly ``Farming Today'' and ``National Farm Report''
Information in programs as presently presented is relevant to the region in which it is broadcast and this is vital to country regions
Country listeners have a long established, traditional link with ABC Rural programs and a reliance on those services.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House ask the ABC to review its decision to alter its rural programs in any way.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Federal fuel excise taxation has reached record levels resulting in high costs for fuel and causing severe hardship particularly for people in country areas.
At the same time there has been a considerable reduction in the amount of Federal fuel excise taxation spent on roads, reduced from 66 per cent in 1983 to 20 per cent in 1989.

Your Petitioners therefore pray that the House call on the Federal Government to take heed of the crisis situation facing small business, large fuel users and the crisis situation relation to road infrastructure and-
1. Reduce by half the CPI Federal fuel tax increases
2. Increase by half the proportion of Federal fuel taxation being spent on roads

PETITION.TITLE: Ozone Layer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully calls for:
1. Legislation to control and limit the use of substances in Australia that damage the ozone layer.

2. Action by the Australian Parliament to raise international awareness, and promote joint action by other governments and parliaments to take similar action to protect the ozone layer from destruction.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Manufacture of Paper Products
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Federal Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully shows that we are gravely concerned about the dangerous substances-dioxins-that are found in the products we purchase and use regularly (products such as tampons, sanitary napkins and baby napkins).
We therefore beseech the Federal Parliament to immediately:
1. Inquire into, and regulate if necessary the process used to bleach the paper used in such products as tampons, sanitary napkins and baby napkins, so as to remove all dioxins.
2. To encourage, through either regulation or incentive, manufacturers (and importers) to produce products made without the use of chlorine.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broken Hill: Aged Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Broken Hill in the State of New South Wales, points out to the House and calls on the Federal Government to accept its responsibility by providing sufficient suitable Nursing Home and Hostel accommodation for those Broken Hill citizens who are frail or aged.
Your petitioners therefore request the House:

(1) Negotiates with the N.S.W. State Government to maintain sufficient long-stay beds at the Broken Hill Base Hospital until it, the Federal Government with whom the responsibility of care for the aged lies, provides the accommodation required.
(b) Also requests that increased funding be provided for support services that provide care for the frail and aged in their own homes in Broken Hill.

PETITION.TITLE: International Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating;
important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (the peoples' arm of the UN), has proclaimed an Australian ERA (Earth Repair Action) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a safer and more peaceful future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that an International Earth Repair Action (ERA) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5, 1990 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly. This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global co-operation to hygienically compost all presently wasted bio-degradable materials into humus to revitalise soils; grow billions of trees to replace forests lost and replenish the atmosphere; establish sustainable, economic and agricultural growth internationally, and end world hunger.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Kakadu National Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned shows:
That we oppose any mineral exploration or mining in any part of Kakadu National Park, the Kakadu Conservation Zone, or the Alligator Rivers Region.
Your petitioners ask that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Halt all mineral exploration and mining in the Kakadu conservation zone by revoking current leases and licences and by incorporating the zone in Kakadu National Park and;

Prevent proposed mining in Kakadu stages one and two by incorporating the Jabiluka and Koongarra project areas in the National Park and by proclaiming the whole park under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act, 1983.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Importation of Tropical Timber
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
Place an immediate ban on the import of all tropical timber.

Throughout the world tropical rainforest is being cleared at a catastrophic pace. The Earth is now losing its tropical forests at the rate of 7% a year and the end of almost all the planet's rainforests is now in sight.

Scientists estimate 200 species of fauna and flora are forced into extinction every day. This is primarily due to habitat destruction which for the majority of the world's species is tropical rainforest.
Scientific evidence is also overwhelming that tropical rainforest destruction is playing a significant part in increasing the greenhouse effect.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law.
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901 and each point depicting a State and the Territories of the Commonwealth.
3. They know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to its form or to its acceptance as the sole Australian National Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled:
will ensure that the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change and remains the sole National Flag.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

This humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that they are totally opposed to any change in the present Australian National Flag as declared in the Flags Act (1953).
Your petitioners humbly pray that Parliament in its wisdom will take no action to change in any way the Australian National Flag.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Overseas Vaccination Clinics
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that:

The undersigned are gravely concerned about the proposed closure of the Overseas Vaccination Clinic in the ACT which is part of a nation-wide network of clinics funded by the Department of Community Services and Health. We understand that these changes:
will result in the loss of expert knowledge on exotic diseases in specific areas;
will place overseas travellers at risk by denying them access to this expert knowledge;
will place the citizens of Australia at risk by increasing the chances of an epidemic in Australia.
will cost the Government more in the long term as the costs of vaccination will be transferred to another area such as Medicare.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in the Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Maintain the Overseas Vaccination Clinics in their present form which provides an accessible expert service.
And you petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House:
That people throughout rural and regional Australia are being discriminated against by unjustly high fuel prices.

They believe the Government should legislate to require a uniform price discount to all wholesalers when this is offered by the oil companies, and thus remove the major component in the retail price differential of approximately ten cents per litre.
Your Petitioners therefore request the House to amend the legislation to allow cheaper fuel price justice for country people.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the electorate of Murray respectfully showeth that:
Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely to a great degree on the local road network for all facets of their lives.
Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infrastructure.
Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Treaty between Aboriginal and Other Australians
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
1. there is a need for continuing reconciliation between Aboriginal and other Australians to enhance the unity of the Australian nation.
2. the Federal Government proposes a ``Treaty'' between Aboriginal and other Australians.

3. as a ``Treaty'' is an agreement between two sovereign states, such an agreement would recognise Aborigines and other Australians as two separate nations and thereby divide Australia and set back prospects for reconciliation.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House oppose the conclusion of a Treaty between Aboriginal and other Australians or any proposal which divides rather than unites Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully draws to the attention of the House that whilst all State Governments have agreed to legislation to prevent the distribution of X-Rated videos, a loophole in Commonwealth laws allows the distribution of this material by mail order from Canberra.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the House urge the Government to pass legislation to ban the distribution of X-Rated videos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Northern Territory Aboriginal Areas Protection Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the Parliament:

We, the undersigned citizens of the Northern Territory, point out to the House that the Northern Territory Aboriginal Areas Protection Bill (1988) is totally unacceptable to Aboriginal people. This new law will take control of the protection of sacred sites away from Aboriginal people and give it to an NT Government Minister. We therefore ask the House to stop this Bill becoming law, to make a better law, and to help Aboriginal people to properly protect their sacred sites.

PETITION.TITLE: Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his Government
(1) to phase out woodchipping for export;
(2) not to renew a long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

(3) to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and
(4) to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including:
re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods on already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and
minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.

PETITION.TITLE: Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of citizens of Australia points out to the House that the ACT Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 has legalised the screening of blasphemy, indecency, and obscenity.
Because Parliament has traditionally respected the beliefs of its people and your petitioners therefore request that the House:
1. retain section 13 of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations as is;
2. control ALL censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation;

3. give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without full and thorough debate in both Houses of Parliament.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT SELECT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS LEGISLATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 April, on motion by Mr Ronald Edwards:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to comment on the report of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation and, in particular, to praise the work of the Chairman of the Committee, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), who, in the course of the inquiry, managed to achieve something which I hope is not remarkable in this Parliament but which I suspect occurs too infrequently, that is, very harmonious and good working relations on a committee which comprised membership from all parties in this Parliament and representatives from both this House and the Senate. I suppose it would be fair in that regard also to express and place on the record my own appreciation of the work of the Deputy Chairman, Senator Jim Short from Victoria. He shared that responsibility and also made sure that the work of the Committee proceeded smoothly and without the kinds of internal difficulties that might have been thought possible for a committee dealing in an area of some controversy.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the ultimate outcome of the report has been very worthwhile. Notwithstanding that there is a rather half-hearted dissenting report saying that the national scheme should not proceed, the Committee's main work has been to put forward very sensible proposals when it comes to the terms of the Corporations Bill itself, proposals which I believe will substantially improve the package and will be broadly welcomed by participants in the marketplace.

It is impossible to deal effectively today with all the various matters that have been canvassed, but I should mention that a couple of aspects required particular attention and took considerable time of the Committee, particularly questions of fundraising and prospectuses and how they can best be dealt with. In that regard the Committee has made proposals which will involve some tightening up of the fundraising and prospectus areas, but without substantially moving away from the aims of the drafters of the legislation which are essentially to move towards a more efficient market approach. The Committee has, however, also been very conscious of the need for adequate investor protection and that has underpinned many of its recommendations.

There was one area where the Committee membership was divided on a matter of substance with respect to the draft Bill. The Committee divided equally on this issue, with five members supporting a particular view and five supporting the alternative view. The issue was resolved by the Chairman exercising his casting vote. I should say that the division was not one along party lines; it simply reflected different views as to the appropriateness of one particular matter, and that was the question of which body within the regulatory framework would be best fitted to make declarations as to unacceptable conduct. As the House would be aware, the Bill proposes to establish a corporations and security panel to decide whether particular corporate behaviour is to be condemned and regarded as unacceptable. Certain conclusions flow from such a declaration, and the Bill now gives enforcement powers to that panel. The majority of the Committee, that majority constituting of five members with the casting vote of the Chair, regarded that as an inappropriate division of responsibility and recommended that the power to make declarations of unacceptable conduct remain with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC)-the successor to the present National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC).

I took the view that the original draft was quite appropriate and, in company with Senator Alston from the Liberal Party, Senator Cooney and Senator McMullan from the Australian Labor Party and Senator Macklin from the Australian Democrats, I expressed the view that it is desirable that the Australian Securities Commission should have only an investigative role and that matters of adjudication should properly be dealt with by the panel. The dissenting report concludes that the NCSC's submission to the Committee had greatly overstated the extent to which the ASC's capacity to police the securities market would be affected by the terms of the draft Bill. The minority report also noted that the overwhelming weight of evidence given to the Joint Committee by the business community favoured the power remaining with the panel. I stress that point. One of the reasons why the corporate world has given such strong support to this proposal is that it sees an end to its fears that an investigatory body would also be the policeman, the judge and the jury in relation to decisions which affect corporate reputations.

Our dissent concluded: `We have a fundamental objection to giving the same body the right to be both prosecutor and jury when other equally effective and convenient alternatives are available'. This was the one point of disagreement within the Committee and in a report of great complexity, a report which deals with great issues of substance. The issues are potentially controversial. All other issues were resolved without a dissenting report being tabled. It is a tribute to the Chairman-who is present in the House-who led that Committee so well. I also pay tribute to the cooperative attitude of all members of the Committee to the work of the Committee. The time available for its work was short. I also note the constructive contribution of the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), from the National Party, who is also present in the House. I conclude my remarks in order that he may place his views on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation, I congratulate the Chairman, the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards), on its report. He had a very difficult role to play and he did it well. I thank our Secretary, Mr Andrew Snedden, and his staff for preparing such a complex report in the short time available. The Committee worked through almost all of the recess. For three weeks of February the Committee was totally involved in hearings. To allow the Chairman time to say something, I will express briefly a real concern I have about the nature and level of consultations that took place prior to the legislation we were investigating being produced.

SPEECH.PARA: There are serious reasons for questioning the membership of the consultative committee, particularly the fact that it was representative of the major players in the corporate sector in the eastern States. It was not until this Committee started its operations that the general community was aware of the extent and nature of this legislation. It was at that time that most of the submissions came forward on the various issues. I should like to speak about the transitional arrangements and the constitutional problems but, in view of the time, I will just read the conclusion brought down in the dissenting report of four members of that Committee in relation to the Australian Securities Commission Bill, Senator Richard Alston, Senator Jim Short, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) and me. Our conclusion states:

The Co-operative Scheme has served Australia well since its inception nine years ago. In particular, the NCSC has built up an impressive record, and is widely regarded and respected both within Australia and overseas.

We recognise that there are improvements that can and should be made to the regulation of the corporations and securities industries in Australia. Many of these are contained in the Corporations Bill now before the Parliament. We generally support the views on this Bill outlined in the main body of this report.

In our view, however, no compelling case has been produced to support the need for major structural change to the regulatory framework as proposed in the Australian Securities Commission Bill. There are, on the contrary, strong arguments against such wide ranging structural change.

Any deficiencies in the present arrangements can be rectified without difficulty. To address these deficiencies by a totally new structure which is opposed by every State and the Northern Territory, and by many other organisations, and which detailed examination shows clearly to be found wanting, would be to embark on a legislative adventure of monumental folly.
Accordingly, we recommend that the ASC Bill be totally rejected, and that the existing Co-operative Scheme be retained and strengthened.

Change is necessary. Anybody who reads the daily business papers will see the sorts of difficulties that so many of our governments and investors run into regularly with some of our corporate structures. We need change, but we do not believe the recommendations the Government is bringing forward are necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank my colleagues for their kind remarks. I simply make the observation that one's effectiveness as chairperson of a committee is determined by the skill of one's colleagues on that committee; that was always evident-their skill and commitment was excellent. I thank my colleagues for their remarks, and I believe that the success of this exercise really is a tribute to them and to the work of the secretariat of the Joint Select Committee on Corporations Legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that a couple of things ought to be said. The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) referred to the question of the declarations power. Yes, there was a division in the Committee over that. It was the view of the majority of the Committee that the power to make declarations of unacceptable conduct should remain with the Australian Securities Commission (ASC), in order that that body have sufficient authority and stature in the business community, and also in the light of recent corporate activity, so that the Commission has sufficient clout to operate in a way that will improve the level of corporate behaviour and compliance in certain areas-obviously, this does not apply across the board, but to certain areas.

In the view of the majority of the Committee, and in my view, it was considered important that the power to make declarations of unacceptable conduct should remain with the ASC. However, as soon as it affects property rights-that is, the disposal of shares or other assets-the power to make orders should go to the panel. We believe that that is an appropriate division of the range of responsibilities and powers. I note that the Committee was divided over that matter, although the majority of members were of the view that the power to make declarations should reside with the Australian Securities Commission.

I now turn to the question of Rothwells Ltd. The circumstance is this: the Committee requested a copy of the interim report on Rothwells, and I must say with some regret that we were denied access to that report until our report was concluded, because there is some evidence that the interim report on Rothwells contained information which would have enabled the Committee to be better informed on the compulsive powers of the current National Companies and Securities Commission vis-a-vis the Australian Securities Commission. In fact, some of the material in that report would have been germane to our considerations. However, the report of the Committee is not considerably deficient in that respect.

I make the following point in relation to Rothwells: what can clearly be deduced from the evidence that has been put before the Australian people and the Australian Parliament in the interim report on Rothwells is that we do need a very strong regulatory authority in this country to deal with business malpractice. It is very important from the point of view of investor protection. It is also important to protect the rest of the business community which, in the view of the Committee, has a very good reputation and conducts its business affairs in the best possible way and promotes an efficiently operating free enterprise economy in Australia. However, whilst matters such as the Rothwells matter are allowed to go on, clearly, the business reputation of Australia will be damaged. It is clearly a concern of the Committee as a whole that it is important to have a proper regulatory framework that will enable us to manage such corporate activity better in the near future.

The only other matter I want to refer to concerns the question of pre-vetting. The Committee as a whole believed that pre-vetting of prospectuses and part A statements should remain. The reason for that is that we could find no-one in the business community who was willing to take responsibility for these statements. In the absence of that willingness to take responsibility, it was the view of the Committee that the regulatory authorities ought to retain a role and, accordingly, we made our determination on this matter. As is evident, these matters are of some current significance. The Committee as a whole worked extremely well. I commend and compliment members of the Committee for their work, and I also compliment the secretariat. I believe that the report is worth serious consideration by this Parliament and by the Australian business community.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned to the next sitting Thursday.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Cobb.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this year some citizens demonstrating outside the front of the new Parliament House burnt an Australian flag as part of their protest. This quite despicable act guaranteed these people nationwide media coverage for their cause. Like many other Australian citizens-I do not overstate it by saying this-I was horrified and outraged at seeing our national flag destroyed in this manner, in a cheap, defiant and quite deliberate action calculated to gain the maximum publicity at the expense of our nation's symbol-our flag. I raised this matter with the Speaker in the House and, like many others, was surprised to find that no penalty exists for such actions. To rectify that deficiency I am introducing this private member's Bill into the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Although relating to the Australian national flag and its ensigns, which are defined under the Flags Act, the penalties contained in this Bill-the Crimes (Protection of Australian Flags) Bill 1989-are described as an addition to our Crimes Act. If this Bill is implemented and passed, anyone who, from then on, desecrates or otherwise dishonours the Australian national flag or an Australian ensign or who, without lawful authority, burns, mutilates or otherwise destroys our flag shall be deemed guilty of an offence and subject to a penalty of $5,000 or imprisonment for two years or both.

Many other countries around the world have penalties for similar offences against their flag. The penalties proposed in this Bill are not inconsistent with penalties imposed overseas. Our soldiers fought under our flag in two world wars so that we might all live in freedom in this lucky country. The price paid for that freedom is one that we should not lightly forget. Those people who so insolently burned our flag outside Parliament House recently should realise that, whatever their grievance, they should never resort to such a treasonable insult. What other nation would allow its flag to be dishonoured with impunity? Such behaviour is totally unacceptable to most people. Are we to be treated, or do we want to be treated, with this sort of spectacle every time some unwashed, disaffected group of people who have probably contributed little or nothing to the welfare of this nation want a cheap publicity shot? When they burn our flag they mock every decent tradition and foundation in Australia-traditions, loyalty and pride that have been built up through the contribution of all Australians over the last 200 years.

Consequently, I and most others strongly and sincerely feel that any actions which desecrate or dishonour our flag are totally offensive. Unless we have respect for our flag we can have no respect for anyone, including ourselves. It is time that the line was drawn. I challenge anyone who disputes that penalties are needed for these actions to conduct a poll among the general population. If we claim to represent the people we much correct this oversight. If we care about our country and what it stands for, we will support what is proposed in this legislation. I ask for and I expect the unanimous support of all honourable members in this chamber for this Bill.
Bill read a first time.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with sessional order 104a, the second reading will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOUTH PACIFIC NUCLEAR FREE ZONE TREATY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) supports the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty; and
(2) opposes the (a) stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia; (b) testing of nuclear weapons in Australia; and (c) acquisition or production of nuclear weapons by Australia.

Before this debate begins, it is important to put on record what this motion calls for. It calls on the House of Representatives, first, to support the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty and, secondly, to oppose the stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia, the testing of nuclear weapons in Australia and the acquisition or production of nuclear weapons by Australia. I understand that the motion is to be seconded by the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). I would have hoped that a motion such as this, which captures so much of the aspirations of what we as a country represent, would have been supported by all the Parliament because it expresses revulsion and abhorrence of nuclear weapons and sends a signal to the world that Australia will not be a part of nuclear weapons. Regrettably, that will not be the case. The Opposition undoubtedly will oppose this motion in line with its newly adopted policy which recently has been actively promoted. It sends another signal, this time to the Australian electorate, to the effect that the coalition is prepared to countenance and support the stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia.

The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty was a very proud initiative, not just of this Government, but of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself. The Government took up the initiative as soon as it gained office and endeavoured to work to achieve consensus within the South Pacific nuclear free zone. Australia promoted the concept at the Fourteenth South Pacific Forum, which met in Canberra in August 1983. Ultimately, in 1986, that Treaty became a reality. If the initiative for the Zone was Australia's, the Treaty itself constitutes a genuinely collective effort by the countries of the South Pacific Forum. The Opposition will effectively attack those countries as well as this Government when it contributes in due course to this debate today.

The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is not like other treaties that have been entered into by this Government. It did not become a part of the Australian legal framework by some simple executive act alone, some decision by the Government simply to sign the Treaty. I, together with a number of other people, including the present Governor-General and our Prime Minister, was present on the occasion of the signing of the Treaty. What we did as a government was something much more. We put into legislation, for the first time ever in the history of the world, a decision of the Government that, by law of the land, we would not permit the testing of nuclear weapons in Australia, the acquisition or development of nuclear weapons by Australia or the stationing of nuclear weapons in our country. Of course, that became a law passed by this Parliament, though opposed by the Opposition. It was assented to by the Governor-General.

When the Opposition brings forward its pro-nuclear policy it is suggesting that it is able to repeal that law of the Commonwealth Parliament. It will not be able to. Not only is the law supported by the Australian Labor Party but it is supported by independent senators and by the Australian Democrats, many of whom would seek to take this policy further. The important thing is that nobody-certainly not the Opposition-is going to be allowed to turn back the clock in this matter.

It is worthwhile to retrace briefly the history of the announcement of the Opposition policy. On 10 March 1989 the Opposition, led by the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) as the shadow spokesman on this matter, distributed to coalition members and senators a draft foreign policy. On page 8 of that document there was a discussion of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. It said:
A Liberal-National government will renegotiate the Treaty-
for which we read `will tear up the Treaty'-
so as not to prohibit the stationing of nuclear forces of allies in Australia's land or sea areas.

As often occurs in the conservative parties, that draft document became widely available to the press before the official policy launch on 7 April. A number of stories were published which recorded that a coalition government would allow nuclear weapons to be based in Australia. For example, the Adelaide Advertiser of 6 April recorded in a banner headline:
United States nuclear forces could be stationed in Australia under coalition government, a leaked policy document has revealed.

Of course, the effect of that was to promote an incredible community backlash. I say to the Opposition that we are not living in the 1950s; we are not living in the Cold War era. We are living in a time when Australians, together with so many other people around the world, have realised that we have got to put an end to nuclear madness. In the same way that the Opposition is out of step with Australian public opinion in its concern for environmental preservation, so too is it out of step with Australian public opinion on this issue. I take the view, as I am sure my colleagues do-in particular, the honourable member for the Northern Territory-that this Parliament ought to be showing the way on issues like nuclear weapons and environmental preservation-issues which go to the very essence of the preservation of life on earth and the safety of our planet.

The problem for the Liberals was that there could have been incredible community backlash from this policy. This gave the Liberals one heck of a fright. They redrafted the sentence and in the final version of their policy, when it was eventually released, read a little differently. It said:
A Liberal/National Coalition Government will renegotiate the Treaty so as to overcome these restrictions on Australia's freedom of action.

The Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for North Sydney, said in his press conference on 7 April that the coalition policy would not allow stationing of nuclear weapons, but this somehow left the impression that the option had not been ruled out. For example, the story written by the Australian Associated Press (AAP) after that press conference recorded:
Australia should have the option of allowing deployment of allied nuclear weapons to deter a threatened attack, Opposition Foreign Affairs Spokesman John Spender said today.
The AAP story went on to say:
In the final document released today the wording was changed but the meaning was the same.

We have a sleight of hand trick and an attempt to gloss over the precise meaning of the policy. But according to independent commentators and the Australian public the meaning is absolutely unambiguous-tear up the Treaty and allow nuclear weapons to be stationed in Australia. We in the Government totally reject that proposition. I might say, as I often do in this House, that this is not a sectarian issue. This is not an issue that is of total concern to the Labor Party. The Australian Democrats-to their great credit-issued a statement that condemned the Opposition policy. Senator Jean Jenkins said in her press release:

The Liberal and National parties have foolishly chosen to identify themselves with the minority who would place the needs of the USA above those of Australia. This greatly increases John Howard's prospects of going into oblivion at the next election.

The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is not objected to by the United States. It is perfectly consistent with the United States interests. Its Government has gone on record saying that. Senator Jenkins went on to say:
The Opposition proposed a course that would warrant nuclear attacks against Australia in the event of hostilities.

It is completely out of step with what the majority of the Parliament, including Independent senators, the Australian Democrats and the overwhelming majority of members of the House of Representatives, believe. It is not just on that issue that the Opposition is out of step with public opinion. I am going to stick very strictly to this debate but let me say by way of example that the policy it has on foreign investment-this free market, open slather approach to foreign investment-is rejected by the Government. We will not support the policy of abolishing the Foreign Investment Review Board. Again, it is a question of whether or not political parties place Australia's national interests ahead of the interests of other people. We on this side have absolutely no hesitation in saying where we stand.

The Opposition's foreign affairs policy, as it relates to these and related matters, was severely criticised by a number of prominent commentators. It was said, for example, that the United States Cold War attitude was very similar to the blinkered and very out of date policy adopted by the Opposition-the then Government-under the late Sir William McMahon when Gough Whitlam went to China in an attempt to build dialogue with the Chinese. At that time, when the now Opposition was in government, it condemned Labor leader Whitlam and said that his actions were an impertinence to the leader of the United States. As it turned out, as Gough Whitlam was in China speaking to the Chinese so too was Henry Kissinger. He was there establishing the same sort of relations that the Australian Labor Party was seeking to establish. The point of that is that it is the same problem. The Opposition is out of step; it is at least 30 years behind developments in this area. The honourable member for North Sydney has as much relevance to current Australian foreign policy and global strategic considerations as do FJ Holdens and 1950 Chiko rolls. His attitude is from a completely different era and is, of course, overwhelmingly rejected by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is getting an ambassador to represent him in his own electorate.

—If that is the case, far be it from me to offer political advice to the honourable member for North Sydney; but I happen to know that the former mayor of North Sydney, Ted Mack, who is widely respected by many Liberals and people across the political spectrum, has been rumoured as a candidate for his seat. I have absolutely no doubt that if one asked Mr Mack, who is a known environmentalist and a very sensitive and far thinking person, what he thinks about nuclear weapons and the idea promoted by the honourable member for North Sydney that they should be permanently stationed in Australia, he would say what we are saying-it is just not on. In response to what the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) said, I say that if I were the member for North Sydney, I would get his ambassador in his electorate to renounce this policy, because if he does not it will be an issue at the next election on which his constituents will pass judgment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to emphasise that the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty has been widely supported not just within Australia but at a number of important forums around the world. In a communique issued by the 46 Commonwealth Heads of Government in 1985 they welcomed the Treaty. They said that it was an important step in global and regional efforts to prevent nuclear proliferation. The members of that organisation range across countries which include members of the Western alliance, non-aligned countries and a whole cross-section of world opinion. This Treaty and initiative has been a model for the world, as is the Act of Parliament which gives effect to that treaty.

I am not standing here today in an attempt to make some short term political capital out of this issue. In my first speech in this House I made the specific point that this Government, of which I am a proud member, should not ever consider having nuclear weapons for Australia. Subsequently, I and my colleagues initiated a motion in the Federal Labor Caucus which was seconded by the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) as secretary. That motion was the genesis of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Act. That idea of sending a signal to the world that Australia would not acquire nuclear weapons captured the imagination of the entire Government. So, we put it forward as an initiative which I believe captures the idealism which is synonymous with the Government to which I belong. I urge support for this motion and I am sure that my remarks will be strongly supported by the honourable member for the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—Yes.

—The motion is seconded by the honourable member for the Northern Territory, who reserves his right to speak. The honourable member will have an opportunity to intervene in the debate at a later point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On most occasions I enjoy listening to the contributions of the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner), and today I have enjoyed listening to much of what he said. He brings to his contributions to the Parliament less of the personal attacks which characterise some of his factional opponents within his own Party. He tends to deal with issues rather than personalities, and this is a subject on which one can do that. Obviously, questions of nuclear proliferation, the stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia and the impact of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty should and can all be argued in a responsible way. Therefore, I am a little disappointed that the honourable member introduced a personal note into his remarks in relation to the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender).

SPEECH.PARA: In dealing with the proposition before the House, I think it is perfectly arguable that there can be a difference of view about the best policy to pursue in relation to Australia's security. That is something which is obviously of great concern to the national Parliament; it should be of great concern to individual governments. One of the great responsibilities facing any national government is to protect the security of the nation. How one goes about achieving that responsibility is, of course, of tremendous moment. What we have to do is to argue the merits of the propositions put before the House in relation to the absolutely fundamental proposition that the responsibility of any national government is to protect Australia's national security. If one looks at the arguments being put by the honourable member for Hughes in that light, rather than with the emotionalism which surrounds much of the debate about nuclear weaponry, nuclear-powered ships and nuclear power generally, then one can get a much more coherent, realistic and, in my view, a much more soundly based argument than is often the case when one allows rampant emotionalism about the horrors of nuclear accidents to cloud one's thinking.

There are a couple of points that the honourable member for Hughes made which I would like to take up initially. In relation to my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney, he said `He has let it around that nuclear weapons should be permanently stationed in Australia', as though that were a direct quote from the honourable member for North Sydney and the position of the Opposition. I would like him to produce the evidence for that statement, because I have no knowledge of the honourable member for North Sydney or any other member of the Liberal and National parties saying that nuclear weapons should be permanently stationed in Australia. If he cannot produce the evidence for that statement, I believe he should come in and apologise to the House and certainly to the honourable member for North Sydney.

When we are looking at the question of security we must face the fundamental question of whether we are going to continue with our defence relationships with Western countries in general and with the United States in particular. If we are going to continue with our defence relationship with the United States-and I think the vast majority of Australians would agree with that proposition-then we must have a look at the potential effects which could come into play should the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty be hardened up in any way or should there be a war. We are all terribly brave in peacetime-just as the honourable member for Hughes is at present-when there is no apparent threat or when people do not perceive an apparent threat. But if Australia were confronted with a significant direct threat, then people's thinking would become much more concentrated on the defence issue and would be led along the lines of supporting in a much more direct way the special alliance with the United States, that special relationship that we have under ANZUS.

That is why so many people in Australia are concerned with the virtual shredding of the ANZUS arrangements by New Zealand at the present time, exacerbated recently by the Prime Minister of New Zealand in a speech in the United States. It concerns thinking people in this country that this unique defence arrangement that we have with the United States could be put at risk. That is fine while we are at peace, but in the event of a major threat we would very quickly look to those countries, particularly to the United States, for assistance. Under those circumstances we must look at the effect of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty on the options that are available for Australian defence forces, for our allies' defence forces and for the proper organisation of any cooperative effort by those defence forces. That is what concerns the Opposition in relation to this Treaty.

How did the Treaty come about? It really came about because the Labor Government wanted to make some sort of gesture which would pick up some of the concerns of the more left wing of its members. One has only to mention the word `nuclear' to left wing members of the Labor Party and they go into a sort of frenzy and lose the power of coherent thought. In many ways what has occurred is that the right wing members of the Labor Government have said, `What can we do that will settle down the boys on the Left for a while?'. One of the things they could do was to look at proceeding with the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. It is like those signs one sees when one drives around Labor dominated council areas in most of the major cities in Australia which state, `This is a nuclear free zone'. What a lot of nonsense! Of course it is a nuclear free zone; it always was a nuclear free zone; there will continue to be nuclear free zones in the major cities of Australia. Yet these councils erect signs depicting the atomic symbol and the pretentious statement that the municipality is a nuclear free zone. It is a load of garbage, but it makes them feel better. One of the statements that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has made in the past with which I agree is the one he made when he talked about the politics of the `warm inner glow'. He referred to the Balmain basket weavers. This is politics of the warm inner glow, if ever I have heard it-that a certain municipality is a nuclear free zone.

What does the Government do? It says, `We will have a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific'. There are some major concerns about some incidents and particularly about some policies in relation to nuclear weaponry and dumping of nuclear waste. They are quite proper concerns and they should be, and have been, addressed. Nobody wants France to continue testing nuclear devices on Mururoa Atoll. Everybody is concerned about it. France is rightly being condemned for the continuation of testing on that Atoll and pressure must be maintained on France to prevent it continuing with that testing.

The other point which is of proper concern is the dumping of nuclear waste. There was a suggestion some time ago that Japan may be considering dumping nuclear waste in the South Pacific. That is quite properly of concern. Was a South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty needed to deal with those problems? Of course it was not. They could have been addressed directly in a way which particularised those issues and everybody would have been happy to support them. What has occurred with the bringing into place of this Treaty is that there has been a blurring of the issue at a time when the South Pacific, particularly, is not the tranquil, peaceful lake that we have known for so long. Some of the states of the South Pacific reluctantly signed the Treaty to go along with Australia. Others said that the Treaty did not go far enough and did not sign it. As I have already said, this has had the effect of complicating an area of concern at a time when political developments within the South Pacific region are of a more fragile nature than they have been for many years-and at a time, I might add, when the Soviet Union has directly expressed its interest in the South Pacific region.

Premier Gorbachev's speech in Vladivostok a couple of years ago was the first occasion on which the Soviet Union clearly and directly spelled out its interest in the South Pacific. At present Mr Gorbachev is enjoying tremendous support from a great number of people in the West. I can understand that and to a certain extent I support it. I fervently hope that the reforms in the Soviet Union are successful. I think that perestroika and glasnost at least offer the hope and opportunity for some worthwhile progress to be made in opening up that massive Soviet bloc, and I strongly support that. However, that does not mean that one should believe that just because these changes have started to take place the actuality of a proper result has been achieved: it has not. At the present time we have opportunities, we are seeing some worthwhile progress and we support and encourage that. However, that does not mean for a moment that we should relax our efforts, that we should undermine the potential that we have for a proper security arrangement simply on the hope and expectation that what we want to see achieved will be achieved. There is a tremendous distance to go before we can safely say to ourselves, `Well, everything has changed, we need not take these considerations into our minds in the future and we can be certain that the threat which may have been present in the past is totally dissipated'.

We should not undermine and put at risk Australia's security relationships. The fact of the matter is that with the present instability in countries such as the Philippines there is no long-term guarantee that the bases of our ally the United States will remain in the Philippines. Where do they go if they are not in the Philippines? If some aspects of the nuclear free zone are hardened up from the present situation-and some of the states in the South Pacific want to see that occur-it could restrict the opportunity of the United States properly to deploy its forces. I remind the House that those are the forces of our allies and they are the forces that we would rely on should Australia face a major threat. That is what the Opposition is saying. We are not in the nuclear proliferation business.

The second part of the motion of the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) is a nonsense. Australia is, and has been for some years, a signatory to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty which prevents us, because of our signature to that treaty, from doing so many of the things that the honourable member for Hughes would have us believe the Opposition supports. We are not in the process of stationing nuclear weapons here and we are not in the process of testing nuclear weapons here. That suggestion is simply a nonsense and a political trick by the honourable member for Hughes to try to label Opposition members as right wing reactionaries; we are not. However, we are concerned about the maintenance of proper security arrangements and the maintenance of freedom of effective coordination and action with our allies should Australia's security be threatened in the future. That is not a right wing reaction. That is a proper concern for the fundamental responsibilities of any national government-the protection of the security of the people of this nation. Despite the attacks that the honourable member for Hughes has made on the position of the Opposition, the fundamental fact remains that we are concerned for the maintenance of Australia's future. We believe that that is best achieved by the strong maintenance of our security relationship with our major ally the United States, and we do not want to see anything done which will undermine our capacity to protect that relationship properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support this motion, which I remind the House reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House:
(1) supports the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty; and
(2) opposes the (a) stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia; (b) testing of nuclear weapons in Australia; and (c) acquisition or production of nuclear weapons by Australia.

I compliment the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) for his very erudite and precise explanation of the reasons why this motion is extremely important to the Australian Labor Party.
