But I am somewhat confused by the contribution made by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar), someone who under normal circumstances takes a very logical approach to the issues before him. He seems to have confused the statements of his Party with his own intentions and desires.

There is absolutely no doubt that this Government has, as its foremost objective, the national security of this nation. Just as we have moved in a way in which the Opposition has never moved in terms of developing a unique defence and foreign policy, which is designed to make us self-reliant, the Opposition has taken what I believe is a very much head in the sand attitude to the issue of nuclear weapons and nuclear proliferation. There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that the honourable member for Hughes is right; that the Opposition is talking about the stationing of nuclear weapons in Australia. He was correct again when he pointed out that this is another example of the difference between the Opposition and the Government. The choice for the Australian community, as we approach a Federal election perhaps in the next 12 months, is becoming clearer. In major areas of policy there is a dramatic gap between the Opposition and this Government. The honourable member for Hughes mentioned the area of foreign investment, but there are other areas and I will mention them briefly to demonstrate the divergence in attitudes to those issues, which go along with the divergence in attitudes to the development of foreign policy and defence policy by the Government and the Opposition. They are, of course, the areas of Aboriginal affairs, immigration, social justice and, not least, primary production. We are seeing the benefits of that debate presently occurring within the Liberal and National parties.

We have come to a period in Australia's political history where the choice has never been so marked, and that has been demonstrated aptly by the Opposition's attitude to the issue of a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific. This nuclear free zone idea is entirely consistent with Australia's position on the general question of nuclear weapons. We are opposed to nuclear weapons. We are opposed to the testing of nuclear weapons. We support disarmament, and we promote it in all areas of the international arena. As a signatory to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, that is consistent with our attitude as a signatory to the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons and it is consistent with our attitude as a signatory to the partial test ban treaty and our commitment to an effectively verifiable comprehensive test ban treaty.

This Government has taken a leading role in the area of nuclear disarmament and in the promotion of a comprehensive test ban treaty. At the United Nations we have done so through crafting a resolution, together with NZ, that in recent years has attracted overwhelming support; at the Conference on Disarmament we urged the establishment of, and demonstration of the capacity and reliability to monitor compliance with, a comprehensive test ban treaty; and domestically, we have established the Australian Seismological Centre and seismic cooperation arrangements with like-minded countries.

The record of this Government's commitment to nuclear disarmament is not in doubt. It is entirely consistent with that commitment that we should be a signatory to the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. I remind the House that the Treaty is open for signature by all members of the South Pacific Forum. Eleven of the 15 members have signed the Treaty: Australia, the Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, New Zealand, Niue, Tuvalu, Western Samoa, Nauru, Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. All of those countries, with the exception of Papua New Guinea, have ratified the Treaty. Vanuatu and Tonga have not yet signed the Treaty, nor have the federated states of Micronesia and the Marshall Islands.

The Treaty entered into force on 11 December 1986 following the deposit of the eighth ratification-Australia's ratification-of the Treaty. Significantly, the Treaty has three additional protocols which are open for signature by the five nuclear states; that is, the United States of America, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the United Kingdom, France and China. Protocol 1 provides that the United States, the United Kingdom and France provide key provisions of the Treaty to the South Pacific territories, and protocols 2 and 3 provide for all states to undertake not to use or threaten to use nuclear weapons against parties to the Treaty and not to conduct nuclear testing in the Pacific. This Treaty in no way inhibits the operations of the ANZUS Treaty and in no way inhibits the present operations of United States forces. This is acknowledged by the United States, contrary to the views that have been expressed by the honourable member for Warringah.

In the short time available to me I want to go back to the position which has been adopted by the Opposition. It is significant that on 10 March 1989 the shadow Minister, the honourable member for North Sydney, distributed to coalition members and senators a draft policy which was referred to by the honourable member for Hughes. That draft document was widely available to the press before the official policy launch. On the eve of the policy launch, on 7 April, a number of stories were published, as the honourable member for Hughes outlined, to the effect that a coalition government would allow nuclear weapons to be based in Australia. For example, Lindsay Olney wrote in the Adelaide Advertiser on 6 April:
United States nuclear forces could be stationed in Australia under a coalition government . . .

On 7 April we saw this headline in the Canberra Times, `Coalition pledge on nuclear weapons'. This apparently gave the Liberals a bit of a fright and the sentence was redrafted, as the honourable member for Hughes said, to read:
A Liberal/National Coalition Government will renegotiate the Treaty so as to overcome these restrictions on Australia's freedom of action.

The honourable member for Hughes outlined the support this Treaty, and Australia's position on it, has been given by the independents in the Parliament and by the Australian Democrats and the way in which they have demonstrated their condemnation of the position which has been adopted by the shadow Minister on behalf of his Party. I emphasise that it demonstrates the rift, the difference, the chasm, that exists between the Government and the Opposition on the matter of nuclear weapons. It is very clear, despite the remonstrations of the honourable member for Warringah, that the coalition has decided to allow nuclear weapons to be stationed permanently in Australia. It has been frightened into trying to hide this policy for fear of adverse public reaction. It has tried to hide the policy behind talk of keeping Australia's options open. But why renegotiate the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, as it has suggested it will, to keep this option open if it has no intention of introducing nuclear weapons? Why should the Liberals wish to see nuclear weapons stationed in Australia?
In a press conference of 7 April, the honourable member for North Sydney reportedly said:
The treaty prevents nuclear-capable forces being available for the purpose of deterring an attack on this country.

This shows that the honourable member for North Sydney wants US nuclear weapons based in Australia not to contribute to the US global strategic posture, as one might expect from his rhetoric, but to defend Australia. In other words, the honourable member for North Sydney sees Australian territory being defended by American nuclear weapons, not by Australia's defence forces. That is typical of the coalition's defence strategy. It has never taken self-reliance seriously. It has always preferred to be defended by others. Nothing has changed in its strategic policy since the 1950s. Mr Spender is wrong on a point of law. The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty does not prevent nuclear capable forces visiting Australia. The Treaty was carefully negotiated to ensure that. The Treaty fully protects Australia's interests and responsibilities under ANZUS, as former Secretary of State Shultz acknowledged. Lastly, Mr Spender's view of the diplomatic possibilities are hopelessly unrealistic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory should refer to the honourable member for North Sydney by his seat.

—Of course, my extreme apologies to the honourable member for North Sydney. May I call him the shadow Minister? As the shadow Minister he reflects an opinion which was so clearly articulated by Laurie Oakes in the Bulletin, which indicated that he really has not changed his view from that which the Liberal Party had in 1951 while negotiating the ANZUS Treaty, when his father was Minister for Foreign Affairs. They have still not changed. The Opposition still has a Cold War McCarthyist approach to foreign policy and defence matters, and its attitude on the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty clearly articulates that. In my view, the Opposition stands condemned for its failure to support this Government's stance, and Australia's public opinion in support of this Government's stance, for the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. I recommend and commend this motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Halverson Mr R.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —While listening to the ramblings of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) I was reminded of that wonderful widely acclaimed biography of our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by Blanche d'Alpuget. Page 108 gives us an insight into the way the Australian Labor Party works and the chicanery involved in some of its more altruistic comments. She states:

SPEECH.PARA: In Brisbane Calwell announced that Labor's nuclear-free Southern Hemisphere idea had been misunderstood; that in a war the USA would ``give Australia nuclear arms''; and that ``we, the ALP, would use any weapon to defend Australia if attacked''.

This debate has an air of deja vu or, perhaps more accurately, onions-it keeps repeating itself. We have heard all these arguments before from the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) and from the honourable member for the Northern Territory. They are just as unconvincing and unrealistic this time as they were last time. The honourable member for Hughes reminds me of an anxious bridegroom who needs constant reassurance about his ability to satisfy, although, in this case, the bed is being shared with the Socialist Left. Nothing appeases their insatiable anti-American desires quite as well as another orchestrated opportunity to practise the well-worn collection of alarmist and extremist catchcries and cliches which form the basis of their ongoing and ill-founded campaign against our Western allies, a propaganda campaign that is based on the demonstrably faulty and totally unacceptable premise that we would somehow be better off if we ignored the realities of international politics, and that there are advantages in slamming the door in the face of loyal friends whilst at the same time opening windows of opportunity for those who are ideologically opposed to freedom and democracy.

That is, basically, what this exercise has been designed to achieve. No one on this side of the House is deceived for one moment about the objectives of the honourable member for Hughes in moving this motion. There is no real need, and no legitimate purpose, in rehashing issues which have already been debated vigorously and thoroughly in this House less than three years ago. But the honourable member is not motivated by need and legitimacy.

Certainly, since the matter was first raised there have been some significant changes-both political and economic-in the region in question. But these changes serve only to illustrate that the South West Pacific is both a dynamic and an extremely vulnerable area. In an article on Soviet Pacific-based strike forces, which appeared in Signal, the journal of the Armed Forces Communications and Electronics Association in December 1986, Admiral R. J. Hays observed:

The southernmost Soviet prong, the South Pacific, is a recent development. Some economically disadvantaged independent nations are vulnerable targets. The Soviets offer attractive economic agreements that have the potential for conversion to economic dependence and then political and military advantage.

Soviet inroads in the South Pacific already have occurred with a fishing agreement with Kiribati and subtle penetration of labour organisations. The next 12 months will likely result in additional fishing agreements, fish processing agreements, landing rights for the Soviet airline Aeroflot, and ship repair and servicing contracts. All the while, Soviet diplomatic activity is increasing throughout the region.

They are prophetic words. Yet it is against this background of obviously increasing Soviet activity and influence in the South West Pacific region that the honourable member for Hughes would have us agree to a motion that further undermines the security of the region. The honourable member wants us to agree to a proposition which will make the whole area more vulnerable and more unstable. In doing so, he threatens the whole basis of the future security of this nation. That fact, however, has either escaped him, or is of little consequence or concern to him. Unfortunately, I believe the latter is most likely the case.

The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty is an excellent example of a wolf in sheep's clothing. Those on this side of the House have no difficulty in recognising this fact. That is why we oppose this motion so vehemently, in the same way, and for the same reasons, that we opposed the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty Bill when it was originally debated in this Parliament in 1986. It may sound good. It may look good. But it is in fact a treacherous document with enormous and frightening implications for democracy, security, stability and freedom in our region.

In the recently released coalition foreign affairs policy, our unequivocal commitment to renegotiating the terms of this Treaty as they now stand is reaffirmed. I will quote from our policy for the benefit of honourable members opposite, who need to hear something several times before it sinks in. Our policy states:

The Labor Government's sponsorship of the South Pacific Nuclear-Free Zone Treaty has undermined the Western Alliance, diminished regional stability, and furthered Soviet interests. It is not generally realised how restrictive this Treaty is on Australia's future options.

Under the Treaty (relevant obligations of which have been enacted into law by the South Pacific Nuclear-Free Zone Treaty Act 1986) each party undertakes to prevent in its territory (which includes its territorial waters) the ``stationing'' of nuclear explosive devices. This includes ``transportation on land or inland waters, stockpiling, storage, installation or deployment''. Deployment would ordinarily be taken to include bringing forces into effective action. So understood, and regardless of adverse changes in the international environment, in the future Australia (unless it breached the treaty and repealed relevant provision of the Act) would be prohibited from allowing the stationing or deployment in Australia and its territorial waters of United States nuclear-armed air, sea or ground units.

Since the policy of the United States is neither to confirm nor to deny the presence of nuclear arms, the result is effectively to exclude from deployment in Australia or Australian waters all United States nuclear-capable forces.
The policy statement continues:

The Treaty's prohibition on deployment in Australia or Australian waters of friendly nuclear-armed forces is contrary to our national interests and to our ANZUS obligations. Article 4 of the ANZUS Treaty states that in the event of an armed attack in the Pacific area on any of the parties to the Treaty, each would ``act to meet the common danger in accordance with its Constitutional processes''. Yet if such an attack took place, Australia would be bound to exclude United States nuclear-capable naval, air and ground units from deployment in Australia's land or sea areas.
Australia's security options should not be so confined.
This significant section of the policy document concludes with the following commitment:
A Liberal/National Government will renegotiate the Treaty so as to overcome these restrictions on Australia's freedom of action.

The fact is that no-one, certainly not one of us on this side of the House, wants to see or promote any armed attack against any nation in the South Pacific region. We deplore the possibility of such an event happening anywhere in the world. But we have to be realistic. If such an event did occur, we would have to be ready. The honourable member for Hughes would have us unprepared and, therefore, unprotected.

Last year, as a member of the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee's South Pacific subcommittee, I had the opportunity to visit many of the South West Pacific nations. The report on this visit-entitled Australia's Relations with the South Pacific-was tabled in this Parliament last month. I would like to briefly refer to some of the statements contained in the report, because they help to clarify the real issues of concern to nations in the region. The report states:

The Treaty of Rarotonga, establishing the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone, came into force on 11 December, 1986. It represented a significant degree of concern among Pacific Forum nations on a number of nuclear issues-French nuclear testing in the region, proposals for dumping of nuclear waste in the oceans and a wish to keep the region free of super-power rivalry and militarism.
The report continues:

The USSR was the first nuclear power to ratify the Treaty, although initially with some reservations, earning for itself much commendation in the region. Although China has also ratified the Treaty, the attitude of other nuclear powers in the region, Britain, France and the United States, was predictable in their opposition to the establishment of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone. The South Pacific Forum nations have been generally supportive, with two notable exceptions. Vanuatu has not signed the Treaty to date, believing it does not go far enough in its provisions; Tonga, on the other hand, has not signed because of concerns that the Treaty has gone too far and restricts unacceptably the operational ability of the United States and her allies.

The report goes on to examine in some detail the issues and the concerns of the South-West Pacific nations, and the increasing involvement in the region of non-South Pacific countries, including the Soviet Union. It makes interesting reading. It highlights many of the reasons why the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty-and this also applies to the arguments offered in support of this motion today-is an inappropriate and unrealistic solution to the very real challenges now facing the South-West Pacific nations, and the future implications and challenges resulting from the continued expanding interest and involvement of the Soviet Union in this region.

During the original debate on this matter, several of my colleagues endeavoured to point out to the Government the obvious deficiencies in the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. The major deficiency is that a real nuclear free zone is not in the best interests of either the security of Australia or the small island nations on our doorstep. I am surprised that honourable members opposite are not able to appreciate or grasp this obvious truth. This ill-advised treaty compromises our national security, because it takes no account of the consequences of what might happen down the track. It limits our ability and the ability of our allies to respond to any adverse changes in the political and strategic environment of a region which is critical to our own security-changes which may pose a very real threat in the long term to Australia and our Western allies.

Is that what we really want? Do we really want to see an expanding and unchecked Soviet influence, hand in hand with measures which very effectively limit the role of the United States and our other Western allies in this sensitive region? That is what the Treaty of Rarotonga does. No wonder that the Soviets were first in line to sign. This treaty suits the Soviets-they recognise it for what it really is, namely, a method of minimising the role of the United States in the region, while at the same time providing an opportunity to expand their own. It is not really a treaty but a trick-a confidence trick of immense proportions and frightening implications.

The motion that we are debating today does nothing to prevent nuclear war in our region. It comes into the same category as those optimistic but useless little signs proclaiming various municipalities as being nuclear free zones. This motion is just as futile. It is misleading in relation to the things that will make for stability in our region. It does not guarantee peace; it simply threatens our security.
I remind the House of the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) in regard to this matter. He said:

The South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty does nothing now nor indeed into the future to prevent the Soviet Union locating missiles at or about the perimeter of the nuclear free area. Those who argue that in some way having a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific is going to insulate that area from any kind of nuclear incursion simply live in some kind of fantasy land or dream world. Of course, the Opposition condemns French nuclear tests in the South Pacific. That was the policy of the Fraser Government; it was the policy of the Whitlam Government; it is the policy of the Hawke Government; and it remains the policy of the Opposition.

We have no argument with the opposition expressed by the Government to French nuclear tests, but we have all the argument in the world with the naivety of a government that pretends that, if we put a circle around part of the world and we declare that as a nuclear free zone, in some way we abolish the capacity of any country to intrude nuclear weapons or nuclear activity into that area. It is a complete fantasy concept.

In conclusion, this motion plays on fears and suspicions. It is not an honest or realistic response to the challenges that we are facing in the South-West Pacific region. It seeks to undermine the role of our allies and our own security. Members of the Opposition are in no way advocating the stationing or stockpiling of nuclear weapons in this country and in no way are we in favour of promoting nuclear testing in Australia or in the South Pacific region. We do not want to acquire or produce nuclear weapons. However, any move, such as that outlined in this motion, that seeks to compromise or restrict our obligations, responsibilities and future options in this regard must be totally rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Out of necessity my contribution must be brief. In moving the motion, my colleague the honourable member for Hughes (Mr Tickner) gave proper credit to the Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the collective of South Pacific nations for the initiative embodied in the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. Indeed, the role played by the honourable member for Hughes is worthy of recognition, and I thank him for his efforts at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, Australians are very wary about nuclear weapons and security issues generally-even more wary than they were a few years ago. To demonstrate this, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table, as an example of survey data contained in the August 1988 issue of Pacific Research. According to an article in that periodical, the polls that were undertaken are part of the `Defence trac' series which are regularly conducted by Frank Small and Associates of Sydney.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
SECURITY ISSUES
Support for an Australian nuclear weapons capability ...
Support for increased defence expenditure ...
Support for compulsory military service for young men
Support for presence of US communication bases in Australia ...
Support for visits of nuclear-armed ships ...

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the attitude of Australians to this issue, I quote from the article in Pacific Research as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past three decades opinion polls have revealed a pattern of public support for increased spending on defence, a return to military conscription and even for Australia to have its own nuclear weapons . . . These attitudes remained remarkably constant throughout the early to mid-1980s despite the rise of an energetic peace movement. Ironically, in the late 1980s, when the peace movement is in a state of relative decline, support for peace movement positions has grown dramatically within the electorate.
The table that has been incorporated in Hansard illustrates that point. The article continues:
The latest polls still show strong (65%) overall public support for the ANZUS alliance but in the youngest group (16-24 years) only 50% support the alliance compared with 75% of the 55+ age group.
The article also points out how the younger generation is more radical and less defence minded than the older generation, on a wide variety of security issues. On this point, the article states:

On support for `US communication bases', for example, only 23% of the 16-24 year group wanted to keep the `bases', compared with 52% of the 55+ age group. Women also tend to be considerably more `dovish' on security issues than men.

That latter finding is no surprise to those of us who have been aware of the overwhelming concern of women on matters of peace and disarmament for a number of years. Generally speaking, their concern is logical and far reaching. It relates to both the present and the future and involves anti-war and pro-environmental components. It is apparent from the survey to which I have referred that Australians do not want to have nuclear weapons stationed in Australia. In other words, the people of Australia agree with the law that this Parliament has passed forbidding such stationing to occur. Australians neither want nor need testing of nuclear weapons in their country or their region. They have learned the lessons presented by Maralinga and they have also learned the lessons presented by the Monte Bello Islands. I whole heartedly support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday. The honourable member will have leave to continue her speech when the debate is resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House condemns the Government for its inept handling of the Wesley Vale issue which led to the abandonment of a $1 billion development and urges the Government to develop a comprehensive set of guidelines for industrial development as a matter of urgency.

During the recent debate on the Wesley Vale issue and the development of a pulp mill at Wesley Vale, a great deal of misinformation was forthcoming and many misleading statements were made by a considerable number of groups and individual people. This has totally misled the people-not just in Tasmania but throughout Australia. Added to that confusion is the fact that the issue has been used for political expediency by a great number of people involved in the political processes. In saying that, I am accusing not just governments but a great number of people involved in the political process.

The end result of the misleading information and misinformation that has been peddled, the use of that issue as a political expedient and the demands that have been placed on the company for the development of a pulp mill at Wesley Vale is that no pulp mill will now be built there. The demands ultimately placed on the company for the development of that mill were simply unachievable and would have resulted in a production process that would not have produced a product saleable on the world market. On that basis, the mill and the resultant production were not economically feasible. As a result, Tasmania has lost a mill, 2,000 jobs have been lost, Australia will not have the development of its own resources and we will continue exporting raw material to the Japanese markets, where those Australian raw materials will be processed into downstream products.

I remind the House that at the moment Australia exports in excess of three million tonnes of raw woodchips to Japan each year. The proposal for the Wesley Vale mill was that 1.8 million tonnes of those woodchips be processed in Australia into downstream, value-added products. This would still have left 1.2 million tonnes, or thereabouts, of woodchips to be exported to Japan. As a result of not having a mill, we will continue exporting three million tonnes of woodchips to Japan. That product will be used in Japan and ultimately will be processed into paper. We will then buy the paper back from the Japanese. I do not claim to be a brilliant mathematician, but to me that just does not add up. It is not commonsense. If we are to develop the economy of our country and produce jobs for future generations, we must process our own raw materials into downstream products. We cannot export jobs to other countries.

During this debate today I want to put to rest some of the misinformation and misleading statements made about the paper industry. First let me claim my credentials. At an earlier stage of my working life I worked for Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd (APPM) at its Burnie plant for six years. During that time I had three years working in the production process on the paper machines. For a further two years I worked in the control laboratory. At that stage I was involved in a wide range of technical matters related to the pulp and paper industry. On that basis, I believe that I have far more credentials to be able to talk informatively on this industry than any other member in this House.

During the Wesley Vale debate it was claimed that APPM, or North Broken Hill Peko Ltd, whichever the proponent was, should be able to use techniques in production that are used in other countries such as in Scandinavia or Canada. Let me put the lie to that. There is a basic difference between what we do in Australia and what Scandinavian mills do. It must be different, because the raw material is different. Our timber is different from Scandinavian timber. The timbers used for the production of pulp and paper in Scandinavia are softwoods, in the main, although some hardwood birch is used. The main difference is the colour. When paper is produced for the world market the buyers of that paper do not care where the paper is produced and they do not care what the production techniques are, but they do demand the same specifications for the end product.

If Australia's paper industry is to compete on the world market with other countries using different raw materials, we have to use different techniques to produce ultimately a similar product that meets the specifications of the world market. To compare our production techniques with those of other countries is simply not to compare like with like. It is totally misleading to say that we in Australia can use the same production techniques used in Scandinavia, Canada or any other country. The simple fact is that our timbers are different and therefore require different treatment.

I turn now to the techniques used by the Burnie mills. The main difference is that our hardwoods are short-fibred. We have heard some mention of short fibre. I doubt whether anyone in this House really understands what it means. When the components of the wood are broken down into its fibre content, the length of the fibre of our hardwoods is about one-third the length of the softwood timbers that come from Scandinavian countries. That is the first different characteristic.

The other different characteristic is the colour of the timber. Because the colour is different it requires different treatments to bring it to a comparable whiteness and brightness of the end product, the paper, required by the world market. During the production process the timber is broken down into woodchips about two inches square and about a quarter of an inch thick. Those woodchips are immersed in a solution of caustic soda under high temperature and high pressure. That breaks the fibres apart. The end result of that process is pulp. The pulp is dark grey or brown and totally unsuited to the requirements of the marketplace.

In order to bring it to the whiteness and brightness that the world marketplace demands, it has to be further treated with chlorine. All paper mills do that. Even in Scandinavia that is done. I remind my friends opposite that even the Scandinavians use a chlorine bleaching process to bring their product up to the demands of the world market. The only difference in those processes is how much chlorine is used in the bleaching process. It is true that, because Scandinavia's raw material is whiter, the Scandinavian mills use less chlorine. But they still use chlorine to bring their product up to the requirements of the world market. We have to use more chlorine because our timbers are darker. It is as simple as that.

As far as APPM or North Broken Hill Peko is concerned, if the world market requires a product that is not as high in brightness and whiteness, if that is the specification of the market place, the company can easily produce it. It is no problem at all. It simply uses less chlorine in its bleaching process. That can be done now, using existing equipment. But there is little point in producing a product that simply does not meet the world specifications and therefore cannot be sold.

In the Wesley Vale debate all those factors were put on the table in negotiations between the proponents of the Wesley Vale mill and the State Government. At the end of the day, after all those negotiations had taken place, after all of the realities of the world marketplace had been considered, guidelines for the development of that mill and the protection of the environment were drawn up and agreed to between the State Government and the proponents. In the course of those negotiations, the State Premier, Mr Robin Gray, pleaded with the Federal Government to involve itself in and be part of those negotiations so that the agreed guidelines, at the end of the day, would have the approval and the support of both governments-Federal and State.

Honourable members might recall the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) sanctimoniously refusing to be part of those negotiations. They said, `No, that is between the company and the State Government. We will not have any part of that. But we will use our powers of export licensing to determine whether the project will go ahead', without anybody knowing what the Federal Government demands would be. What happened in the final result was that the State Government and the proponents of the mill did reach agreement. They did produce guidelines for environmental protection. When the guidelines got to the Federal Government, the Federal Government said, `No, that is not up to our standards; we want standards for this company'. The Government wanted it to use production techniques that would produce a product that is simply unsaleable on the world markets.

The end result was that the company said, `This is impossible. We cannot meet those guidelines and expect to be able to make a profit, expect the mill to be economically feasible, because the product will not sell'. That was the position of the Federal Government. That position has not changed because the Federal Government still has given no indication to North Broken Hill Peko Ltd, Noranda Forest Inc. or to any other industrial proposer about the guidelines for environmental protection that this Government would want for any future proposal. All proposers are still in the dark. The Government still has done nothing about it. It does not matter what proposal is put forward; the proposers still would not know what the Federal Government would be demanding. Shame on it for that. Do not blame the State Government; do not blame the proposers. Blame Senator Richardson and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). They are misleading not only proposers for industrial development but also the entire Australian community.

The issue is being used for political purposes not only by this Government and by Senator Richardson, but also by the environmental politicians. I speak particularly of those people who are standing for the Tasmanian elections.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not prepared to sell off the environment like you are.

—Obviously I am touching raw nerves with some people on the other side of the House who have a conscience. I can see that. What is the situation now? We have a proposal which has been put forward. A further proposal has been put forward by, we understand, the Prime Minister. We know that the Leader of the Opposition in Tasmania, Mr Field, was here earlier this week and had discussions with the Prime Minister.
—Another midnight meeting?

—Another midnight meeting, as my colleague says. We do not know what they discussed. We do not know whether any agreements were reached. We do not know what proposals are going to come from that meeting or what demands are going to be put on future development projects for Tasmania. One of the suspicions that has come out is that this Government is going to offer some form of contract to North Broken Bill to produce paper that does not use the chlorine bleaching process. That is fine. I am sure the company would accept that. The company would provide low brightness and low whiteness paper to the Commonwealth Government if the Commonwealth wanted to buy it. But I doubt that the Commonwealth could take up all the production of a new mill. The remaining production that could not be absorbed by the Commonwealth Government would have to go into the marketplace. In the marketplace, if the Commonwealth or anybody else wanted paper of a particular specification, it could be produced. It can be done now. It does not have to be done by a new mill; it can be done by the existing mills.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the other furphies that is often thrown into the ring concerns the recycling of paper. We have heard a lot about that from the conservation movement and others on the opposite side of the House. They ask why we do not recycle paper in Australia. I wonder how many people understand that about half of the paper produced in Australia at the moment is from recycled fibre. Paper is being recycled. Recycling is a major industry right now.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be bigger.

—The reason why it is not bigger is that it is uneconomic to cart the paper to the recycling points. Recycling is a major industry right now. To suggest that this is a new technique that can be used is totally misleading. It has been done for years.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has been totally inept in the way in which it has handled the Wesley Vale issue. It has not produced guidelines. It has totally confused the proponents of the development. It has given no indication to any future developer about what it will require as far as environmental protection is concerned. It is totally misleading to blame the Tasmanian Government for the difficulties it has with its economy while this Government refuses to cooperate and give the Tasmanian Government the flexibility needed to develop its own resources. On that basis, I believe that the Federal Government should be condemned for its inaction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Politics is sometimes full of ironies and serendipities. It is one of the serendipities of politics that a motion that might have been thought timely and damaging when it was put before the House by the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) some weeks ago now will be a thorn in the side of the Government in Tasmania. The Tasmanian Government is desperately trying to keep the pulp mill issue off the front pages. It is squirming in anguish about the prospect of one or two pulp mills now being built in Tasmania. The prospect that the honourable member for Lyons suggests, that this issue is over as a result of Federal Government intransigence, simply means the honourable gentleman has not read a newspaper-state or national-for the past week.

SPEECH.PARA: The Weekend Australian of 29-30 April carried the headline: `Pulp mill revived in Tas poll shock'. Whose poll shock is it? It is a poll shock that must be sending shivers down the spine of any Liberal Party voter in the State of Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?

—Because the Liberal Party has destroyed its credibility. It has been shown consistently to be incompetent and deceitful. It is not just me or the Labor Party which makes that judgment. An editorial in the Australian of 28 February 1989 on this issue prior to the decision being made said:

SPEECH.PARA: If Tasmania does, in the end, get a pulp mill that provides new jobs . . . it will be despite, not because of, the Gray Government.

It was speaking about the backflip on the guidelines that might have had some respectability before they were watered down and turned into the white flag of retreat. Speaking of the Gray Government's bowing to industrial pressure and its complete sell-out of the environment in the State of Tasmania, the article said:

Evasion and lack of candour, if not downright shiftiness, have been the hallmarks of the Government's actions on the mill. It has created confusion where clarity about the choices involved would probably have won speedy consensus in favour of the mill project.
The article than proceeded to dismiss, point by point, the kind of shallow nonsense that we have been hearing today.

Let us go through this exercise. The methodology was wrong from the outset. Tasmania has a timber resource. It is a resource that is often overestimated. It has fragility. It has areas which need to be preserved on the National Estate Register, areas which are important on a world scale for the environmental sensitivity. If those areas were taken out, Tasmania would still have a significant resource but it is a resource that has to be tended carefully so that it is not overexploited.

But what do we have? We do not have a situation where the Tasmanian Government says, `Look, we need some sensible plan for downstream processing'. What happened was that a proposal came along, the Tasmanian Government latched on to that proposal and then admitted no criticism of it. The Tasmanian Government did not offer the resource in any way to the most productive tendering process. It did not look at alternative uses. It did not expose the process to public scrutiny. It rammed through legislation in the State Parliament, taking the proposal out of the normal environmental and planning appeal processes. It then enacted its own set of guidelines. When the companies jacked up and said, `Look, we don't like what you have done; you have given us a bit of a hard time on the environment', the Government did a 180-degree backflip. It caved in. It made substantial revisions of the guidelines but deceitfully maintained that it had made no changes. It said, `There has not been a backdown; there has been no cave-in to the commercial interests involved'. That is implausible nonsense. It then had the cheek to send along to this Parliament spokespersons like the honourable member for Lyons to plead a case on behalf of those very companies. It is really a nonsense.

We can see why the electors of Tasmania in all the polls that have been published recently are repeatedly saying that they are fed up with the Gray Government. They are unfortunately being pushed into a position where it is possible that Independents will hold not only a balance of power but many seats on the simple basis that the Government has so confused this issue that the basic sensible position of the Opposition in Tasmania has been inadequately understood. This issue really goes right to the core of Tasmanian politics. We see here a gambler's mentality. Tasmania has economic difficulties. When the Gray Government went to the polls in the last election it said that job creation was its No. 1 priority. That is what it was about-job creation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have they done?

—Tasmania is the only State in Australia which has gone backwards, where there has been a net loss of jobs. It is the only place in Australia where economic performance has been in reverse. This Tasmanian Government, like the gambler that keeps on losing, is looking for the one big win-the one win that will fix it, the big fix. It was looking to dam the Franklin and have hydro-electric power. It wanted to sell out the environment and sell off its assets. It does not give a damn about those things. The gambler lost on that. The gambler says, `Look, after three years of failure in economic policy we are going to throw the dice again. We are going to invest it all in a project of dubious environmental soundness. We will throw the dice on the mill'. Gray does it and he loses again. But who is really losing? It is Tasmanians who are losing and we have only to look at the sorry statistics to see why.

SPEECH.PARA: The Tasmanian unemployment rate stands at 9.7 per cent, 3.1 per cent above the national average. Twenty per cent of our young people cannot find work. Employment continues to fall in contrast to the national trend. Tasmania has the lowest growth in building approvals of all the States. In 1988 motor vehicle registrations in Tasmania grew by only 3.9 per cent, compared with a national rise of 15.5 per cent. Tasmania's population grew by only 470, or 0.1 per cent, in 1987-88, compared with a national increase of 1.7 per cent. The State experienced a net loss of 3,434 jobs in 1987-88. In the year to September 1988 Tasmania received only 2.18 per cent of national private investment. This is the mark of an economic strategy which does not exist. The gambler throws the dice and sends his representatives into the Federal Parliament to say, `Look, if we had only got this one up it would all have been all right'. What nonsense! The Tasmanian Government talks about its non-existent economic strategy. But, like a desperate gambler, it is prepared to risk what does not exist and it wants to sell off the house and clothes and hock the future on a project that it hopes will somehow bring home the bacon with a spin of the wheel. That is nonsense. That is not an economic strategy; it is fairyland.

The reality is that the Wesley Vale mill was a project that the developers pulled the plug on. In negotiations after the Federal Government said that the Tasmanian guidelines were not adequate, Noranda said it could live with tighter guidelines but it was not going to negotiate. Why? Because in Canada the pressure is on Noranda. What sort of company is Noranda? Again, I do not want to use my words to describe the Noranda company, so let me quote from an editorial in the Canberra Times. It says.

But before they get too excited they would do well to consider Noranda's track record which is not quite as white as the paper pulp it hopes to produce at Wesley Vale. . . Noranda has the distinction of having one smelter that is North America's second-largest contributor to acid rain. It has also been linked to the technique known as `job blackmail' which involves threatening to close mills and put people out of work if environmental guidelines are considered too rigid.
The consortium's actions thus far have done little to help its case, and where the Tasmanian Government has wilted under its corporate pressure the federal Government should not.

Of course it should not. The other point is that Noranda kept on saying, `In Canada we do it well; we do not have any impact on the environment'. It wrote letters to people in Tasmania saying this. But in another irony three fisheries where its effluent is discharged were closed, again, just before a decision was going to be announced in the Tasmanian Parliament. This is the shameful record that the honourable member for Lyons seeks to glorify and say that we have acted improperly in regard to. What nonsense! The reality is that the Labor Party in Tasmania has an economic strategy that will give Tasmania new directions through the creation of a new area of community involvement in economic development, the development of a dynamic enterprising economy, new export orientation to put more quality Tasmanian products on to the national and international markets, new training and employment initiatives designed to lift the skill level of Tasmanian workers, and better use of control of our financial and government resources.

The important programs that have been announced by Labor leader Michael Field include a Tasmanian economic partnership with strategies involving all aspects of the community and based on better and more effective relations with the Federal Government. There is one thing that should be plain-in this whole debacle the Gray Government's incompetence and its bullying tactics and inability to know that it had to work out a constructive relationship with the Federal Government contrasted with previous successful Labor governments in Tasmania. By contrast I remember Eric Reece. In the times when there was a Liberal Government nationally Eric, as leader of the Tasmanian Labor Party, would always give credit when it was due and he could always work with the national government. Tasmania benefited. We now have small-minded, shamefully deceitful leaders in the State of Tasmania, refusing to be cooperative, refusing any partnership with the Federal Government and determined to go on their way but doing it to the great detriment of the State of Tasmania and the people of Tasmania. There is no doubt that in the State election that is forthcoming the Gray Government will lose savagely. Seats will be slashed from it. We have only to look at the seat of Lyons to see the predicament the Federal member would be in if the polling figures that are now being published were reflected in national elections. There will not be a Liberal member for Lyons after the next Federal election if those polling figures are reflected.

We should look at the knocking and the lack of imagination as to what might happen. Tasmania does have a forest resource that needs downstream processing. The idea has been floated by the honourable member for Lyons that the Hawke Government might issue contracts and could use some unbleached paper. But he even knocks that proposal. He knocks anything that might mean the Tasmanian environment could be put compatibly in a picture with sound economic development. Instead he is looking backwards; trying to defend the indefensible. He is looking to support industrial development that savages the environment while thinking that this is in some way an economic or development strategy. It is not. These days we must balance environment and employment. The world is our environment. If we defile it and allow it to be ruined, our generation and future generations will be the losers. There are sensible ways through it. We need to look sensibly at downstream processing of our economic timber resources. To put forward the nonsense motion with which the honourable member for Lyons is seeking to criticise the Government, which has been right and has protected the environment and ultimately will be seen to have also protected jobs, is just the kind of backward-looking negative nonsense that this Parliament should absolutely condemn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Being a Tasmanian, I second this motion from my colleague the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr). The current events are being keenly watched by all honourable members on both sides of the House. After listening to the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), I have to say that I wondered whether he was a Tasmanian. It seemed to me that he was talking down Tasmania at a time when that State has immense problems and is under political pressure like it has never been before.
—Who brought it on?

—You sit in the Cabinet, Minister. Let us not forget what happened on the day that the Wesley Vale pulp mill came to an end. It went to the Cabinet room and it was thought by Cabinet that the company would agree with the suggested guidelines and that it would proceed. Senior Ministers said afterwards in the corridors that they could not believe it, they thought the mill would proceed. They were totally surprised when the company turned around finally and said that those guidelines could not be met economically. It was a matter of economics. The Cabinet knew that this pulp mill was needed, not just by Tasmania but by Australia, and that is why editorial writers of the time described it as a debacle.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all right for people to stand up in this place and say, `You are at fault'. I think that the blame can be shared in a couple of quarters and those members who have been objective about what happened will have to agree with me. But do not let us hear Tasmanian representatives saying that it is all the Tasmanian Government's fault. What has happened is a tragedy for Australia-that is the starting point and it ought not to be forgotten. This was the largest single manufacturing project ever contemplated in Australia-and it is lost. Australia is on an economic slippery slide-let no-one try to convince us otherwise.

Tasmania has a population of 450,000 people. I can quote figures which I have quoted in this chamber ad nauseam. Tasmania has taken a disproportionate amount of cutbacks under Commonwealth funding than has any other State, by about 3 per cent across the board. Tasmania does not have a rapid increase in population. Do honourable members know how many people we get under the business migration program? Very few-one or two. Tasmania is a very small island yet its contribution to the wealth of this nation since Federation, as the figures show, has been as a net exporter. It has constantly added to the value of this nation. The Wesley Vale pulp mill would have been a gain-it would have added value, something which all of us in this place want to do; but it fell apart at the last moment. So do not say that it is the Tasmanian Liberal Government's fault, because it is not. Anyone who says otherwise is wrong.

I think there has been a little bit of premature rejoicing in the current political situation. In the sober dawn of just before the election, honourable members will find that people will realise that they have to make a choice. It is a difficult choice-no-one would deny that-of which direction Tasmania should go. Should it go towards sustainable yield policies and a balanced development of resources, which is what the Liberal Government puts forward? I might add that even the Labor Party in Tasmania says the same thing, in part. There is not as great a difference of opinion as some speakers in this debate would indicate. Should Tasmania go down that path, or should we turn our backs on that type of development? If Tasmania wants balanced development and sustainable yield policies, and if it wants economic growth-and all of us are driven by the need to continue economic growth in times of very difficult economic circumstances-then there has to be development. The question is: how does one go about managing that development? The management of balanced development and a balanced approach is the nub of the argument about the Wesley Vale pulp mill, environmental issues and the role of the independents.

My view is that the balance has shifted too far towards embracing issues of the environment. Honourable members in this place know that environmental issues are difficult. One has only to look at the difficulties faced by the Government in relation to the Convention on the Regulation of Antarctic Mineral Resource Activities. We all want mining in Antarctica not to take place. There are two paths to that situation: one is to say `no convention', and the other is, `Yes, have a convention'. The Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) supports it and there are people with different views on this side of the House as well. However, this indicates that the issue of finding a balanced way to meet environmental needs and development needs requires some complexity of argument; it cannot be embraced by simplistic approaches. I fear that in Tasmania simplistic approaches have been embraced by the independents.

Is it not interesting that only yesterday in Hobart standing shoulder to shoulder with the leader of the Labor Party was Senator Richardson, the noted knee-capper of the Labor Party. What did he say? He said the very thing that I have just said: that this problem does not lend itself to simplistic approaches. There needs to be a balance and, above all, there needs to be stability, so do not vote independent, vote for either of the major parties. That is what will happen, and the balance of the numbers will come out in favour of the Liberal Party, because other issues need to be addressed; primarily, the issue of stability needs to be addressed.

We have a nation which is on an economic slippery slide, where the national debt is rivalling that of Mexico. Unemployment is high and Tasmania is suffering. Exports need to be increased and import substitution needs to be improved. The Wesley Vale pulp mill would have provided us with that opportunity. Interest rates are three times those of our major trading partners and they are impacting on family budgets. If one talks to families one will realise how difficult they are finding it in conjunction with the blow-out of health costs. These are the issues that the people are concerned about. When they see that there is a possibility of instability, that there will be more elections and when the hard decisions about these matters are not being addressed because of diversions, they will come back and vote for stability. Mark my words-it will happen. There will not be a hung parliament in Tasmania; there will be a clear majority.

It is recognised by this Government's own polling and by its own Party-Federal and State-that this will not happen. Their left wing trendies stabbed Neil Batt in the back. They ditched the former president of their Party and I predict that he will lose his seat in Hobart. The former Leader of the Senate in the Whitlam Government, Ken Wriedt, who was also a former Leader of the State Labor Party, will also lose his seat. Unfortunately, Ken Wriedt is a tired person. Those two people took the approach of balanced development. They did not go the trendy route and grab the latest headlines and the latest feeling in the community; they wanted balanced development. They are pragmatic men who could see what was needed, and they knew that Tasmania was suffering economically. Unfortunately, their arguments were not listened to. The community will not listen now to their arguments because the Labor Party in Tasmania will not allow them the opportunity to put those balanced views. That is a tragedy for the Tasmanian Labor Party because Michael Field will be defeated and Patmore will come through and take over. He will take the Labor Party into the wilderness for a long time, and for the Labor Party that must be a matter of regret.

In my view, the Wesley Vale pulp mill could be a turning point for Australia. There is some uncertainty as to which way Tasmanian voters will go. I have my view and those on the other side of the House have their view. But let me say this: this country, which is, as I said, on an economic slippery slide and which knows that it must respond to those pressures-which, after all, is the role of the Federal Government-is now confronted with the twin dilemma of maintaining growth and of adding value to resources, and it must do this on a sustainable yield basis and protect the environment. In my view, and I think that of the Federal Government, this can be done.

Look at what happened in this place yesterday. The Government introduced the Resource Assessment Commission Bill. I cannot pre-empt debate on this matter, but this commission recognises that there was a failure at Wesley Vale. It recognises that the Federal Government failed to publish guidelines in advance. It recognises that people were going in a hundred different directions. This Bill may be an advance-it recognises a glaring gap in the development of balanced resources in this nation. For people on the other side to say that it is all Tasmania's fault when only yesterday this Bill which recognises a major failure was introduced, is hypocritical in the extreme.

There are two other points I want to mention before resuming my seat. At Question Time yesterday there was a disgraceful response from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, and the Minister for Employment and Education Services, Mr Duncan. I have never heard anything so destructive and inaccurate since I have been in this chamber. An attack was made on the unemployed in Tasmania-on people who are suffering. I was in Launceston recently when the Minister for Employment and Education Services opened up the new employment agency and the new employment programs. He recognised then, in a sober moment of proper reflection, that all over the nation we needed to develop programs that could help young people to get into work. But yesterday we saw cheap political point scoring from him and from the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, who again referred distortedly to retention figures. He said that in getting young people to stay longer in school, Tasmania started from a lower base than anywhere else. If one has a close look at the figures, one sees that Tasmania has achieved more in a shorter period than any other State. For him to say what he did and to decry Tasmanian youth and the efforts that they are making was a deplorable display and a blatant exercise in stupid political point scoring that showed no sensitivity to the people and the programs that he, as a Minister, is trying to help and administer.

I am sure that if Tasmania's young people heard those two points they would be appalled. To make flippant remarks about Tasmania exporting apples and about its future was a deplorable response to complex problems which require a sincere and long effort from governments and parties on both sides. The Minister really was debasing the whole issue.

Finally, to go back to Wesley Vale-it was a tragedy. Tasmania was the major loser. We hope to recover that ground and see a mill proceed at some time in the future. More importantly, we are not the only ones who hope that it will proceed; most of the Federal Labor Party hope it will proceed because our balance of payments problems and our economic problems are monumental. The people who have been in the driving seat and are leading us down that economic slippery slide are on the other side of the House. A bit of genuine concern about Tasmania would not go astray at this time from Ministers in the Hawke Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr). I used to follow another member for Denison, whose name I cannot remember, but we used to call him the `mouth from the south'. However, I do not think we will see him around again. It is good to have a true representative of the people of Tasmania here once again. We have not had one for years. I can assure the honourable member for Denison that it is good to have him here. As I hold the most southerly seat in Victoria, for many years I was like the de facto Australian Labor Party member for Tasmania, hopefully looking after the interests of the people of that State.

SPEECH.PARA: We have had a bit of electioneering here today in the speeches of a couple of honourable members from Tasmania. One has only to contrast what is happening in Tasmania with what has happened in Victoria. Things have changed dramatically. In Victoria, we have a tremendous growth. One has only to look around the city of Melbourne. Buildings are going up; there is work. We cannot get enough people in Victoria. It there are any Tasmanians listening to this who need a job-if the Gray Government has not found them a job-they should come over to Victoria because we need as many people as possible.

It was mentioned that Ken Wriedt, one of the members of the Tasmanian Parliament, looked tired. The Liberal Government down there is so tired that its members cannot wake up to what is happening; they just do not know what is going on down there. Tasmania is a very beautiful island. I have visited it many times. It is magnificent; it is of world importance. It must be protected. The national parks have been set aside, and they are something that future generations from all over the world will come to look at. The people of Tasmania also have a very pleasant and relaxed lifestyle-different from some of the conditions here on the mainland.

The problems with the Gray Government and the problem of Wesley Vale started with Lake Pedder. That was the first environmental issue in Australia. That greatly raised the profile of the environment, which is now one of the top three issues of concern. It is more important to many people than how many dollars a particular opposition party can offer them or bribe them with. We must not forget that the Gray Government wanted to dam the Gordon below Franklin. The all-up cost of that particular effort would have been about $1.4 billion. The new head of the Hydro-Electric Commission in Hobart has said that not one watt of the power that would have been provided by the Gordon below Franklin dam is needed. Events since 1983 have proved that correct. The Gray Government wanted another great project, costing $1.4 billion. I cannot remember how much Wesley Vale would have cost, but it was a lot of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —One billion dollars.

—It is about the same. The Tasmanian Government said that it would create jobs and do everything, but it did not say that it would wreck the environment. That is exactly what it would have done with that first proposal that was put forward. The Liberal Government in Tasmania has a very sorry record of protecting the environment. I have had a look at some of the Forestry Commission work that is being done down there. The Commission says, `Look, we are selecting the trees-we leave avenues of trees along the roadside so that people cannot see that we have devastated the back'. It is starting to learn-very rapidly.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to look at a little of the history of Wesley Vale. What we have heard this morning is not correct. The honourable member for Lyons (Mr Burr) and the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) said that the Federal Government had set no guidelines. But in February 1988 North Broken Hill Peko Ltd officials met with Federal Ministers to outline plans for a pulp mill. In May 1988 North Broken Hill wrote to the Federal Government saying that it had found a partner-Noranda Forest Inc.-and that agreements were needed from State and Federal governments. In July 1988 the Federal Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) officials met with North Broken Hill. On 12 July 1988-this is just a couple of months later-30 pages of draft guidelines for preparing an environmental impact statement (EIS) were sent to the Tasmanian Department of Environment. The guidelines were sent on 12 July 1988. It is wrong to suggest they were never sent. On 25 July 1988 DASETT officials met with Tasmanian departmental officials, the joint venturers and their environmental consultants to discuss the details of the guidelines for the preparation of the EIS. The whole premise of the argument of the honourable member for Lyons was that there were no guidelines. The guidelines were drafted back in July 1988. These are the facts. I just cannot believe that honourable members can get up here and misrepresent these facts so greatly.

On 18 August 1988 the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, announced a package of financial incentives to assist the development of the mill, including accelerated depreciation, et cetera. On 23 August the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to Premier Gray referring to previous discussions between Commonwealth and Tasmanian Ministers. On 17 October 1988 the Tasmanian Government signed a contractual agreement with North Broken Hill to allow the mill to be built. On 24 October 1988 the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, visited the site and met with the companies. He said that he would only recommend approval if he was satisfied that the mill was environmentally sound. On 27 October the EIS was released to the public. On 24 November the Tasmanian Government put through the fast-tracking legislation concerning the Northern Pulp Mill Agreement. This removed the appeals procedures from the EIS process. The Tasmanian Government said, in effect, `We are not going to have anyone speak out against what we have said'. It intended to gag everyone who wanted to appeal against the decision.

There was a bit of movement over Christmas and then on 5 January 1989 the Tasmanian Government's environmental controls and guidelines were made public. However, North Broken Hill was critical of them and wanted them changed. On 6 January 1989, Tasmanian Environment Minister Hodgman said that the guidelines were `fit and proper'. On 10 January 1989, the Tasmanian Government introduced guidelines for the environmental management plan. On 31 January 1989, North Broken Hill and Noranda said that they would shelve the project unless the guidelines were changed by 3 February. The companies said that the guidelines contained requirements which were not technically possible to meet. In other words, they were saying. `If you do not do what we want you to do and what we tell you to do, we will not build this $1 billion project'. It is called blackmail.

On 1 February 1989, Premier Robin Gray said that according to technical advice that he had received the guidelines could be met. Surprise, surprise! On 3 February 1989, there was an announcement on a North Broken Hill letterhead-not from the Tasmanian Government, but on a North Broken Hill letterhead-that Parliament would be recalled `early in the week commencing 13 February' to `approve legislation designed to clear the way for the project to proceed'. The legislation was to be `jointly agreed to by the companies and the Government'. Just who is running Tasmania? Is it the Liberal Government or is it North Broken Hill? It appears that North Broken Hill wanted Parliament to meet, so it sent out a letter over its letterhead telling everyone that Parliament would be recalled. I do not know what the Speaker of the Tasmanian Parliament had to say about that, but obviously he must have concurred.

On 8 February 1989, the Department wrote to North Broken Hill seeking clarification on issues, and it mentioned dioxin emissions, chlorine, and so on. On 16 February 1989, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories met with company representatives to discuss concerns. On 21 February 1989, the Tasmanian Government signed a new pulp mill agreement incorporating more than 40 changes. On 6 March 1989, the head of Noranda said that the project would be shelved by the companies if any changes were made to the guidelines-another billion dollar blackmail attempt. On 9 March 1989, the Tasmanian Parliament ratified the Doubts Removal Bill, which incorporated new interpretations. This is a saga of pure and unadulterated blackmail of the Tasmanian Government by Noranda. On 15 March 1989, Senator Richardson, Senator Button and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) met with the companies who then announced the withdrawal from the project. This is the sort of thing that has been happening in Tasmania.

People seem to have forgotten the history behind this issue and they tend to forget the amount of leverage that this company was applying to the Tasmanian Government. It would not happen to any other government in Australia, but it happened in Tasmania. Why? It happened because the Tasmanian Government has done nothing for its industries over the years that it has been in power. In fact, Tasmania is losing its people to the rest of Australia and it cannot build up any industry. Why? It is because it is weak. Tasmania needs a new government and a premier who can stand up to these large companies, someone who has a bit of forethought, who can look to the future a bit and who will balance these things.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is that?

—A chap called Field, the Tasmanian Opposition Leader. In a couple of weeks, when he becomes Premier of Tasmania, he will do a good job. I can assure the honourable member for Braddon of that. In the short time I have left I will give the house an example of the type of reply that came from North Broken Hill to questions asked by the Federal Government. The Tasmanian Government wrote to North Broken Hill outlining 85 matters set out in environmental impact statement guidelines which were either inadequately addressed or not addressed at all in the EIS. For example, studies were requested and the company was told that the outfall site must be specified and mapped and the dilution and dispersal of effluent must be predicted. In reply, the company supplied an addendum to its EIS, but it was far from satisfactory. For example, the company said that it would not carry out some studies until approval was given for the project-another nice little bit of blackmail.

SPEECH.PARA: The company has since said that environmental issues should have been cleared up earlier in the process, and it simply disagreed with some of the queries and criticised the government departments which made them. A detailed question was asked about the design and location of the outfall site, which I would have thought was pretty important because it incorporates the pipe that will spew out into Bass Strait dioxin, chlorine and the combination of chemicals that come from paper mills. I have seen pictures of these sites and they are pretty horrendous. As I said, in answer to one detailed question relating to the design and location of the outfall site, the company provided a seven-word statement.

I would have thought that the outlet pipe from a huge complex like this, which will put millions of litres of all sorts of chemicals into Bass Strait, deserved a bit more than a seven-word answer. That is the sort of disdain some of these huge multinational companies from overseas have for Australia, which they think is still part of the frontier. They think they can rape and pillage the environment and get away with it, but I am glad to say that that is not the case. I am glad to say that the people of Tasmania have woken up to this. But there are many things still happening in Tasmania that need to be looked at, for instance, the woodchip freight trains that travel through the back of Burnie in the middle of the night at midnight and 1 a.m. These sorts of things still happen.

The decision by Noranda not to build, I think, was brought about by the Gray Government. It just did not know what to do. I believe that the Liberal Government of Tasmania advised North Broken Hill and Noranda incorrectly. In fact, I think that this has been stated by some key North Broken Hill people. The turning, weaving and twisting of the Liberal Government in Tasmania over this Wesley Vale issue and what it has come out with lately is all about trying to stop Christine Milne and the other green party people from winning a seat in the district of Lyons. This situation is occurring in the Lyons district, which is where the Premier has his seat. I trust that when the Tasmanians go to the polls in a couple of weeks time we see a change in government. I do not know why some members of this Federal Parliament support Robin Gray, because he has never supported them. People should look at the history of this type of issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Voyager Disaster-Tax Avoidance and Evasion-Tasmania: Taxation Revenue Sharing Arrangements-South Africa-Tasmania-Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport: Proposed Third Runway-Deregulation of Wheat Industry-Death of Mr David Gundy

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tenth of February this year marked the twenty-fifth anniversary of one of the worst disasters in the peacetime history of the Royal Australian Navy. I speak of the collision between the destroyer HMAS Voyager and the aircraft-carrier and flagship HMAS Melbourne off Jervis Bay on the New South Wales south coast, claiming 82 lives of all ranks in Voyager, including the commanding officer, Captain Duncan Stevens. Once again I take the opportunity to highlight on the public record this historic, albeit black, event. On that fateful night it is now clear that for those involved there was a mixture of understandable fear, of disregard for personal safety, of mutual trust of shipmates, of bravery and, regrettably, of personal sacrifice and death-characteristics we have come to respect and honour in the great and proud traditions of the thousands of men and women in Australian naval service in peace and war.

SPEECH.PARA: Today I pay tribute to those who lost their lives in the service of their country that evening, to those who survived and continue about their everyday lives, and very specially to their families. Regrettably, many of those survivors and their families still bear the scars of the tragedy-scars of psychological trauma, of persistent nervous shock, of domestic instability, of financial strain and, importantly in this parliamentary setting, of misplaced confidence in, and neglect by, a government which espouses social justice, but demonstrably fails in this instance and beyond.

Today I wish to draw the attention of the House to the case of one survivor, Mr Bernard Verwayen, a totally and permanently incapacitated pensioner of Buderim on Queensland's Sunshine Coast, whose fight for justice has already cost him $100,000 and has placed him on the verge of bankruptcy. Late last year, after a lengthy battle, Mr Verwayen gained approval of the Full Bench of the Victorian Supreme Court to sue the Commonwealth for damages resulting from the Voyager disaster. Many in the legal profession considered that the decision would provide a precedent for other survivors, totalling about 100, to follow.

I would remind the House of the history of the Voyager damages claims since this self-satisfied Government took office.
