Firstly, in 1985 the Government, through the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), admitted liability in relation to at least six, and arguably all, survivors, to waive the statute of limitations to allow common law action. After two successful common law actions, involving damages pay-outs of nearly $500,000 it did a rapid about-face and moved to reapply the statute of limitations which prevents action being taken if seven years or more has elapsed since the accident. This was used as a defence against the claim of Mr Verwayen.

In March 1986, the Government altered regulations to facilitate the imposition of the statute of limitations in relation to Voyager claims. About the same time it took certain psychiatric examination measures with some of the claimants but did not continue when the results were clearly in favour of the claimants. In December 1987, Mr Justice O'Bryan of the Victorian Supreme Court, although critical of the Government's behaviour, ruled that the Commonwealth was entitled to rely on the statute of limitations to bar the claim of Mr Verwayen. I also refer honourable members to the Hansard record of this place on 9 December 1987, in which the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) defended the Government's change of mind in 1985, at the same time imputing ulterior motives of those involved, including legal counsel. Of the latter he said:
Is it not a fact that a firm of lawyers in Melbourne decided that it might be an opportunity to ginger up a bit of business?

He also said that the Government had not admitted liability, whereas the court record and correspondence on the matter shows that this is untrue. I strongly reject those imputations on behalf of the people concerned and specifically on behalf of legal counsel, who are present in the Gallery today.

In November 1988 the Full Bench of the Victorian Supreme Court overturned Mr Justice O'Bryan's decision, clearing the way for Mr Verwayen to continue his claim. In handing down this decision, Mr Justice Kaye and Mr Justice Marks said, in part:

The facts of the case disclose effectively a promise by the respondent not to seek to have Mr Verwayen's claim barred under the Victorian Limitation of Actions Act. There can be little doubt that the promise was made deliberately and with the knowledge and intention that Mr Verwayen pursue his claim and have his damages assessed.

In March 1989 three members of the High Court of Australia granted the Commonwealth leave to appeal to that court against the Victorian Supreme Court ruling. I understand that this will take about a year to decide. In April 1989 the Government introduced into this House the Limitation of Liability for Maritime Claims Bill-which we will support in this place later today-allowing a twelvefold increase in maximum compensation for loss of life or personal injury to passengers, including ships' companies of naval ships, on the surface a very commendable initiative by the Government but seemingly at major odds with its persistence in its appeal to the High Court in the Verwayen case, where the same principles are at stake.

The Government appears to be alarmed that this Voyager case will cost it some money-money which it should properly pay, and without further delay, if it desires to return any vestige of honour and of decency as regards its handling of these matters. The public feelings in these matters are best demonstrated in the words of a letter to the Melbourne Sun on 26 April from the brother of one of those lost, which concludes with the words:

`I ask the people of Australia to let Voyager and her lost crew finally rest in peace by pressuring the Government to stop its scandalous behaviour and allow the survivors the opportunity to put their case before the courts, so that justice can finally be seen to be done.

I wish to assure Mr Verwayen and the Voyager families that the next coalition Government-and that is not far away-will not hide behind the statute of limitations as the Government has chosen to do. We will allow those damages claims to proceed in the courts and provide the long overdue justice for those concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Neil Mr L.R.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My grievance this afternoon concerns the ridiculous situation where we have the Opposition criticising this Government on the subject of tax policy. The Opposition does not even have a tax policy. It keeps promising to outline where it stands on taxation, and never does. Who can blame it? Its record is nothing to be proud of. The only growth industry that the Opposition ever fostered was that of tax evasion-the bottom of the harbour schemes. It allowed the taxation system to deteriorate over a number of years to the point that it was unfair and open to abuse. The Opposition nurtured a tax system which encouraged its mates to earn their income in forms that went untaxed. While the average wage and salary earner sees only what is left after the tax man has taken his share, the Opposition felt that paying tax should be optional for its mates. These weaknesses in the tax system meant that ordinary taxpayers were asked to shoulder an unfair share of the nation's tax burden.

SPEECH.PARA: The Howard-Fraser Government not only left this country with a tax system which was riddled with loopholes and tax havens, and thus was not effective in gathering its tax, but it burdened pay as you earn (PAYE) taxpayers, that is, the ordinary working class people, with high marginal tax rates. Treasurer Howard crippled the lowest income earners with a lowest tax rate of 30c in the dollar, which then jumped to 46c in the dollar at a salary level of only $19,500. Then those who earned above $35,788 were required to pay 60c in every dollar earned; what is more, because the tax system was riddled with holes people in these higher tax brackets could find ways simply not to pay their personal income tax.

This Labor Government, in comparison, has reformed the tax system over its period of office, making it both more efficient and more equitable for everybody. This Labor Government has restored some equity to marginal tax rates. People earning less than $20,600 will have to pay only 29c in the dollar from 1 July 1989; people earning between $20,600 and $35,000 will pay only 39c in the dollar; and the top rate has been slashed from 60c to 49c, soon to be 47c in the dollar. Not only have we provided these honest taxpayers with some relief from their tax burden but also we have placed an enormous amount of resources into catching the tax cheats. By making everyone pay his fair share we can reduce the load previously placed solely on the shoulders of PAYE taxpayers. Let me remind the people of Australia that by the taxing of capital gains and the taxing of fringe benefits, an attack on the exploitation of entertainment expenses including the free lunch, we have recouped another $1 1/2 billion in taxation each year from stopping these rorts-$1 1/2 billion that has been redirected to the most needy in our communities.

Some of the other measures we have put in place to tackle those tax cheats are: a series of legislative measures that have stopped the proliferation of bottom of the harbour schemes; the general anti-avoidance measures contained in part IVa of the Income Tax Assessment Act; a series of changes in relation to retirement lump sums and superannuation that broadened the tax base and removed avenues for avoidance and deferral; the introduction of the anti-evasion prescribed payments system; substantiation requirements that curtailed the allowance of deductions for expenditures not incurred and aided the process of self-assessment; the imputation system that, by removing the effective double taxation of company profits, removed distortions in the system, including pressure for business to operate through non-corporate forms; the anti-evasion upgraded tax file number system; and the strengthening of mechanisms for the collection of tax, increasing the level of penalty for breaches of the taxation law, and modernising provisions for the prosecution of such breaches.

This Labor Government has also given the Commissioner of Taxation additional staff and funding to assist him in his efforts in combating tax avoidance and evasion. The Tax Office has dramatically increased its auditing efforts in order to catch tax avoidance and evasion. There are audit teams set up to check every level of the taxpayer community equally. No section of the community, large or small, can afford to think it can escape the gaze of the Tax Commissioner. Companies trying to avoid paying their fair share of tax now run a much greater risk of being caught, thanks to determined action by the Hawke Government. In 1987-88 there were between 300 and 400 Tax Office auditors working on the company audit program. Over the next three years, this number will grow to nearly 1,000.

The expanded company audit program will concentrate initially on Australia's 100 largest company groups. Some large companies now have Tax Office auditors permanently located in their head offices, going through the books, making sure that the right amount of tax is paid. By June 1990 there will be 100 large company group audits under way. The increasing emphasis being placed on company audits under this Government has already produced spectacular results. While company tax revenue has doubled under this Government, extra tax collected from companies through special audits has increased 4 1/2 times to nearly $400m this year. This increased effort on the part of the Commissioner of Taxation has brought him under attack from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). The Leader of the Opposition proposes to replace the Commissioner of Taxation with a board of five people who would be drawn from the private sector. That is wonderful! The Leader of the Opposition wants the tax system to be run by a group of corporate tax experts whose interests lie in defending the interests of that very sector. How can the Opposition consider that to be an impartial set? Nobody would agree to that. No-one in his right mind would place any confidence in such an arrangement.

The money we have collected in tax avoidance has been used for social justice. Since coming to power in 1983 this Government has done much to implement its commitment to achieve a fair and just society, a society in which economic resources are distributed fairly. The taxation system has been central in allowing the Government to carry out these promises. The tax system enables the Government to collect the levels of revenue considered necessary to provide the services that the Australian community needs and deserves. All this extra revenue, which is collected by the diligent Tax Office, has enabled remarkable progress in areas such as family assistance and age pensions.

In relation to age pensions, this Labor Government has allowed the full indexation of pensions in comparison to the restraint being exercised by the rest of wage and salary earners. It has allowed an increase in the single pension rate from 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings in 1983 to 24.7 per cent in December 1988. The 12 April economic statement announced increased pensioner tax rebates so that age pensioners with earnings within the earning test free area of $40 for single pensioners and $70 for married couples pay no tax at all. When fully phased in by July 1990, this major reform will mean that 80 per cent of Australia's 1.8 million age and service pensioners will be exempt from tax.

As well, major improvements have been made in assistance to low income families under this Government. The family assistance supplement (FAS) was introduced in 1987, benefiting some 550,000 low income and pensioner and beneficiary families, with a total of over one million children benefiting. There is also increased assistance to low income families renting privately, including large increases announced in the 1988-89 Budget which will, for example, double current maximum levels of assistance with those with three or more children by 1990. The family allowance supplement increases will provide, as part of the social wage, major improvements in assistance for most families. A two-child family, for example, will receive an additional non-taxable $5.25 a week assistance-an increase of 41 per cent-from this measure alone. This Government will also, for the first time ever, index FAS each January so that the Government's major commitment to assisting all families with children is maintained over time.

One needs guts, discipline and determination to succeed in government. It is not easy, but we have had the courage to accept the challenges and make the tough decisions. I am proud to be part of this Australian Labor Party Government. I say to the cynics who say that the Labor Party has changed that it has not; it is the same Labor Party that Chifley talked about when he gave his `light on the hill' speech; it is the same Labor Party that gave us the great reforming Government of the 1970s under Gough Whitlam; it is the same Party that Australians have always called upon in times of difficulty: the Australian Labor Party. It has not had to change its name; its history goes back to the last century. All members of the Party are important. They are the people who keep members of parliament like me going; they keep the Government in office. As long as they believe in the Party and the things we stand for and as long as they are prepared to keep giving their time, energy and loyalty to this great cause of ours, Australia is in good hands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on the treatment of Tasmania by the Federal Labor Party in regard to taxation revenue sharing arrangements. I take issue with one or two of the comments made by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil). I point out that this is the highest taxing government that Australia has ever had. In the last few weeks, of course, the Government has said that it will hand back $5.9 billion to Australians. I point out to the people who are listening to the broadcast of this debate that in the Budget brought down in August last year the Government took $7.9 billion from our pockets. Then, six months later, it decided to hand back $5.9 billion. So we are still out of pocket to a substantial extent-by about $100-odd for every man, woman and child. Whatever is being said in this Parliament, let us keep the record straight: this is the highest taxing government; it is a government that presides over a record inflation rate at the moment, compared with that of the rest of the world, and the highest interest rates in regard to housing that we have ever seen.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address my comments to the state of affairs in Tasmania at the moment. In regard to taxation revenue, I point out that over the last few years taxation revenue collected by the present Commonwealth Government since it came to office has gone up by approximately 75 per cent. But general revenue grants which are given back to the States have gone up by only 55 per cent. Overall, this Government is increasing the amount of tax taken from Australians' pockets and pay packets and it is keeping greater amounts of that money at the Commonwealth level than ever before. It is not increasing funding to the States. What we find is that those services for which the States have responsibility-health, education, police departments, and so on-are short of financial assistance from the Commonwealth, even though the Commonwealth is increasing its tax take from Australians.

As I said, on average, the percentage of taxation revenue returned to the States has gone up by only 55 per cent in the last six years. But the figure for Tasmania has increased by only 46 per cent. That is having a devastating effect on the Tasmanian economy and on employment rates in that State. The Commonwealth is gradually withdrawing more and more money from the States and it is withdrawing money from Tasmania at a much faster rate than for the other States. In real terms, it means that that State has lost about $440m in a year-that is the effect-and it is no wonder that the unemployment level in Tasmania is increasing.

It is very interesting to look at the rate of the increase in the unemployment level since the Hawke Government came to power. Until 1978, Tasmania had exactly the same average unemployment rate as in the rest of Australia. The rate then started to drift marginally until about 1982-83. Since that time the difference between the average unemployment rate in the Commonwealth of Australia and that in Tasmania has actually doubled. That is largely due to the withdrawal of Commonwealth services from Tasmania and the withdrawal of funds for capital works in that State.

In 1982 Tasmania had been led by a Labor government for approximately 40 consecutive years. There had been a government of a different political persuasion for only three years during that period, and that was a government in which the independents held the balance of power. It led to a considerable amount of instability. During 1978-82, the Labor Government that was in power could best be described by the words, `procrastination', `dithering', `lack of leadership' and `indecision'. We had a large debt-$34m at that stage. That has been reduced by the present Government, under the firm leadership of the present Premier. There has been strong, stable and progressive government in that State for the last seven years.

Certainly, when the election is held on 13 May, I have no doubt that the Tasmanian people will elect the Robin Gray Government to a third historic term because they do not want the instability of having independents hold the balance of power in that State. They do not want to go back to having a Labor government which shows a lack of leadership and which is indecisive. That can be seen no more clearly than in the present debate on the Wesley Vale issue. The present Leader of the Opposition in that State has been described by one of his colleagues in the Senate as having `two bob each way'. That has been said not by the Liberal Party, but by one of his own Party colleagues, who has said, `The Leader of the Labor Party in Tasmania is trying to have two bob each way'.

There has certainly been a lot of debate about environmental matters in Tasmania. I certainly welcome that, because Tasmania is one of the most beautiful States in Australia and certainly has maintained its forests in much better condition than those in any other State. I want to point out a few matters in regard to the environment that we are facing in Tasmania. When were the big mills established? Who established them? They were established under a Labor government. There were very few controls in regard to effluent. It has only been since the Gray Government came to power that controls have been gradually imposed on all those big companies. That has not occurred before. The Gray Government has tackled the environmental problems positively. I applaud that Government for its very positive approach to its tree planting program, for the cutting back of urban effluent into the Bass Strait area and also into the rivers, and for reducing the number of exemptions from companies that are allowed to discharge effluent into the environment from 109 to about 56. That has all happened in the last few years. No Labor government tackled it. It was left to the Gray Liberal Government to take a strong, positive, commonsense approach to environmental matters, as well as to development.

The Wesley Vale debate, of course, is interesting. The Wesley Vale mill was lost because the Federal Government thought it could play one-upmanship. It thought it could go one better than a State government. That is what it was all about. What really happened was that it lost one of the biggest industrial development projects in Australia's history. A lot of nonsense was talked about dioxin. I say to the people listening to the broadcast of this debate that dioxin is also produced when one has a barbecue; and 98.5 per cent of dioxin is produced from car emissions, the burning of plastics in garbage tips, et cetera. There should be greater concern in that regard than in stopping the construction of any pulp mill.

The proposal for the safest pulp mill in Australia was ditched. It would have been the safest pulp mill of that type built in the world. We are now left with other pulp mills in Australia which will put out effluent which is much more dangerous than anything put out by that new pulp mill. It would have employed the best technology in the world. I trust that it will not be too long before that new pulp mill will be built. That will certainly help alleviate the unemployment problems which Tasmania faces.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In a recent paid advertisement in the Weekend Australian of 1-2 April, the South African Ambassador accused many newspapers of putting out disinformation about South Africa. He concluded his article by urging readers to beware of giving any credence to this alleged disinformation about his country. It is my contention that the same warning must be given about information coming out of the South African Embassy, especially through paid newspaper advertising. I did answer the points made by the Ambassador in a letter to the editor of the Australian but, no doubt aware of the likely loss of advertising revenue from the Embassy, the newspaper declined to publish my letter. I raise this issue in this Parliament today so that I can refer to the crux of the matters that I raised in my letter.

SPEECH.PARA: In his paid advertisement the South African Ambassador claims that there is no evidence to support the claim that South Africa is supporting the vicious Mozambican resistance movement known as Renamo. He claims there had been no assistance `of any kind' after the Nkomati Accord. There are many well documented accounts of South African involvement in Renamo raids. In 1985 Zimbabwe troops in Mozambique captured a base where documents where found which showed continuing South African support even after the Nkomati Accord. Some of these documents were published and the South African Foreign Minister went so far as to concede `technical' violations of the Accord.

At the trial of an Australian missionary, Ian Grey, in March 1988, evidence was given of South African involvement with Renamo. The report by Robert Gersony to Ambassador Moore, Director of the Bureau of Refugee Programs, and Dr Chester A. Crocker, the United States Assistant Secretary of African Affairs, entitled `Summary of Mozambican and Refugee Accounts of Principally Conflict-Related Experiences in Mozambique' provides a graphic account of Renamo brutality. When Assistant Secretary of State Crocker appeared before a United States Senate subcommittee on 24 June 1987 he stated:
The evidence clearly indicates a continuing relationship of communication and support for Renamo from the Government of South Africa.

No doubt the South African Ambassador would likewise dismiss this as further disinformation. Despite these reports emanating from the United States, apologists for the racist South African regime still cry, `Where is your evidence?'. The evidence lies in the many documents captured from Renamo. On a recent visit to Mozambique I spoke with the United States Ambassador and there was no doubt in her mind of South African support for the rebels. Likewise, there was no doubt in our Australian officials' minds or in the minds of the aid workers there. Margaret Thatcher, not renowned for supporting left wing governments, has, since 1986, permitted British Army personnel to train the Mozambican Army.

As I have said, Chester Crocker, in testifying to the United States Senate subcommittee hearing on Renamo's activities, put the blame well and truly on South Africa. In fact, throughout the world people of all political shades agree on the destabilising activities of the South African Government in Mozambique; that is, except for the apologist, of racist South Africa. Some of those, unfortunately, sit on the Opposition benches in this House. I refer especially to National Party members. It is no wonder that they invited the South African Ambassador to address their conference late last year. Indeed, he must have felt very much at home.

People might ask: Why would South Africa wish to destabilise one of her neighbours? Would it not be in South Africa's own interest to have a peaceful, prosperous neighbour reaching its full potential? But Mozambique, like Zimbabwe, is a multiracial country. If there were a successful multiracial country next door, even people in South Africa would ask, `If it works in Mozambique and Zimbabwe, why not in South Africa?'. The racist regime in South Africa therefore is determined to see that a multiracial country cannot exist as its neighbour.

Australia can assist Mozambique more. We must bring diplomatic pressure on South Africa to stop its destabilising activities. We can give more aid, especially technical aid. We can better understand the situation in that country. Many Australian-owned organisations and our Government are distributing food, clothing and tools to the distressed and displaced people of Mozambique, yet time and again these efforts are being destroyed by vicious Renamo attacks. Farming projects are ransacked, food convoys ambushed, and development workers murdered.

I have recently been involved in two campaigns directed at the South African Government, urging it to stop the killing and maiming in Mozambique. How, I wonder, would the South African Ambassador react to the fact that, according to a United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF) report published in Harare just a few weeks ago, more that one million people have been killed and 11 million displaced by South African wars in Angola and Mozambique since 1980? The report, Children on the Frontline, written for the United Nations agency by outside experts, doubles cautious estimates of the economic costs to the southern African region of war and Pretoria's destabilisation during this decade. The new estimate, using United Nations, Economic Commission for Africa and World Bank statistics, puts the cost at $60 billion for the nine countries of the Southern African Development Coordination Council.

The UNICEF report highlights the tragedy that continues in the region as a result of war and terrorism perpetrated by South Africa. The costs comprise direct war damage, particularly in Angola and Mozambique, higher defence spending by all the countries, loss of economic production, boycotts and embargoes imposed by Pretoria, and caring for the tide of refugees and internally displaced people.

The Namibian section of the report-one of the first detailed analyses of the social conditions of the territory's 1.7 million people-reveals a shocking situation, according to Mr James Grant, Director-General of UNICEF. Mr Grant pointed out that in the first edition of the UNICEF report on children in southern Africa two years ago, his organisation had forecast a worsening situation. The report states that in 1988 alone, 150,000 infants and young children died in Angola and Mozambique from the direct and indirect effects of war. Two years ago, the figure was 140,000 child deaths. This will be the legacy that South Africa will leave in Mozambique: an infant mortality rate well above the world figure, after a period of destabilisation perpetrated by the Pretoria regime.

A recent article in the Australian Financial Review gives some indication of the activities of the South African Embassy. I stress that it operates within the law, but there must be something wrong with one's message if it cannot be conveyed by normal means. We are told that the Ambassador appears to have been adopting a two-fold strategy. The first is aimed directly at the media; the second at the public. The South African Embassy, according to the article, has set out to woo journalists by hosting lunches and parties at a rate unequalled by other embassies. There are even a number of apologists for the racist South African regime within this House who are frequent visitors to the Embassy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful.

—As my colleague says, it is disgraceful. It is a well-known fact around the corridors of this building that any member can very easily arrange a trip to South Africa as a guest of that country's Government. I must say that a few of those trips have been arranged for the apologists. The honourable member for McPherson (Mr White) may care to admit that he, as an apologist for that racist regime, has participated--

—I raise a point of order. The honourable member has accused me of being an apologist for the South African regime. I find that offensive and I ask it to be withdrawn. The fact that I have had a trip does not mean I am an apologist for any particular regime.
—I withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker. He did beat his breast as I was looking at him, but I withdraw.

—I have withdrawn. I now turn to the recently released policy of the coalition which follows the Thatcherite line regarding South Africa. The condemnation of apartheid is totally hollow when accompanied by the refusal to apply any of the measures that might bring the South African Government to the negotiating table, and when measured against the tirade of distaste directed towards black African governments elsewhere on the continent. It is, as I say, an apologist for the regime in South Africa. The coalition's foreign policy--

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some comments today about the relationship between the Tasmanian Government and the Federal Government. I am sure that all members of this House are aware that an election campaign is under way at the moment in Tasmania. During the course of that election campaign, and in the lead-up to it, a great many misleading statements have been made in this place and in publicity given by other people, particularly those representing the Federal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the constant claims that is made is that the Tasmanian Government, led by Mr Robin Gray, has been incompetent in the way in which it has managed the Tasmanian economy. Very often, figures are cited about the level of unemployment and other economic activity that is taking place in Tasmania. I can assure you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there is a great deal of concern about the level of unemployment in Tasmania and the lack of job opportunities for young people. The effect, of course, is to force young people to move to other States in order to seek employment and other opportunities.

Contrary to the constant accusations that are made in this place and in other places by people representing the Federal Government, the cause of that blame does not lie with the Gray Government in Tasmania. I want to put on record today some of the facts about what is happening, and what has happened in recent years, in Tasmania, that has caused considerable anguish to the people of Tasmania and restricted very greatly the opportunities available for Tasmanians to advance their own economic circumstances.

Let me begin by mentioning the funding that is available through the Commonwealth to the Tasmanian Government. As we all know, it is a feature of economic distribution in Australia that the Commonwealth is the major tax raiser in the country. It then distributes, through the Premiers Conference and the Loan Council, a great deal of those taxes to the States for them to spend on behalf of the community. As a result of actions taken by the Hawke Government, grants to Tasmania have now been reduced in real terms by $440m a year. In other words, had the financial arrangements that were in place under the Fraser Government still been in place today, Tasmania would be receiving an additional $440m from the Commonwealth. That equates to $1,000 per head of population-per man, woman and child-in Tasmania.

I understand the difficult economic circumstances facing the country as a result of the mismanagement of the economy by the Hawke Government. We understand that there have been cutbacks to all States. But while the cutback to Tasmania has been at the rate of $1,000 per head, the average cutback to all the other States has been $500 per head. Clearly, this Federal Government has been much more savage in the way in which it has treated the Tasmanian Government than it has in regard to any of the other States.

Let me refer now to the Commonwealth's own activities-the capital works program and other activities that the Commonwealth undertakes. In the period 1988-89 to 1990-91, the projections for capital works activities in Tasmania will amount to a meagre $17.3m. In other words, on a per capita basis, that equates to $38 per head of population in Tasmania. The average for all other States is $145 per head. We have here two avenues in which the Commonwealth is attacking the Tasmanian Government and the Tasmanian people: firstly, the way in which it has cut back the direct grants to the State Government-Tasmania has suffered twice the severity of treatment of any of the other States; and, secondly, the lack of activity in Tasmania by the Commonwealth through the Commonwealth's own capital works spending programs.

The Commonwealth is also, because of its lack of activity in Tasmania, continuing to cut back on the spending and employment opportunities that it can create. The most recent reduction can be seen in the Australian Taxation Office, a further 72 jobs in Tasmania having been withdrawn. The Commonwealth continues to take this type of action in Tasmania, yet the response we get from the Commonwealth is to blame the Gray Government for its mismanagement.

What I have so far referred to on the one hand is direct inaction on the part of the Commonwealth in Tasmania which, clearly, is not within the control of the Tasmanian Government. On the other hand, the Gray Government has made numerous proposals about the way in which it can develop the resources and economy in Tasmania. Those proposals continue to come forward as a result of the initiative of the Gray Government. What happens when those proposals reach Canberra for the final stamp of approval from the Commonwealth Government? Repeatedly, the Commonwealth Government overrules the Tasmanian Government and refuses to allow those initiatives to be undertaken which would lead to new industries and new economic activity in Tasmania.

I have now referred to three methods by which the Commonwealth constantly attacks and retards development in the State of Tasmania. Yet, for political expediency, the Commonwealth Government and Ministers of the Commonwealth constantly criticise the Gray Government and Ministers of the Tasmanian State Government for the fact that there are economic difficulties in that State. I put it to the House that much of the reason for the economic difficulties in Tasmania is not as a result of actions by the Gray Government but as a result of actions taken, or actions not taken, by the Commonwealth Government.

I appeal, for the sake of some equity for the people of Tasmania, to the Commonwealth to change its policy directions and at least give the people of Tasmania a fair go. Even if it will not match its own direct spending in the State of Tasmania and bring it up to par with what is being contributed to the other States, it should at least let the Tasmanian Government get on with developing our resources, our industries and our economic future, without being constantly overridden by the Commonwealth Government.

The latest and most widely publicised of those actions in overruling the State Government involved the proposed Wesley Vale mill. The mill, which was to cost $1,000m, was to be the largest industrial development in Australia recently. There are significant national implications for the contribution it could have made to the national economy, yet the Commonwealth Government overruled the State and prevented that development from taking place. The Tasmanian Government is still very keen to develop the natural resources of Tasmania so that those resources can be processed and value-added. If that is done, it will not only contribute to the economic prosperity of Tasmania but also make a significant contribution to the national economy. But because of the way in which the Commonwealth Government has treated Tasmania in the past there is considerable apprehension as to what might result if new proposals are brought forward. There are still discussions about development of our resources, but nobody really knows how the Commonwealth will react, whether it will simply overrule the State of Tasmania once again, as it has done in the past.

I appeal to the Commonwealth Government to stop using the State of Tasmania for its own political expediency, to have some compassion for people in Tasmania, and to allow the development of our resources in that State, so that we can enjoy the prosperity of our own possibilities by using our resources for our own development. While it might be doing this for its own political expediency, it is the young people who are suffering most bitterly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this grievance debate today I will speak on behalf of my constituents, as distinct from speaking on behalf of the Government. I am going to talk about an issue that is of enormous significance to my constituents, and it is a matter on which, I believe, thus far the Government has made an incorrect decision. It is a decision which I intend to try to see is never implemented. I refer, of course, to the decision to give in-principle approval, subject to an environmental impact statement (EIS), for a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport.

SPEECH.PARA: I and some of my colleagues who have also expressed strong public opposition, have been accused of looking after our own political backyards and disregarding the broader national interest. That is an assertion which I reject absolutely. I believe that if a proper evaluation is undertaken of the decision that has been taken, and of the basis and criteria which led to that decision, our position clearly is not contrary to the national interest; in fact, it is very much in the national interest.

The Government's decision, as I said, is to give in-principle approval for a third runway, subject to a favourable environmental impact study. So that whole area of environmental assessment must be undertaken, and it is obviously critically important that that be done objectively. One of my main concerns at the moment is to ensure that there is some sort of proper, objective environmental assessment and that local community groups and local residents have a genuine opportunity to have an input into that process. Most importantly, the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC)-which, under the legislation as it stands, is responsible for conducting the EIS-which has shown itself time and again to be a strong advocate of a third runway, should not be able to get away with a Claytons EIS. I believe that that is a very real danger. I was approached by one of my constituents who had contacted the Federal Airports Corporation and had spoken to one of its environmental staffers about this matter, and who was told by that staffer that the thing was a non-event and that it was a foregone conclusion. I think that is absolutely outrageous. I will be doing everything in my power to ensure that there is a proper and genuine EIS.

I believe that it is highly desirable and essential that community groups receive some support from government in the development and presentation of their case, and I will certainly be pushing for that. I also believe that there needs to be a quite separate parallel process involving those in the local community who collect information during the period in which the draft EIS is being prepared, so that they are in a good position to offer a critique of the draft EIS, to be produced by the Federal Airports Corporation, which should be available in about a year's time. That is a terribly important issue, and I intend to take the Government very much at its word when it says that there will be a genuine and proper EIS. I had discussions with Senator Richardson about this matter and I will continue to press this issue.

I turn to the question of the so-called cost benefit analysis which underpinned this decision. A few weeks ago, before the decision was made, I and a number of my colleagues in the Labor Party had an opportunity to question at length representatives of the Federal Airports Corporation when they appeared before a Caucus committee. Their opening comment was that, on their assessment of the costs and benefits, the third runway was the right way to go. It was very interesting because were were able to query them about that. The reality is, of course-and this became clear from questioning-that they had not anything which remotely resembled a proper or genuine cost benefit analysis. What they had was a variety of costings for the third runway, on the one hand, and various development options for Badgerys Creek, on the other. They also had an estimate of the capacity gain that would be provided by a third runway at Kingsford-Smith; they cited a figure of 40 per cent or so.

The interesting thing was that they had no estimation of the capacity gain that would flow from the building of any of the Badgerys Creek options. In other words, they had an estimate of the costs of the third runway versus Badgerys Creek; they had an estimate of the added capacity provided by the third runway; but they had no estimate whatsoever-and they could not give any answer at all-about what capacity gain would flow from any of the development options from Badgerys Creek. That fact makes an absolute nonsense of their opening suggestion that they had done a genuine cost benefit analysis.

Since the decision was taken by Cabinet I have been able to glean quite a bit of information about the basis on which the decision was taken. I believe the decision is fundamentally flawed and wrong. I think that an awful lot of gold plating has gone into the proposal for the development of Badgerys Creek. I understand that there was talk of the need for not one but two high quality road links between Badgerys Creek and the central business district. There is a huge disparity between the costings provided by Bechtel-the American construction company that prepared the costings for the Federal Airports Corporation-and the costings prepared in a report submitted in July last year by the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, which, one would imagine, would have some expertise in this area.

There is also a huge disparity, in regard to what has been allowed for associated roadworks that would be required if the Kingsford-Smith proposal were to proceed and traffic at Kingsford-Smith were allowed to grow, between what the Cabinet, I understand, has allowed for, and what the Wran Government in 1981 estimated would be required. In 1981 Neville Wran wrote to then Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, estimating that the cost of additional roadworks required if Kingsford-Smith continued to expand and traffic continued to grow would be $300m. The Cabinet, I gather, has allowed for a fraction of that amount.

The most glaring deficiency in the so-called cost benefit analysis is the complete absence of any attempt to put a monetary value, or any value, on the noise and suffering endured by people under the flight path. The fact is there is no doubt that the building of the Badgerys Creek airport would be, environmentally and from a noise point of view, a preferable option to building the third runway. That seems beyond dispute. The Government has argued that some reconfiguration of the noise pattern will result from building the third runway. The fact is that on noise criteria grounds there is no question that Badgerys Creek is the correct way in which to proceed.

Some analytical work has been done as to how one quantifies the inconvenience and stress suffered by people living under flights paths. During the major airport needs of Sydney study, over 10 years ago, quite a bit of work was done on how one quantifies those aspects-by seeing how they are reflected in property values, and so forth. There was no attempt to incorporate that sort of analysis into this so-called cost benefit analysis.

I believe that one must take into account the fact that the Government was relying on one set of costings prepared by an interested party, that is, by a consultant commissioned by the FAC. One must take into account the clear disparities that exist between the costings-particularly as they affect Badgerys Creek but also Kingsford-Smith-claimed by the FAC and those claimed by various credible sources of information. One must take into account the failure explicitly to incorporate in the cost benefit allowance any allowance for the effect of the impact of noise on people. One must take into account the other environmental effects that are impossible to quantify in monetary terms, such as the effect on Botany Bay. One must take into account another intangible, that is, the risk that at some stage over the next few decades there will be a major accident involving a large aircraft, and the consequence of a major aircraft falling into a densely settled area. When all those considerations are taken into account, I do not believe for a minute that the national interest is best served by the decision to build a third runway.

I believe that the right way in which to proceed is to build the second airport at Badgerys Creek. That involves more upfront expenditure, but one must look at these things over a longer time-say, 20 years. That is the only proper way in which to evaluate public investment. If one looks at it from that point of view and from the point of view of the longer term issues concerning the urban and regional development of Sydney, the benefit of moving a major piece of infrastructure away from the densely populated central areas, I believe the airport decision the Government has taken is wrong. I will be working to ensure that that third runway is never built. I will be working in conjunction with all interested parties who are prepared to work towards that objective, including trade unions and local community groups. My parliamentary colleagues who have expressed a similar opinion will be working in a concerted way to that end. I conclude by saying that I think it is a disgrace to suggest that the consideration of the third runway proposal be taken out of the purview of the Public Works Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Sydney (Mr Baldwin) pointed out that he was going to speak on a matter which was of enormous significance to his constituents. I respectfully submit that the matter that I am about to discuss is of enormous significance to Australia, its future and certainly to the survival of everything that is, or was, best in the Australian character. Before I do so, I apologise in advance for one or two very personal comments which I may be obliged to make. The subject that I want to discuss-and, good heavens, it has been aired time and again in this House, particularly over the last 24 hours-is the legislation dealing with the deregulation of the wheat industry.

SPEECH.PARA: The aspect that I want to discuss is a little different from what has already been aired in this House. What I want to say is that the National Party, right back in the days of Sir Earle Page, was based on a very fundamental rural principle-orderly marketing. It has been said that the wheat industry is possibly the flagship of primary industry. I would not argue with that for a moment. In fact, I point out-this is one of the personal matters that I want to mention-that my daughter's husband is a member of the O'Brien family, who were perhaps the earliest wheat growers on the Darling Downs in Queensland. They later switched to the production of flour, but that is another story. The honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) is a wheat grower from way back, as was his family before him. We heard his very emotional address in the House, and I agreed with everything he said.

Let me make it perfectly clear that I would not subscribe to anything which would jeopardise the future of the wheat industry and wheat growers. Let me tell honourable members one thing: a wheat grower, someone who raises cattle or a person involved in the pastoral industry or the agricultural industry, inevitably--

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. I wish to draw his attention to one of the Standing Orders. Although a formal point of order has not been taken, there is a debate dealing with the wheat industry before the Parliament at the moment. Standing order 82 states:

INTERJECT.PARA: No Member may anticipate the discussion of any subject which appears on the Notice Paper: Provided that in determining whether a discussion is out of order on the ground of anticipation, regard shall be had by the Speaker to the probability of the matter anticipated being brought before the House within a reasonable time.

Within my knowledge is the prospect that the debate on the Bills that are presently before the House will be resumed later today. I am conscious that the honourable member mentioned that he did not wish to canvass the debate, but I would sanction him against canvassing speeches that have been made in that debate or issues that arise from that debate and would encourage him to address matters largely outside the ambit of the wheat legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I presume that I will be credited with the one or two minutes of my time which have elapsed. The primary producers of this country, be they wheat growers or whatever, are usually regarded as people who can afford to run expensive cars, and that sort of thing. If one lives among them, one will know how totally mythical that is. They contend with drought; they contend with diseases and the use of agricultural products; they contend with adverse market conditions; they contend with the ever present penalty of distance. There is a close affinity between any genuine member of the National Party-and the coalition as a whole-and genuine land-holders particularly the second, third and fourth generation producers.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there are always people who stand on the sidelines-this relates to each of the major parties and perhaps the minor parties-and look for some particular way in which they can accentuate factional differences in the Labor Party and differences that may or may not exist within the coalition. What they do not understand is that if one has to weigh one thing against the other-this is the guts of what I have to say-there could be an intrusion into other areas. The article in the Australian today which quoted me was reasonably accurate. I do not think I am intruding into the areas that you mentioned, Mr Deputy Speaker, when I say that it was suggested that a fundamental view of my Party is that there should be orderly marketing. My comment was that the wheat industry is efficient and well controlled, so why is anyone interfering with it? It is one thing to seek protection, and to try to look at the whole spectrum of trade, but when an industry is going along very nicely, why should there be this sudden intrusion?

Let me return to my main point. These people stand on the sidelines and work out ways of doing what they have never been able to do, they never participate in the political arena themselves; they set themselves up as God, pass judgment on members of the various parties and want to bring them down, and do not realise that there is always a pro and a con. I am a coalitionist to the death. One might say, `Why, do you love the Liberals? I have many very close friends in the Liberal Party. I do acknowledge one particular reality, that is, if one feels, as I do, that the Future Directions document that was introduced recently by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) sets the pattern and is the bible, which outlines what one wants for Australia, one would be terrified at the proposition of the coalition breaking down.

With all due respect to some of the most honoured members of the Labor Party, I know that some members are uncomfortable and unhappy with one or two of the things I am about to mention. We stand four-square for the old times. I will never forget what the Leader of the Opposition said when he was interviewed by one of these smart commentators-one wonders what they are all about; one wonders what their principles are-who said, `After all, Mr Howard, you are going to turn back the clock 25 years'. What did the Leader of the Opposition say? He said, `What is wrong with that?' Twenty-five years ago we did not have the drug scourge that we have in this country at the moment'. Some parents say `Jenny is like all the young people these days, she is living with a fellow but they are friends'. Where are the standards? Can any parent say that he would be satisfied with that?

What I am getting at is that we stand for the family; we stand for the traditions of the flag. People say, `There goes Katter. He won't be around for much longer'. Do not bet on that. My nomination form is half signed. In my view, and in the view of those who sit down and think about this, many of the principles of the Australian Labor Party are devastating to this nation. This is the national capital, and everything good and healthy should come out of here. It is now regarded as the pornographic capital of Australia. Am I preaching? A halo would look particularly silly above my head. I do not claim to have the great sanctity that I envy in other people. I conclude on this note: if I have to make a choice, I will stand firm to see that the coalition is maintained because it is the only way out for the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the grievance debate today I want to raise the case of David John Gundy, an Aboriginal man who was shot to death in a police raid on his home in Sydney. It is a matter of deep personal concern on my part because prior to my election to this Parliament one of my jobs had been as principal solicitor for the Aboriginal Legal Service of New South Wales, which is headquartered in the inner city area of Sydney. I am particularly distressed about the circumstances of his death because I am aware from my own experience that years of work, done to reconcile the necessary presence of the police force with the local Aboriginal community, can easily be set at nothing and racial and other tensions encouraged by the sadness and tragedy of the kind that has occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the relationship between the police and Aboriginals in inner Sydney is not pretty. There have been numerous instances of allegations of police misconduct, of brutality against Aboriginals in custody, Aboriginals in the street and Aboriginals in their homes. These allegations have, on occasions, been sustained by the New South Wales Ombudsman. I am particularly aware of one instance, where, in a police raid on a hotel, a young woman was savagely beaten about the head, sustained injuries which were disfiguring, and only after a lengthy and opposed investigation by the Ombudsman was it ultimately found that this woman had suffered these injuries at the hands of a police officer.

Because of this background an incident like the death of David John Gundy could be the trigger for a breakdown in what had been, I believe, improving police relations with the Aboriginal community in the inner Sydney region. What it does point to is the need to respond quickly so that there be no suggestions of a cover-up in this instance. I would entirely endorse the call by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand), for there to be an independent investigation into Mr Gundy's death. I accept that some might take the view that the ordinary processes of coronial inquiry could be adequate to deal with such a death, but I think that this overlooks the important point that in this case there is a deep wellspring of suspicion and a real concern amongst Aboriginals living in inner Sydney, that they have been the victims of cover-ups, of violence, and of police oppression in the past. They fear that any inquiry other than one which is expressly independent would be possibly tainted. If that feeling is allowed to grow, damage to community relations would be very great, so, I think it is most important that the New South Wales Government accepts the wisdom of establishing a special independent inquiry to investigate David John Gundy's death. He was an innocent man, shot to death in his home following a police raid by the Special Weapons and Operations Squad. It is not a situation we as a community should take lightly; it is one which calls on us to express our deep feelings of grief towards this tragedy, our deep feelings of concern for his family. We should say that there must be an independent investigation.

Anyone who has been reading the sad, trammelled history in the reports that have so far been published by the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody would have the conviction reaffirmed that we are looking at an area in which social policy has failed. We have witnessed through the Royal Commission instances in which young blacks have been abused; have been taken from their families; have suffered the most appalling deprivations; have been mistreated in custody and have ended up taking their own lives.

The raid that caused the death of John Gundy, of course, is in an entirely different category, but I think it needs the same response-to have these matters thoroughly investigated and no stone left unturned in making sure that the Aboriginal community, which has so many legitimate grievances, does not have yet another, that is that the system is in some way locking out the process of proper inquiry and not looking into their legitimate grievances. This raid also points to some difficulties with the way in which police have been dealing with the problem of major crime. There is no doubt we are living in a time when weapons are not infrequently used in crime and police responses have to take into account the fact that criminals may be armed. But there have been a number of instances where police conduct, and that of security forces, to say the least, has been questionable. Most of us will remember the raid in a Victorian hotel when security forces knocked down a door and terrorised guests. The Gundy case, of course, brings to mind the situation in New South Wales, and a few days later, in Queensland, when the Special Operations Squad in that State stormed premises looking for a wanted man and, in the process, fired a stun grenade which landed in a baby's bassinette.

All these instances suggest that we do need to look very seriously at the problem of police self-management and how they conduct their difficult job in these areas. I strongly support the call by the Victorian Council for Civil Liberties for a judicial inquiry into police use of firearms so that we can look at these questions. They are ones which are important to our community as a whole and touch us in a fundamental way. Nothing could be more frightening to all of us as civilian members of the community than to find, because of a mistake having been made, our homes broken into in the middle of the night by a police raid, guns pointed at us and, as in the tragic case of Gundy, an accident occurring in which somebody dies. It is no good saying that this could not happen to us. It has been shown at least on two recent occasions that it does happen to somebody; there are innocent people in the community who are facing this terror. Whilst the police must have proper avenues to respond to armed crime, I think that there is a need to look at the way in which the armed response of the police force has been conducted, particularly given the large list of deaths that have occurred in recent times. Some years ago Professor Harding wrote a seminal book entitled Police Killings in Australia. That book has been overtaken by time. I think there is a need for some public inquiry, perhaps at a national level, with the cooperation of the States, to look at the way in which our armed police forces operate--
