DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment Statistics-Miss Mary Ellen Hurley-Tasmania: Election-Endeavour Foundation-Two Dollar Note-Japan: Killing of Whales-Pensioners: Allowable Income Levels-Telecom Australia: Phone Connections-Antarctic: Mining

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has become customary for the Hawke Government, under seige for the failure of its economic policies, to set great store on the increase in employment of the order of 1.3 million since the Government came to office. But this outcome needs to be seen in proper perspective. Firstly, employment growth has always been much higher in Australia than in most other Western countries. Over the 20 years from 1968, job growth in Australia averaged 2.5 per cent annually, compared with an average of just over one per cent for the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development. One factor in this has been the relatively faster rate of population growth in Australia. Secondly, the growth in employment has not been confined to the years of Labor's overrated accord. Apart from the 1950s, 1960s and early 1970s, I cite the robust growth from 1979, with the economy generating some 530,000 jobs over the Fraser Government's period in office to the cyclical peak in September 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, under the Hawke Government we have had a large measure of `growth on tick'. When we note the resulting build-up in overseas debt we might say that each extra job from this forced-feeding cost upwards of $350,000 in overseas debt. Finally, unemployment-the true measure of an effectively functioning labour market-has, except very recently, been stuck at the relatively high figure of seven per cent. So, in sum, continued unemployment, the massive increase in Australia's overseas debt, the abysmal growth in productivity and lower standards of living for most Australians heavily qualify the employment growth outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At Loreto House in my electorate today a great celebration is taking place. I wish I were there. It is the 109th birthday of Miss Mary Hurley, a really marvellous lady. Mary Ellen Hurley was born on this day, 4 May, 1880, that is, 109 years ago, near Young on the Lachlan River. Her parents had a sheep property. Her father was Robert Hurley and her mother was Elonora Ryan. Mary's working life was spent at Lewisham Hospital and later at David Jones. She loved the shops. I asked her when she was 105 whether she had seen much change in the shops over all those years, and she said `Not much. They still will not let you have the goods if you have not got the money for them'.

SPEECH.PARA: She was 35 when the First World War broke out and for her war efforts she was crowned Queen of Allies Day in January, 1915. A beautiful photo records that event. She became very ill when she was about 30 and her doctor warned her that she may not survive. It was for that reason, it is said, that she did not marry the man that she knew during the First World War. She thought she was a little too delicate for marriage. She is 109 today and is a great tribute to staying single. She has a sherry every day and eats extremely well-a snack before breakfast, breakfast, morning tea, lunch, afternoon tea, dinner and supper. She has a great sense of humour. Her eyesight and hearing are no longer wonderful but she still loves to read, she is very perceptive and has a good sense of humour. I am sure that the whole Parliament congratulates Mary Hurley.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I regret to have to interrupt the honourable member. It was an interesting story.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I would like to thank everybody who sent me cards and letters when I was crook. I especially would like to thank the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr). I thought that was a nice gesture. He has a green tie on today. That reminds me. I hope that the Tasmanian people do not vote for the greenies down there. I sincerely hope that they look into the future and realise that if they vote for the greenies, they will be voting for single issue people. They will not be voting for the people concerned with all the other problems associated with Denison, Franklin and the rest of Tasmania, people concerned about the elderly-about everybody.

SPEECH.PARA: Those greenies are single-minded. I have read reports today that they may get elected. I only hope to God that they will not. The Australian Labor Party would not form an alliance with them if it got elected, which it will not. If the Liberal Party gets elected, which it will, it will not form an alliance with them. I am saying to the people of Tasmania: `Please do not vote for them'.

The greenies are getting a fair run from the media. I cannot understand that. The Australian and other mainland newspapers seem to know all about Tasmania. They seem to be prompting and promoting the greenies. They seem to think that Tasmania is a wilderness for everybody; that that is all Tasmania is about. There are a lot of young people in Tasmania. The Acting Treasurer made an interesting point the other day. He said that Tasmania is not exporting apples any more; it is exporting its young people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I regret to say that the honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a little disturbed by a newspaper article today which talked about the Endeavour Foundation's treatment of its staff. The article commenced:

SPEECH.PARA: An Endeavour Foundation supervisor has been suspended over her statements that the foundation treated its intellectually handicapped clients like slaves.

That person has been sacked from her job because she was willing to speak out against the treatment of some employees of the Endeavour Foundation. The Endeavour Foundation does good work with intellectually handicapped people in Queensland, but at times it simply rules its workers and clients with an iron rod. It is an oppressive organisation that cannot allow its work force to seek proper remuneration and proper conditions for their work, especially in the workshops which Endeavour runs.

I find it intolerable that Endeavour treats its staff like this. I have seen the Endeavour operations. I applaud some of them, but I am very critical of the way Endeavour operates. It keeps some parents in fear and ignorance of its operations. It certainly keeps some of its work force in fear and ignorance. The Endeavour Foundation is supported publicly both through the Government and through individuals who pour a great deal of money and effort into it. I think it is time it became somewhat more democratic.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ruddock) Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The difficult times the Hawke Government is having with its economic policy have been well proven and documented. However, I wish to raise something else. Since the demise of the $2 note, the Government has removed any recognition of Australia's two greatest income earners: wheat and wool. The $2 note recognised the work of John Macarthur, whose wool industry `On the Sheep's Back' alone this year, 1988-89, had a gross production value of $5.86 billion. Its obverse side paid tribute to William Farrer and the wheat industry, whose 1988-89 gross production value was $2.37 billion. Our image, our currency, our status as a manufacturing and exporting nation propped up by primary production, is not even recognised on our currency by this out of touch Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal art on the $1 note has now been replaced by a clutch of kangaroos on a gold coin. The $2 coin is reflected by an Aboriginal elder and the Southern Cross.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's all right.
—I do not doubt it. But when we start to toss the coin for the start of a game and choose a side, we cannot even call `heads' or `tails'. It is `heads' or `platypus'.

—I wish to use the short time available to me this afternoon to express my concern about the Japanese Government's decision to increase the number of whales it intends to kill this year. In 1986, in an historic decision, the International Whaling Commission banned all commercial whaling. Japan, in 1987, agreed that it would abide by that decision. But what has the Japanese Government now announced? An article which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald on 18 March stated that `Japanese officials' had `vowed to kill more minke whales next year'. A Mr Katsu Shima, of the Japanese Ministry of Agriculture and Fisheries, is reported as saying: `It is no-one else's business what we eat', condemning people who criticise Japan's decision to increase the number of whales it intends to kill this year as `glorified Japan bashers'. I believe that the Japanese Government cannot simply announce that it is going to increase the number of whales it intends to kill by a factor of five. Next year it is expected that Japan will catch 1,650 whales. The Japanese say that they wish to conduct scientific research.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—I support my colleague the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) in his appeal to the people of Tasmania not to support the green independents in the forthcoming Tasmanian election. As my colleague the honourable member for Franklin quite correctly pointed out, a vote for the green independents in Tasmania will be a vote for political instability in that State. There is no doubt that those so-called independents who are, in effect, an organised political party and campaigning as such, cannot bring political stability; they cannot govern in their own right; they are only a single issue group, a protest group; and they cannot in any way lend political stability and direction to Tasmania. My colleague the honourable member for Franklin was quite correct in labelling them politically unstable people who are looking only for short-term political expediency. I urge the people of Tasmania not to support them during the forthcoming election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today I want to talk about some of the more important aspects of the April economic statement, particularly in so far as they relate to the question of the amount of income that can now be earned by pensioners without affecting the amount of tax payable and without affecting their pension. I believe that many of our pensioner community still are not aware of reforms that have been made in this area. For instance, a single pensioner, as at July 1989, can have $10,500 invested at 12 per cent and not pay tax and not have to worry about his pension being affected. As at July 1990 a single pensioner can have $16,000 in a bank account earning 12 per cent interest without his pension being affected. As at July 1989 a pensioner couple can have up to $30,000 plus in the bank earning 12 per cent interest without their pension being affected.

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, I strongly urge those pensioners who may have taken some notice of the old Fraser adage in 1983 of putting money under the bed, to get the money from under the bed; get it out from under the mattress; get it out from under the biscuit tin and put it in a bank account where it will earn realistic interest rates. If their investment is in a no-interest bearing deposit, they should get it out. The banks do not need any favours from the pensioner community. They should get it out, improve their standard of living and not be scared about the money that they will earn, because their pensions will not be affected. Single pensioners can earn up to $40 a week in extra income; the figure for couples is $70. I strongly urge them to follow this advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—The monopolistic charges imposed by Telecom Australia under certain circumstances have been highlighted in two recent cases in my electorate. They apply with regard to charges imposed on residents in homes for the aged. In both cases, the residents of the aged homes were moved to a different room from the one they had formerly occupied. Each of those original rooms in which they had lived had a phone connected. Each of those new rooms had no phone, but there was a point for a phone connection. In each case, the outside Telecom connection had to be rejoined because the line had previously been allocated to a new subscriber. Not satisfied with charging a $45 transfer fee, Telecom also charged $13 for every quarter of an hour required to make the connection outside the room. In one of those cases the total charge came to $225. This Government's record of looking after our aged is not one of which it can be particularly proud. Telecom's service to the aged can now be added to that record. In the financial year 1987-88 Telecom spent $20m on advertising. This expenditure, much of which would have been used to extol the virtues and advantages offered by Telecom, does not equate with its handling of residents in aged homes seeking Telecom connections. The Liberal Party's commitment to privatise Telecom will address these inequities.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—It is a very great pleasure to get the call. I would like to speak in relation to a petition I presented to the Parliament yesterday containing 21,640 signatures to stop mining in Antarctica. The people who live in Antarctica are not represented in this Parliament. If the Electoral Commissioner ever looks for someone to represent them, the electors of Dunkley would welcome all people in Antarctica to join them. I would be very pleased to represent them. Some of the people who cannot, because of the rules and regulations of this Parliament, present a petition, are from Mawson and from the Macquarie Island station. Those people cannot have their petition presented because of some of the rules and regulations of this Parliament.
—Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—I ask the Prime Minister: As Ambassador Wilenski's speech regarding Israel, to which the Prime Minister referred yesterday, was delivered on behalf of both Australia and New Zealand, did he deliver his rebuke to Ambassador Wilenski on behalf of both countries? If so, was there any consultation before he gave his answer yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have, of course, delivered no rebuke to New Zealand.
—No; to the Ambassador.

—Or to the Ambassador. Let us take a bit of time dealing with this matter. There is a practice of some considerable standing, I understand, in the United Nations in relation to arrangements between our Ambassador to the United Nations and the Ambassador for New Zealand, and on some occasions it also extends to the Ambassador for Canada, whereby there is a division of responsibilities. There is much work going on simultaneously in the United Nations, and resources are deployed, I am informed, in a way where, often, an ambassador from one of the countries will speak not only for his own country but also on behalf of others.

ANSWER.PARA: In these circumstances I assume that, in regard to the statement to which the honourable gentleman refers, there was consultation between the ambassadors there as to the position of their governments and that when Ambassador Wilenski spoke on behalf of Australia and New Zealand he had cleared, through the New Zealand Ambassador to the United Nations, the approval and endorsement of the New Zealand Government for that position. That would be normal practice. I have no reason to believe that on this occasion, when Ambassador Wilenski rose to say that he spoke on behalf of Australia and New Zealand, he would have done other than to act in accordance with that custom and practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I rise on a point of order. My question related to the Prime Minister's rebuke to the Australian Ambassador in New York and to the substance of the speech, and the Prime Minister has quite deliberately ignored the question that I asked him.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat. Does the Prime Minister wish to add to his answer?

—I would like to, in terms of that intervention. I am not ignoring in any sense what the Leader of the Opposition has said. The Leader of the Opposition uses the word `rebuke'-that is his language. I repeat what I said in this House yesterday and what I had the opportunity to say recently at a press conference: I believe that, in the terms that I put to this House yesterday, there was a lack of balance, which I regret, in the statement that was made. I have explained the terms in which I think there was a lack of balance, and I have indicated that to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and he has accepted that. The Leader of the Opposition now says that I have rebuked the Ambassador to the United Nations. I prefer to use the language that I have used. I trust that, as a result of the observations that I have made, any future statement that is made on behalf of Australia by our Ambassador to the United Nations will have the appropriate balance.

ANSWER.PARA: As the Leader of the Opposition has gone to the matter again, it is appropriate that I emphasise again-as I did yesterday in this House-the fact that I say that there was that lack of balance, which I think was regrettable, in no way changes the substantial position which was covered by Australia at the United Nations, and that is, that our vote was cast in the way that it was in support of the resolution. In those circumstances we were in company with 128 others. The total number voting was 129, with two against-the United States and Israel-and one abstention, Liberia. The Leader of the Opposition, in his frantic attempt to divert attention from his own troubles, which are very considerable by any measure, may go on for as long as he likes in trying to beat up this matter. He will not have any success, because he will not divert this Government from the view that we have taken that the vote was correct, albeit that in the brief explanation of the vote and in the limited time available there was the regrettable lack of balance in the statement that was made. The vote was correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I have a question for the Minister for Community Services and Health, which I know will be of particular interest to you, Sir, given the reports in today's newspaper of extraordinary action being taken by members of the Canterbury-Bankstown Medical Association, which is in your electorate. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports that some doctors in New South Wales and Victoria propose to stop direct billing pensioners and disadvantaged patients and to charge them at rates above the Medicare schedule fee? Can the Minister tell the House whether such action is justified and what patients can do to protect themselves?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to media reports, under the headlines `Pensioners hit by doctors' and `Doctors' bid for bulk bill boycotts'. I must say that I am appalled by the decision of some 70 doctors in Bankstown, Sydney, to charge pensioners and other patients who were previously direct billed and, by a decision of the Victorian branch of the Australian Medical Association and Private Doctors Association, to encourage Victorian general practitioners (GPs) to mount similar campaigns.

ANSWER.PARA: The spokesman for the Canterbury-Bankstown group attempted to justify this behaviour by saying how GPs were financially disadvantaged by Medicare. Of course, as one might expect, the figures quoted were wrong. In New South Wales the Medicare fee for a standard GP consultation has risen in the past six years by 40.9 per cent-increasing from $13.20 to $18.60-and the honourable member can check these figures. In Victoria, the fee has risen by 50 per cent in the same period, from $12.40 to $18.60, and there has also been a 50 per cent increase in Tasmania. In Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia, the fee has risen by 60.3 per cent. That is because of the effects of our courageous decision in relation to uniformity.

The contention is that somehow GPs have been disadvantaged, but all those percentage increases are greater than have been increases in average weekly earnings in that period and greater than the rise in the consumer price index. It is true that they have been only marginally greater in New South Wales, but they have been much greater in the remaining States. I accept that in this country there is a very great gap between the average fees paid to specialists and the average fees paid to GPs. I accept, too, that at the moment there are probably too many GPs chasing too few patients. But those things have nothing to do with Medicare. They are the result of historic problems which have long been a characteristic of the health system in this country. They do not provide a justification for GPs treating pensioners in this way. They may have some quarrel with the Government but, if so, they should take up the matter with the Government and not seek to penalise patients such as pensioners, the poorer elements of the community.

I am confident that the vast majority of GPs-who put the health and welfare of their patients above all other considerations, whatever objections they may have to government policy-will reject this proposed boycott as contemptible. I am sure that most GPs will continue to direct bill patients who are most in need and that they will continue to adhere to the Medicare schedule fee for the rest of the patients. We should look at that adherence, which amongst GPs is very high. In New South Wales, 71 per cent of all GP services are direct billed, and 80 per cent of GP services in New South Wales are charged at or below the schedule fee. In Victoria, the figures are slightly lower, at 54 per cent and 66 per cent respectively.

Given the number of GPs on the ground, my advice to any patients affected is that they shop around for one of the majority of Australian GPs who will provide the service they want at a reasonable price which they can afford. I think it is true to say that the fact that most ethical doctors in this country are more interested in the quality of care that they provide to their patients than how much money they can squeeze out of the system is evidenced in that historic agreement reached between the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. That package of measures, which revolutionises general practice and which further strengthens Medicare, will address some of the historic problems that, I admit, have persisted in the GP area. That agreement was the result of negotiation; it was not the result of the efforts of a few GPs to blackmail patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Acting Treasurer confirm that, even based on the Australian Statistician's new analytical series, the annual rate of inflation is stuck at nearly 7 per cent, which makes the Government's Budget forecast of 4.5 per cent impossible to achieve? Can the Acting Treasurer explain to the House how this higher rate of inflation underpins higher interest rates, particularly in the light of the move by the Reserve Bank of Australia this morning to raise rediscount rates from 16.6 per cent to 16.8 per cent? Will the Acting Treasurer now acknowledge that his statement seven months ago that `this Government has set the circumstances whereby there will be a general downward trend in interest rates' was wrong?

—The Leader of the National Party of Australia referred to some minor technical adjustment made this morning by the Reserve Bank to the rediscount rate. He knows-or should know-that that is a technical adjustment and does not reflect any change of monetary policy being pursued by the bank. As for the inflation rate and the consumer price index figure which was announced today, I am at least pleased to see that the Leader of the National Party accepts our conclusion and the Statistician's conclusion that the correct figure is 1.6 per cent. The Statistician has calculated that figure on the basis of the new debt profile treatment of mortgages for housing. In relation to the point he makes about my statement many months ago, I indicated earlier this week that circumstances had changed. The Government took appropriate decisions earlier this year and will continue to take appropriate decisions, consistent with its essential objective of containing demands as a prelude to reducing inflation and, therefore, interest rates.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LEGAL AND MEDICAL ADVICE FOR VETERANS

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General would be aware of representations made to the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate, on behalf of members of the Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia and Returned Services League sub-branches objecting to the decision by the New South Wales Legal Aid Commission to force veterans and war widows to pay for the legal and medical advice that they receive on repatriation cases. Given the fact that the Commonwealth contributes $27m to the Legal Aid Commission, has the Federal Government been able to persuade the New South Wales Government or the Legal Aid Commission to review this imposition on New South Wales veterans?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As is known, the question of legal aid is dealt with through independent commissions which comprise representatives of the New South Wales Government, in this case, representatives of the Commonwealth and other people. The funding of those commissions is on the basis of the Commonwealth providing 55 per cent of the funds and the State 45 per cent of the funds. That is the New South Wales arrangement. The funds provided are substantial. For some reason best known to the members of the New South Wales Commission, they decided in 1988 to impose limits on services to veterans such as the honourable gentleman has mentioned, particularly the Vietnam veterans. They said that those services would not be provided unless there was a means test and also, perhaps, a contribution requirement.

ANSWER.PARA: The agreement that we entered into with New South Wales before 1988 was on the basis that the same types of services would continue to be provided as were provided by the independent Commission of New South Wales and the Commonwealth Legal Aid Commission prior to that arrangement. At that time, when we were directly handling legal aid, we were providing services to veterans free of charge. There was no means test and no contribution test. In 1988 that arrangement was revoked in a decision made by the Commission-a decision which, on vote, the Commonwealth representatives were against but which, regrettably, the New South Wales representatives were in favour of. At that stage the Commission decided that in future veterans would be subject to a means test and also, perhaps, a contribution requirement.

The Commonwealth opposed that position and made it very clear, through a ministerial colleague, that if the Commission continued to act in that way the Commonwealth would, through its own office, provide service but would deduct the cost of those services from the contribution formerly made on a percentage basis to the New South Wales Commission.

That decision agitated the honourable member for Dobell, who made speeches in this Parliament about what the New South Wales Commission had done and asked whether it was acting in accordance with the dictates of the New South Wales Government. That must have embarrassed the Commission, because at its meeting on 26 April last it decided to revoke the former decision. In future, assistance will continue to be granted to war veterans free of any means test and free of any contributions. We owe a debt to the honourable member for Dobell. We are very appreciative of the fact that the Commission has seen the light of day. Regrettably, the decision was not unanimous. The representatives of the New South Wales Government still continue to oppose the decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Treasurer to the prospectus for treasury indexed bonds. Does this prospectus state that changes to the calculation of the consumer price index (CPI) which, in the opinion of the Treasurer, would be materially detrimental to the interests of stockholders will be notified by the Treasury in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette as soon as practicable and stockholders offered the right to redeem their treasury indexed bonds at market related prices as determined by the Reserve Bank of Australia? Does the Acting Treasurer believe that the change to the CPI announced today will be materially detrimental to the interests of indexed bond holders? If so, when will Treasury put a notification in the Gazette to that effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will find out what the Treasury may or may not do in relation to that matter and let the honourable member know. It would be interesting to know what the Opposition's position is in relation to the CPI figures. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in his press statement of this morning, said:

ANSWER.PARA: Prices rose by 1.6 per cent in the March quarter, based on the series which the ABS itself recommends be used for analytical purposes . . .

I agree with him entirely. That is the appropriate figure. The Government's position in the press release I put out at 12 o'clock is identical to the position of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. We have received notification from the honourable gentleman who asked this question of a matter of public importance saying that there is a deliberate attempt on the part of the Government to deceive the Australian people regarding price increases. As matters of public importance have to be notified before 12 o'clock, and as the Government's position was made clear just after 12 o'clock, presumably the Opposition got it wrong. It thought that the Government would be concentrating on the one per cent figure which the Australian Statistician produced today but we, like the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, believe that that one per cent figure is not an accurate indication of the inflation rate for the quarter under review-the March quarter. Obviously the honourable member for Wentworth is now going to make extremely heavy weather of his matter of public importance because it is based on a piece of absolute fiction. I do not know whether the Opposition remains wedded to the idea--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I raise a point of order. For the past several minutes I believe that the Minister has been anticipating debate. I ask you to rule on that.

—The honourable member for Richmond might be aware that frequently during Question Time there are questions asked of Ministers which directly relate to questions which might be canvassed in the matter of public importance debate. Any Minister can give factual items of information. For the Minister to restate what the matter of public importance is about is not anticipating the debate on the matter. The Minister was asked a question about the effect of the consumer price index on some activity. The Minister is relating his answer to the CPI, and he is thus in order. He is not anticipating the debate on the matter of public importance. If the Minister does start to canvass the matter of public importance, I will pull him up. At present the Minister is in order.
—I raise a further point of order. In the Minister's remarks he said, `Presumably the honourable member for Wentworth will say something about the--

—I think he said, `Presumably the honourable member for Wentworth will have heavy going'. I do not think that is anticipating the debate. I would hope that the honourable member for Wentworth would not have heavy going.

—I am certainly not anticipating my participation in the debate. I am not going to contribute because I contributed yesterday on the same topic. I am not going to waste my time giving yesterday's speech today. In relation to the official use for legislative purposes, contractual purposes and so on, the figures which will be used will be those published by the Statistician, that is, one per cent for this quarter and 2.1 per cent for the previous quarter. However, the suggestion is that that is not an accurate reflection of what happened to prices during the March quarter. Therefore we have been relying on the 1.6 per cent figure for the March quarter as the appropriate measure of what happened to prices during the March quarter. As everybody knows, one cannot go back to adjust in an historical way the published CPI figures; so the Statistician took the decision to make a one-off change to the index for the March quarter. That will be the figure which will be used for official purposes.

—Will the Minister for Trade Negotiations report to the House on the likely effect of the recently announced export enhancement program (EEP) subsidised sale of wheat from the United States of America to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that on 2 May the Bush Administration announced a new initiative under the export enhancement program for 1.5 million tonnes of wheat for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Australia's sales to the USSR have declined considerably over recent years, largely as a consequence of the export enhancement program. What makes this sale even more perplexing is that it is made at a time when the wheat market is so buoyant. It is presently very much a seller's market for wheat; so subsidised wheat sales at this time make absolutely no sense at all. It is not in the United States' interests and it is not in Australia's interests to force down artificially the world price of wheat below the level that it should otherwise be. It will undermine Australian farmers' returns from international wheat sales. It further highlights the fact that the United States export enhancement program does have an effect on countries such as Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: I was pleased to see this morning that the United States agricultural attache here in Canberra is reported in the press as accepting the fact that the United States export enhancement program does have an adverse effect on Australia. While I would continue to debate with him the extent of the effect on Australia, he is reported nevertheless as at least acknowledging an effect of the EEP on world prices and Australia. Further, he is reported as saying that Vice-President Quayle also understands that there was some impact by the EEP on Australia. That is also welcome news. I can only hope, and I think all honourable members would agree, that, as more people in the United States Congress and the Administration realise that the export enhancement program is not securing market share for the United States from the European Community-which is what they intended it to do-but is taking a share of markets from countries like Australia, they will re-assess, on that basis, the use of the export enhancement program, especially with the present world market conditions for wheat.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Defence to his answer to a question on notice from me on 4 April 1989 relating to numbers and categories of FA18 pilots. The Minister has refused to answer the question on the ground that it relates to national security. As the Government has released numbers, categories and qualifications of pilots and other service musterings in the past, why has the situation changed? Is it the present state and capabilities of our F18 squadrons that constitutes a threat to our national security?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will look again at the honourable gentleman's question. As I understand it, we have actually released the basic statements about the number of operational pilots filling operational slots. There are 426 operational slots across the Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) for pilots and there are about 439 pilots filling those operational slots. The persistent suggestions by the honourable member opposite that we do have a shortage of pilots in operational slots and that their operations are therefore in a state of serious deterioration, like most of the claims he makes in this place, are false. I am not certain whether previous governments have released that level of detail. One can go into a much greater level of detail than that which I have discussed here. As I recollect it, that is what the honourable gentleman was attempting to do in his question on notice to me. I would have thought that, very sensibly, the detail that he asked for was a security sensitive matter. I do not believe previous governments have treated the issue any differently. I will make some inquiries as to whether they have treated those points differently in the past. It seems to me that Air Force advice to me that it ought to be kept as a matter that is security sensitive is sensible advice. Whether governments have followed that advice in the past, I do not know.

ANSWER.PARA: My attitude certainly does not arise out of any embarrassment of this Government. On the question of operational pilots in the Air Force, I can state that we do have sufficient numbers of operational pilots in the Air Force. There are some shortages of pilots but the shortages that we are taking in that area we are taking in the area of desk jobs. Increasingly, we are utilising people from other branches of the RAAF to fill those desk jobs. It has been a matter of some conjecture in the RAAF for some time as to whether in the past all those jobs were appropriately classified as for pilots only. That has always been a matter of substantial debate. A degree of necessity is starting to resolve that debate in a different direction from the way it has been resolved in the past. That again is simply a sensible way, I would say, of handling the problem. Our Air Force, like every other air force in the Western world, largely as a result of the burgeoning domestic and international civil aviation market, is experiencing a substantial call upon its pilots. We have a slightly worse situation in terms of calls but a slightly better situation than some in terms of actual losses, largely as a result of the great success of the Government's tourism policy-but combined with, until very recently, a shameful neglect by the airlines of their responsibility to train pilots, for which we have to carry the consequences.

Our loss rate for pilots is now going down. The year before last the figure was 120-odd. Last year the figure was 99. We are beginning to return to something like a normal loss rate. Nevertheless that is not to say that the situation could not dramatically worsen if a sudden additional requirement came upon the trained pilot community from the civil airlines. I do not rule that out by any means. The Air Force is doing a fine job plugging those gaps; it is a really excellent performance. In the course of this very difficult time it is bringing new aircraft into service and bringing pilots up to speed, so it ought to be supported.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. What action has the Government taken to expedite the release of Commonwealth land for housing purposes following the special Premiers Conference held in Canberra recently?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the recent Premiers Conference regarding the introduction of supply side measures to help the housing situation in this country I have set up an implementation group within the Australian Property Group of the Department of Administrative Services. Following that I sent a letter to the State Premiers seeking bilateral discussions to determine the attitudes of the States and their various housing departments to the offers that we are about to make. I am pleased to report to the House that we have already instigated discussions with four States-Western Australia, Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. Despite the public attitude of the Premiers after the conference-that in their view there did not seem to be much in this process-I am pleased to report that since then they have changed their attitude. The procedure that I am adopting, following the bilateral discussions, is to make the offers to the States within a firm time frame and if the States are not interested in the particular property, we will immediately test the private sector on the open market. That is what we are doing. I think that within the next six or eight weeks-in fact, probably within the next four weeks-I will be making firm offers to the States and to the Defence Housing Authority, possibly with regard to several properties, and will then test the open market with regard to the disposal of surplus Commonwealth land for housing.

ANSWER.PARA: The bilateral discussions with the States have produced a very interesting result. Despite what the Premier of New South Wales, Nick Greiner, said after the Premiers Conference New South Wales has indicated interest, through its Department of Housing, in a number of properties. The first one is a 90-hectare property at Silverwater, some eight or nine kilometres from the central business district (CBD). This 90-odd hectares, as a first stage, would produce something like 700 medium density housing lots. That is a significant contribution to the Sydney housing scheme. The New South Wales Department of Housing is very interested and I expect to make a firm offer soon. A bit further out from Sydney, at West Menai, we own a major property of about 177 hectares. Similarly, the Department of Housing is interested and I will be making an offer to that Department within the next few weeks.

In Perth there is a major property at Bushmead, of 200 hectares in size. I think Homeswest intends to take advantage of the firm offer that I will make within the next six weeks to purchase that property to provide housing for first home buyers. Even Mr Ahern, the Queensland Premier, who was most critical of our propositions at the conference and after the conference, this very morning forwarded a letter to me in which he made a firm offer for a very important property close to the Brisbane CBD, at Coopers Plains. The Queensland Housing Commission would like to build public housing on this particular site.

I conclude with a quick report on the Victorian Cain Government's attitude to the major property in question in Victoria-the ex-Defence property, Albion, comprising 500 hectares. We have looked at a major plan supplied by a steeering committee of State, local council and Federal Government officials. We have offered it to the Cain Government but it is not going to accept the offer. On 20 May we will test the private sector interest in Albion. I expect that I will have that transaction tied up by the middle of November.

All in all, these five properties that I have described, plus several others, would produce about 1,100 hectares of housing. I am firmly of the conviction that the housing divisions that will emanate from these firm proposals will make a very positive contribution to the supply side of housing policy. I trust that the disposals can be completed within the next six months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Acting Treasurer to his press release today on the March quarter consumer price index in which he indicates that the published figure of one per cent is not the true underlying rate of inflation; rather, the figure is 1.6 per cent. For the purposes of adjusting pensions and other payments will the Government use as an indexation factor the figure of one per cent or the figure of 1.6 per cent, which he says is the true underlying rate?

—The next adjustment to pension increases will be based on the September and December movements in 1988. Those figures were 1.9 and 2.1-the sum, 4 per cent. If we had used the new basis we would have used figures of 1.7 and 1.7, which would have been only 3.4 per cent. We and the Australian Statistician are saying that the new debt profile method is providing a proper measure of the underlying rate of inflation, but because we cannot adjust the old figures historically those old figures of 1.9 and 2.1 will be used for the next upcoming adjustment of pensions.

—Can the Minister for Employment, Education and Training inform the House of recent developments in improving Australia's training arrangements? Is it true that an historic meeting of State and Commonwealth Ministers recently agreed to establish a national training board? What will be the benefits of this decision for Australian employees and employers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that it is not engaging too much in exaggeration to describe the meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers last week as being of historic proportions. On 28 April the Ministers responsible for training and labour met at the Government's invitation in Canberra and took a very important decision to establish on a cooperative basis a National Training Board. This Board, which will comprise members drawn from each of the States and Territories, industry, employers and unions, as well as the Commonwealth, will be responsible for the setting of skill standards in a consistent and uniform way across the country.

ANSWER.PARA: Our training infrastructure has been bedevilled in the past, as it is at present, by inconsistencies as a result of different skill standards being established in each of the States and Territories. If there are different skill standards, it is difficult to have curriculum development and proper assessment and accreditation of skills developed on a national basis. The point is, however, that award restructuring will proceed on what we imagine will be a nationally consistent basis driven in the first instance by Federal awards. It is therefore important to develop a greater degree of national consistency in the training infrastructure of this country. This is part of the thoughtful and constructive approach which the Government is taking in all areas of education and training. I think that this decision to establish the board will be seen as a very important development.

Honourable members will be aware that in the April statement the Government announced additional funding to assist areas such as curriculum development, skills audits in various industries and so on. This is all part of careful preparation to ensure that the award restructuring process can be matched by a proper improvement in skill levels across the country in order to continue the development of a truly modern Australian economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Now that we know that veterans and pensioners are going to be hit again, I refer to another area of cutback. What is the exact amount of the specific annual limitation--
—Order! The honourable member for Farrer should rephrase his question so that it is in order.

—What is the exact amount of the specific annual limitation on the four categories of dental treatment for veterans and why has the Government imposed this severe limitation, impacting as it does on World War I and World War II, Korean, Malayan and Vietnam veterans and ex-prisoners of war?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Farrer for his fourth question in the Parliament. It is interesting to see that the Opposition is finally taking a bit of notice of the veterans of this nation. He knows as well as I do what the limitations are--

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The members on my right will also cease interjecting. The honourable member for Maribyrnong is about one second from going out the door if he is not careful.

—Thank you for your protection, Mr Acting Speaker. It is very interesting that when Opposition members ask a question in relation to veterans' affairs they never want to hear the answer. They are not interested in the answer. The honourable member for Farrer well knows that the limitation in certain cases is $300, but any veteran with a dental problem can have every tooth in his head filled. The Government does not discriminate against veterans for that dental care. But the honourable member knows as well as I that there is a $300 limit. As I said yesterday in this Parliament, when Bob Hawke became the Prime Minister of this nation the Budget was $2.5 billion. It is now $4.5 billion and going up. The Government is proud of its record in veterans' affairs. It does not neglect the veterans of this country and the honourable member for Farrer knows that. He misrepresents the facts all the time. It is a shame because he as a Vietnam veteran should be caring for veterans and not trying to scare them all the time. The Government looks after the veterans of this nation more than anybody else in this country. Yesterday the Leader of the National Party of Australia asked what the Government was doing about merchant mariners.
—I am still waiting for the answer.
—What did Opposition members do for the merchant mariners? The Government has an inquiry going on in relation to merchant mariners and allied veterans. They said nothing about merchant mariners.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member also asked about prisoners of war. What did he do for the prisoners of war?-absolutely nothing. The Government is looking after the prisoners of war. The Prime Minister and I are obliged to do exactly what the honourable member for Reid has asked us to do-and we will do that. We will give the matter all the consideration for which the honourable member for Reid has asked.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just answer the question.
—You will not allow me to answer the question.
—You didn't answer the question yesterday and you did not answer the question today.
—There you are, Mr Acting Speaker; they do not want to hear the answer-
—Order! The Minister might not respond to the interjection.

—Is the Attorney-General aware that so-called games are still being used to rip-off unwary ordinary Australians, sometimes for very large sums of money? I refer particularly to the continuing problem of pyramid games in my own electorate of the Northern Territory. What protection can the Government give to my constituents and other ordinary Australians from these shysters and rip-off merchants?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pyramid selling is prohibited by section 61 of the Trade Practices Act. The honourable gentleman talks about pyramid games, which come within the ambit of that section. In pyramid games very few people win and most lose their money. Accordingly, the Trade Practices Commission has been obliged to take action in the Northern Territory because regrettably the Northern Territory does not have any legislation on this matter. It is a pity that the Northern Territory does not have mirror legislation as do most States, which would prohibit pyramid selling.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the Trade Practices Commission, in accordance with its responsibilities, is publishing all information to schools and community groups in the Northern Territory, has written to over 2,000 individuals advising them of the dangers of pyramid games and the law in this regard, and is using all sorts of questions in the media-whether it be radio or community groups-to advise them of the liability and responsibility of the Northern Territory not being able to adequately cater for this problem. The Commonwealth is working with local groups. I add that there have been a number of prosecutions solely by the Trade Practices Commission as a result of some joint investigation by local consumer authorities. But we hope that in view of this outbreak of outrageous consumer rip-offs, the Northern Territory will do what other States are doing and introduce its own legislation.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER: MR LIONEL BOWEN

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAWKE
TALKER.ROLE: Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker, I seek the Chair's indulgence in order to make a few remarks on the occasion of a significant parliamentary milestone.
—The Prime Minister may proceed.

—I thank the Chair and the Leader of the Opposition. I am sure that all honourable members on both sides of the House would wish me to draw the House's attention to a notable even which will occur on Saturday 6 May 1989. It concerns our most distinguished friend and colleague the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen. On that day our colleague will become the longest serving Minister from the ranks of the Australian Labor Party in the history of the Australian Parliament. It adds lustre to that achievement, and for honourable members on this side of the House a very special significance, when I say that that record of service will then surpass that of our great and beloved leader Ben Chifley. For the record book, our colleague will have served a total of just over nine years-to be precise, 3,307 days-as a Minister of the Crown.

SPEECH.PARA: This is certainly not an occasion for me to say anything in the nature of a valedictory. A few more records may be chalked up before the Parliament expires. But I cannot let this occasion pass without placing on the record our deep appreciation of our colleague's service-his unsurpassed service to our Party, the Parliament and, above all, to Australia-and, in particular, expressing my deep personal appreciation and my indebtedness for the magnificent partnership we have had over the past six years.

This is not the only record to his credit. I suggest that no Australian in active public life would have had a longer period of public service-42 years in all. He was an alderman at 25, Mayor of Randwick at 27-I might say that they seem to catch them young around Botany Bay-a member of the New South Wales Parliament from 1962 to 1969 and a member of this Federal Parliament for nearly 20 years.

I point just briefly to the range of Lionel Bowen's ministerial service. In the Whitlam Government he was Postmaster-General, Special Minister of State, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister and Minister for Manufacturing Industry. In my Government, he has been Deputy Prime Minister, Minister for Trade, Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, Vice-President of the Executive Council and, of course, Attorney-General, the office he currently holds. He has been Acting Prime Minister on more than a dozen occasions in my absence, and in that post had indeed been a model of competency, efficiency and dispatch. At this time there is no need to list all the measures with which he has been associated over the years-Federal grants to local government, the Remuneration Tribunal, the National Archives, the Maritime Museum and his monumental work in relation to the national companies and securities legislation. I should particularly mention his immense personal commitment to constitutional reform, a commitment that I am convinced will ultimately bear the fruit that it so richly deserves.

There is one achievement I especially wish to mention. I believe it a great personal achievement and, importantly, an enduring achievement for Australia. In November and December 1973 our colleague, Mr Bowen, was Acting Minister for Education in the absence through illness of Mr Kim Beazley Senior, the father of our Minister for Defence. In that capacity of Acting Minister for Education he had the carriage of the Schools Commission Bill and the States Grants (Schools) Bill-I believe properly described as two of the most historic pieces of legislation ever before this Parliament, the foundations of the process by which this nation has been enabled to put behind it the sectarian divisiveness on education which disfigured our country for more than a century. These Bills were in grave jeopardy in the Senate, but there was a ray of hope. Quite remarkable as it may seem in terms of the sweetness and light which prevails today, there was at that time a difference of opinion between the Liberal Party and the then Country Party, at least about electoral tactics, and it was in very large measure due to the negotiating skills and the political acumen of Lionel Bowen that commonsense prevailed and these historic Bills became law.
Mr Acting Speaker, to end on a completely bipartisan note, let me quote from a quite impeccable source. In his memoirs, Jim Killen, writing on his own period as Leader of the House, says:

My dealings with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Lionel Bowen, who handled matters for his party, revealed a person of conspicuous integrity and fair dealing. Once an arrangement had been made it would take the most unusual happening to disturb it and he would put his cards frankly on the table and say, `Look, I'll make up the time somehow.'

It is just these qualities-integrity, fairness, frankness, honest and open dealing, and to which I shall add loyalty, staunchness, steadiness and wisdom-that have made Lionel Bowen so great a colleague, a great Minister, a great mate and a great Australian. I am sure that all honourable members will join me in congratulating him not so much on this record of tenure that he has set but on his whole record of achievement in the service of this Parliament and the people whom we all represent.
Honourable members-Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On behalf of the Parliamentary Liberal Party, I would like to associate myself with the Prime Minister's remarks.
—Don't go too far or you will lose preselection.

—I have had mine. I would just like to say that despite our political differences quite a lot of us over here rather like the Deputy Prime Minister, the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen). We think that some of the things he has done in this place over the last few months have been pretty good. We liked his referendum proposals. We particularly liked the outcome of them. I think Lionel Bowen has made some interesting contributions to the political history of Australia. He has brought a particular style to the post of Acting Prime Minister. It has been one of the interesting features of politics over the past 10 or 15 years that we have had two fairly frequent Acting Prime Ministers. We had Doug Anthony in the former Government, and Doug was different from the bloke he replaced on occasions. Apart from anything else, when Doug was there you could get on with your work and there were not interminable meetings.

SPEECH.PARA: The other great quality that I think Lionel Bowen has brought to the job is that he has an unerring deadpan capacity to deal with the most outrageously insistent armada of pressmen. I remember one very celebrated occasion, which the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) would remember even more than I, in December 1987. It was the morning that the Sydney Morning Herald had published a leak from whatever department it was which was a bit of a problem for the honourable member for Parramatta. The Herald was calling loudly for his head and others then took up the refrain. The spotlight switched to just outside the Acting Prime Minister's Maroubra office. The honourable member for Kingsford-Smith was striding towards his office when he was stopped. The pressmen said, panting, `You've heard all about it. What are you going to do? The Herald is demanding that he resigns, he has misled the Parliament'. The honourable member looked them straight in the eye and said `That's very interesting, I'll have to think about that.' They had no answer. It was a fairly effective put-down, but the sigh of relief of the honourable member for Parramatta was fairly short-lived.

The Deputy Prime Minister is a special kind of Labor man. He has some attitudes that are not so prevalent in the Australian Labor Party these days; he represents some of the old values of the Labor Party. He has a fine punting reputation and, in the years that he has served the Labor Party, he has brought a very distinctive, low-key, laconic sense of humour to his task. I can very genuinely say on behalf of the Liberal Party that we enjoy knowing him and will be sorry to see him go, because we think his term as Attorney-General has been pretty beneficial to us. We think his referendum legislation in particular falls into that category.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's cheap.

—The Prime Minister says that it is cheap. I would simply say to the Deputy Prime Minister that we wish him and his family well. We enjoy his company, and I am very happy to associate myself and my Party with the good wishes that have been conveyed to him by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-For the sake of the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith (Mr Lionel Bowen), we are all glad that this particular debate will not finish with a minute's silence and everybody standing. I commend the Deputy Prime Minister for his record and length of service. It is a remarkable achievement to survive both the days of Whitlam and the days of Hawke. It is more remarkable that he has been able to bridge the various gulfs that have emerged within his own ranks and in the Parliament over that time. I know that in his service to the community as Mayor of Randwick in local government, as a member of the Legislative Assembly in New South Wales and subsequently here, both on the front bench in opposition and on the front bench in government, he has rendered, according to his lights, great service to his party and to this nation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one notable thing that I remember from the contributions that he has made, and that is his remarks at the time of the late Frank Stewart's funeral when he commented that every good Catholic boy from the eastern suburbs had three aspirations: to go to mass on Sunday, to go to rugby league on Saturday and to join the Australian Labor Party. I suggest that things have now changed and that, instead of joining the Labor Party, he would probably join the conservative parties. I think that that is probably one of the differences between the period that Frank Stewart and Lionel Bowen entered politics and now, when people enter the political fray. Lionel, I congratulate you on behalf of the National Party of Australia for your very fine record and wish you well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just say, on behalf of all members, that we wish you well. You are held in very high affection by all of us, particularly the younger members with whom I am probably not identified now. You have always been a person we could go to for advice and a person who is loved by all of us, Lionel. Congratulations on a job well done. I think I should now call on the Deputy Prime Minister to say a few words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I just want to say thank you very much, particularly to my boss the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). I have enjoyed very much being Deputy Prime Minister, although earlier in my career I wanted to be Prime Minister; but that is bad luck. I must say that a great contribution has been made by the present incumbent. I thank in particular the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) for his remarks on behalf of the Liberal Party of Australia, and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) for his remarks on behalf of the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been said today and probably the less I say the better the debate will be. I want to say how much I appreciate being part of the Labor philosophy. Despite what the Leader of the National Party of Australia said, the three principles still stand because rerum novarum placed a lot of interest in the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government has decided that the twelfth national census of population and housing will be conducted by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 1991, as required by the Census and Statistics Act 1905. Regulations specifying the topics to be included in the census in accordance with section 8 of the Census and Statistics Act were tabled earlier this week. In order that the Parliament and the general public should be fully informed on the questions to be asked in the census, I shall table, at the conclusion of this statement, an Australian Bureau of Statistics information paper entitled 1991 Census of Population and Housing: Content and Procedures which describes the topics to be included and the procedures for conducting the census. Final wording of questions and definitions and the sequencing of questions will be decided once all testing for the census has been completed.

SPEECH.PARA: The census is the most wide-ranging collection undertaken by the Australian Bureau of Statistics as it involves contact with every household in the nation. It provides a considerable amount of information used extensively for planning, administration, policy development and evaluation. It provides a statistical snapshot of the whole population in terms of number, age, geographical distribution and a range of other characteristics. Users of census statistics include Government agencies at the Federal, State and local level; social service organisations; churches; research institutions; businesses; and private individuals. The vast statistical output from the census is available to everyone in the community through the Australian Bureau of Statistics.

The Government has decided that the 1991 census will cover seven topics about the household and 24 topics about people in the household. Topics included in 1991 represent a reduced content, compared with the 1986 census, with five topics in the 1986 census not considered sufficiently justified on cost-benefit grounds for inclusion in 1991.

Although the ethnic origin topic will not be included in the 1991 census, comprehensive information on the ethnicity of the population will still be available. Questions will be asked on birthplace, birthplace of parents, year of arrival in Australia, citizenship, Aboriginal-Torres Strait Islander origin, language use and religion. The inclusion of additional topics was requested by users, but the topics selected by the Government are considered to represent a reasonable balance between the need for information, the appropriateness of the census as a means of collecting particular kinds of data, the cost of the undertaking and the need to ensure that completing the forms does not impose too great a burden on the public.

The Government recognises that asking questions of householders in order to obtain statistical information involves a degree of intrusiveness and places a workload on the community. The Government has aimed to minimise both load and intrusion but nevertheless recognises and accepts that some degree of each is necessary to support the information required for efficient planning and administration. For most households the completion of census forms requires at the most half an hour every five years.

The population census affects every household in Australia and it is essential that public cooperation and acceptance be obtained in order to achieve the high quality response that has been a feature of recent censuses. For this reason a public awareness campaign will be conducted prior to and during the census. The aim of the campaign will be to maintain high quality response to the census by convincing the public of the usefulness of the statistics obtained and the confidentiality of the information provided. The availability of assistance for those who may, for language or other reasons, experience difficulty in completing the form will also be made known.

The Government places great significance on the census as a means of collecting important and social and economic data which is of primary concern to a wide range of users. It is recognised that to be of maximum utility such data must be both accurate and timely. Consequently the Government has decided that the census will be conducted without sampling and that all forms collected at the 1991 census will be processed fully and without delay so that detailed information will be available to users as soon as possible. A number of organisations and individuals have requested that information on identified persons and households not be destroyed, but be transferred in some form to archives with access after a specified period. The Government rejects this request.

The purpose of the census is to gather statistical information and the legal power of the Statistician to direct people to answer census questions, except one relating to religion, is accompanied by strict measures to ensure the confidentiality of the information provided. The Government believes that it would be inconsistent with that purpose and with that guarantee of confidentiality to retain information on identified persons or households. The decision not to retain information on identified persons and households was reached after arguments for and against their retention had been carefully weighed. A relevant factor was the very real fear that public confidence in the census, and hence the willingness of individuals to provide full and accurate information about themselves, could be undermined. A further consideration was the substantial costs which would be incurred in storing and accessing the records.

Accordingly, as a measure of the importance which the Government places on protecting the privacy of Australians, it has been decided that the past practice of destroying all records of names and addresses of persons and households and of not storing these names and addresses in computer files will be continued. The destruction of records will be carried out in accordance with authorisation under the Archives Act. The Australian Statistics Advisory Council has devoted a considerable amount of time to considering plans for the 1991 census and its conclusions have been of great assistance to the Government in reaching its decisions. I now table the information paper to which I referred earlier. I also present the following paper:
1991 Census of Population and Housing-Ministerial Statement, 4 May 1989
