DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The deliberate attempt of the Government to deceive the Australian people regarding price increases.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter of public importance before the House today is indeed a very important one. It reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The deliberate attempt of the Government to deceive the Australian public regarding price increases.

It follows on from the matter of public importance that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) moved yesterday on the same subject, carefully documenting the extent to which pressure was brought to bear by this Government on the Australian Statistician to lower the consumer price index (CPI) artificially by changing the treatment of housing costs.

It is important to look at this issue against the background of where we are as a country at the present time. We are at the top of the league table in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in terms of wages and inflation outcomes. Even at the sorts of price increases given on the most favourable measure of the Acting Treasurer, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), we are still sitting at around twice the average of our major trading partners. The point is that this Government has never had an anti-inflation strategy, and not once in six and a bit years has it brought inflation under control. Its record on this speaks for itself. It is a record of disinformation, it is a record of cosmetic adjustment and fiddles and it is a record of unjustified claims and of intellectually dishonest argument. It prefers constantly to shift the goalposts rather than address the problem of inflation. It is a record of incessant rhetoric and absolutely no substantive action when it comes to dealing with inflation.

We can take, as a few examples, three recent statements-and I emphasise the word `recent', as there have been literally hundreds over the life of the Government-by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). On 26 July last year, in his press conference on the consumer price index for the June quarter, he said:
The long and short of it is that the Government's policies have dealt and are dealing with inflation.
In his speech to the British-Australian Chamber of Commerce in October, he said, in relation to a wage-tax trade-off:

The prospect of such a trade-off means that Australia has within its reach a level of inflation at the start of the 1990s in the 3 to 4 per cent range, fully in line with that in the rest of the world. That is our clear objective.
At the end of January this year, the Treasurer said:
I remain convinced that Australia has before it the very real prospect of securing a substantial fall in its inflation rate.

None of that bears any relation to what was going on in the economy at that time. Over the last nine months we have seen inflation break away well above the forecast level, and even at the artificially low level that it appears to be at today it is still substantially above that forecast of 4.5 per cent. The Acting Treasurer is obviously being trained in these ways, as in evident in today's statement on the CPI-which again is a very dishonest representation of the facts. In this first paragraph he refers to the fact that today's outcome:
. . . confirms that Australia's underlying rate of inflation is running at a lower level than had been indicated by the previous statistical series.

That is a statement designed to create the impression that inflation is falling, but all he is doing is acknowledging the fact that the CPI has been artificially lowered by that adjustment. Similarly, he talks about how the calculation of the annual rate of inflation is complicated by the statistical change in respect of the treatment of housing prices. He said:
. . . however, on the two bases presented in today's release it is running at approximately the same rate, 6.8 or 6.9 per cent.

He forgets to admit that he left one of the key bases out, the old basis, so that we cannot make a comparison and determine the full extent of the fiddle that has been rorted by bringing in a new housing cost element to the CPI. It is that sort of dishonest and inflationary rhetoric that characterises this Government's performance on inflation-no substantive action. The electorate will not be fooled by this. Every time people go to the supermarket, pay their mortgage or do their own assessments of their cost of living, irrespective of what this Government says, and irrespective of the extent to which this Government tries to deceive them about price increases, they have a very clear idea of what is going on. We have heard about the rate of inflation in this country. We heard today an admission by the Acting Treasurer that the Government is quite prepared to carry on cheating the average pensioner and all those who have entered contracts based on the CPI by tying contractual arrangements to the lowest outcome rather than anything like a realistic inflation number.

I think it is instructive to go back over the life of this Government, consider its record on inflation, and focus on some of its so-called anti-inflationary strategies so as to explode the myth it perpetrates. I guess there have been three major fiddles over the life of the Government. There was the Medicare fiddle, then there was the cut in the beer excise in last year's Budget, explicitly said to be the purpose of artificially lowering the CPI by 0.5 per cent, and now this year we have the adjustment with mortgage costs and housing price increases being put into the CPI. The facts are that as a result of that sort of process, even on a most favourable, fudged basis, inflation is still stuck at around 7 per cent and has been since the December quarter of 1987. It should not be forgotten that this has happened over a period in which the Government claims it has had substantial wage restraint.

On a more appropriate basis, if we were to exclude the effect of some of those favourable fiddles, I believe the current inflation rate probably would be in excess of 8 per cent. We would have to add back about 0.7 or 0.8 per cent for the housing cost adjustment and add back the 0.5 per cent for the indirect beer excise. So we are looking at an inflation rate well in excess of 8 per cent. Contrary to the Acting Treasurer's suggestions, the inflation rate is accelerating away and not falling. The impression that is constantly being created by this Government is that inflation is on the way down. The three quotes I identified from the Treasurer are consistent with that sort of line, but we know that not to be the case. If we look closely at the Acting Treasurer's press release today in relation to the March quarter CPI, we see that he draws attention to a number of factors which will in fact, if we look at them objectively, serve only to further increase the CPI in the months to come. In this sense he is damned entirely by his own mouth, for he admits explicitly or implicitly that the inflation rate in the next several quarters will be higher because of the price effects of recent devaluations; because of a seasonal pick-up in clothing costs, which were seasonally low and in fact made a negative contribution to the CPI this quarter; the effects of the floods, such as the effect they will have on fruit and vegetable prices in the next couple of quarters; increases in State government taxes and charges; and, of course, because of the prospective increases in wages and the continuing stronger than anticipated domestic demand. They are the ones referred to in his press release, and they do not mention the effect of abattoir strikes on meat prices, rising world inflation, possible further increases in petrol prices and so on. Inflation is not under control, it is nowhere near the artificially low level of 7 per cent that has been suggested, and it is accelerating away and will continue to accelerate away this year.

The key point is that this Government has never had an anti-inflationary strategy. In every single year since 1984-85 it has overshot its Budget forecast, and in some cases quite significantly. It has never been anywhere near the mark. Indeed, an objective observer would say that it comes out with an inflation forecast which it knows to be low and then just lets the passage of time see it overshot, and repeats the process next year. Government members, of course, talk about their claimed success in bringing down inflation in 1983, 1984 and 1985. They would pin a lot of that on the so-called magic document with which they came into government, the accord. We all know that any objective assessment of the fall in inflation over that period was principally due to flat domestic and world activity, and that it was largely due to the Fraser Government's wage freeze that broke the inflationary expectations of that time, and there were some favourable effects of an appreciating currency beyond the end of 1983. The fact is that despite what they said, they did not have any policy to control inflation through that period.

It is instructive to recall the statement that was made at the time of the accord which was repeated at the National Economic Summit. The Government said that its prices and incomes policy `offers by far the best prospect of enabling Australia to experience prolonged higher rates of economic and employment growth and accompanying growth in living standards without incurring the circumscribing penalty of higher inflation'. It claimed that with inflation control being achieved in this way, budgetary and monetary policies may be reasonably set to promote economic and employment growth, thus enabling unemployment to be reduced and living standards to rise. Nothing could be further from the truth. The accord did nothing of the sort. It did not control inflation.

I have given the House the reasons why inflation fell in 1983, 1984 and in early 1985. It had nothing to do with the accord. The Government's stimulatory fiscal and wages policy ultimately came through and had a substantial stimulatory effect on inflation, which blew out in the course of 1985 and into 1986. We know what happened. There were major exchange rate crises in 1985 and in 1986 as a direct consequence of the fact that it lost control of this economy and its inflationary forces. It abandoned money targets and monetary and policy discipline. The accord document was an absolute failure at that point. Inflation accelerated, as I said, throughout 1985 and into early 1986. It only started to slow in late 1986 and early 1987 as there was a substantial tightening of policy in late 1985 and into early 1986. It was forced on the Government by the exchange rate collapse and, in particular, through monetary policy which precipitated, as we will recall, a recession in the latter part of 1985 which carried into 1986.

The Government did not learn anything from the experience, because it did the same thing again in 1987. It stimulated the economy, this time, essentially, for political reasons. It eased monetary policy, overheated the economy and, of course, blew us out of the water. Since that time we have seen no new anti-inflationary strategy brought down. Last year's Budget referred to the fact that inflation was the No. 1 economic disease in this country. When we looked for the things that would bring it under control, we saw, firstly, its CPI fiddle by reducing beer excise by 0.5 per cent, and, secondly, it had this wage-tax deal, this tax trade-off, that was going to do the job. We now know what that was. There was no wage-tax trade-off. Look at what we have got. The possibility that the Treasurer argued for-zero wage increase in return for a $20 tax cut at the time of the Budget last year when his forecasts were on track-ended up being something like $50 to $70 a week across the board, unrelated to productivity, in terms of a wage increase, as well as the $20 tax cut.

In those terms, that wage-tax deal was really the surrender terms of economic management in this country for the second time in six years. The first surrender terms were summarised in the Treasurer's press release in late January 1985 when he abandoned money targets. The second set of surrender terms is this wage-tax deal. It has nothing to do with controlling inflation and promises to stimulate inflation significantly from here on. So the Government has never tried to deal with the inflation problem. Generally, it has tried to ignore it. The best example of how much it can ignore a problem of such significance is shown in the 12 April statement just a few months after the Treasurer said that inflation was the number one economic disease in this country. Inflation gets one line in the document. It states:
And with demand running too strongly inflation has not fallen as we had hoped.

Inflation is running at about 8 per cent against a Budget forecast of 4.5 per cent. It has not fallen as the Treasurer had hoped. There is absolutely no suggestion of an alternative anti-inflationary strategy. The bottom line is that this Government is quite happy to rip off the average Australian. It cynically gives tax cuts and promises wage increases, yet it knows that in doing that it is giving back only part of what it has taken. It knows that in time any temporary relief from those tax cuts and wage increases will be clawed back through higher interest rates, bracket creep and higher inflation. It is prepared to sit in this House and go around this country blatantly cheating the average Australian, many of whom live in very difficult economic circumstances, people such as pensioners and people who have a host of contractual commitments linked in one way or another to the CPI. In terms of my question today, those who bought government indexed securities have been conned by this sort of behaviour. It goes on as though there is no problem with any of that.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) has given an impassioned speech which, as an economist, he should be absolutely ashamed of. I presume that it was impassioned because the content was so vacuous. Let us examine more reasonably what he had to say. For a start, this was the second matter of public importance on the consumer price index (CPI). Therefore, it was redundant. The issue was debated yesterday. The new basis for calculating mortgage interest rates in the CPI was outlined then, and that should have been quite enough to explain it to Opposition members, who obviously are not careful in understanding what is going on; I would even say that they are not particularly intelligent in understanding what is going on. It should have laid to rest any remaining doubts about the nature of the improved method of calculating the CPI which is now being used. Most of the comments by the honourable member for Wentworth were irrelevant to the allegations he made in the motion. Most of them were historic and were not to do with the subject matter about which he was supposed to be talking.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members are trying to create a sense of distortion which does not exist. Perhaps they think that by raising the issue a second time their views will be reinforced in the public's mind. But just because a charge is repeated a couple of times does not mean that it is correct. It simply means that the Opposition has some reason for wanting to spread around their falsehoods. It is not difficult to guess their motives, of course. They want to inflame a sense of economic crisis so as to hide the good news-and the good news is that today the inflation rate has come down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was this written in Keating's office?
—Order! The honourable member for Flinders and the honourable member for Mayo are not assisting the debate, and I ask that they cease interjecting.

—Those honourable members do not like the truth, either, Mr Deputy Speaker. Using the debt profile method for calculating the impact of mortgage interest changes on the inflation rate, the inflation rate fell from 9.4 per cent in the March quarter of 1987 to 6.9 per cent in the March quarter of 1989. There has been a fall of 2.5 percentage points in two years. The present inflation rate is 6.9 per cent-not 8 per cent as the honourable member for Wentworth says. This fall has occurred partly because of the appreciation of the Australian dollar. It is good to see that the impact of that appreciation is now feeding through to prices. The prices of imported goods increased by 0.7 per cent in the March quarter-less than half the overall increase in the CPI. The fall has also occurred because of the effect of petrol discounting and the seasonal fall in volume costs, which normally happens in the March quarter.

SPEECH.PARA: The inflation rate is certainly higher than the Government would like, but it is higher because the economy is growing strongly, because we have substantially faster economic activity-faster than the Opposition appears to want-and because we have a faster growth of employment. The effect of that increase in national income, economic activity and employment is that average incomes are rising-and that is good news. Of course, that has allowed the increases in after tax incomes that were announced in the April statement. A wage-tax trade-off was announced in the April statement, and that allows for a modest increase in before tax wages and a significant reduction in taxation, so that after tax wages will rise substantially.

The inflation rate is not above that which exists in all the other Western countries, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Wentworth, suggested. In fact, I am surprised by his lack of information. He is an economist, and I would have expected that even a cursory reading of the Australian Financial Review, let alone the other newspapers which I would hope he would be consulting, would have indicated to him that the inflation rate in a number of Western countries is now higher than that in Australia. So, at present three major economic improvements are occurring: we have an increase in after tax income, an increase in employment, and a reduction of the inflation rate. That is the good news which the Opposition is trying to hide.

Let us look again at the changes to the CPI, on which changes the Opposition has based its false claim. Mortgage interest changes were first included in the CPI in December 1986. Therefore, that is a quite recent development. It is an improvement in the index, but it was clear that, technically, it was going to be quite difficult to include mortgage interest rates for the first time. Two methods were considered at that time. The first, the simple revaluation method, operates as though all home buyers had increased the size of their mortgage each quarter in line with increases in average housing prices. Clearly, that is a nonsense, because people do not go out and increase their mortgage every quarter to keep in line with other changes in housing prices.

The problem is that the assessment of the mortgage increases by the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) must reflect both interest rate changes and changes in the quantity of debt on which that interest is paid. The alternative method, the debt profile method, which the Australian Bureau of Statistics has always preferred, goes further than the simple revaluation method, by recognising that mortgage interest changes paid by households depend on the age of the mortgages. That is obviously a more realistic assumption. The debt profile method therefore answers the question about the changeover time in interest payments required to finance a stock of housing identical in terms of the age of the mortgage relative to that being financed in the base period. The debt profile method involves calculating debt price indexes for mortgages entered into in each of the previous eight years and a single price index for mortgage interest rates. It is therefore a much more realistic method of calculating the impact of interest changes. This method is much closer to the reality of what actually happens, as well as being suitable for the requirements of a statistical index. In its information paper on the treatment of mortgage interest changes, the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicated:
The ABS considered the debt profile method was conceptually superior but that the simple revaluation method was easier to understand and to explain.

It is difficult enough to explain either of the methods, I must say, but the ABS chose the simpler of the two. That is why the simple revaluation method was first introduced; it was easier for the community to understand.

The matter of public importance seems to be based on a completely false assumption. It suggests that the Government has been trying to deceive the community about the CPI. However, the Government makes quite clear that it is using the underlying rate of inflation for the quarter. In the statement which was made by the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins), and which was repeated in the House, he made quite clear that he accepts that the underlying rate of inflation is 1.6 per cent-not one per cent as the revised index would show. This underlying rate compares prices over the past couple of years, using the debt profile method for evaluating the effect of mortgage interest changes. The government is not using the quarterly CPI, including the change of method, which gives a price increase for the quarter of one per cent.

It appears that the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) put out his statement about the CPI on the assumption that the Government would attempt to mislead, but it has not done so. It is quite impossible for the previous CPI to be revised, so the effect of the change in method has to occur in one quarter, and that is why we have a one per cent increase in the index itself. The underlying rate, the rate which compares price changes on the same basis, quarter by quarter, indicates, as I said, a fall of 2.5 per cent in the annual inflation rate during the past two years, and a small 0.1 per cent fall during the last quarter. That underlying inflation rate is 1.6 per cent. The Opposition appears to have been expecting a misleading emphasis from the Government in this matter of public importance-but that has not occurred.

Experience with the two methods has shown that, for most of the period since the mortgage interest rates were introduced into the calculation, the CPI varied little, whichever method was used. However, in the last couple of quarters a significant diversion began to emerge. The Australian Statistician, Mr Castles, has said that the change had been made because of the inadequacies of the simple revaluation method. He said that it was simplistic, gave a distorted impression of what was happening to mortgage interest rates and therefore had to be abandoned. Mr Castles said:
The Bureau's decision has been taken solely on the basis of statistical considerations, and in the interests of providing the best possible CPI.

Mr Castles said that the Bureau was aware of a serious problem when a 0.4 percentage point divergence in the CPI opened in December between the use of the relatively unsophisticated, simple revaluation approach and the more conceptually sound debt profile method. The debt profile method has the effect of reducing volatility in the series. Both methods lead to the same result, over time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the section written by John Dawkins, is it?

—Fortunately, I wrote this whole thing myself. It appears to me that the honourable member for Mayo does not understand what is going on. However, I will refrain from responding to these childish, schoolboy interjections. The honourable member for Mayo is well known in this House as a pretentious public schoolboy. The debt profile method involves much smaller variations in the consumer price index, slower increases and slower reductions. However, both methods lead to the same result over time. The only debate is about the method and timing of the introduction of the change. The change is being made now because of demonstrated defects in the simple revaluation method. Surely, it is important to get the greatest accuracy possible. The debt profile method is a more accurate method; it presents a true picture of the impact of mortgage interest changes on prices.

SPEECH.PARA: To charge the Government with attempting to mislead is to attack the integrity of the Statistician. The Opposition is saying, in effect, that the Statistician would change the index just to please the Government. I know Ian Castles, the Statistician, well. I know that he would not do that. He is clearly a man of integrity. As well as being a man of integrity, he is a highly professional statistician. His professional position depends on acting in a rigorous, sound way. He has to use methods that other professional statisticians accept as being the best available. His change has been checked with the tripartite Australian Statistics Advisory Council. It has been checked with the Confederation of Australian Industry, with the Australian Council of Trade Unions and with other departments. All people consulted have agreed that the change is justified and statistically sound. Commentators and the business community accept that the change is appropriate.

The honourable member for Wentworth is a professional economist. In his heart of hearts he must know that this change is entirely and completely justified because of the greater accuracy it will give to the CPI. I was rather shocked with the shallowness and hollow rhetoric of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Wentworth. His arguments really do not stand up to examination. He is simply attempting to inflame an artificial dispute. That is not the essence of sound or reasonable debate. He should be concentrating on policy issues which are really debatable rather than concentrating on an esoteric issue with no foundation.

The honourable member for Wentworth claimed that this change would lead to lower indexation of pensions. Of course, the reverse is actually true. Pensioners will be better off than they otherwise would have been because the pension increase for the September and December quarters will be higher than it otherwise would have been. The indexation for the September-December six-month period is 4 per cent. If the debt profile method had been in place at that time, the indexation increase would have been 3.4 per cent. So, pensioners will benefit from this change, rather than the reverse. Of course, later changes will be lower, but that lower increase will be on a higher base. Eventually, there will be no difference in the impact of the two forms of CPI change over time.

The Opposition has a vested interest in bad economic news. It appears to want to give the impression that the inflation rate is higher than it really is. It does not seem to care that that comes from wrongly calculated figures. This motion, therefore, amounts to another of its attempts at economic sabotage. It thinks that it will be easier to get into government if the news is bad and it tries to create that bad news. The Statistician has, in fact, acted professionally. The CPI is now more fairly based, more accurate and more reliable. Let us welcome this structural improvement in the index and the improvements in inflation which it indicates.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl Mr G.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was interested to hear the previous speaker, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore).
—You are the only one who was.

—I am always interested in listening to the speeches of the Acting Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). What we have here today is the latest great fiddle of this Hawke-Keating Government-a desperate last ditch stand of a failed government, a government that is out of touch, out of control and out of order. The Treasurer forecast that in 1988-89 we would have a 4.5 per cent inflation rate. Some forecast! It is just as well that he does not give any tips for the races, because if we followed them we would all be down the drain, just as the Government has gone down the drain by following the Treasurer's crystal ball and just as the Australian economy has gone completely down the drain by following the Treasurer's mental meanderings through the field of prophecy. But we have to forget the fantasy.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all right for the Treasurer to tip toe through the tulips, but the people of Australia have to face the facts-and the facts are very compelling. Fact No. 1: the Treasurer said that the inflation rate in 1988-89 would be 4.5 per cent. Fact No. 2: the December quarter rate was 2.1 per cent, just in one quarter. Fact No. 3: that gave an annual inflation rate of 7.7 per cent. Fact No. 4: the Treasurer then decided to change the rules. He did not like the answers, so he had to change the rules. If one does not like the results, one can just move ahead and cook the books. We know what he is like and now-it has taken some time-all Australia knows what he is like. Come the next election, the people will demonstrate that knowledge because they know that it is not the Keating method; it is the cheating method. Fact No. 5: that is why the inflation rate announced today has the March quarter at only 1.6 per cent with an annual rate of 6.6 per cent. This still does not compare too well with the 4.5 per cent.

Fact No. 6: because the Australian Bureau of Statistics was forced by political pressure to change the rules, no figure has been provided on the previous basis of calculation. Why? Because the Government wants to hide the truth. It does not want any comparisons. The reality is that on a comparative basis, on the best estimates, the real rate is between 7.4 per cent and 7.7 per cent per annum. And that does not compare too well with the 4.5 per cent either. Fact No. 7: even based on the Statistician's analytical series, inflation is stuck at nearly 7 per cent for the fourth quarter in a row. Where does that leave Mr 4.5 per cent? He is up the creek without a paddle, and Australia is sinking.

Fact No. 8: the Acting Treasurer not only is confused, as usual, but also appears to have set out to confuse the Australian people. He has succeeded. Just look at his press release issued today. In the first paragraph he says:
Today's March Quarter Consumer Price Index figure of 1.6 per cent is at the lower end of market expectations . . .
He then says:
The published quarterly CPI increase of 1.0 per cent reflects the one-off step down . . .
Is it 1.6 per cent or one per cent? The Acting Treasurer does not even know himself. I quote from what he said on the World Today program:
First of all, we are not saying that the one per cent is the correct figure.
We know that. All of Australia knows that. At last the Acting Treasurer knows it, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!
—The honourable member may laugh. The Acting Treasurer continued:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are saying the correct figure is 1.6 per cent on the basis of the new method of calculation.

In one way I am fairly similar to the Treasurer. I am not an economist either, but I know one thing-and that is what Disraeli said: `There are lies, damn lies and statistics'. That is the trouble with this Government. It is so consumed by statistics that it is out of touch with the people, the economy and reality. Honourable members opposite are so busy sliding up and down their J-curves and getting shiny backsides that they have forgotten why they are here. We are here for one reason-for the people of Australia. The `p' in politics stands for people. This Hawke-Keating Government has forgotten that, if it ever knew it.

How will this change affect the people of Australia? Once again, those in the front line are those least able to suffer or to take the blow-the pensioners and the unemployed of this country. The artificial cut in the consumer price index (CPI) will reflect directly on the pensioners and the unemployed. The Government says that it is a oncer-a one-off for this quarter. That would be bad enough, but it is not true. The fact is that the Government's move has reduced the base rate not for one quarter, not for one year, but forever. There has been a cut in the spending power of the people of Australia, of those on pensions and the unemployed, and those people will start hurting from October. There is a very real cut in spending power.

The cuts could cost the 770,992 single age pensioners up to $12.3m in just one quarter. The cuts could cost the 557,822 married pensioners up to $14.5 in just one quarter. There are total cuts for age pensioners of up to $26.8m for one quarter. Veterans and war widows are always in the front line too with this Government. Up to $4m a quarter or $16m a year has been cut from their benefits. With the age pensioners the total possible cuts for the year amount to $107.2m. At the end of June 1989 there were 389,000 invalid pensioners. Their benefits are going to be cut by up to $7m in one quarter-$28m in one year. At the end of March there were 550,000 unemployed people in this country. They are going to be slugged up to $5.5m in one quarter, up to $22m in a year. We have a total of up to $173.2m being cut from the poorer people of this country just by this one despicable, absolutely disgraceful playing with the figures-cooking the books so that expenditure can be cut back.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is disgraceful to mislead people in that way.
—I am not misleading people. This is the fact. It is the reality. We have nearly $175m a year for ever more being--
—That is absolute nonsense.

—That is nonsense! If the base is reduced, that reduction stays for ever more. In the next quarter people will be short that much again; in the next quarter they will be short that much again; and so on. This is what the Government has done. This is the despicable dishonesty of this Government. Once again it has attacked those who are least able to afford it, the old age pensioners, the veteran pensioners--
—This is a disgraceful speech.

—The unemployed, the invalid pensioners. The honourable member can say it is a disgraceful speech but that is camouflage. The Government is trying to hide it. What has happened is that this Government-and I will repeat it-is going to take from single age pensioners up to $12.3m a quarter. Their pensions are indexed to the CPI. Surely the honourable member for Fraser can understand that. Even an economist could understand that. If one reduces the increase in the CPI, one reduces the amount of income for pensioners. For most of these people the pension is their sole income. Their spending power is being cut by the amount the increase in the CPI is reduced. That means that their pensions or unemployment benefits do not go up. The honourable member must be able to understand that.

SPEECH.PARA: What will the position be for these people? For veterans and war widows there is a cut of up to $4m a quarter or $16m a year. We come back to the total thrust of the deception of this Government, the way it is cheating the people of this country who are least able to afford it. I repeat: nearly $175m a year will be removed from the income of the age pensioners, the veterans, the war widows and the unemployed of this country for ever more by this Government that says it is the friend of the poor. What a joke! It is the friend of multimillionaires. We all know that and we know the Government is totally out of touch with reality. It does not know what is going on and it does not know that the `p' in politics stands for people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most appropriate that the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) bases the matter of public importance on the concept of dishonesty. That is what he gave the House this afternoon-one great dose of dishonesty. The reality is that this matter of public importance was written and submitted prior to the Government's announcement of its reaction to the consumer price index (CPI) increase. It is predicated on the assumption that the Government was going to claim that the rate of increase for the quarter was one per cent when the reality was that the Government accepted, due to change in calculation method, that the appropriate figure was 1.6 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Having been caught out on this assumption, which was proven to be terribly wrong, what we had was a pathetic attempt by the honourable member for Wentworth to simply rehash the matter of public importance from yesterday. Unfortunately the arguments have gone terribly stale over the last 24 hours. The matter of public importance is supposedly based on three factors concerning the Government's dishonesty in relation to the calculation of the CPI. The honourable member for Wentworth mentioned three. They included the most recent one concerning the cost of new housing and how it is calculated. The second argument he put forward was the change in the Budget in relation to beer excise. The third was the change in relation to the Medicare levy.

Let us deal with each of those three factors in turn. As the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) quite adequately pointed out, this furphy floating around about changing the housing cost component is nothing but a furphy. The Australian Statistician himself, Mr Castles, has made it quite clear that the method which is now being adopted, that is, the debt profile method, is vastly superior and is a far more accurate reflection of the true cost of housing than the method that was in place, the simple revaluation method. The revaluation method was introduced by the Statistician in December 1986. At the time, Mr Castles quite readily admits, the method now in place, the debt profile method, was the superior method. But due to the fact that the simple revaluation method was a simpler concept to explain to the public and that an analysis done over the preceding nine years showed that there had been no great difference in the end result when applying either method, he decided to adopt the course he did.

Of course, as events turned out, that proved to be a mistake in that we have had over recent years unprecedented demand in relation to housing. We have had a very buoyant housing sector with record new building starts. We have had difficulties in the Sydney region in terms of land supply and the added costs being imposed through local government and State government practices. There is also the high level of interest rates operating at this time. A combination of those factors meant that new housing prices and the cost of new mortgages are significantly higher than one already in place.

That was giving a false picture in terms of the total housing cost across the Australian community because we were only looking at new housing purchases. Clearly the debt profile method being now adopted by the Statistician is a superior method. There is no suggestion that this is some bodgie method and not an accurate calculation. If any honourable member of the Opposition is suggesting that and saying that the Statistician is a liar in claiming that the method is superior and that he was not leaned on by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to change the method, he should go outside the safety of this House and make that statement publicly so that the Statistician can challenge its veracity through the courts. Really, what it boils down to is that the Opposition is calling the Statistician a liar. There is no ducking from that particular point.

The matter simply flows on from a series of attacks the Opposition has made on high-ranking statutory office holders in this country. We all remember the attacks on the Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, in relation to his stand against corporate tax evasion and on the Statistician in relation to householders' surveys conducted last year and this year. It is simply a campaign to try to kill the messenger because the Opposition does not like the message it is being given. That is all it boils down to.

The second argument is that somehow reducing the excise on beer is really some sort of fiddle in relation to the calculation of the inflation rate. It may surprise the honourable member for Wentworth because I doubt whether he ever buys a beer. I would be surprised if anything but the finest cabernet sauvignon or the dearest bottle of French champagne ever passes his lips. If the honourable gentleman actually goes out into the real world, gets out of his red sports car and goes to the bottle shop in his local hotel, he will find-surprise, surprise!-that the cost of beer actually has fallen. He might also find-again, surprise, surprise!-that average Australians do not mind buying a beer. In fact, beer is an important component of expenditure in a lot of households. To say that a reduction in the price of beer in some way is a false indication of the level of inflation and should not be taken into account is ridiculous. It is an absolute furphy. So much for that argument.

The third argument concerns the Medicare levy. One would think the Opposition would give up beating a dead horse. We are talking about something that occurred five or six years ago and has been widely accepted by the Australian community and by economists in the business sector. No-one is now seriously arguing-if anyone ever did seriously argue-that the decision to discount the introduction of the Medicare levy was not a legitimate calculation in determining Australia's inflation rate. We have these three hollow, weak arguments put forward by the honourable member for Wentworth who is suggesting that there has been dishonesty in calculating Australia's inflation rate. He then went on to point out what is self-evident-that is, that the Government would like inflation to be lower than it is. Of course we would like that. The reality is that we have in place the policy framework which will achieve that end. Unlike when the honourable member was the adviser to the then Treasurer and present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), Australia does not have double digit inflation at the moment.

We have now the famous troika trying to get control back on the treasury bench-the former Treasurer and now Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Wentworth, who was his adviser, and the former head of the Treasury, Senator Stone. Those three famous Australians who gave us double digit inflation are back for a second go, saying, `We can do it better'. They still do not have the fundamentals in place or any wages policy. They decry the accord, saying, `The accord has led to an increase in wages; isn't this a terrible thing?'. That is not a terrible thing. Wages should increase and through the accord we have had the sacrifice which the Australian community has needed to make in recent years in order to spread successfully and evenly the burden of economic change. As a result of the accord there have been increases in wages, especially to those most in need. There has been a large increase in the social wage and government assistance to those most in need, but at the same time in terms of business the accord has led Australia to have a competitive wage situation. That has resulted directly in 1.3 million more Australians now being in employment than was the case when the honourable member for Wentworth had something to do with the way Australia was managed.

The Opposition has no alternative. It has no policy framework in place for dealing with inflation. If it has any policy at all it is simply to throw Australia into recession, to throw hundreds of thousands of people out of work. It tries to destroy union power and at the end claims that this may lead to decreased inflation. The present Opposition had its chance in put its policies in place. It attempted to do that. It had huge levels of unemployment. Business confidence was at an all time low while bankruptcies were at an all time high. We had double digit inflation. It simply did not work. The Opposition talks about our learning nothing over recent years, but over the last decade it has gone nowhere. It has gone backwards. That is the reality of the situation. The Government has in place a suitable inflation policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

DEBATE.TITLE: CERTIFICATION OF PETITIONS NOT IN ENGLISH

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, the following amendment to the standing orders be adopted with effect from 4 May 1989: Standing order 117 be omitted and the following standing order substituted:
To be in English or accompanied by translation

117. Every petition shall be in the English language or be accompanied by a translation certified to be correct. A person certifying a translation to be correct shall affix his or her name and address to the translation.

This motion arises out of a proposal of the Standing Committee on Procedure to amend Standing Orders. The Committee examined the existing standing order which requires that any petition not in English be accompanied by its translation, which the member lodging the translation must certify to be correct. That is all right in some ways except that the linguistic ability of honourable members on both sides of the chamber has not been noted as being particularly high in English, let alone in some of the languages they would be obliged to present these petitions in. It must be doubted as to whether or not the honourable members are not in some obscure way creating a problem of privilege by the sorts of petitions that they put in.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FEDERAL POLICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
TALKER.ROLE: Attorney-General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill provides an additional weapon against potential corruption in the Australian Federal Police, increases the functions of the Australian Federal Police and improves the administration of the Australian Federal Police (AFP) in a number of significant respects. The Bill proposes the inclusion of a new part Va in the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 which provides for existing and former members of the AFP to lose certain superannuation rights and benefits if convicted of an offence involving corruption and sentenced to life imprisonment or a term of imprisonment longer than 12 months or, if a member is found guilty of a relevant disciplinary offence and dismissed from the AFP, as a penalty for that offence.

The amendments provide that all contributions payable by the Commonwealth under a superannuation scheme in relation to a relevant member or former member of the AFP shall cease, or cease to be payable, when the appropriate court makes a superannuation order. In such cases, the Commonwealth is not liable to pay any employer contributions or benefit under the scheme in respect of that person. The amendments entitle a member or former member of the AFP to payment only of a sum equal to the employee contributions plus the accrued interest on those contributions. Similar provisions apply where a member is found guilty of a relevant disciplinary offence and dismissed from the AFP for that offence.

The Australian Federal Police (Discipline) Regulations do not apply to the Commissioner or the deputy commissioners. Amendments to section 17 will enable the Governor-General to determine terms and conditions about superannuation in relation to the Commissioner or deputy commissioners having a comparable effect to proposed subsection 49 (2) and applying where that person's appointment is terminated because of misbehaviour involving corruption, an abuse of office, or the perversion of the course of justice, or an attempt to pervert the course of justice. The loss of superannuation rights and benefits are penalties for dishonest service and breach of obligation to the Crown. They are not and should not be seen as penalties for committing certain criminal offences. Part Va is not retrospective in operation. Division 2 only applies to existing or former members of the AFP convicted after the commencing day for part Va while division 3 will only apply to members found guilty of relevant disciplinary offences and dismissed from the AFP as a penalty for that offence after the commencement day.

This Government is adamant that it will not fund superannuation benefits of any kind for corrupt members of the AFP. This should be a major financial disincentive to any member of the AFP or to any person who may attempt to corrupt any member of that police force. Whilst this Bill applies only to existing and former members of the AFP, it is this Government's intention to introduce similar legislation in the Budget sittings of the Parliament which applies to officers of the Australian Public Service, other government employees and persons holding statutory offices.

This Bill also provides for the repeal of the cumbersome redeployment and retirement provisions currently in the Australian Federal Police Act and the inclusion of streamlined provisions. The proposed redeployment and retirement provisions will enhance the efficient administration of the AFP to the mutual benefit of the community and members of the AFP alike.

This Bill also gives effect to the Government's decision, in light of the recommendations of the Parliamentary Joint Committee, that a national witness protection program be established. It is to be administered by the AFP on a cost recovery basis. Section 8 of the AFP Act is being amended to enable the Commissioner to enter into arrangements with a Commissioner of a State or Territory police force, the Chairman of the National Crime Authority, and a prescribed authority of the Commonwealth, State or Territory-other than the Australian Capital Territory (ACT)-to facilitate the provision of appropriate services. The AFP Act as currently drafted allows the AFP to provide protection for witnesses in relation to Commonwealth and ACT offences.

The national witness protection program will not be fully operational until a substantial number of Commonwealth, State and Territory laws are amended to facilitate the effective operation of the program. It is an important and necessary tool in the fight against organised crime in Australia, and the Government is determined to ensure its early implementation.

This Bill also contains amendments to the AFP of a minor policy nature relating to the appointment of fixed-term senior executive officers, superannuation for fixed-term senior executive officers, prescribing fees for certain police services, the making of regulations for the advancement or accelerated advancement of a member within a rank and for arrangements between the Minister and the Administrator of an External Territory for the provision of police services in relation to that Territory.
I present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Horticultural Legislation Amendment Bill amends the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987, the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Act 1987, the Horticultural Levy Collection Act 1987 and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation Act 1987. The purpose of the Bill is to provide additional charge and levy collection arrangements under which horticultural industries are able to participate in the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation through product levies and export charges.

Two problems have arisen with the current arrangements. Firstly, some industries, such as the nursery industry, have confirmed their willingness to participate in these corporations. However, their proposed levy and charge collection arrangements cannot be accommodated under existing legislation. Secondly, more cost-effective collection arrangements have been identified for some industries already participating under the corporations but again these cannot be implemented under existing legislation. At present, in order for the better securing of levies and charges on horticultural products, amounts are paid to the Commonwealth on behalf of the producer or owner of prescribed horticultural products by the first purchaser, selling agent or exporting agent as the case may be. This arrangement is satisfactory where there are a relatively few first purchasers and agents. However, this structure is not the case for some horticultural products and alternative cost-effective collection arrangements have been developed in consultation with industry.

Under these proposed arrangements, amounts on account of levy and charge will become payable at the point of purchase of prescribed goods and services used in the production of horticultural products prescribed under the amendments. The point of collection will be moved forward in the production and marketing chain to a point before the product being levied has been actually produced. The sellers of these goods and services will be obliged to pay the amounts on account of levy and charge to the Commonwealth, but only after they have in turn received payments of the amounts from the purchaser. If, however, the purchaser does not intend to produce leviable or chargeable horticultural products with the goods or services purchased, it will be possible for them to seek an exemption from the requirement to make payment. Refunds of amounts paid will also be possible under certain conditions.

The nursery industry has advised that it wishes to participate in both the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Research and Development Corporation. Its proposed collection arrangements will be based on the purchase by industry members of containers such as plastic pots used in the production of potted plants, which will be prescribed as the leviable or chargeable horticultural product. The blueberry industry has confirmed that it wishes to participate in the Australian Horticultural Corporation only and has suggested a similar collection arrangement involving the purchase by blueberry growers of cartons in which fruit is packed for sale. The operative rates of levy and charge applicable to nursery products and blueberries and other administrative matters regarding the manner of payment will be set down in regulations.

I am particularly pleased to see that these industries have decided to join these corporations, which were established principally to assist horticultural industries to develop their potential in export markets. Exports are fundamental to the further development of the horticultural industries. These industries will come under increasing pressure as production rises above the capacity of the domestic market to absorb it, and as competition from imports increases. This competition will occur as a result of such factors as the development of quarantine protocols, and the Government's commitment to the freeing of agriculture and other trade through multilateral trade negotiations. It is therefore imperative that horticultural industries develop a commitment to export, through marketing; through the development of quality produce; and through a commitment to sustain long term production for export.

While the response needs to come largely from industries themselves, the corporations are well placed to act as catalysts in this process. The Government is to contribute $7.1m over five years to assist the corporations in their early operations. The apple and pear and citrus industries have participated in the corporations since their inception and the addition of other industries will assist in the longer term industry funding of them. It is expected that the amount raised under the nursery industry levy and charge will be approximately $750,000 per year, rising to $1m within the first few years. Amounts equal to half of the total raised are expected to be directed to the Australian Horticultural Corporation and half to the Research and Development Corporation. The Commonwealth will match expenditure of industry moneys identified for the latter body dollar for dollar, up to a limit of 0.5 per cent of the average gross value of production of the nursery industry. Amounts raised by the blueberry levy and charge are expected to be approximately $150,000 per year. This will have no financial impact on the Commonwealth as all proceeds will go to the Australian Horticultural Corporation. This body is to be fully funded by amounts by levy and charge, and fee for service.

I now turn to the second main purpose of the Bill, that of providing alternative collection mechanisms for industries already participating in the Corporation. These amendments will provide for the Commonwealth to enter into an agreement with a State or Territory in order to provide for State and Territory authorities to collect horticultural levies on the Commonwealth's behalf. This arrangement will have particular application to the citrus industry, where it will lead to significant reductions in the cost of collecting levies and charges. Levy and charge payers will, under the proposals, be able to make payments to State citrus boards at the same time as they make payments of State levies. This will provide for substantial economies of scale in the administration of levy collections. In areas where there are no State boards or where a State elects not to enter into an agreement with the Commonwealth, the present arrangements whereby payments are made directly to the Commonwealth will continue to apply.

In addition, provisions in the Bill will allow persons having responsibility for levy and charge collections to receive payments from the corporations to offset costs borne by them in the collection process. The corporations will be able to enter into agreements with these persons on payments of costs. It is expected that they will first need to consult with individual industry bodies on the payment of levy collectors for that particular industry levy or charge. Funds for such payments would be expected to be drawn from the relevant industry accounts of the corporations.

Finally, the Bill amends the search warrant provisions of the Horticultural Levy Collection Act and the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Act. These amendments refine the powers of authorised persons in relation to entry of premises and provide for seizure of evidence of the commission of an offence.
I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill is to amend the Horticultural Levy Act 1987 to increase the maximum rate of levy. The Horticultural Levy Act 1987, together with the Horticultural Levy Collection Act 1987, provide for the imposition and collection of a levy on prescribed horticultural products produced and sold or used in Australia. Currently, the Horticultural Levy Act 1987 sets the maximum rate of levy at 2 per cent of the annual average unit gross value in relation to the classes of horticultural products covered by these Acts. The funds raised are to finance the operation of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. These corporations are an essential element in the Government's strategy to enhance the capacity of the horticultural industry to expand exports. They provide the mechanism for this sector to realise its full export potential through coordinated and sustained activity both in horticultural products marketing and in research.

Industry, notably the apple and pear sector, have requested the maximum rate of levy be increased from 2 per cent to 5 per cent with a view to possibly increasing levies to support these corporations' future activities. This Bill reflects industry's wishes in this regard. Operative rates will continue to be set by regulation under the Horticultural Levy Act. Total amounts of levies to be collected will rise over the next few years as the number of participating industries increases, and as the rates themselves rise as determined by the participating industries. Funds raised through increased levy receipts in respect of the Australian Horticultural Corporation will have no financial impact on the Commonwealth. This is apart from the $5.85m to be contributed by the Government over its initial five years of operation. All operating and administrative costs of the Corporation are to be fully funded by levies from industry fees-for-service.

Additional funds raised through the increased levy receipts in respect of the Horticultural Research Development Corporation will be matched by the Commonwealth, on a dollar for dollar basis, up to a limit of 0.5 per cent of the average annual gross value of production of groups of products. The extent of the Commonwealth's contribution to research will thus depend on the number of industries which agree to participate in the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation and the rates, up to the maximum, at which they are prepared to fund Corporation research activities. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Kerin, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

The purpose of the Horticultural Export Charge Amendment Bill is to amend the Horticultural Export Charge Act 1987. The Horticultural Export Charge Act 1987, together with the Horticultural Export Charge Collection Act 1987, provides for the imposition and collection of a charge on the export of prescribed horticultural products. The funds raised are to finance the activities of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation.

This Bill is the companion of the Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill 1989 dealt with earlier. Whereas the purpose of that Bill was to increase the maximum rate of levy on prescribed horticultural products produced and sold or used in Australia, this Bill increases the maximum rate of charge payable on exports of prescribed horticultural products. The maximum rate in both cases is increased from 2 per cent to 5 per cent.

There are no financial implications other than those covered in the second reading Speech for the Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill 1989. I commend the Bill to honourable members and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ROBERT BROWN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989, which is now before the House, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Firstly, clause 3 of the Bill amends section 26 of the Act to complement changes made to the beer provisions of the Excise Tariff Act; and changes set out in Schedules 5 and 7 to this Bill. Schedule 1, operative on and from 1 January 1988 contains the following amendments: a change to reduce the rate of duty on embroidery kits from 25 per cent to 15 per cent as part of the new textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) arrangements; minor technical changes to rules 5 and 6 of the general rules for the interpretation of the harmonised system; and a change to item 42a in schedule 4 to accord with the tariff classifications set out in schedule 3 to the Act.

Schedule 2, operates on and from 1 July 1988, and contains an amendment to remove the 2 per cent revenue duty applying to chemically pure fructose; and amendments to the rates of duty applying to certain wallpaper and similar wall coverings, yarn of jute and certain textile hosepiping and similar textile tubing. These amendments reflect the Government's decisions on the chemicals and plastics industries, the post-1988 TCF arrangements and the 1988 May economic statement. Schedule 3 restores assistance arrangements to local production of certain spray heads. The new rate results from an Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) recommendation on these goods and came into operation on 14 October 1988.

Schedule 4 operates on and from 25 January 1989 and implements the IAC's recommended rate of free for transport containers. Schedule 5 clarifies the Government's policy that topped crude oil for use other than as a refinery feedstock is subject to duty at a rate equivalent to that applying to fuel oil. Topped crude oil used as a feedstock remains duty free. This clarification is necessary following a recent decision by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and operates from 15 February 1989.

Schedule 6, operative on and from 1 March 1989, contains minor adjustments to the assistance arrangements for the textiles, clothing and footwear industries. These have been made following consultation with the industries. They allow concessional entry to certain carpets and floor coverings made by non-powered tufting machines held in the hand; and facilitate the importation of non-certified industrial crafts imported before 1 September 1989. The schedule also reduces the rate of duty applying to industrial overalls of New Zealand origin from 20 per cent to 10 per cent. This latter action is necessary to comply with the Australia New Zealand Closer Economic Relations Trade Agreement. Finally, schedule 7 which operates on and from 1 July 1989, contains amendments to provide a free rate of duty for gaseous hydrocarbons of heading 2711. This amendment arises out of the IAC's report on certain petroleum products and taxation measures; restore the rate of duty of 15 per cent to coated kraft paper and paperboard of subheading 4810.3 in accordance with the Government's decision on the pulp, paper, paper products and printing industries; implement the Government's decision on the tobacco growing and manufacturing industries, announced in November 1988; and provide a new concession for certain imported goods used in the production of excisable goods. This change complements amendments to the Excise Tariff Act.
Financial Impact

Anticipated revenue losses from the changes affecting transport containers are minor: approximately $300,000 in a full year; and approximately $165,000 for the balance of 1988-89. However, this will be more than offset by the substantial reductions in costs to the shipping industry. Savings are estimated to be in the order of $9m for a full year. The measures relating to topped crude oil clarify existing Government policy and as such should not increase or decrease revenue. Without the proposed amendment potential exists for revenue erosion exceeding $14m per annum. The remaining measures in the Bill are expected to have minimal financial impact.
Details of the amendments contained in this Bill have been included in an explanatory memorandum which has been circulated for the information of honourable members. I commend the Bill to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hand, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Today I bring into the House legislation establishing the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). This legislation, the principles of which I first talked about 17 months ago in this place, has undergone the most extensive process of consultation and examination of any piece of legislation in recent times. It fulfils the commitments first given by me in this House on 10 December 1987 and reaffirmed, by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and me, in our statements to the Parliament on 11 April this year. The Government will proceed with ATSIC, which provides for an overdue and radical restructuring of the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio. We will proceed with ATSIC because of the urgent need for change, because of the urgent need to streamline the current administration and, above all, because of the urgent need to give Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people a real say in the decision-making process.

There are three Bills-the ATSIC Bill which I have just presented, the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies Bill, and a Bill to amend the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980. The first two of these replace the Bill which was passed by the House last year but which the Senate set aside for report by a select committee. The changes being made today to the proposals put to the Parliament in that Bill do not affect the essential features of ATSIC. The Government has decided, however, that it would be more convenient to the Parliament and to the public generally, and in particular to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, to present new Bills which can stand on their own rather than to amend the 1988 Bill, which is being withdrawn.

The third Bill amends the Aboriginal Development Commission Act in ways to make the operations of that Commission-the ADC-consistent with the way in which ATSIC will operate. Although the ADC will cease to exist when ATSIC comes into existence the Government considers it desirable to make these changes to address the problems that recent inquiries by the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance have brought to public attention. The ATSIC Bill I have introduced today is further evidence of the Government's willingness to consult on our original proposal. We have listened to the views and suggestions of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and have made the relevant changes. We have accepted the overwhelming majority of recommendations made by the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs and included them in this new Bill. And we have taken on board the comments of the Auditor-General and the Department of Finance and have acted on the very important questions of accountability.

We now have a Bill which has had extensive input from a range of people. It is a piece of legislation which will give effect to Aboriginal and Islander self-management and it will do this through a structure which will be effective and accountable. I will now highlight the main features of the ATSIC proposal, as contained in the original Bill of August last year, and then outline the main changes. The 1988 Bill provided for-
the Commission to replace the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) and the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC);

a system of 60 regional councils, elected by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander residents, which would determine priorities, develop regional plans, and generally represent the interests of the regions;
a Commission of 15, of whom 12 would be elected by regional councillors grouped in zones for this purpose;
programs administered by Commission staff in line with regional priorities, with funding direct to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and individuals;
Aboriginal Hostels Ltd (AHL) and a renamed Institute of Aboriginal Studies to retain their independent existence, but with three Commissioners on their governing bodies;
staff to come under the Public Service Act;
ministerial powers balancing the requirements of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-management with those of accountability to the Parliament;
a new body, the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation (AEDC), providing finance and services on an independent commercial basis for major Aboriginal enterprises.

Thus ATSIC is to combine, in the one organisation, the means for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to have a real say in the management of their own affairs with an administrative structure that eliminates existing overlaps. It will be more responsive to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander wishes and attain appropriate standards of accountability for public funds.
Main Changes Arising from Recent Inquiries

My statement of 11 April this year and the Government's response to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee contain the main elements of the proposed amendments to the legislation before the House today. The first group of these changes deals with issues relating to accountability. We have sought to balance the objective that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should have greater control over matters affecting them, with the principle of ministerial accountability for the correct and efficient use of public funds. The new Bill therefore-

establishes within ATSIC an Office of Evaluation and Audit, to undertake evaluations and internal audits on programs, projects and procedures, and to report at least quarterly to the Commission and the Minister. The head of the Office will have senior rank, and will be appointed by the Minister;
requires ATSIC to observe financial guidelines determined by the Minister;
requires ATSIC to keep the Minister informed about specific projects that are encountering difficulties;
specifies that a corporate plan will be prepared, and the Minister will be consulted about it; and
clarifies the distinction between commercial and non-commercial activities-a problem which has bedevilled the ADC.
The Government's consideration of the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee has also produced a second set of changes, including-
an increase in the number of zones, and hence of elected Commissioners, from 12 to 17. This will achieve a better population balance between zones;

a sliding scale of numbers of Regional Councillors, commencing at 10 for regions with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander populations of under 1,000 and rising progressively to 20 with populations of 10,000 or more;
a separate Bill, as mentioned at the beginning of this speech, for what is now to be called the Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies;

a strengthening of provisions in such areas as eligibility for elected or appointed office, pecuniary interests, requiring full written assessments before substantial expenditures are approved, acting appointments and employment of consultants.
Voting System

One matter which had not been settled at the time of my statement to the Parliament last month was the system of voting for regional councils. I made it clear then that the Government would prefer to have a system which did not involve the establishment of a separate role based on race, and that it would explore certain possibilities with the Australian Electoral Commission. I can now inform the House that it is proposed that the electoral system will have the following features:

Voters fill out a `voter card' which is printed on an envelope. The voter will certify that he or she is an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person, enrolled on the Federal Electoral Roll at an address within the region.

Each polling booth will have at least one Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander Liaison Officer. If the Senior Liaison Officer is of the view that a person is not eligible to vote, he or she must note that fact on the voter-card envelope.

Those people whose eligibility to vote has been challenged will have seven days to produce evidence of their Aboriginality. If they do so their votes will be included in the count. Those people whose votes are not counted will be able to have the matter heard in the Court of Disputed Elections.
Completed ballot papers are sealed inside the voter's `voter card' envelope, and are opened only if the vote is not rejected, and once the count begins.

Postal votes close off six days after the poll. Postal votes will be witnessed by a person on the electoral roll in the normal way. The sealed `voter card' envelope will be endorsed by a second person who is either an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person who is an office-bearer of an Aboriginal Corporation active in the region, or a member of the staff of ATSIC. The endorsement will certify that the person voting is in fact an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander. A false certification of Aboriginality will be an offence under the electoral rules.
The Australian Electoral Commission will satisfy itself that all voters are enrolled at an address which is in the relevant region.
The vote of any person not on the federal electoral roll at an address within the relevant region will be rejected.

The Commission will prepare for each region a statement showing the particulars of all cases where voter cards have been set aside on the grounds that the voter was not an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander person. The statement will be available for inspection by interested parties.

This system will ensure that Aboriginality or Torres Strait Islander status is open to challenge and determination on an open and fair basis, and will avoid the negative factors associated with the establishment and maintenance of a special public roll for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The system outlined will be part of the election rules to be gazetted under part 3 of the Bill, and could be disallowed by the Parliament.
The Preamble

The House will recall that in my statement of 11 April I explained why the Government was not accepting the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee in relation to the preamble to the Bill, and for the transfer of certain functions of the ADC to the proposed Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation. It is clear that concerns that have been expressed about the preamble are not well based. The majority report of the Select Committee confirms this. Note, for example, paragraph 3.7 which states:
. . . a preamble is of no legal force by itself. It is generally treated by the courts as an aid to ascertaining the intent of the Parliament in making a particular piece of legislation.
And later, in paragraph 3.16, the Committee says:
. . . some may be misled into thinking the Preamble has some force in law which it does not.
