In paragraph 3.9 the Committee notes that the preamble does not relate to the content of the Bill, and expresses the belief in paragraph 3.12 that the legal position of a preamble as set out in the Acts Interpretation Act, combined with my second reading speech, would tend to ensure the legal neutrality of the preamble. Such views support the Commonwealth's carefully considered position. I remind the House of what I said about the preamble in my second reading speech last year. I shall repeat it all, because of its importance in interpreting the Government's intentions:
In my statement of 10 December-
that is, of 1987-

I indicated that it would be fitting, particularly in this our bicentenary year, for the legislation establishing the Commission to contain a declaration, in the form of a substantial preamble, which sets down the Australian people's commitment to the recognition and protection of the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and to measures to overcome their disadvantage. In addition, I made it clear that the preamble would contain a significant and historic recognition by the Commonwealth Parliament that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people of Australia were the prior occupiers and original owners of this land. Since making that statement, much has been said and written about the proposal to have the Commonwealth formally recognise what the vast majority of Australians have been prepared to acknowledge for some time as historical fact. There has been considerable discussion amongst Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups, and between them and the Government, about the wording of the preamble. In particular, I wish to inform the House of consultations which have taken place on recital three of the preamble and the role of these consultations in the formulation of recital three.

During the consultations some Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander groups expressed concern about the Government's original formulation of recital three. They feared it could lead to certain Aboriginal and Islander groups being disadvantaged in current litigation. The Government's intention has, by contrast, always been that the language of the preamble would be neutral and have no legal consequences for present or future litigation in relation to land claims. The language was, and is, in no way intended to recognise land rights claimed to exist, to create new rights for land or compensation or to remove or qualify rights under existing law. Nor was it, or is it, intended to restrict any future developments in the law. Accordingly, the Government was prepared to agree to amend the original language of recital three to meet the perception by some groups of a possible negative impact upon current litigation. I emphasise the neutrality of recital three, conscious of the fact that courts can, in certain circumstances, have regard to second reading speeches and other extrinsic material to assist in ascertaining the Parliament's intention with regard to relevant legislation. Recital three, as now written, is intended simply to record the historical fact that up to the present time the Australian courts have not recognised Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander property rights in land except in relation to title granted by Federal, State and Territory governments. When endorsed by the Parliament in the name of the Australian people, the preamble will stand as an historical expression of philosophy and principle. The intention that the preamble has no legal consequences in no way detracts from its importance as a statement of those facts. I am happy to state that the preamble has the support not only of the vast majority of the indigenous groups of this nation but also will, I am confident, enjoy the support of the wider community throughout Australia.

This Parliament has already passed a resolution affirming its commitment to Australia's indigenous peoples. It should therefore not shrink from recognising, in a symbolically significant way through this preamble, the facts of history, and of the Australian people's commitment to the recognition and protection of the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and to measures to overcome their disadvantage.
The Development Corporation

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation-which was previously titled the Aboriginal Economic Development Corporation-is intended to operate on a totally commercial basis. To transfer to it functions of the ADC, containing as they frequently do concessional elements such as grants and lower interest loans, would jeopardise the commercial standing of the Corporation in the marketplace. In addition, such a transfer would be at odds with a prime purpose of ATSIC-to achieve better coordination of portfolio programs and administrative efficiencies.
Implementing ATSIC

As foreshadowed in my 11 April statement, the Government's preferred position is that the legislation be passed by the Parliament in the current sittings, and that ATSIC commence, on an interim basis under five appointed Commissioners, on 1 October 1989. I remind the House that the Bill it passed in 1988 allowed for the possibility, in clause 221-replicated as clause 202 in this Bill-that ATSIC might need to operate on an interim basis with appointed Commissioners only. The interim Commission arrangement will allow the administrative machinery time to shake down and to prepare for the vital tasks for servicing regional councils and the full Commission.

The Government also recognises that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people need time to understand the changes that are being made and, more broadly, to get to know more about ATSIC and how it will work. They need this information before being asked to make the important decisions of electing their regional councillors and then those regional councillors electing commissioners. Following passage of this Bill the Government will provide adequate resources to assist in these processes. It has always been envisaged that only three commissioners would be ministerial appointments. For an interim Commission, however, this would result in unacceptable heavy burdens for commissioners; accordingly, for the interim period only-which cannot exceed 12 months-the number will be increased to five. It is the Government's intention, however, that the regional council elections be held as soon as possible after 1 October.
Detailed Provisions

I turn now to the main elements of the Bill itself, focusing particularly on those elements that are changed from the 1988 Bill. Full details are, of course, included in the explanatory memorandum. I have already referred to the preamble, and the Government's firm resolve that it should remain in the Bill. The text of the preamble, I should say, is unchanged. Clause 2 provides for the Bill to commence on proclamation or, failing that, at six months from the date of royal assent. The objects of the Act in clause 3 have been expanded, consistent with the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee, to include reference to past dispossession and dispersal of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. These words, I remind the House, are taken from the similar section of the Aboriginal Development Commission Act 1980.

A number of clauses relate to questions of accountability and administrative priorities. Clause 11 requires the Commission to prepare a corporate plan and to consult the Minister about it. Clauses 14, 17, 18 and 19, dealing with the Commission's powers in relation to grants of interest in property, enterprise loans and grants, grants for specific purposes, and guarantees, have been substantially tightened, and clause 20 requires repayments where conditions of grants or loans have not been met. Clause 27 provides for the establishment of the interim Commission of five members, while clause 57 deals with the estimates of ATSIC during the life of the interim Commission. Clause 73 requires the Minister to give ATSIC written directions about financial administration. Clauses 74 to 77 establish the Office of Evaluation and Audit; in clause 70, the Commission is required to include in its annual report a report by the Director of the Office.

Part III of the Bill establishes the system of 60 regional councils, comprising elected representatives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people living in those regions. Functions of the councils include: formulation of regional plans; proposals for ATSIC expenditure in the region, including the preparation of regional budgets; and generally to advice on the views, and interests, of the residents of their region. This part also deals with regional council elections, though as noted earlier in my speech the detailed provisions will be contained in electoral rules made under clause 109. As I mentioned earlier, the numbers of regional councillors will vary, as recommended by the Senate Select Committee, between 10 and 20 according to population; this is covered by the definition of `prescribed number' in clause 4 of the Bill. There are to be special provisions for the Torres Strait Regional Council, and these are enabled by clause 112. I inform the House that I have reached agreement with the Islander Co-ordinating Council for a regional council of 20 members, to comprise the chairpersons of the 18 Islander councils established under the Queensland Community Services (Torres Strait) Act 1984, plus representatives of two other communities in the region who do not have Council status under that Act.

Part III also establishes zones for the purpose of elections of commissioners. As I have mentioned, the number of zones is to be increased from 12 to 17. The new zone structure is set out in schedule 1 to the Bill. The additional zones will be: one each for the Sydney, Brisbane and Perth regions; for the Darwin, Tiwi Islands and Daly River regions in the Northern Territory; and for the existing Aurukun and Doomadgee regions in Queensland, combined with two new regions-Yarrabah-Palm Island, and Woorabinda-Cherbourg.

Clause 136 and schedule 4 provide for disputed elections. Such disputes will now be taken before a Court of Disputed Elections. The previous Bill provided for a system involving application to the Minister for an inquiry which, if agreed to, would have been considered by a suitably qualified person.

Part IV of the Bill establishes the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commercial Development Corporation-the Corporation-which would have Commission representation on its Board of Directors. The Corporation would concentrate wholly on commercial activities, and thus provide a focus for the commercial and economic development of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people through the accumulation and utilisation of a substantial capital asset for those people. Apart from the change of title to the proposed Corporation, the main changes in this part relate to strengthened administration and accountability.

Parts V and VI deal with a range of miscellaneous, consequential and transitional provisions. Included in part V is the provision, in clause 198, that the staff of Aboriginal Hostels Limited will come under the Public Service Act. Apart from this change, and the intention that three members of the Company's Board be drawn from the numbers of ATSIC Commissioners, the operations of Aboriginal Hostels Limited will not be affected.
Conclusion

For the last 16 months the Government has been consulting with interested groups about this legislation. We have extensively examined our original proposal as well as the first ATSIC Bill introduced into this place last year. We have listened to people's concerns and we have followed their recommendations. We have been extremely flexible on this piece of legislation because we wanted to get it right. We wanted to ensure that the new structure we put in place was an improvement on the current arrangements. We wanted to ensure above all else than any new administrative body would work to the benefit of Aboriginal and Islander people. The Government believes that this Bill will achieve all of these aims.

There have been some people who have criticised the proposal to involve Aboriginal and Islander people in the decision making process. The main argument used against ATSIC by these people-and in the main they are political opponents-is that the new Commission will `divide' Australia. They tend to justify this by alleging the Government is setting up a separate Black Parliament. ATSIC is not a parliament. It has no powers to make laws. Its own power is derived from legislation and it is accountable to the Minister and to this Parliament. The Opposition knows this. It uses the term only to distort the debate and to attempt to do exactly what they accuse us of doing-divide Australia.

There has been no critical analysis of ATSIC by the Opposition. Opposition members have never offered anything constructive, nor have they come up with any viable alternative. Their only contribution has been to say that the existing system is fine and does not need changing.

The debate on this legislation provides an opportunity for the Opposition to make some contribution on the future directions for Aboriginal Affairs. The Opposition's response should be closely examined by all of us to see whether it really is interested in the improvement of delivery of service and in Aboriginal and Islander self-management.

In summary, I stress again what I said in this place in my speech in August last year. The establishment of ATSIC will lead to a very significant change in Aboriginal Affairs and in the way the portfolio will be administered in the future. It is important, however, that this change be looked at not in isolation but as part of a series of changes aimed at bringing about long overdue reforms. These reforms can and should only occur with the proper participation and involvement of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The implementation of reform in Aboriginal Affairs depends largely on how governments, the bureaucracy, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities and the broader community tackle the challenges that now confront them.
Aboriginal and Islander Studies Bill

At a government level it is important to maintain the political will to follow through the changes. The challenge for the bureaucracy is to adapt positively to changes in their roles in a responsive and constructive way. It is equally important that the broader community builds on the understanding and support that currently exists in society to bring about far-reaching reform.

Finally, in order to realise the philosophy of self-determination and self-management-demands Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have been talking about since well before the 1967 referendum-it is crucial that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people take up the challenge and provide the direction for all of us.
I present the explanatory memorandum and I have great pleasure in commending the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr N.A. Brown) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INSTITUTE OF ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER STUDIES BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hand, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

As a consequence of a recommendation of the Senate Select Committee into the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, the Government has agreed to introduce this Bill as separate legislation, rather than as a component part of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Bill 1989. The Bill establishes a new body to replace the Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies (AIAS) established by an Act of this parliament in 1964. In large measures, the legislation enables the new Institute to operate very much as the AIAS currently operates, but with a new emphasis on the participation of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander persons with an interest and involvement in Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies.

In essence, the Institute's functions are to undertake and promote Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander studies, to encourage and train research workers, particularly Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander researchers, and to undertake research in its own right. The Institute also has a role in encouraging greater understanding in the general community of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander societies.

Membership of the new Institute will be made up of those persons who are now either full, associate, or corresponding members of the AIAS, plus such other persons appointed by the Council to be members.

The Council of the new Institute will consist of four persons elected by the members of the Institute, one person who is a Torres Strait Islander appointed by the Minister, and four other Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders appointed by the Minister, of whom at least three will be members of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. As a consequence, the Council will henceforth comprise a majority of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander members. As at present, the Council will determine the policy of the Institute with respect to all matters.

There will be a research advisory committee with a majority elected by the membership of the Institute. The functions of the Committee will be to advise the Council in relation to research matters, applications for research grants, and applications for Institute membership.

The staff of the new Institute will be engaged under the Public Service Act 1922. Provision will be made for the Institute to engage research fellows as consultants to undertake research as at present.

The Government, in formulating this Bill, consulted with representatives of the Council, and has attempted to meet the various concerns articulated where consistent with its overall objectives. For example, in response to concerns regarding the status of information held by the Institute, the legislation now provides that the Institute, in providing advice to the Commission or the Minister, is not required to disclose information which is either held sacred by Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders or which infringes the privacy of particular persons.

It is the Government's firm intention that the provisions of the Bill maintain the scholastic excellence and independent research capability which is very much a part of the operation and history of the AIAS. The Government is confident that the new Institute will remain an internationally recognised focus for study and research related to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander societies.
I present the explanatory memorandum and I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hand, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HAND
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
This Bill was foreshadowed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his statement to this House on 11 April, when, in referring to the recommendations of the various inquiries, he stated:
We have, moreover, considered to what extent the thrust of those recommendations should apply to the ADC while it continues to function in the lead up to ATSIC.

The main elements of this Bill, which I will outline, will ensure that the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC), during its remaining life, operates on a similar basis to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission and in a manner that properly reflects the Government's priorities.

The functions of the Commission will be amended to enable the Commission, upon request, to provide information or advice to the Minister, including information regarding the Commission's expenditure. This will clarify the Minister's right to request information from the Commission.

The business enterprise provisions in section 24 of the principal Act will be modified to take into account the concerns identified by the Auditor-General in his recent report. In particular, the Commission will be required to satisfy itself that the enterprise is likely to become, or continue to be, commercially successful. This criterion replaces the previous criterion which merely referred to the capability of the Aboriginal persons involved to engage in the enterprise.

The capability criterion is inadequate, because it leaves open the possibility that an enterprise may be funded notwithstanding that it has no prospects of commercial viability. In the Government's view, the commercial viability criterion is much more appropriate, focusing as it does on outputs rather than inputs; in effect, it encompasses the capability criterion without the paternalistic undertones.

The Bill also provides for a number of changes to the financial provisions of the principal Act. The Minister will be given the power to approve the Commission's estimates of expenditure and to issue financial administration guidelines and directions. This will ensure that appropriate ministerial oversight can occur, and that the Commission operates within the parameters of government policy. The Bill also extends the potential role of the Auditor-General to the audit of subsidiary companies controlled by the Commission. Section 24 (4) of the principal Act already provides for the recovery of business enterprise loans and grants where the terms and conditions of funding are breached. This provision is to be extended to cover all grants-loans of the Commission.

Finally, a number of changes are proposed to staffing arrangements. The Commission currently determines terms and conditions of employment in consultation with the Public Service Commission under section 33. In fact, the approved terms and conditions are almost identical to Public Service Act terms and conditions. The amendment Bill will formalise this by providing that all ADC staff be engaged under the Public Service Act 1922. Staff currently employed will be transferred into the Public Service under section 81b of the Public Service Act 1922.

The amendment Bill will also provide for the appointment by the Minister, after consultation with the Commission, of a General Manager with responsibility for managing the day to day administration of the Commission. The ancillary provisions relating to appointment, remuneration, leave of absence and so on are consistent with those provisions proposed for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commissioner.

In conclusion, let me state once again that this Bill is directed toward remedying the administrative defects in the legislation which established the Aboriginal Development Commission, while maintaining an appropriate balance between accountability and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander self-management and self-determination.
I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Miles) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Staples, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Housing and Aged Care)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill authorises the Commonwealth to enter into a new five-year agreement with each State and with the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory for the provision of services for homeless people in crisis under a new supported accommodation assistance program (SAAP).

When this Government came to office in March 1983, it identified homelessness as a major priority for urgent attention. At that time, there were no clear policies or directions to remedy youth or older age homelessness and there was no co-ordination of emergency accommodation services for women and children. Some programs were administered and funded by the Commonwealth and others were administered and cost shared by States. There was no overall planning and programs were uncoordinated and unnecessarily complex. Needs were not being met due to lack of planning and due to restrictions on the assistance which could be provided. Funding of approved projects under existing program guidelines was often inadequate.

On coming to office, we established, in 1983, a major review of crisis accommodation programs. The review found that there was no logical basis for the existing arrangements. As a result of the review's recommendations, the Government established the supported accommodation assistance program-or what is known as the SAAP program-in January 1985, bringing together existing services under a common funding and policy auspice.

SAAP is a joint funded Commonwealth-State program administered by the States. Under the program, non-government organisations and local government authorities receive recurrent and non-housing capital funds to provide supported accommodation and related support services to homeless people in crisis and who need help to move towards independent living.

A wide range of services are provided including refuges, drop-in centres, half-way houses, meals services, counselling in daily living skills and referral and advocacy services. The program's operation is governed by a Commonwealth-State agreement, which will expire on 30 June 1989.

A jointly funded national evaluation of the SAAP program was conducted by an independent consultant, Colleen Chesterman, in 1987 to examine the program's effectiveness and to advise on ways of refining its design and focus. In the course of the review, virtually all SAAP service providers were consulted, as well as numerous organisations supporting the homeless in every State and Territory.

The SAAP review report, Homes Away from Home, was publicly released in February 1988. The report noted the program's major achievements to date. It concluded that SAAP was well targeted, providing vital emotional and material assistance to the most disadvantaged people in Australia-people who are poor with insecure housing, many of whom having suffered physical abuse, addiction or institutionalisation.

The review noted that there has been a marked increase in the level of resources allocated by both Federal and State governments since the introduction of SAAP, which has resulted in greatly expanded assistance for homeless people in crisis. There are now some 800 SAAP services operating in a co-ordinated fashion from some 1200 outlets.

Data from the national SAAP client data collection indicates that, on any one day, more than 11,000 people throughout Australia are assisted under SAAP, of which 1,500 are in youth refuges; 2,500 are in women's refuges; 4,200 are in general crisis accommodation services; and 3,100 receive non-accommodation services such as meals, counselling and advice.

Moreover, the introduction of SAAP has placed many services on a secure financial footing for the first time. This has enabled providers to improve the quality of accommodation and the appropriateness of services provided, particularly through the provision of non-institutional client focused services. The SAAP review recommended the continuation of SAAP as a jointly funded Commonwealth-State program, supported by a new five-year agreement with each State and Territory.

The recent report of the National Inquiry into Homeless Children undertaken by the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission-known as the Burdekin report-reinforces the need for a supported accommodation assistance program. Clearly, responses to the complex web of issues related to youth homelessness cannot be confined to one policy area or level of government. However, the new SAAP program will provide major improvements to the Government's reponse to the problem of homeless young people. Some States have already increased the emphasis on medium and longer term alternatives to youth refuges, and this trend will continue under the new program. The development of a range of types of services with an emphasis on moving to independent living as soon as possible will be encouraged, consistent with the recommendations of the SAAP review report.

A draft Commonwealth-State agreement was presented to social welfare Ministers at their meeting on 20 March 1989. State Ministers endorsed that agreement but the Commonwealth was concerned to ensure that the position on young children was clarified. To this end, a definition of young people has been included. The agreement, which forms a schedule to this Bill, covers the joint arrangements for a new jointly-funded Commonwealth-State program administered by the States and Territories which would operate for five years from 1 July 1989. The agreement takes account of the experience of the current program, the views of States and community groups expressed through the operation of the program and its advisory processes and the SAAP review's findings and recommendations. The objective of the new program will be the provision by non-profit organisations and local government, with financial assistance from the Commonwealth and the States, of transitional supported accommodation services and related supported services to men, women and children who are homeless and in crisis to help them move towards independent living, where appropriate, or other alternatives, such as long term supported housing, as soon as possible.

The primary principle of the new program is to ensure that homeless people in crisis in Australia have access to adequate and appropriate transitional supported accommodation and related support services. In implementing this principle, assistance provided will also reflect the following detailed principles.

The focus of the program will be on transitional assistance. Services will be designed to be of varying duration and levels of support to meet the needs of individuals to move towards independent living or other appropriate alternatives; the emphasis will be on ensuring individuals retain maximum independence; there will be early assessment of clients' needs, referral to more appropriate services or programs where required and available and assistance to secure long term housing alternatives; services will be available to all sections of the community; services will be sensitive to the problems of homelessness, domestic violence and personal crisis and will actively work to enhance the dignity, self-esteem and independence of clients; services will assist clients in ways which recognise the individual needs of clients, develop clients' independence and enhance their own support network; and priority will be given to services involved in direct service provision for homeless people in crisis and whose focus is on assistance for individual clients.

The new program will cover a range of service models of varying duration, type and level of support. It will include services designed to meet the particular needs of women who are homeless and/or in crisis as a result of domestic violence as well as services for Aboriginal people and people from non-English speaking backgrounds. Services for chronically homeless people with limited capacity for independent living will continue to be eligible. It is important that SAAP not be used as a substitute for other programs of assistance by State governments for homeless youth. State governments have responsibility for children under 16 years and the Commonwealth is concerned to ensure that SAAP does not become the easy way out for States. For this reason, the agreement provides that new services-and I stress `new services'-which cater exclusively for children under 16 years will not be funded under this program. As well, the agreement provides that SAAP will not be used to replace or duplicate services and assistance already provided by, or which are the responsibility of, other government programs or services, such as substitute care and aged care.

Under the new program all people who are homeless and in crisis are able to be assisted. However, for some groups, such as young people under 16 or the frail aged, SAAP cannot provide the specialised services required. The program embodies the principles that for all groups helped under the program there is to be early assessment of clients' needs and referral to more appropriate services or programs where required and available. No existing SAAP services will be disadvantaged by the introduction of the new arrangements. Services currently funded under SAAP will continue to be funded under the new program, subject to normal accountability and performance standards.

Financial assistance to the States shall be by way of grants. The Commonwealth and the States will continue to provide base funding equivalent to the level of their annual contributions to the program as at 30 June in the year immediately preceding the relevant financial year, indexed on an annual basis. At 30 June 1989, Commonwealth base funding for SAAP will be $64.1m and the States' base funding will be $40.3m. This represents a real increase of 240 per cent in Commonwealth-State funding for SAAP since the commencement of the program in 1985.

Despite the very great increase in Commonwealth-State resources devoted to homeless people in crisis, there is an urgent and increasing need for additional services. Accordingly, the Commonwealth is providing $5m per year for new and expanded services for the first three years of the new program on the basis of equivalent forward commitment and dollar for dollar matching by the States. Commonwealth and State growth funds accepted in one year would be incorporated in the program base for the following year and the total base indexed. In total, this represents an increased Commonwealth commitment of $40m over three years. These additional Commonwealth funds will bring the total Federal Government commitment to the program, including maintenance of current expenditure, to about $240m over the three years to 1992, which represents real growth of some 20 per cent over the three-year period.

An important new feature of the SAAP program will be the development of Commonwealth-State and Territory plans which will set out the operation of the program for each year in the State or Territory. The plans shall include:

An assessment of existing service provision and distribution; an assessment of unmet need; the agreed Commonwealth-State priorities for the year, including identified target groups; program finances for the year; the timing, content and process of major program reviews; proposed research and data collections for the year in relation to the State program or on national issues; and the timetable for planning and approval processes in the current and the subsequent financial year.

Feedback and advice from SAAP service providers and relevant community groups are a vital element in the development of the Commonwealth-State plan. Accordingly, the new program provides for the development of new and enhanced advisory structures. A ministerial advisory committee will be established in each State comprised of members drawn from service providers and other parties with relevant expertise-forming the majority of the Committee-and Commonwealth and State government officials. The ministerial advisory committee shall provide advice to Ministers on priorities to be taken into account in the annual planning processes, levels of unmet need and matters such as program accountability requirements, service standards and data needs. The plan itself will be jointly approved by the responsible Commonwealth and State Ministers.

Within the current SAAP program, there are three subprograms for homeless people in crisis relating to women, youth and general services. The SAAP review found that the current SAAP subprograms have played an important role in the establishment phase of SAAP but suggested that the subprogram focus had created unnecessary complexity, led to restrictions which disadvantaged certain high need groups-for example, single homeless women and families-and hampered flexibility in planning and referral. It recommended the replacement of subprograms with target groups. Accordingly, under the new program, funds will be allocated within States each year according to priority target groups rather than subprograms. Planning for the development of services and the allocation of resources will be on the basis of priority target groups identified in the planning process. The new program covers a range of measures which will lead to improved program effectiveness and efficiency. Apart from the plan, these include service agreements between all SAAP services and State governments incorporating agreed nationally consistent provisions, and regular review of service performance.

Another important feature of the proposed agreement is in the area of user rights. The Commonwealth and States will agree within two years of the commencement of the agreement on mechanisms for resolving breaches of individual rights. Such mechanisms will include principles and strategies for the protection of users' rights, which may include such matters as participation in decision-making. Mechanisms will also include internal grievance procedures for the resolution of breaches of user rights at the service provider level and external review procedures. SAAP has been to the forefront in involving clients in decisions about issues which affect them. These proposals will continue to provide protection and dignity to people at a traumatic time of their life.

Assistance for homeless people in crisis is a shared Commonwealth-State responsibility and an area which requires close cooperation in order to achieve the best possible outcome from available resources. Both the Commonwealth and States have vital but different roles to play. To ensure that there is no duplication of effort, the Agreement clearly sets out Commonwealth and State roles and areas in which joint action is required. While the States will continue to be responsible for administration of the new program, joint ministerial approval will continue to be required in respect of matters such as the funding of new services and variations to, or defunding of, existing services.

Capital funds for SAAP services will continue to be made available under the crisis accommodation program (CAP) within the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. In 1988-89 the Commonwealth will provide $19.5m under CAP. SAAP and CAP will be dealt with by the same advisory committee in each State to provide a coordinated approach.

Apart from authorising financial assistance to the States, this Bill seeks authority for the Commonwealth to use up to 2 per cent of Commonwealth growth funds each year for the purpose of national research and development. This will provide scope for Commonwealth initiatives in program development and national research. Access to adequate and affordable housing for all is a major priority within the Government's social justice strategy. The new supported accommodation assistance program will build on the experiences of SAAP over the last 4 1/2 years and will provide a more coherent and effective approach to the problems of people who are homeless and in crisis.

Through this Bill, the Commonwealth, in partnership with the States and Territories, is continuing its commitment to the funding of supported accommodation and related services. I thank the State and Territory Ministers for their cooperation in the formulation of the new program.
I commend the Bill to the House. I now present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Downer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Banking Legislation Amendment Bill 1989 is to amend the Banking Act 1959 and other banking legislation to reflect a number of developments in the past several years. The major changes proposed are to provide the Reserve Bank of Australia with formal authority for the prudential supervision of banks; to remove the distinction between trading banks and savings banks; to replace the statutory reserve deposit requirement on trading banks with a new non-callable deposit requirement on all banks; and to make the arrangements for collection and publication of banking statistics more flexible.

The banking system is central to the operation of the financial system and has an important contribution to make to the wider economy. It is therefore important that the stability of the banking system be promoted through the observance of high prudential standards by banks. The Reserve Bank has a statutory obligation under the Banking Act to protect those who deposit funds with banks. In keeping with this obligation and its general responsibility for the stability of the financial system, the Reserve Bank has developed arrangements under which each bank is encouraged to keep itself in a sound financial position and to conduct its business in a prudent and professional manner.

The prudential requirements observed by banks in Australia, like those applying in other developed countries, relate to such matters as the adequacy of capital, the structure of assets and liabilities, management of exposures to risk, the capacity of its directors and senior management, and the representation of shareholders by directors. These arrangements for prudential supervision have relied heavily upon the cooperation of individual banks. This system has worked well but, in the light of the increased number of banks now operating in Australia, changes in banking activities and the more competitive and demanding environment in which banks operate, it is desirable for the Reserve Bank to have a clear statutory basis for its prudential supervision of banks. The Government considers that prudential arrangements for banks should be related to specific powers within the Banking Act and that the role of the Reserve Bank as prudential supervisor of banks should be recognised formally.

The Bill will amend the Banking Act in a number of ways to achieve this. In particular, it will provide for the Treasurer (Mr Keating), having consulted with the Reserve Bank, to recommend that the Governor-General establish requirements in relation to prudential matters by way of regulations. This power will be supplemented by an increase in the scope already permitted in the Act for the Governor-General to place conditions on banking authorities. The Bill will also establish formally the role of the Reserve Bank in the prudential supervision of banks and transfer to the Reserve Bank the powers currently resting with the Auditor-General to conduct investigations of banks. As a consequence of the Reserve Bank's continuous conduct of prudential supervision, and the publication of its prudential rules, its present requirements are well known and understood by the banking sector.

It is not the Government's intention that the amendment of the Act should alter the prudential standards being met by banks or the way in which they are administered. Rather, the Government considers that the power to make regulations relating to prudential requirements should be seen as a reserve power to be used when circumstances require it. The amendments proposed in this Bill will also give legislative effect to the Treasurer's announcement in the Budget last year of the removal of the distinction between savings banks and trading banks. The general nature of these amendments is to make the provisions currently applying to trading banks apply to all banks, and to repeal specific provisions relating to savings banks. The maintenance of a distinction between savings banks and trading banks no longer serves any policy purpose. In recent years most savings bank subsidiaries of banks have existed not as distinct physical or managerial structures but as different sets of accounts within banking groups. From a customer's viewpoint there is no effective difference between savings and trading banks.

Removal of the distinction between them will enable banks to have better use and allocation of funds, more simple funding and accounting arrangements, and greater flexibility in servicing customers. These gains ultimately will benefit bank customers through a lower cost of bank services. As a result of comments which have been received from the banking industry consideration is being given to some further amendment of the Banking Act to facilitate the integration of the accounts of savings banks and trading banks. This change will not change the extent to which banks now lend money to customers for housing purposes, nor will it affect the price of housing loans.

The third major change proposed in this Bill is the removal of the statutory reserve deposit (SRD) requirement on trading banks. Both the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the Martin Group recommended that this outmoded measure should be modified. The SRD requirement has had distorting effects on the financial system because it has increased the cost of trading bank lending, diverted business to savings banks and other non-bank financial institutions, and encouraged banks to fund their operations through sources other than Australian dollar deposits, such as commercial bills, offshore borrowings and foreign currency deposits.

As the Treasurer announced at Budget time, the SRD requirement is being phased down over a three-year period and replaced with a system of non-callable deposits which banks will be required to maintain with the Reserve Bank as part of their obligations as authorised banks. By the end of the transitional three-year period all the banks affected will hold non-callable deposits with the Reserve Bank equivalent to one per cent of their liabilities. The effect of the new arrangements will be to remove the distorting effect of the SRD arrangement and generally reduce the burden on banks and their customers.

The new arrangements represent a further and significant step in the process of financial deregulation which the Government has brought about with a view to raising the overall efficiency of the banking sector and thereby increasing the scope for it to contribute to the broader economy. The change is estimated to involve a cost to revenue of $100m each year, or roughly half the SRD revenue in 1987-88, by the time the transitional period is completed in 1991-92.

Precise costs will of course depend on a number of variable factors such as the level of interest rates and the rate of growth in banks' assets and liabilities. The Government proposes to review the non-callable deposit arrangements before the end of the transitional period and, in particular, to consider adopting a lower maximum rate than that currently proposed in the Bill.

The Bill proposes a number of other changes to the Banking Act and to related legislation with a view to ensuring that the legislative framework is relevant to the present banking system and flexible in its administration. The Bill proposes that arrangements for the collection and publication of statistics about banks should be simplified and made more flexible by allowing the details of these arrangements to be determined through regulations rather than spelled out in the Act as at present. The latter arrangement has proved to be inflexible in the light of the significant and rapid changes which have taken place in the nature of financial markets and the types of financial instruments used by banks.

The Government's ability to monitor the financial sector will be improved by the scope which it will have under the amended Act to adjust the form of statistical returns which banks are required to make. We shall, however, keep in mind the continued need for consultation over such changes and for minimising reporting burdens. There should be some resource savings both for the banks and the Government from these amendments, since unnecessary requirements will be able to be dropped more rapidly and the obligation on the Australian Statistician to receive and publish banking statistics, which duplicates work undertaken by the Reserve Bank, will be removed.

The first schedule to the Act, which lists authorised banks, will be updated and a procedure will be introduced to allow the Treasurer to amend the first schedule through publishing information in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. These changes will allow the public to be better informed as to those financial institutions which are authorised as banks.

Provision has been made in the Bill for a banking authority to be revoked by the Governor-General where a bank requests it and the Governor-General is satisfied that there is no objection on grounds of national interest. The new provision will allow greater flexibility since, in contrast to the present section, it will allow an authority to be surrendered or removed where a bank has not ceased to carry on business but wishes to continue as a financial institution without having the status and obligations of a bank.

Section 66 of the Banking Act, which requires that consent be obtained from the Treasurer for the use of the word `bank' in a business name or as a descriptive expression in relation to the business of a financial institution, has been revised in the Bill to clarify the meaning and scope of the provision. The purpose of the more detailed provision would remain as before-to avoid confusion on the part of the public between banks authorised under the Banking Act and non-bank financial institutions. The Bill proposes that a new provision be introduced into the Banking Act to provide a clear legislative basis for regulating the establishment of representative offices by international banks. Under the new provision it is intended that such banks should be required to seek the Treasurer's consent to open a representative office and to observe any conditions which he may establish. This provision would formalise arrangements which now operate on an informal basis. It would not imply any change in the Government's policy of welcoming the establishment of representative offices to undertake purely liaison activities on behalf of international banks.

The Bill also includes some proposed amendments to the Commonwealth Banks Act and the Reserve Bank Act. The proposed changes to the Commonwealth Banks Act would widen the board's power over the Commonwealth Bank's capital structure in line with the revised definitions of capital announced by the Reserve Bank in 1988, and streamline the Commonwealth Bank's reporting requirements. The proposed changes to the Reserve Bank Act are to simplify its internal accounting arrangements by abolishing the artificial separation between the note issue and central banking functions, and to remove some redundant reporting obligations.

Finally, the Bill addresses the fact that penalties for offences against the Banking Act have been unaltered since the Act came into force in 1959 and provides for them to be revised. It is intended that the relevant sections of the Act be amended to establish penalties for breaches of the Act or of its regulations which are consistent with penalty levels imposed on corporations in other significant legislation. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill, and I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Hewson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill, and a complementary Bill I shall introduce shortly, essentially bring to completion the Government's tax reforms in the superannuation arena. The first ingredients of the reform package where brought before the House in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1988 which I introduced on 30 November last. That Bill puts in place the framework of the new tax regime for superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts. The present Bill complements those measures. Broadly, it effectively reduces for recipients of superannuation benefits and related amounts the tax they pay on eligible termination payments, superannuation pensions or annuities. This compensates them for the tax being imposed at that earlier point on employer contributions to superannuation schemes.

Consistent with the Government's undertaking at the time of the May 1988 economic statement, the Bill ensures that recipients of end benefits are not worse off because of the earlier taxing point for affected superannuation contributions. It also places the tax treatment of the superannuation business of life assurance offices, including State and Territory government insurance offices-known as SGIOs-and registered organisations-that is, friendly societies and employee associations-on the same footing as general superannuation funds, at the concessional rate of 15 per cent, allowing full franking rebates for dividend income under the imputation system on the same basis as for individuals. Associated measures in the Bill modify in various ways the deductions available to life offices to make them more compatible with the new tax treatment of superannuation business.

To complete the new rules for the taxing of entities conducting superannuation business, the Bill gives wide-ranging capital gains treatment to disposals of assets held in superannuation funds or in connection with the superannuation business of life offices and other entities. This gives them the benefit of the capital gains indexation concession which ensures that only real gains, rather than nominal ones, are subject to tax.

Following discussions with industry, the Bill also proposes several modifications to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6). A number of concessions sought by industry are being provided and there are some practical adjustments to the ways in which tax liabilities are determined. There remains to be put in place a tax instalment payment arrangement for superannuation funds that is to apply for the 1990-91 income year. Legislation to achieve this will be introduced later in the year. New legislative arrangements, also to apply from 1990-91, for the limiting of superannuation benefits under rules applied by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner are also to be included in later legislation.
I now move on in more detail to the features of the Bill.
Superannuation and other Retirement Benefits

With effect from 1 July 1988, lower tax will apply to eligible termination payments, known as ETPs, superannuation pensions and roll-over annuities. This will balance the taxing of contributions to superannuation funds and rolled-over unfunded ETPs. The new measures-which were announced in the May 1988 economic statement and expanded on in later announcements-will generally reduce the tax payable on superannuation and other retirement benefits in three ways. First, they will reduce the rates of tax for post-June 1983 components of ETPs by 15 percentage points to the extent that such a component is attributable to a taxed source. Secondly, a 15 per cent rebate of tax is being introduced for superannuation pensions and roll-over annuities taken from age 55, or as a death or disability benefit. Thirdly, by authorising tax reductions in appropriate cases, the Bill gives effect to our commitment that no recipient of a superannuation benefit will be worse off because of the tax on superannuation contributions. Transitional measures will phase in the tax reductions on end benefits to fit the gradual impact of the new tax arrangements on amounts being paid out under superannuation schemes.
Taxation of Life Assurance Companies

Consistent with the treatment of superannuation funds generally, the Bill will give effect to the decisions announced in May 1988 to tax the superannuation and roll-over annuity business of life assurance companies from 1 July 1988. The assessable income of a life assurance company will include investment income from its superannuation and roll-over annuity business. It will also include post-30 June 1983 components of lump sum retirement benefits taken in the form of `golden handshakes' that are invested with the company. Also in the Bill are rules for apportioning the taxable income of a life assurance company between complying superannuation and roll-over annuity business, non-complying superannuation business, other life assurance and accident and disability business, and non-life assurance business. This break-up will allow the separate tax rates applicable to each class of business to operate.

With effect from the 1988-89 income year, all expenses of life assurance companies will be apportioned between exempt income and assessable income. Again lightening the effective tax burden, expenses incurred in bringing in superannuation premiums are to be made fully deductable even though those premiums are not taxable. In keeping with the taxing of superannuation funds, including State and Territory government superannuation funds, SGIOs are to be subject to Commonwealth income tax on income derived from their superannuation and roll-over annuity business in the same way as life assurance companies from 1 July 1988.

The Bill extends entitlement to franking rebates under the imputation system for franked dividends received by the insurance funds of life assurance companies on or after 1 July 1988. Surplus rebates from the taxation at 15 per cent of dividends received as part of their superannuation business will serve to reduce these companies' overall tax burden. The inter-corporate dividend rebate will no longer apply to dividends on shares forming assets of the insurance funds of a life assurance company. The Bill also safeguards against any technical argument that a life assurance company may be entitled to deductions as general management expenses for items of expense which are expressly not deductable to other categories of taxpayers, such as expenses incurred on entertainment or in paying fringe benefits tax. This amendment operates with effect from 26 May 1988.

In the May 1988 economic statement it was also announced that a life assurance company would be taxed on an overall company basis rather than on a fund-by-fund basis. This was to prevent life assurance companies from manipulating transfers of assets between statutory funds to gain undue tax advantages. In response to industry requests, life assurance companies will continue to be taxed on a fund-by-fund basis. However, the Government is committed to preventing life assurance companies from transferring assets between statutory funds solely for the purpose of reducing taxation liabilities. This matter is to be addressed further in consultation with the industry.
Non-resident Life Assurance Companies

Dividends derived from assets included in the Australian insurance funds of a non-resident life assurance company are to be exempt from dividend withholding tax and instead taxed on assessment. The non-resident assurer will become entitled to a franking rebate in respect of the franked proportion of those dividends. These changes will apply to dividends paid to a non-resident life assurance company on or after 1 July 1988.
Rebate on Short Term Life Assurance Bonuses

The Bill will also implement the proposal announced in the May 1988 economic statement to increase the rate of the rebate of tax on bonuses received on or after 1 July 1989 in respect of certain short term life assurance policies. The rebate is to be increased from 29 per cent to 30 per cent in the case of friendly society policies and from 29 per cent to 39 per cent in the case of life assurance company policies.
Taxation of Registered Organisations

The comprehensive coverage of the superannuation tax reforms extends to the superannuation and roll-over annuity business of registered organisations. The new arrangements which apply to such business of life assurance companies will apply similarly to registered organisations from 1 July 1988 on the basis of the May 1988 economic statement. They are to apply to all registered organisations-both to friendly societies and to any other registered organisations that engage in relevant superannuation or roll-over annuity business.
Gains or Losses on Disposal of Assets

The Bill proposes amendments that will extend generally the application of the capital gains and capital losses provisions of the income tax law to disposals of assets by complying superannuation funds, complying approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts. The special capital gains rules will also extend to disposals of assets refer- able to the complying superannuation and roll-over annuity business of life assurance companies and registered organisations. All assets owned by such entities as at the end of 30 June 1988 will be taken for capital gains purposes to have been acquired on that date. This allows the capital gains tax provisions to apply regardless of the actual date of acquisition of the assets.

To prevent any retrospective application of the capital gains provisions to gains or losses that accrued on or before 1 July 1988, the acquisition cost of an asset will be taken to be either its market value or the amount of costs incurred on it to that date, whichever produces the smaller gain or loss on disposal. A major benefit of this capital gains tax treatment is that entities engaged in superannuation business will attract the indexation advantages of the capital gains provisions, including on dealings in some assets that would otherwise have been treated as trading transactions not subject to indexation. Further, the Bill provides for an exemption from tax for gains on disposals of units in a pooled superannuation trust by a complying superannuation fund, a complying approved deposit fund or a pooled superannuation trust. This exemption also extends to certain disposals of assets by a life assurance company or a registered organisation.
Superannuation Funds, Approved Deposit Funds and Pooled Superannuation Trusts

The Bill modifies in several respects provisions dealing with the taxation of superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation trusts that were introduced in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6). These modifications will provide a number of concessions and options that have been developed after consultation with the superannuation industry. One will provide an alternative optional method for calculating the tax exempt income of a superannuation fund which segregates some of its assets solely for use in meeting the fund's current pension liabilities. Income derived from the segregated assets will be exempt from tax.

Vicarious exemption from tax is being provided for pooled superannuation trusts, life offices and registered organisations on such part of their income derived from complying superannuation fund business as would have been tax exempt current pension income had it been derived by relevant funds. Another alternative method is being introduced for calculating the deduction available to a superannuation fund in respect of the cost of providing death and disability benefits. At their option, funds may claim a deduction for a portion of any death and disability benefits actually paid in a year of income.

A special deduction will enable tax exempt death benefits paid by superannuation funds to be paid at the same levels as before the changes taking effect from 1 July 1988. This deduction acknowledges that the contributions tax cannot be compensated for in such cases by the 15 per cent reduction in tax rates applicable to taxable ETPs. A provision that allows a superannuation fund to transfer its contributions tax liability to a pooled superannuation trust, life assurance company or registered organisation has been redrafted to ease the requirements to be met before such a liability may be transferred. It will now allow a fund to transfer contributions tax liability to the relevant entity up to an annual limit based on the highest value of the fund's investment in the transferee in the year of income concerned.

The Bill will also allow the Commissioner of Taxation to anticipate that certain compliance notices will be given by the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. The provisions being inserted will allow an assessment to be made on the assumption that the relevant notices will be given but will also permit those assessments to be amended if it subsequently transpires that the relevant notices are not given. To ensure that non-reversionary bonuses-that is, cash bonuses -paid on life assurance policies are not effectively subject to tax twice when paid to a complying superannuation fund, a complying approved deposit fund or a pooled superannuation trust, such cash bonuses are to be exempted from tax.
Exemption from Tax for Contributions to Superannuation Funds

Finally, the Bill gives effect to two measures announced on 11 August 1988 to exempt from tax certain employer contributions to superannuation funds. Some superannuation funds had unfunded liabilities related to benefits accrued prior to 1 July 1988. Contributions subsequently made to meet these liabilities are to be excluded from assessable income. The Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner will be permitted to consider applications for recognition of a pre-1 July 1988 unfunded liability and, as appropriate, to issue notices specifying an available pre-1 July 1988 funding credit. Broadly, such a pre-1 July 1988 funding credit may be transferred to another fund or the fund trustees may, within specified limits, elect for an amount of employer contributions to be excluded from assessable income. Outstanding unapplied pre-1 July 1988 credit balances will be indexed.

The second measure covers cases where an employer does not fund benefits until retirement. An exemption from tax for these late employer contributions to a fund will be given for amounts not exceeding `untaxed' benefits paid in a year of income. As I indicated when introducing the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6), the changes in the tax arrangements applying to the superannuation industry completed by the measures in this Bill are expected to generate $980m in additional revenue in 1989-90 and $1,400m in 1990-91 but the net gains will be smaller after taking account of the proposed reductions in tax on end benefits.
I present the explanatory memorandum, which contains more detailed costings and explanations of the provisions of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Hewson) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Peter Morris, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALKER.NAME: Mr PETER MORRIS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1989 complements the measures in the Bill I have just introduced. It will amend the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 to declare the rates of tax payable on the various components of taxable income of life assurance companies and registered organisations. For the component referable to policies held by complying funds or in respect of roll-over annuities the rate is to be 15 per cent. A rate of 47 per cent is to be set in respect of the component referable to policies held by non-complying funds. The rate set for the component referable to other life assurance and accident and disability insurance is 39 per cent where the insurer is a life assurance office and 30 per cent where the insurer is a registered organisation. Finally, a rate of 39 per cent is to be fixed in respect of the non-statutory fund component of the taxable income of a life assurance company.

The new tax rates for life offices and registered organisations will generally have effect for the year of income commencing on 1 July 1988, but the 47 per cent rate in respect of non-complying fund income is to apply from the income year commencing on 1 July 1990. The rates to apply to non-complying fund income for the income years commencing 1 July 1988 and 1 July 1989 are to be 49 and 48 per cent respectively.

The Bill will also reduce, in two stages, the rate of tax applying to the taxable income of non-complying superannuation funds and approved deposit funds and the special component of the taxable income of a complying fund or pooled superannuation trust. The existing 49 per cent rate is to be reduced to 48 per cent for the income year commencing on 1 July 1989 and to 47 per cent for the year commencing 1 July 1990 and later years. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Dr Hewson) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: WHEAT MARKETING BILL 1989[COGNATE BILLS:WHEAT INDUSTRY FUND LEVY BILL 1989WHEAT INDUSTRY FUND LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1989WHEAT (TERMINATION OF TAX) BILL (No. 1) 1989WHEAT (TERMINATION OF TAX) BILL (No. 2) 1989WHEAT (TERMINATION OF PERMIT TAX) BILL 1989WHEAT TAX (PERMIT) COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1989]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 3 May, on motion by Mr Kerin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ruddock) Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering the Wheat Marketing Bill and the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Bill, the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Collection Bill, the Wheat (Termination of Tax) Bill (No. 1), the Wheat (Termination of Tax) Bill (No. 2), the Wheat (Termination of Permit Tax) Bill, and the Wheat Tax (Permit) Collection Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to some of the preceding speakers in this debate one would not know that the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989 and associated Bills are all about achieving a more efficient and effective marketing system. I recall the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) telling me in a private conversation just after he was elected that there would need to be a very strong look had at all the statutory marketing authorities and other authorities of government while we were in government. I see this measure as further progress in his long overhaul of some of the authorities that come under his portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is not some blind fervour about deregulation, though it is welcome that the Government has had the courage to deregulate the dollar, take action in the telecommunications area and free up services to compete more. It has also enabled government bodies such as the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation to market better, compete more and take advantage of opportunities: in other words, they have been removed from restrictions. Nor are the wheat Bills an attempt to split the National and Liberal coalition apart, although that is happening. On the one side, we have the Liberal Party, which has all the courage in the world in opposition but not very much in government, proclaiming deregulation. On the other side, we have the Nationals, who regard farmers as lame ducks for whom crutches must continually be found. Wheat farmers are not lame ducks. They are perfectly capable of operating in a competitive environment. Australian farmers have the greatest record in the world as initiators, as marketers and for being open to change.

Nor is the legislation anti-State, although one would think it from reading some of the newspaper reports. For instance, on 28 April the Sydney Morning Herald stated that the New South Wales Government was considering a legal challenge to the Federal Government's controversial plans to deregulate the domestic wheat market, claiming that the proposed legislation would override the powers of State-based agricultural marketing boards. The article continued:

The State Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Armstrong, said he had received legal advice that the Federal Wheat Marketing Bill would allow the Commonwealth to ``effectively neutralise'' statutory authorities such as the Grain Sorghum Marketing Board.
On 19 April the Melbourne Age said:
The Queensland Government is considering legal action over Federal Government plans to deregulate the wheat industry.
Queensland had sought senior legal advice on the issue the state's Primary Industries Minister, Mr Harper, said in a statement yesterday. Queensland would take all appropriate legal action, he said.
``We will be seeking the advice of senior counsel and, unlike the Commonwealth, any action we take will be after consultation with the industry,'' Mr Harper said.
``In the meantime, I believe the federal Opposition should show some fortitude and stand up to the Commonwealth,'' he said.

While States like Queensland and New South Wales are considering legal action, their Federal colleagues agreed that it was only fair to wheat farmers to ask them to free up the transport regulations in those States. If wheat farmers are to be competitive through deregulation, then the transport system ought to be much more competitive. I agree with the Federal members of the Liberal Party who proclaim that view against the State Ministers' views.

There are strong reasons for believing that this legislation will provide additional competition in the transport area. I believe it will lead to a ceiling on rail freight charges which have formerly been able to blow out in some States. I believe that road substitution will not be extensive when deregulation of the transport industries throughout the States comes about. This is because most wheat is transported long distances. The average distance is about 380 kilometres. As well as that, the volume of wheat transported, which was 14.9 million tonnes in 1988-89, is considerably higher than most other areas of freight transport. In addition, we have to take into account that if the rail systems want to be competitive then they can have a very low cost structure. The cost of transporting wheat over 100 kilometres is about 4.51c per tonne kilometre. It is 3.03c per tonne kilometre over 300 kilometres, which is much less. It is 2.76c per tonne kilometre at 500 kilometres. The cost of a six-axle articulated truck making a 300 kilometre trip would be 6.3c compared, as I said, with 3.03c for rail. That is twice the cost. So 84 per cent of total grain traffic should be kept by the rail system, because it really can compete if it is forced into quoting competitive prices. There is certainly no reason why wheat farmers should have to cross-subsidise city train users. If this legislation is a means of forcing rail systems into being competitive, that is all the better. The rail authorities should be forced into being competitive. There will be some increased road use, largely between farms and major central receiving terminals. However, we should not ignore a major cross-subsidy that is happening here.

Light vehicle users are subsidising the much higher level of damage caused by heavier vehicles, which is an issue that must be tackled. It is good that the Inter-State Commission is investigating registration charges throughout Australia. As well, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Department of Transport and Communications have established a group to progress further the introduction of a more reasoned system of registration charges to take account of the damage done by heavy vehicle traffic on roads.

In conclusion, I point out that like the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) I believe that Australian wheat growers are intelligent men and women who are perfectly able to accept innovation and change. Since my first job after leaving school, which was as a wheat and flour tester at James Malcolm and Co. in St Arnaud in Victoria, I have seen a lot of changes in the wheat industry. The wheat industry has been able to adapt its production systems to a changing environment. Its method of adaptation has been impressive, and I believe that it will endeavour to see that marketing arrangements are not the factor which limits its future prosperity. I have every confidence in the wheat industry and I believe that this legislation stresses the confidence that the Government has in the industry to develop a much more competitive environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Wheat Marketing Bill and associated Bills pass in their present form, no rural Australian Labor Party member deserves to be re-elected to this Parliament. This legislation is not about the wheat industry; it is about politics. It is an attempt to destroy, as far as it can, the efficacy of the family farmer who, through hard work and endeavour, has settled and developed so much of Australia. The legislation is designed to prejudice existing operations that have been vital to the States, and each State has been responsible for establishing separate marketing authorities for grains.

SPEECH.PARA: Traditionally, in conjunction with the Commonwealth, the States have passed complementary legislation to allow for a viable and strong Australian Wheat Board. This is legislation which, over the course of the nine months since the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) first announced at a meeting of State agriculture Ministers in Cairns that initial negotiations had taken place, has been progressively manoeuvred to drive a wedge between the National Party of Australia, the Liberal Party of Australia and the wheat growers. It is not designed to assist wheat growers.

Sadly, there are still fundamental concerns in respect of this legislation which the Government has ignored and, in fact, the Government itself has found it necessary in this package of Bills to foreshadow more than 45 amendments. I think that that is an indication that, instead of giving the legislation proper foresight, consideration, care and concern, the Minister has been rushing around from day to day, ideologically determined to introduce a position which he believes is in the best interests of the Labor Party and Labor members while totally ignoring the quite critical plight of many people who produce wheat in this country. There are four fundamental concerns of the Opposition in respect of these Bills. I will refer to the first concern briefly.

The Government has totally failed to consult and to maintain consultations with State agriculture Ministers, the Grains Council of Australia and grain growers. The consultations that have taken place have been between only the Minister and his cohorts in the Department to try to find some vehicle which the Minister thinks might divide the coalition and might be politically advantageous in the presentation of the Labor Party to the electorate. The Minister has failed abysmally because, in ignoring consultation, he has put at risk the continuation of a very effective marketing arm of one of Australia's major export industries.

My second concern is that, in the process of the Minister's toing-and-froing and shuffling around the campus, he has finished up prejudicing the ability of the Australian Wheat Board to be a strong domestic trader from 1 July.
