There is absolutely no excuse for a Minister to allow that situation to develop. Since last July, the Minister has been talking about the necessity for complementary legislation, and he has known that it is necessary to provide legislation which will ensure the continuation of the Australian Wheat Board as a major marketing arm for the wheat industry. The fact that within Australia there are individual States that have rejected the legislation is something that I regard as a condemnation of the Minister. It is not satisfactory that after all these consultations no State, even those with Labor governments, has seen fit to introduce and pass complementary legislation. If the Australian Wheat Board is no longer a strong domestic trader after 1 July, it is the Labor Party and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy who will be responsible. No-one in Australia should fail to understand that that could be to the quite significant price disadvantage of the Australian farmer. Indeed, Clinton Condon, the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, said on 7 July last year:

If you are looking at further deregulation of the domestic market, bearing in mind that the feed wheat market is deregulated now, farmers have asked me what would happen to the price. The price on the domestic market for milling wheat under deregulation will fall. There is no question about that because at this time we sell on the domestic market at a price we sell to our best export markets.

In a situation where the Wheat Board itself will be able to trade only uncertainly, the impact will be even worse. So my second concern is that the Minister and the Labor Party have left every Australian wheat trader in a position of significant uncertainty because of the failure to allow States to pass complementary legislation and the failure to address the difficulty of that significant part of the wheat trade that reflects the domestic trade, both interstate and intrastate. With the intrastate trade comprising about 80 per cent it is particularly significant that there is no complementary legislation, and there are doubts in the minds of the Wheat Board and every trader as to the position of the Wheat Board after 1 July.

My third concern is that the legislation will have a significant impact on other grains. I know that as far as the Wheat Board is concerned there is reason for incidental trade with respect to a whole range of other grains. Members on this side of the House accept that as necessary and desirable. However, we certainly do not accept that the powers of the Wheat Board should be so extended that they prejudice the continued viable operations of State marketing authorities. Those State marketing authorities have been constituted across a whole range of products of the soil, many of which the Minister can incorporate by regulation as commodities to be traded by the Wheat Board. There is no reason whatsoever why the powers of those State marketing authorities, which have traded effectively and well on behalf of their producers, should be threatened by this Bill.

I refer to ginger, for example, which is way outside the normal responsibility of the Wheat Board. It would be ridiculous if this Bill were to intrude on the authority of the Queensland Ginger Board. It might apply across the whole range of commodities, including rice and soya bean. It is of concern to us that in that third area there are significant doubts. Therefore, my colleague the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) will be moving amendments to address that problem.

My fourth area of concern relates to the arbitrary manner in which the Government, yet again, seeks to override the responsibilities of the State governments. The States of Australia have prime responsibility for production and distribution of all produce within their own boundaries. It is not of concern that the Government has moved, for the first time, to deregulate the labour market to the degree it has in proposed section 7 of the Bill which provides powers in respect of the storage, handling, loading and unloading of wheat, including such facilities at ports; and to arrange for the provision of storage, handling, transport and other marketing services for wheat. Nor is it of concern that for the first time legislation will reflect some measures of micro-economic reform. The concern relates to the way in which the Government has deliberately ignored the continued responsibilities of the States and said, `We do not really care what you want to do; we will pursue this course and proceed with this legislation because we think it is in our political interests'.

The Opposition sees those four concerns as quite fundamental in respect of the failure of the Government to address the problem which, as I have said, the Minister first suggested needed to be considered way back on 14 July last year. As far as the National Party is concerned, we are glad that the Minister has at least moved away from some of the arbitrary measures that are included in that first statement. Honourable members will recall that he reversed his position on the export of feed wheat. On the coalition side there is a total acceptance of the need to preserve the powers of the Wheat Board as the sole export marketer.

There is concern among members of my Party at the impact that the changed domestic arrangements will have, particularly in the light of that advice from Clinton Condon, the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board. It is very important for those growers that in the changes there be sympathy for the preservation of the Australian Wheat Board as a strong domestic trader. When even that authority is at risk, the attitude of the Minister in trying to play this Bill for politics and not for the interests of the wheat growers becomes paramount.

Let us go beyond that to what the Government is trying to do. Over some little while it has not just been because of the fundamental and arbitrary changes that the Government is introducing into this Bill that I have taken difference with the Government, but because of the way it is saying that everybody else is responsible for the present condition of the wheat industry. Any- body knowing and looking at the wheat industry should remember that it is not an industry which is necessarily always prosperous. In an analysis I made a little while ago of the situation of wheat growers, I found that in the 1987-88 financial year 50 per cent of Australian wheat growers earned less than $130 a week. This is the industry that is being arbitrarily changed. It is this industry that the Minister is saying does not need the protection of the Australian Wheat Board as far as the domestic market is concerned. Between 1982-83 and 1987-88, the wheat price per tonne declined from $151 to $102. Of course the Minister says that it is all the responsibility of those big bad Americans, and I will come to that in a moment. The reality is that prices have declined and more than 50 per cent of wheat growers earn under $130 a week, far less than the basic wage. Over the period 1983-84 to 1986-87 wheat growers' terms of trade fell by 10 per cent, while real net farm incomes declined by 75 per cent. So we have an industry with a lot of very marginal producers who are affected by drought and the decline in the wheat price and whose real net farm incomes have declined by 75 per cent.

The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics estimates that average real net farm incomes in 1977-78 dollars for Australian wheat farms, classed as family farms, fell from approximately $71,000 in 1981-82 to $12,200 in 1986-87. From the beginning of the Australian Labor Party's period in office to 1986-87 net farm income fell by 83 per cent. This is the industry we are talking about. It is not an affluent industry. In an electorate such as that of the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher), where seasons have been adverse, many wheat growers are in a parlous state. Over the period 1977-78 to 1985-86 farm debt doubled in nominal terms and increased by 40 per cent in real terms. Here we have an industry that is, and has been, in an extraordinarily difficult circumstance. While the prospects in the international market might presently be bolstered by bad seasons, predominantly in the United States, the situation in Australia has been deteriorating and it is in that climate that the Minister has been imposing his arbitrary change on the industry. If people think this is in respect of only the wheat grower, they need only to look at the papers this morning to see that John Shearer Ltd, Australia's largest agricultural machinery manufacturer, is going to shut its doors. It is not only the wheat grower who will be affected, it is also those involved in producing agricultural machinery. If we look at the statistics for purchases of new machinery, we see that they too have gone down.

The reality is that seasons and markets are unpredictable for agricultural producers and there has been and is significant uncertainty for the wheat growers, against which in the past they have looked to the Wheat Board to provide them with some form of insurance. If we look at the Australian wheat industry and the export scene, we also see a picture somewhat different from the rhetoric that has emerged from the Minister at the table and other Ministers in the Government. Australia is not a major exporter in comparison to other countries. It is true that our exports are significant; they totalled $1.71 billion last year, or 4.2 per cent of Australian exports, produced by about 38,000 farmers. The reality is that our seasons, and the attractiveness of producing wheat, have meant a significant variation both in the number of hectares sown and in the volume of production.

What concerns me, as a farmer and somebody who has been involved initially as a wheat lumper and in subsequent years in various forms of agricultural production, is that there has always been in the Australian wheat industry a guarantee that through the Wheat Board there would be at least in one agricultural industry a fundamental base structure, a floor if you like, in the market. From that, farmers have been able to make some assessment of their future.

The difficulty in the Minister's proposal with respect to the United States is not that we disagree that the export enhancement program (EEP) has been anything other than disastrous for world wheat prices, but that the Government has concentrated excessively on that one source of influence and ignored, in at least its recent rhetoric, so much of the impact of the common agricultural policy (CAP) of the European Community. The reality is that in 1977-78 the European Community was a net importer of 18.2 million tonnes. As a result of the CAP, by 1988-89 the European Community was a net exporter of 25 million tonnes. In other words, it had swung from being a net importer to a major exporter, and that is distinctly a product of the CAP.

Of course there are problems as far as Australia is concerned, with our dependence upon being able to set a price structure. We need friends in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to help us, and in relation to that the members of the coalition totally endorse the actions of the Government in establishing the Cairns Group. But as an Australian, I felt sad that the Minister persistently undertook, even on a personal level, attacks against the American Vice-President. The reality is that we have to argue the cause by virtue of fact and not emotion. One does not go about damning the Vice-President of the United States; one tries to ensure that the facts presented to him are accurate. If the advice given to me is correct, then I understand that the figures shown to the Vice-President reflected only a relatively short period of years. In relation to that period the argument of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was correct but, if we go back to a few years before, Australia was a much smaller exporter and, according to the American briefing for the Vice-President, Australia's case failed because we did not go back to that earlier period. If that is so, we have to ensure that everyone knows that there is a demonstrable impact on Australian wheat returns not only from EEP but also from the European Community's price support program, which for so long has made life difficult for us. The reality is that the European Community and the United States have borne down on prices to a very significant degree. If the advice of the American Vice-President or of anybody in the European Community suggests that they have not done so, one need only turn to some of the information that is available in official publications in both arenas that shows something of that. For example, the General Accounting Office of the White House in a brief of March 1987 said:
In retrospect it appears that Argentina, Australia and Canada have all been adversely affected by the EEP.
On 28 April this year I understand that the President of the North American Export Grain Association, a Mr Steven McCoy, said:

The United States could better achieve its goal of competitiveness by lowering loan rates, reducing acreage set aside for major crops, realigning target prices and giving farmers more flexibility in what they can plant.

My concern at some of the emotional rhetoric about the Vice-President is that instead of our going back to him and setting out the facts and explaining to him the impact on Australian exporters and on those of other countries-as mentioned in that article quoted from the General Accounting Office it has impacted on Argentina, Canada and other exporters-the Government has failed because it has not done that. Because of the rhetoric, and in part I suspect in a reaction to what the Americans saw as an unusually personal attack on their Vice-President, we have had another wheat sale today to the Soviet Union.

There is no argument on this side of the House about the effect of EEP. There is argument as to whether sufficient facts were presented before the Vice-President and whether the rhetoric against the common agricultural policy of the European Community has been sufficient. Particularly when one sees the extent to which both in the US and the European Community there is to be a significant increase in acreage and tonnage for the future, the situation is critical. It is in that climate of a corrupt world market, of uncertainty in the ability of the Wheat Board to trade domestically, that the Minister comes into the House with an inadequate Bill.

I regard it as a tragedy for wheat growers that no member of the Labor Party when speaking on this Bill has highlighted the uncertain predicament of the domestic Australian wheat producer. Most Australian wheat producers are family farmers. Most of them do not have the expertise or the ability to engage in marketing. Since the late 1940's the Australian Wheat Board has been the major marketing arm. It is critical that the Minister and the Government accept responsibility to ensure that the Wheat Board remains a strong domestic trader. It is critical that the Government understand that with the present corruption of the world market-place, unless the Wheat Board is allowed and encouraged to maximise the price received for Australian exports the Australian wheat grower will suffer. Sadly, given the climate, and the variations in the climate, so much depends upon whether the United States has a good season. We all know that the demand from the Soviet Union and China tends to set world prices. It is not only the EEP and CAP that effect prices, but they certainly serve to bear down on world prices. I am disappointed to hear from my American contacts that Vice-President Quayle has not been satisfied with the arithmetic presented by the Australian Government. If that is so, I blame the Government for its inadequate presentation.

The Minister has to understand that this legislation has serious deficiencies. We seek to amend it. I hope the Government will accept those amendments because they are proposed in an effort to present inadequate legislation in a more adequate form. Above all, the Minister must go to the State Ministers and attempt to get some complementary legislation, otherwise the Australian wheat industry will be totally disadvantaged in the domestic market after 1 July this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleeland Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say, with great regret, that I did not hear one mention of micro-economic reform in the speech made by the Leader of the National Party of Australia, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair). There was no debate about why the legislation should not proceed. We heard much about the Vice-President of the United States of America for nearly 10 minutes and the United States of America's subsidisation program, which has nothing to do with this legislation. There was much discussion about the income of wheat farmers, the effects of drought on wheat farmers, the effect of the subsidisation program on the European Community, and the effect of the United States policy on our wheat farmers' incomes, but there was no discussion of micro-economic reform or the fundamental principles of deregulation. So the National Party does not have a view of micro-economic reform. It does not have a view on what this legislation is about. It was not discussed at all by the Leader of the National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: This is important legislation because it reveals fundamental differences in economic management between the Government and the Opposition. It discloses the fact that those on the Opposition benches who want to call themselves monetarists, free marketeers, the Friedman theory carriers in this House, do not believe their own rhetoric. It discloses that the Opposition, when it comes to micro-economic reform, is a very shallow and hollow Opposition. It discloses that if it should ever be in government in this country, should its members ever grace the treasury bench, the shallowness and hollowness in opposition would be carried forward. In fact, members of the Opposition would be too frightened to make any decent micro-economic reform. They are, after all, the people who admire Margaret Thatcher. They are the people who admire what Ronald Reagan has done to America. They are the people who run on that kind of rhetoric. Yet when we place before them a proposal to deregulate the domestic wheat market-not the export wheat market-they shy away. They cannot get their act together as a coalition, yet they want to talk to us about their togetherness and their lying in the same lovely bed. We know that to be a nonsense. A headline in the Sun Herald last night throws that idea right out the door and makes a mockery of what the Opposition is saying.

The Opposition likes to support the concept of perfect competition, that wonderful economic theory that tacitly assumes that there is a perfect world where there are many buyers and sellers, where there is perfect knowledge in the market-place, where there are educated consumers and no product differentiation, and no interference with prices by governments. That is the theory that the Opposition runs with-perfect competition. From its rhetoric, it would like to see a market-place where there is no government at all. That is what Opposition members say. They want Australians to believe that that is their economic philosophy. That is the nonsense they go on with all the time, but the reality is that no such market exists, has ever existed, or is ever likely to exist. Governments need to regulate and, through legislation, to force a level playing field.

What does the regulation of our domestic wheat market mean? In the first place it is a nonsense, because it does not exist. The 20 per cent of the Australian wheat market which is called the domestic market is mostly a black market. Anyone who knows about Australia's wheat industry-and it is obvious that the National Party does not; it is very ignorant because it does not seek the facts-would know of certain practices in that industry. When I lived in Cohuna in the Murray Valley for many years, trucks would come from Victoria during the wheat season, cross the Murray River and travel to Koondrook and into Barham. There they would then stop and put a new prime mover on and bring the wheat back across the river and sell it on the domestic market under section 92 of the Constitution, the free trade section. That is the domestic wheat market. That is what is happening now. It has been going on for years. There is no regulated market. Victorian farmers are laughing on television at the nonsense the National Party is going on about. Farmers there have said that they cart by truck now. They do not really care whether this legislation goes through because they are doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name one.

—We hear absolute nonsense from the honourable member for Mallee, who would not know economic theory from practice if he walked across it on a dark night. What is the Government doing? Some think this is the end of the world. The deregulation Opposition, which is going to take micro-economic reform on its ear if it gets into government and deregulate anything and everything, cannot handle a 20 per cent deregulation of the domestic market.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is very simple. The provisions include a continuation of the monopoly export powers of the Australian Wheat Board. That has been the main element of our export wheat marketing program for many years. Other features include the enhancement of the commercial base and powers of the Wheat Board which will thereby boost domestic and international competitiveness. It will remove the remaining restrictions on the private market, most of which have been whittled down over the years.

I am concerned about the so-called de- regulation of the transportation of wheat by rail. I am not frightened to express that concern in this House because I am concerned about the increased transportation of wheat on rural roads by heavy transports. I do not believe that transports pay their fair resource cost on the use of the roads. I do not believe that if there were a massive move of wheat onto roads that our roads would stand the extra traffic, or that the users of the roads would pay their fair share of the cost and the cost of the damage done to those rural roads. If the playing field were, in fact, level, if road transports were paying their fair cost of that road resource and were competing fairly against rail, my concerns would be somewhat mitigated. However, I believe the Government is on the right track in its attitude to opening up the market-place. The Government is on the right track in suggesting to the State rail authorities that they need to have a good look at the way they are currently running their organisations in order to get extra efficiencies in them. It is for that reason that I support the Government's legislation, although I have that concern. I hope that there will be further discussion when the tripartite body is established-Government, unions and rail organisations-about the Government's intention on the rail transportation issue. Tonight, four or five members of the so-called coalition will vote against this Bill.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before proceeding with my remarks on the Bills currently before the House, I should perhaps inform the House that there are some students from the Seymour Technical High School in the gallery. That school is located in my electorate. Those students have had a wonderful day today. They have met with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair), the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), Senator Powell, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly), and the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and they have sat in the Cabinet room. They have had a wonderful afternoon in the Parliament and I am very pleased that those people from my electorate have been able to come here today. I might add that Seymour is a wonderful town.
—They have a great member representing them.

—As the honourable member for Denison says, they do have a good member representing them, but that is because I represent a fine electorate. It is a wonderful electorate, with wonderful people and wonderful schools and teachers.

SPEECH.PARA: Before dinner I was discussing the wheat deregulation legislation. I referred to the great disruption that this legislation is causing in the Opposition parties in this country. I note that the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) will be following me in this debate, and I will be very interested to hear his views, because I know he is a member of the Opposition who does firmly believe in deregulation across the board and I know that he is not intimidated by the agrarian socialists-members of the former Country Party, now the National Party of Australia. The honourable member for O'Connor is prepared to voice his views.

Whilst the honourable member for O'Connor and I might have our disagreements from time to time-probably more often than not-I am pleased to say that on this occasion he and I stand in the same position. We understand the benefits that will flow to Australian wheat growers from what I regard as being probably a very minor deregulative program and a very minor micro-economic reform.

The reality is that the Industries Assistance Commission report in fact called for much more deregulation than the Government is proposing. One could argue in this House that perhaps the export monopoly should be deregulated. Those of us who believe in a deregulatory market could well argue that we should not be satisfied with pretending that we are deregulating a market which, de facto, through the black market, has been deregulated for many years indeed. The fact that the Opposition Parties are so disrupted by this legislation is indicative of their inability to provide a unified front-should they ever win government-in relation to the hard decisions which governments must make from time to time.

I note with great interest the suggestions in Victoria that there has been some sort of a marriage between the National Party and the Liberal Party in Victoria. I watched with interest the Leader of the Opposition wandering around Victoria saying that there was a wonderful new relationship between those two conservative parties, that they now had a joint Senate ticket. In relation to the recent National Party conference in Warrnambool, I read with interest the comments made about Pat McNamara and Jeff Kennett walking out almost arm in arm, saying that the two parties were now married, that there were no problems and that they could now put forward policies because they had agreed on major issues.

Of course, the sort of exercise that we have before the House today absolutely shatters that concept. Certainly, in the north-east of Victoria, I do not believe that the National Party members will not field candidates. I happen to have good close contacts with the National Party in my electorate, and the National Party branches in my electorate are making it very clear that they will not accept a suggestion that National Party members cannot stand in rural electorates against other candidates-whether from the Liberal Party or the Labor Party. Those National Party members in my electorate have made it very clear to me, and very clear to other people in the electorate, that they will field candidates against people from any other political party whenever they see fit to do so. For that reason, I do not believe that the so-called marriage will hold; in fact, it is one of the great jokes of Victorian politics at the moment.

Before dinner I expressed my concern about the potential for increased road traffic due to haulage of wheat. That is the only concern that I have with the entire legislation. I do not criticise the Government for the level of road funding, as some members in this House have done. As to my electorate, with the Hume Highway running up through the centre, in three or four years time, due to the efforts of this Government, we will see the completion of the Hume freeway. This is due to the Government's commitment to build a major national road network. The Hume Highway will be a freeway from the outskirts of Melbourne to the Victorian border. Only several sections are left to be done. One of those is around Euroa, which is in my electorate, and work is currently under way there to complete that section of the freeway. Another section that has yet to be completed is the Wangaratta by-pass, but that work is currently under way and I hope that it will be com- pleted in the next three years.

However, as to the secondary roads in my electorate, residents are very concerned about the increase in articulated vehicle traffic which is now occurring, with many owner-drivers trying to avoid the weighbridges on the Hume Highway. The damage that those vehicles are doing to our road network systems, particularly the Melba Highway and the Kinglake-Flowerdale Road, is quite severe. It would be very worrying if those so-called B-doubles and larger sized articulated vehicles, carrying quite heavy tonnages of wheat, started tearing up rural roads, with the drivers of those vehicles not putting back into the system the necessary funds to compensate for the damage caused. With insufficient resources being provided by the users of those roads. The Government will have to monitor the position to ensure that roads are not thus damaged. I certainly have some sympathy with those people who have raised this concern.

However, this legislation should not be rejected simply on those grounds. We should not forget that only last week the State Rail Authority of New South Wales successfully tendered for the cartage of the entire New South Wales grain crop for 1989-90. The Authority tendered successfully against five major road hauliers. That indicates very clearly to the House that the proposition that the proposed deregulatory program would mean that all grain would be transported on the roads is a myth and a nonsense. It was demonstrated quite clearly only last week that rail is obviously the preferred method of bulk transportation of grain. I do not intend to speak at length as I know that there are many speakers who wish to follow me. I suspect that we will have a rather late night in trying to get through this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't stop now.

—I still have my friendly audience behind me but I will not be encouraged. I will ignore the requests that I go on. The reality is that this is major legislation. It is major in that it discloses and exposes for all and sundry the vast difference between the Government and the Opposition in relation to major economic management issues. The present position indicates to everyone that the Government is unified, that it comprises a unified collective of people who are not frightened to make hard decisions and who will undertake what is necessary to bring urgent micro-economic reform to this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The raw divisions within the Opposition have been exposed-not just in this Parliament but throughout Australia. The present situation shows quite clearly that when it comes to making hard decisions members of the Opposition cannot take it. They will not make such decisions. It is typical of their whole policy approach. They talk in rhetoric about policy but never put the facts or figures on the table for debate. For that, as always, they stand condemned. This legislation, as I have said, exposes once and for all their inability as a group to have a marriage and the inability of the Thatcherites and the Friedmanites in the Opposition-the new dries of the Liberal Party-to cope. They cannot cope with the agrarian socialists of the National Party. In the Liberal Party the Peter Costellos and Professor Kemps are rolling long-standing Liberal Party members of this House. Possibly this will happen at the weekend and new dries will be coming in. They are extreme right wing Thatcher fans, and the agrarian socialists just cannot cope with that. They will not sit back and be part of a marriage with a party which has within it these dries who, if they are serious, would undertake much deregulation in rural areas and go further down the deregulatory path in the major rural areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait till Professor Kemp gets here.

—That is right; just wait until Professor Kemp or Costello gets here. We have seen nothing yet on dry views. There are some lulus standing for preselection in the Liberal Party at the moment. This will just further exacerbate the divisions in the now tattered Opposition. I look forward to next week, when the preselections are over and the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) and the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Shipton) will have been rolled and the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) will be looking for another seat somewhere because he is not game to stand for the seat he was elected for in the first place. He has told the people in that seat that he does not want them. I look forward to next week, after the preselection, when we come back and see just how divided the lot on the other side is. This legislation further demonstrates that.

SPEECH.PARA: I will listen with interest to the honourable member for O'Connor. I know that we disagree on certain issues, but on this issue we stand united on the basics and the fundamental economic principles of it. I congratulate him on the principled stand he has taken. I will welcome him when he crosses the floor and I will hold a seat next to me here so that we can sit together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wheat marketing legislation which is before the Parliament today has been introduced to replace the expiring Wheat Marketing Act of 1984. If this legislation does not pass the Parliament before June 1989, the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) will have no legislative base and although it can continue for a limited period there will be no obligation for government to provide the guarantees necessary to allow the Board to make the large borrowings it needs to make to fund the first advance payments, which are fundamental to the Board's performance and attractiveness to wheat growers. Consequently, this legislation can be viewed both in philosophical terms and from the standpoint of the practical effect it will have on wheat growers' incomes.

SPEECH.PARA: In philosophical terms, the debate revolves around the degree of regulation and government business activity which is appropriate for Australia in the 1990s. The Liberal Party of Australia recognises that any regulatory activity that artificially increases the costs of the goods we produce is bad and will contribute further to the phenomenon of our international debt, which at $120 billion now exceeds that of most banana republics. Whether it be the regulation of our labour markets, which creates wage increases which are not related to productivity, thus inflating our cost structures and reducing our standards of living, or the controls of our waterfront, airlines and coastal shipping, the results are always the same. Cost increases and inefficient and sometimes fraudulent work practices arise. Both management and the work force, secure in the knowledge that they have no competition, continue to pass costs on to the captive consumer.

Mr Deputy Speaker, this philosophical point is not remote to wheat growers' incomes. Wheat growers are the traditional consumers. It is they who stand at the end of the income queue and must measure their profits after all these other regulated sectors take their share. When in recent years Australia's economic activity went into upturn as the result of increases in rural returns, it was the trade unions and their manufacturing employers who were first in the queue, using the arbitration system to share in those returns. Before bank managers could be repaid, farmers were confronted with massive inflation to the cost of all their production inputs.

Whilst the Hawke Government recognises this situation and consequently announced its third term of office as the term of micro-economic reform, its successes have been few and far between. It has failed to privatise such government institutions as Qantas Airways Ltd, Australian Airlines and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia. It has failed to introduce meaningful competition within the operations of Telecom Australia and Australia Post. It has failed to deregulate the labour market, the waterfront and coastal shipping-all areas which directly affect the cost of production of wheat growers.

All the Government's success in deregulation has been in the area of our-the conservatives'-constituency, such as financial services and agricultural marketing. All the claimed success of this Government has been because the coalition has stood by its beliefs and been prepared to assist the Government with its limited program. This is in stark contrast with the Australian Labor Party's performance in opposition. When led by the present Treasurer (Mr Keating), it opposed every attempt by the Fraser Government to proceed in these areas and even cancelled some of those Fraser Government decisions when first in government.

This Opposition-the Liberal-National Party coalition-accepts its national responsibility. In this legislation we have even drawn the Government screaming to the barrier by insisting that deregulation of the sales component of the domestic wheat industry be accompanied by deregulation of freight and handling in terms of both competition for State government institutions and the labour they employ. When the inevitable change of government occurs at the next election, it will be interesting to test the resolve of some people in the Labor Party to support our mandate for deregulation and privatisation which will similarly affect the Labor Party's constituency of labour and the bureaucracy.

Nevertheless, Mr Deputy Speaker, as the member representing the largest wheat producing electorate in Australia and as a wheat grower myself, my responsibility has been to ensure, as much as a member of the Opposition is able to, the protection of my constituents from any harmful effects of this legislation. I made that judgment not on the basis of people's prejudice but on the basis of where I genuinely perceived they would be at a financial disadvantage. It was therefore my responsibility first to identify their problems in order of priority, hoping that I could correct the most important, if not all of them. Consequently, in considering the press announcements of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), I decided that his intention to dilute the Australian Wheat Board's sole export power by approving of certain private stockfeed export sales was a very large threat and a matter of great concern in my electorate. It was considered the thin end of the wedge. There is no doubt in my mind that a total export monopoly is essential to protect our wheat exports, in the present world market conditions.

I was delighted, therefore, to be a member of an Opposition select committee that set, as a condition of Opposition support for this legislation, that the Australian Wheat Board maintain its existing export monopoly. I was therefore gratified when, in introducting the legislation, the Minister indicated that the AWB would retain this power and, what is more, will never again be confronted with a sunset clause which would put the AWB's export monopoly at risk.

Secondly, I concerned myself with the guaranteed minimum price (GMP) and underwriting arrangements. The 1984 legislation calculated the guaranteed minimum price by using a moving three-year average based primarily on historic prices. The Government then provided what was effectively a 95 per cent underwriting guarantee. The use of historic prices ensured that in falling markets there was a possibility that the GMP would exceed the actual pool returns and government would then be called upon to provide its guarantee. Such a contribution occurred as a result of the 1986-87 season at a cost to government of approximately $176m. This money was of great assistance to farmers in those difficult times, yet over the decades it was the first government contribution.

The 1989 legislation removes the three-year moving average and the 95 per cent underwriting, replacing them with a single year estimate and a initial 90 per cent underwriting which will reduce to a 80 per cent level over five years. I have constantly argued in all forums for retention of the 1984 guaranteed minimum price underwriting arrangements and warned my constituents of the implications in the new proposals.

I am pleased to join with grain grower representatives in supporting Opposition amendments to increase the underwriting level to a flat 95 per cent and to remove the 1993 sunset clause on this underwriting commitment. The Minister is obliged by the legislation to take account of the advice of the AWB and the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) in regard to this estimate. I can only conclude that he will maintain the estimate at fair and reasonable levels. The immediate effect of the removal of historic price data in the present rising market is that the first advance will be much higher. Using the ABARE forecast of a net pool return of $207 per tonne, the first advance calculated on the 1984 formula would be $139 per tonne and under the new 1989 formula $167 per tonne.

However, there is no doubt that the GMP and the first advance will now be much more volatile. Falls will be as abrupt as rises. This gives much better market signals than have previously been received. I believe that the prospect of underwriting payouts is dead. It must be obvious that a single-year ministerial estimate made in October, just before harvest, is unlikely to be 10 per cent or even 5 per cent incorrect before most wheat is sold. I do not think the Minister has too much concern in conceding that point. In his second reading speech the Minister-and I want him to take close notice of this-said:

I am aware that the averaging arrangements in the previous GMP scheme provided support to growers in circumstances of extreme market downturn such as in 1986-87. If such a crisis were to occur again the Government would need to give close consideration to special support arrangements for the industry.

I really believe that that is a matter of great concern and one we should address in the legislation. If this is the Minister's considered view, I believe he should include a clause in this legislation to provide legislative effect to his observations, thus guaranteeing some financial support after a precipitous price reduction. I am not suggesting for a moment that there needs to be any proposal that affects other than the sort of crash that occurred in 1986-87. But during the 1982-83 drought the Fraser Government saw fit to introduce massive fodder subsidies to protect the Australian breeding stock. This was to the great benefit of the Australian economy, and also the Hawke Labor Government, which came to office shortly before the drought breaking rains and was able to benefit from the immediate economic advantages to Australia of our rural industries being able to get back into full production because farmers had breeding stock on their properties.

There is need for legislative protection of our wheat industry in a crisis such as occurred in 1986-87. Furthermore, confidence must be maintained to ensure the maintenance of national export income. It is easy to say that market indicators will survive but if we drive too many people out of the wheat industry we will miss out on our regular clientele and our export income. I hope the Minister will consider such a proposal. I do not think in the very near future it would be a great cost to government; it would just give some security for the very bad year that pops up once in a while.

Another matter of considerable interest to me, as a resident of the most remote wheat growing State, is the actual membership of the Australian Wheat Board. During debate on the 1984 legislation I took a strong stand on wheat grower representation. I believe I contributed to the eventual decision to create producer selection committees, which I still think is a very good approach. The current legislation provides for the appointment of eight of the board's eleven members by a selection committee which the Grains Council of Australia will appoint.

To better guarantee the representation of wheat growers, the Opposition has proposed an amendment that five of those eight, and the chairman, who is a ministerial appointment, be wheat growers. It will be up to the Grains Council to decide from which State these representatives are appointed. However, considering the longevity of this legislation, I would have preferred that direct representation be given to each State. Nevertheless, I accept the decision that has been made on this issue.

The next issue of importance to me is the issue that has stood head and shoulders above all others in terms of public debate-that is, domestic deregulation. The prospect for the continued credibility of any political party or organisation which calls upon the workers of Australia to accept substantial deregulation of their protected centralised wage fixing system whilst it is prepared to support a price fixing mechanism for the principal component in the manufacture of bread, is of course beyond consideration. Any party that put forward the deregulations proposals that have been put forward and then demanded that its constituencies not be harmed would have no credibility at all.

Forgoing this philosophical point, this issue did not warrant the level of exposure it received, for two simple reasons. Firstly, this legislation is not a proposal to deregulate the 80 per cent of national wheat production that goes to export. It is not 1935 revisited. As I have already described, due to the successful efforts of the coalition the Wheat Board's export monopoly is even more secure than in the past. Secondly, the domestic market was deregulated to all intents and purposes in the 1984 legislation.

Since the introduction of that legislation wheat growers have had the right to trade directly in both stockfeed and human consumption wheat. There have been no controls on the quantity traded or the price negotiated. Stockfeed wheat has been traded purely with the constraint that purchasers must buy, for approximately $2.50 per tonne, a permit to cover the collection of levies covering matters like research. What is more, as a consequence, farmers have voted with their feet and 90 per cent of stockfeed wheat is now traded privately. Sale of human consumption wheat was more constrained inasmuch as that, although wheat growers could negotiate privately, the proceeds of the sale were then processed through the Wheat Board on normal pooling conditions, with the Wheat Board deducting charges notwithstanding that it had provided no services.

Persons wishing to process their own wheat for such purposes as organic flour were forced to repurchase their own wheat at a direct net cost of approximately $40 per tonne. That is no encouragement for people to go out and develop the niche markets that are needed. In the terms of the 1989 legislation, deregulation means that wheat growers who choose to deal privately with flour mills will in future get the cheque in the mail. That is hardly an earth shattering move. That the previous arrangements were not supported by farmers is evidenced by the fact that only 11 per cent of human consumption wheat has been traded privately while 90 per cent of stockfeed wheat has been traded privately during this period.

Many claims have been made as to the effect on pool proceeds that will result from the Board's loss of revenue in this area. In my electorate these claims at times have been as high as $50 per tonne. The Minister's second reading speech clearly identifies that the worst one-year effect was $2.93 per tonne in 1986-87. I have seen the calculation sheets for that, and they are correct.

When one checks the legislation and understands the principles of the formula for calculating the regulated domestic human consumption price, which is also a historic price formula, it is clear that in a falling market the domestic price lags above the export price but in a rising market, as at present, the domestic price lags below the export price. On 25 April 1989 the domestic price was $20.69 below the world export price. In other words when the Wheat Board sells a tonne of wheat domestically at present it loses approximately $20 compared with selling the same wheat to an overseas customer. Over time the pool proceeds have won and lost but the result has probably been neutral.

Nevertheless, partly because of this perception, the Opposition was not prepared again to see the Government further impose its one-sided approach to micro-economic reforms upon the rural sector. Another condition which the coalition imposed was a demand for the further deregulation of the domestic market to be accompanied by de- regulation of freight and handling within this industry. I have been a long-time proponent of that. It is not by any initiative of this Government or this Minister that wheat growers for the first time will see competition in that component of their industry which represents 22 per cent of their costs based on free on board values or 45 per cent cost, insurance and freight. Even the cost of overseas shipping are greatly inflated by the intransigence of our waterfront unions. Overseas shipping companies price Australia as though it was a war zone. One shipper once said to me, `Up in the Red Sea we lose our ships; down in Australia we never know if we are going to get them back'.

It is the Opposition which caused the Government to put its micro-economics where its mouth is. The coalition welcomes the inclusion of sections 7 and 88 which give the Wheat Board the power to grant contracts and give immunity from State regulations to private transporters and grain handlers who can provide these services more cheaply. In my electorate there are numerous examples of price differentials between the cost of regulated rail and road transport. A classic example involves the centres of Kojonup and Broomehill, towns some 25 miles apart. Kojonup is served by road and the freight rate is $8.60 per tonne. Broomehill, which is on rail, must pay $11.60. Yet both are the same distance to port. There is no theory in these prices, just plain facts. I could give many more examples.

In Western Australia we have been extremely fortunate that our Main Roads Department has a very innovative approach to truck configurations. From my own farm I am entitled to cart-and through the highways of Perth-40-tonne loads. In fact, they go up and down those highways without trouble. An ordinary truck contributes 30 per cent of its revenue in one tax or another. On a 1,000 mile journey loaded one way on 2,000 mile round trip some years ago I calculated the sales tax on my tyres at 50 cents a tonne. The fact is that if they chose, as has occurred in New South Wales, the railways can compete, but the price has to be right and the farmers must be the beneficiaries.

I welcome this legislation in general. I want to see the alterations made that the Opposition proposes. In general, we have achieved something in the long term for farmers where the profits will certainly be with them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation marks a further step by this Government to free up Australian primary industries on the domestic market. In his second reading speech the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) indicated that whilst some farmers might be determined to resist the change, the wheat industry has been undergoing significant changes in response to influences and pressures in the market-place at large anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation continues the Government's micro-economic reform program. The process of mircro-economic reform is aimed at developing the industrial structure which best utilises Australia's resources of labour, land and capital. However, it is not done without affecting the status quo. It is not done without affecting the perceived status quo. We contend that in general this will be beneficial, even though the initial response will always cause some reaction. There is nothing particularly strange about this.

While there is a fair degree of acceptance of the advantages to accrue to the wheat industry from this legislation, there is nevertheless some disquiet among some sections of the community about some feared consequences of the deregulation of the transport of grains. As the House would know, the situation with respect to the transport of wheat varies from State to State. Transport costs, even where related to rail, also vary from system to system. As the Minister has indicated, the Wheat Marketing Bill contains measures which will allow traders and the Australian Wheat Board to operate without the constraint of State laws. The Federal Government has already removed restrictions on the Australian National Line's South Australian operations. When the transport of grain was deregulated in New South Wales the State Rail Authority won the tender and was therefore able to move the entire New South Wales wheat crop.

While the report of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport recommended a freeing-up of grain transport, it is seen by some rail unions to be flawed. It may well be that there will not be a significant shift in the transport of grain from rail to road, but the rail unions remain unconvinced. This is especially so in Victoria. I happen to believe that this matter will need to be kept under very close scrutiny. There would be no merit, in social terms, in large quantities of grain being moved to export terminals by road. For one thing, this would increase the wear and tear on the road system, with a consequent rise in the cost to taxpayers and ratepayers of the burden of maintenance and construction. The Minister assures us that on the evidence available to him this circumstance is unlikely to occur because of the cost savings of rail over road.

In the Ararat Advertiser of 2 May 1989 the honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker)-I notice he is in the House-is reported as rubbishing the arguments put forward by rail unions that job losses would result if the wheat industry were to be de- regulated. He is reported as saying that the rail unions had indirectly forced the loss over the last decade of the livelihood of thousands of wheat farmers and employees. He is further quoted as saying that the railway unions have bled the wheat farmers through their cosy transport monopoly.

I happen to know that in recent years V/Line has undergone a marked series of changes in the transport of wheat. These changes have benefited the wheat industry. For instance, the number of wagons used for grain haulage in 1981 was 5,437. These were GYs; they were a small, inefficient unit. Since 1988 this has been reduced to 730. Those are the VHGYs. The number of locomotives used in 1981 was 77. In the post-1988 period it has been 33. Whereas in 1981 the largest train sizes were 22 VHGY wagons, they are now 50 VHGY wagons. The crew size has been reduced from three persons to two. Cartage in hopper wagons has grown from 51.8 per cent to 100 per cent. The percentage of grain dedicated to VHGY wagons jumped from 61 per cent in 1981 to 100 per cent currently.

Extensive use is made of integrated road usage. In Victoria during this time there has also been a marked decline in the labour usage in State rail. From 1971-72 until 1985-86 labour productivity in V/Line has doubled. According to the Victorian State Minister for Transport, the Hon. Jim Kennan, there will be a further reduction in the work force and an expected increase in productivity. As one who has a large body of workers in Ballarat and Ararat I know how painful these changes have been, but I also recognise that they are proud men. They are proud and dedicated rail workers. They have not bled farmers dry. Instead, they have been prepared to modernise their industry. They also happen to believe in it-and this is something union knockers, such as those on the other side of the House, just do not understand. If there is resistance to change by the rail workers, it is not unique. Why would it be? They try to preserve their jobs. That they would sometimes like to defend their territory and established practices makes them no different in principle from the wheat farmers. It is a terrible pity that the kind of understanding shown by the National Party to some wheat growers could not be balanced by an equal concern to understand the feelings and concerns of rail workers. In the upshot of the deregulation of the transport of wheat, convenience and cost will be the deciders. Rail is still more efficient. I believe farmers and my local government leaders will bear this in mind.

I wish to refer to the slap in the face that Australian farmers have received from the United States Administration by its quite unjustifiable decision to use export subsidies with the sale of 1 1/2 million tonnes of wheat to the Soviet Union. In the wake of the recent visit to this country of the Vice-President of the United States, Mr Dan Quayle, during which he denied the export enhancement program (EEP) was resulting in any damage to Australia, this decision of the United States shows Vice-President Quayle to be either an ostrich or a goose. Perhaps he ought to take gander at the facts. As has been pointed out by the Minister for Trade Negotiations (Mr Duffy), there is simply no justification for this United States action. We know what happens when the sale of 1 1/2 million tonnes under the EEP precedes a sale of 1 1/2 million tonnes at the going rate. The effect of putting the two together is that Australian farmers and farmers in the leading export countries are the ones who suffer. As the Minister pointed out, there is no justification for this action.

The buoyant state of world markets indicates a healthy demand for wheat. All this has done for some years is to cause damage to us and other wheat export nations. It may be true that the US is using the export enhancement program to apply pressure to the Europeans to force them to reduce their practice of subsidising primary industry products; a practice which grossly distorts world trade in these goods and causes havoc in the economies of smaller exporting countries. However, we, along with other members of the Cairns group, are caught fair and square in the crossfire. It is the major commodity exporters, our producers and economies which suffer.

As has already been mentioned, Australia's share of the world markets has decreased by 45 per cent while the US share in the market of wheat has increased by 48 per cent. It is no surprise that this can be attributed to a large degree to unfair trading practices, such as the EEP.

Change in any industry, as I said, is not achieved without the onset of misgivings and often resentment and resistance. Those of us who were here during the heady days of the changes to the dairy industry-the Kerin plan-will recall most vividly the heat generated by that debate around the country. The Minister was subjected to long and bitter attacks with emotion and rancour running high. He knew at the time that the situation was unsustainable, that maintenance of the then existing structures would result in disaster for the industry. The present situation attests to the wisdom of those changes for at least the dairy industry is just that-it is an industry, and a very good one, which is assured of a sound and profitable future.

I happen to believe that the decision to deregulate the wheat industry by opening up the domestic market to enable growers to choose to whom they wish to sell their wheat will result in a more dynamic industry with better returns to growers. These Bills are designed to introduce competition and efficiency in the marketing of wheat. Those farmers who do not wish to sell directly from the farm gate to a buyer may continue to use the pool. Changes to the AWB will enable it to function more commercially. It has been said that farmers will be at the mercy of a few large agribusinesses. I believe that the effects will be quite the contrary. After all, what farmer is going to sell his wheat for the cheapest price? With more takers the competition is between buyers. The seller will be the beneficiary. After all, it is not as though there has been no selling of wheat on the private market. Currently, 40 per cent of wheat sold on the domestic market is sold by the permit system. This comprises primarily stock feed wheat.

It has to be admitted that a number of growers have bypassed the Australian Wheat Board and sold outside the system. It should also be recognised that 80 per cent of Australia's crop is sold solely by the AWB for export and that will continue. It will not change. Protective devices are available for farmers. As I said, they can still use the pool system if they wish.

There has been argument that the quality of wheat sold will suffer when we move away from an AWB controlled monopoly. I believe that this argument is not sustainable because the monopoly pricing power of the AWB does not govern its power to influence the quality control of the industry. Such important functions as control, grading and classification will still be possible under the statutory marketing authority of the AWB.

I do not wish to continue my remarks further except to say that I support wholeheartedly the measures taken by the Minister in introducing this legislation to put the wheat industry on a far more commercial basis. I caution the Minister and the House to recognise that other people in the community have a concern. They are concerned that the benefits may damage their industry. I refer to the rail unions and the rail workers. I hope that there will be continuing negotiations and discussions with them so that they will be assured that their interests are being taken into consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity tonight to participate in this debate on the Wheat Marketing Bill and cognate Bills. I welcome also the opportunity to follow the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and compliment the reasoned and persuasive approach which he used in the House tonight in reference to these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: In my opening remarks I want to refer to a couple of closing remarks by the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren). Not surprisingly, the honourable member has called for some measure of negotiation to be entered into with those people indirectly affected by this legislation. He referred particularly to the railway unions. If the honourable member for Ballarat's plea for negotiation had been echoed by the Government in mapping out this legislation and if the Opposition had enjoyed a little more the confidence of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), and more negotiation between parties perhaps some of the discomfort that has been experienced by the Opposition in this debate would not have occurred.

Thankfully, all of us have childhood memories. We all have memories which for some inexplicable reason stay with us. For some of us they are memories of particularly momentous events; for others they are memories of things which we simply cannot shake off. I have long had a boyhood memory of feeding a winnower. I do not know why. The property I grew up on was not a grain growing property. My father always had a paddock which he turned into wheat so that he could cut some hay for the house cow and some wheat for the chooks-an experience with which the Minister can identify. I recall my father for some reason-perhaps simply because he wanted to instil into the family some measure of appreciation of what our forebears had gone through-taking my grandfather's stripper and winnower and turning part of the crop into hay and putting the grain from the stripper through the winnower.

As I listened to the debate last night I thought that a measure of winnowing would have done a great deal of good because there was an awful lot of cocky chaff caught up in the grain. I suspect that this has been a problem with this debate for the past 12 months. It has been very difficult in all of our electorates to separate the grain from the cocky chaff. I was distressed last night that in this chamber-which is the premium debating chamber of the land-we should be dealing with one of the nation's finest industries and treating it with scorn and derision. I was particularly distressed that the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) used the opportunity simply to pour scorn on the action being taken by the Opposition as it endeavoured responsibly to deal with the legislation before the House.

I am not critical of my colleagues in the National Party who may have difficulty, for sincerely held reasons, coming to terms with this legislation. Not only am I not critical; I welcome the fact that on this side of the House they are able to exercise whatever they feel their conscience bids them to do without recrimination. What I am critical of is that that freedom was treated so lightly by the Government last night. As I said earlier, it seemed to me that the husk, the kernel, of the debate was lost in the cocky chaff, as so often it has been around the electorate.

I rise representing one of South Australia's major wheat growing electorates. I have to say to the House, and to my electorate, that I will be voting for the Opposition amendments but will also be supporting, with the Liberal and National parties, the deregulation of the domestic market that has been so much the focus of this debate. Why? Because I believe that in voting for this legislation I will be voting for my wheat growers and for the new opportunities it will give them.

The coalition, in opposition in this House, has much to be proud of for the way it has dealt with this debate. As a result of our insistence and the assistance of such bodies as the Grains Council of Australia, the Minister has been forced out of the export market when earlier he had entertained the idea of exporting denatured feed wheat. As a result of our insistence and the assistance of the Grains Council, a more realistic level of guaranteed minimum price (GMP) is being offered to the industry than was originally intended. If the amendments, constructively and responsibly put to this House by the shadow Minister for primary industry-the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd)-are passed or supported by the Australian Democrats in the Senate, the realistic level of GMP that we believe ought to exist will be able to be legislated for.

The only real difficulty in this legislation for us has been in the level of domestic market deregulation. The problem has been that so many of our farmers have merely seen the cocky chaff of the word `deregulation' and failed to see the grain of the opportunities that deregulation would give them. The debate is about the domestic market, which is only 15 per cent of the crop. The Opposition parties have been prepared to entertain this level of deregulation not because we are enchanted with the word `deregulation' but because we see opportunities for grain growers in taking this particular course of action. The difficulty is that as soon as the cocky chaff word `deregulation' is thrown up into the wind everybody imagines that the proposal is to return the wheat industry to the 1930s.

The difficulty is even more insurmountable in my electorate of Wakefield, which is an area well known by the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Pratt) because he has farmed and continues to farm there-and in order to be even-handed, the same description applies to the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), who is sitting alongside him-since an industry known as Gulf Industries, pea grain purchasers, went broke. So Wakefield farmers immediately see deregulation as taking the wheat industry back to the 1930s or, alternatively, leaving them facing the same sort of uncertainty as the pea industry currently faces. Of course, that is nonsense; that is the cocky chaff.

The grain reality is that the Wheat Board continues to be in place, will be the sole exporter and will have 80 per cent of the crop locked up no matter what happens. I put it to the House that in the electorate of Wakefield the vast majority of my farmers will use the Wheat Board as the principal domestic seller of wheat because they prefer the security of the Wheat Board to the uncertainty of the free market. The point is that they will now have a choice. The Opposition's preparedness to support much of the Government's legislation is not in any sense an attack on the Wheat Board. We have nothing but commendation for the Wheat Board and for the capacity it has shown to be a successful grain exporter in the face of what have been cruelly corrupted world markets.

In the 40 years from 1944 to 1984, the production of Australian wheat has gone from 1.4 million tonnes to 18.6 million tonnes, all of it sold successfully by the Wheat Board in markets that over recent years have been corrupted to the tune of $50 a tonne. That is no mean achievement, and the growers and honourable members on this side of the House gladly recognise it. Furthermore, not only has the Wheat Board had to deal with an unpredictable world marketplace; it has also had to deal with the unpredictability of droughts, fires and floods which have meant that it did not know what it was going to be marketing from one year to another.

The legislation before the House, and our support of that legislation, far from being an attack on the Wheat Board, is merely, from our point of view, accepting what is being offered by the Government as an opportunity for farmers to have a choice in the way in which they go about their domestic marketing. I repeat that I am confident that the majority of Wakefield farmers will continue to market through the Wheat Board and not notice any difference at all. But there will be those-and I call them the niche marketers-who will say, `Here is an opportunity to get a premium out of the domestic market and this legislation will allow us to do so'. Of course, I am well aware that farmers can currently do that, but in order to do so they have to enter into a rather complicated and convoluted grower to buyer permit. Under this legislation, such a permit will no longer be necessary.

In the north of my electorate, in the Orroroo-Peterborough area, where farmers have sandy paddocks and a dry climate, they can choose to plant a variety, not necessarily recommended, that will grow with a premium protein level wanted by a particular flour miller and command from that miller a premium price for it. Alternatively, I could use the illustration of a chemical free grain producer I currently have at Tarlee in the centre of my electorate. Frankly, he is bit of an embarrassment to the Wheat Board, even though he supports the Board. We have sat down and talked to the Chairman of the Wheat Board about this very instance. He will now be able to do as the Wheat Board wants him to do and go about industriously developing the chemical free grain market within the domestic market, so making sure that more and more Australians are consuming wheat grain on the domestic market and not being locked into a Wheat Board obligation that he does not particularly want to have and the Wheat Board does not want him in any sense to feel.

I recognise, and I think it should be said that everyone on this side of the House recognises, that one cannot have the opportunities that this legislation provides without also exposing the industry to some risks. The Minister has conceded that the card price, the premium export price, the domestic price, could be eroded to the average export price. That risk is not likely to apply in the next two seasons, given that the world wheat reservoir is currently empty. Even if the worst possible situation were realised-and the Minister ran through this in his second reading speech-the difference between that premium price and the average export price need not be any more than, and let us be generous about it, $3 or $4 a tonne.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, not that much.

—I welcome the interjection from the honourable member for Wannon, who is even better informed than I. He has been a little premature with his interjection. I attended the Grains Council meeting in South Australia under the auspices of the National Farmers and Stockholders and at that meeting the Deputy Chairman of the Wheat Board, Mr Michael Shanahan, a farmer in my electorate and not one particularly fond of the action currently being taken by the Liberal and National parties, was specifically asked by the farmers there, who were also unhappy about the proposal, what the disadvantage to South Australian farmers would be if this legislation were passed. He said that it would be between $1 and $2 a tonne, to reinforce the point being so eloquently made by the honourable member for Wannon.

SPEECH.PARA: In the light of the opportunities presented, that is hardly an enormous risk. Because the risk is minimal and the opportunities great, the Opposition has been in support of much of the legislation and will be moving some amendments that will make the Bill even more effective. Frankly, I am sorry to say that because there is a long list of speakers the Whip has asked me to prune my remarks and, as I am under somewhat more of an obligation to be obedient to the Whip than anyone else in this chamber, I do not have an opportunity to run through all of the amendments. However, I note that the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), the honourable member for Wannon and the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), and I have no doubt other honourable members-and, of course, one must concede, the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray-have extensively addressed the amendments, anyway. So I will skip over the amendments and simply plead with the Minister to look at what the Opposition is prepared to do to make this legislation more meaningful.

It is of some concern to me that legislation that we have known for five years had to come in has been introduced in such a shoddy form. It is a matter of great concern to me that this legislation needs such extensive amendment. How does one excuse a situation where the Opposition finds reasonable cause to introduce 41 amendments and the Government finds reasonable cause to introduce 28 amendments in respect of its own legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty-five Government amendments.

—I beg the pardon of the House; it is 45 Government amendments-the situation gets worse. I had better sit down before the Minister is left without a feather to fly, if he pardons my taking the chook analogy a little further. In fact, the Bill requires such extensive amendment that one must wonder how the Minister can excuse such poorly drafted legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude at the point at which I began. I began by reflecting on the process of winnowing grain, which separated the cocky chaff from the wheat. Australia generally, and South Australia in particular, has been noted for the innovative way it has gone about inventing the machinery needed to make our grain harvesting techniques more efficient. One of those most involved in developing agricultural machinery successfully in Australia was Arthur Cliff Howard. As a result of Howard's work, particularly in developing the rotary hoe, agricultural practice in Australia was turned around. Now, under another Mr Howard, the opportunity exists for agricultural practice in Australia to be again turned around. I suggest that, just as my electorate of Wakefield led the way in the development of agricultural machinery, so we have an opportunity in cooperation with the Grains Council and in support of the constructive parts of the Government legislation currently before the House to see that new opportunities are presented to Australia's wheat growers. The Opposition finds itself practising a great deal of philosophical consistency in accepting much of the Government's legislation. I hope that the Government is as consistent in its practice of philosophical consistency when we look to the further deregulation of the wages market and the waterfront.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Wheat Marketing Bill and associated Bills is to allow others as well as the Australian Wheat Board to trade wheat on the domestic market, to allow greater competition in the handling, storage and transport of grain, and to restructure the Australian Wheat Board. The Bill and the debate have aroused much passion, much anger, much joy and a wide spectrum of opinion both within the community and among all parties in this chamber. I acknowledge in particular the wide range of concern evident amongst coalition members, many of whom have very close ties with the wheat industry. Naturally, they are concerned about the degree of uncertainty this legislation creates in respect of the welfare of wheat growers, but they are also concerned about the extraordinary volume of errors and omissions in the legislation itself. I know that the Minister acknowledges that himself through the number of amendments-45, I think we just heard-that he is proposing to his own Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I also pay tribute in particular to the shadow Minister for primary industry, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), for the immense effort he has devoted to drafting the coalition's amendments, which I believe should be supported. The wheat growers indeed have a friend in this Parliament in the form of the shadow Minister. In particular, we will see whether the Government is fair dinkum about deregulation as a principle, as opposed to deregulation just for the marketing side of the wheat industry, when we come to the shadow Minister's amendment to free up the labour market on the waterfront. Government members have tried to give the impression that they have been trumpeting from the high moral ground throughout this debate, but I know that they are squibs on deregulation when it comes to the waterfront, the labour market, industrial relations and even things such as uranium mining, where we have in Australia this ridiculous three mines policy. So, when it comes to deregulating its own constituent areas, the Government backs off every time. I ask the Government to be mindful of that when it sees some of us on this side of the chamber quite rightly and sincerely agonising over our constituency of wheat growers. I remind the Government that, despite our concerns and difficulties, we as an overwhelming majority have bitten the bullet and decided to go ahead and support further deregulation in the wheat industry. We are committed in our approach to deregulation. I will be interested to see whether the Government is as committed itself when we come to vote for the shadow Minister's amendment on labour market deregulation.
