I also point out to Government members that, even though a few Opposition members oppose this deregulation-and who amongst us has sat through a more moving and sincere speech in this chamber than that of the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) in this debate-I am proud to belong to a party and a coalition that ultimately allow members to express opinions different from the majority party line. It is sad that in a so-called democratic country the party in government forbids its own members such basic human freedoms. How insecure members on that side of the chamber must be to have to resort to such restrictive, jackboot tactics. I declare myself a supporter of the direction of this legislation, and I would like the opportunity to explain why.

In round figures, the world produces about 515 million tonnes of wheat each year, of which Australia's contribution is about 15 million tonnes or about 3 per cent. In that sense, Australia is very much a minor producer on the world wheat scene-unlike, say, in regard to our share of world wool production. Most wheat-35 per cent-is actually grown in Asia; Europe grows 21 per cent; North America 17 per cent; the Soviet Union 17 per cent; and 10 per cent is grown elsewhere, which includes the three continents of South America, Africa and Australia, as well as all the Oceanic islands. However, as we, unlike most of these large producers, export most of our wheat, Australia is actually one of the major exporters of wheat, along with Argentina, Canada, the European Community and the United States. The biggest importers of wheat are the Soviet Union, China, Japan, Brazil and Egypt. It is interesting to note that 25 per cent of world wheat consumption is feed wheat. Of the 500 million tonnes or so grown worldwide, around 100 million tonnes of wheat is traded outside the country in which it is grown. I quoted these figures to show that Australia, although a major trader, is nevertheless a relatively small player on the world wheat market and is therefore largely dependent on world wheat prices for what we are paid for our wheat.

Short of a massive subsidy commitment from general revenue, which we could not afford anyway, Australia's influence on the overall world wheat market is that of a minor player. Wheat, like all commodities, is ultimately subject to the laws of supply and demand. When volume is up, such as occurs through increases in yields from new varieties-helped along with fertiliser usage in Asia-relative oversupply occurs and the price falls. Similarly, an increase in assistance levels in Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries also depresses prices. In fact, such government intervention can cause a 15 per cent drop worldwide, which flows through to roughly a five per cent loss in income for Australian wheat farmers after our wheat growers-most of the 45,000 of whom are mixed farmers-substitute wheat growing for other areas of primary industry. I say this to get the wheat debate into perspective.

Australia grows three per cent of the world's wheat, of which we export 80 per cent. Of the 20 per cent or so of the wheat that we sell on the domestic market, around 40 per cent is sold as feed wheat on a virtually deregulated market through the permit system. So tonight we are really only debating whether to deregulate further the sale of 12 per cent of our total wheat production, that is, about one eighth of our crop. The Wheat Board has, of course, already gone some distance down this deregulatory path, especially over the past few years. It was once quite a rigid and inflexible statutory marketing authority-of which, incidentally, we have about 60 in this country-but grower demands, and especially the pressure of this legislation which has been mooted now for quite a long time, have acted to bring aspects of the Wheat Board into the real world, the commercial world, with long overdue reforms. I am referring to the tentative steps taken with increased selling options, deferred deliveries, further disaggregation of individual grower's costs and so on. All these moves have been both welcome and successful. The Wheat Board, for whatever motive it introduced these changes, is to be congratulated on doing so.

The introduction in 1984 of permit selling for domestic feed wheat sales is a good example. Before its introduction, a number of prominent commentators predicted that the sky would fall in for the wheat industry in Australia. I am over six feet tall, and I have no bruises on my head yet. Despite these gloomy prognostications, the growers endorsed this change overwhelmingly. They voted with their feet to the extent that over 90 per cent of growers-indeed I think about 96 per cent in Victoria-now choose to bypass the Wheat Board and sell direct through the permit system for feed wheat.

On this subject it is interesting to note that Australia and Canada are the only major exporting countries in the world to use a central agency with powers to acquire wheat compulsorily. Indeed, of the 100 million tonnes of wheat traded on the world market, some 75 per cent is handled by private traders. Even in Australia the Wheat Board allows 20 to 30 per cent of its export sales to be handled through private traders. That is to the benefit of us all. In fact, it could be argued, despite what nearly everyone in this House may claim, that there is no need to have a Wheat Board monopoly for export. For example, if it is argued that a single seller structure is necessary to extract the best price from a single designated market-something, incidentally, that has never been able to be proved-the Wheat Board could sell that entitlement to that market to the highest bidder. In this way growers could still get the benefit of the premium along with the cost saving advantages of private sector marketing. It is not only wrong to say that these premium prices, or monopoly rents, to use the correct economic term, can be secured through Wheat Board sales; it is even detrimental to the interests of wheat growers.

I mention these things simply to illustrate that the further deregulation of that 12 per cent of Australia's wheat crop that we sell on the domestic market, when put into that sort of context, is no big deal. We are talking about that fraction of our crop which is sold for human consumption or for industrial use.

Numerous studies have been done on the wheat industry in Australia. The Industries Assistance Commission (IAC), a great friend of the farming community over the years through its advocacy of tariff reduction, has written three reports on the wheat industry over the last decade. In the 1978 report it recommended deregulation of the domestic market, and this was rejected by the government of the day. In 1983 it again recommended deregulation of the domestic market, and again it was rejected. In 1988 it once more recommended deregulation of the domestic market, and it was finally accepted.

In one sense, domestic deregulation is a concept whose time has come. As with all such moves, the downside is usually clear and visible and can be easily pointed to whereas the upside cannot be so clearly defined. It is a similar situation to removing tariffs. The disadvantage to wheat growers from this proposed legislation is that that portion of the price that is made artificially higher because of the present legislation than it would otherwise be on the open market, will now largely disappear. Averaged over the whole crop sales, including export sales, this amount ranged from a few cents to a few dollars per tonne, probably in the 50c to $2 per tonne category. The advantages are numerous, and the Wheat Board will be in an excellent position to dominate a fully commercial domestic wheat market.

A new range of selling options should open up to growers, and the growers themselves should be able to base their decisions on much more up to date, accurate and detailed market reports. As well, private traders will offer an expanded range of cash options, deferred payments, forward selling options, deferred delivery sales and so on. No seller will be penalised more than the costs that each uses. Impositions such as the $16 per tonne domestic selling charge and the Tasmanian freight equalisation charge of $1.90 per tonne, these monopoly costs, will disappear, I am pleased to say, and charges will more accurately reflect genuine costs.

Some growers will have the choice to grow new varieties, such as specialist high protein varieties. Market niches will open up for those who can take advantage of specific agronomic factors and locations. Until now the Wheat Board has found that such quantities are too small for it to handle in many cases. The increased number of buyers entering the market will put pressure on transport, storage and handling services to improve their efficiency through changing their work practices, varying and extending their operating times and by speeding up the use of technical innovations.

The more buyers that enter the market, along with the consequent investment in facilities that will follow, the greater the pressure there will be to enact and discover new efficiencies and lower costs. Private traders will use a wider variety of marketing techniques, will have a much more specialised knowledge of their markets because of the decentralising effect of their emergence that will result, and they will offer new market packages of various grains of various origins. Their greater marketing efficiency will lead to lower costs.

The Wheat Board will be strengthened immeasurably by certain measures in this Bill which further untie its hands, allowing it to buy wheat for cash, market other grains, trade in wheat produced in other countries and so on. The Wheat Board will have a commercial advantage over private traders, and this should not be overlooked. It is assured of a supply of capital through a levy. It will not have to generate a commercial rate of return on its shareholders' funds, and it is guaranteed a continuing monopoly on exports. If the Wheat Board is not a major player under these circumstances, it could be classed only as grossly incompetent. Its 80 per cent export market share alone will permit it to dominate the market overall and so set a floor. Private traders will be forced to match the Wheat Board instead of vice versa.

Why sellers of grain, that is the wheat growers, would do anything but welcome more buyers into the market is beyond me. As a wool grower and a meat producer, I cannot have too many buyers when I come to sell my product. More buyers increase the chance of a higher price. This fear of collusion amongst grain merchants that was supposed to take place in the 1930s is virtually overcome by restrictive trade practice laws, by having a Wheat Board as an alternative buyer, which the farmers did not have then, and by having much better market information and storage facilities available than were ever dreamt of in the 1930s.

Australian farmers are now much more informed, competent, sophisticated and adaptable than they have ever been. The expertise of the farmers I know gives me the confidence that these days the hay is in the paddock and not in their hair. Naturally, because they have been sheltered and have limited first hand experience of wheat markets, many are apprehensive of the changes. However, change in this modern world is inevitable for survival, and a prerequisite of success is direct contact with the market. We should not deny this to our growers. The fallacious argument of the market being set by the weakest seller, is an economic nonsense. How could someone selling 1,000 tonnes of wheat for a low price, or even giving it away for that matter, set the market for the rest? The 1930s slump in prices was not due to greedy merchants, as most seem to believe; it was due to government policy, whereby growers were urged to grow massive amounts of wheat for guaranteed government prices, which the Government later found it could not meet. Its chopping and changing of promises after the glut of wheat arrived and the farmers delivered, created awful uncertainty amongst the buyers and they could not pay more than the world market price or else they would go broke.

Today I believe a successful seller's friend is a buyer, and the more buyers there are, the more friends the seller will have and the happier everybody is. Let us not talk of restricting buyers from the market-place. Indeed, the prices in real terms for wheat were higher in the 1930s than they were in the last couple of seasons before this one, when we had a Wheat Board. I would like permission to incorporate in Hansard two tables-I have shown them to the Minister and have received his approval-which will demonstrate this fact.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. On the matter of underwriting, I accept that there is little logic in having a government guaranteed price for wheat but not for other commodities. But leaving that aside, several speakers on the other side have been saying that a 95 per cent underwriting guarantee, as we have proposed in our amendment, would involve the Government in huge pay-outs. That is quite untrue. Over the last 10 years, if we set the gross national product on a one year basis instead of a three-year rolling average, the 95 per cent level would have been triggered only once, and that would have been in the 1980-81 year when the shortfall was only a mere $3.46 a tonne. However, that was before the Wheat Board was allowed to hedge on the futures market, which would probably have meant that it would not have had even that small pay-out. In the 1986-87 season when we did have that big pay-out of $220m, which amounted to about $14 a tonne, under our amendment formula there would have been no pay-out at all. In light of these figures, I hope that the Minister will look more benignly on the shadow Minister's proposal rather than rejecting it out of hand.

SPEECH.PARA: As I know time is short and as other honourable members wish to speak in this debate, I say in conclusion that there are many good things in this legislation. I support the general thrust of it, but it is very disappointing for many honourable members on this side of the House and for the wheat growers that so many substantial corrections are needed. I hope that, at the committee stage, the Government will see fit to accept most, if not all, of the proposed changes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The whole sorry wheat saga shows just how incompetent and irresponsible this Labor Government is. Instead of having a rational debate about new wheat marketing proposals, last year the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is at the table, announced a number of vague propositions that were floated around the country. Amongst other things they involved substantial changes to underwriting, deregulation of the domestic market, and an undermining of the Australian Wheat Board's export powers. Many wheat farmers justifiably said, `The last thing we want is an undermining of the Board's powers and a return to the 1930s'. In no time at all, fears regarding the future of the Australian Wheat Board spread like wildfire through the bush.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two reasons why there were such deep rooted fears. Firstly, farmers just do not trust this Labor Government. Consistently Labor has applied one rule to the farmers and another to its union mates, and they do not trust it. Secondly, the original vague wheat marketing proposals had major flaws which, in many respects, justified the wheat growers' fears. The Government and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy have been responsible yet again for the gross mishandling of what should have been a very sensible debate about ways of reducing costs to growers by cutting bureaucratic intervention and by cutting transport and storage costs, especially in the eastern States, thereby increasing the efficiency of handling and increasing returns to growers. What hope have we got of this Government introducing a much needed and meaningful deregulation of the labour market when it cannot even handle a simple matter of improving the returns to growers in the new wheat marketing legislation.

The coalition has always been in favour of scrapping the rorts in the system, thereby increasing returns to growers, but we have never been in favour of undermining the Wheat Board's ability to gain the best possible price overseas by having the responsibility for selling Australia's wheat crop on the world market. So, yet again, it has been left to the coalition to clean up Labor's mess and bring sense to the debate and to the new wheat marketing proposals. How many more times are we in the Opposition going to have to save the Australian farming community from the crass stupidity of this Government. My colleagues and I saved the nation from the identification card. We stopped the stupid constitutional changes proposed by Labor and now we have to clean up the mess that it has made of what should have been a sensible debate about improving the wheat marketing arrangements for Australia. For example, as a result of our unswerving opposition, the Government has now scrapped its proposal to undermine the export powers of the Wheat Board. It is a significant victory for the coalition and for commonsense.

The number of amendments to be moved by the Opposition and the Government highlights the unmitigated disaster the Government has made of this proposal. Some 45 amendments are to be moved by the Minister and almost the same number are to be moved by the Opposition. I have met, as have so many honourable members on this side of the House, with wheat growers in my area. I have had meetings with them throughout the electorate, in Bordertown, Lameroo, Wanbi, Loxton and Waikerie. Those meetings reflected growers' concerns about the vagueness of the proposals as they were put up last year and earlier this year. At those meetings I gave undertakings to my growers, some of which are met by the Government's back-off from its original proposals in areas such as the Australian Wheat Board's export powers. Other commitments I made are picked up in the amendments to be moved by the Opposition, especially those relating to underwriting, penalties on illegal exports, and the vital application of the same rules to the unions as this Government is applying to wheat growers.

Let me deal briefly with some of our proposed amendments. It is important for wheat farmers, who have a very large capital investment in equipment and a very large annual cost in planting crops, to have the advantage of knowing what the likely return is to be if they can grow and reap that crop successfully. This is one of the core reasons for establishing the Wheat Board as the farmers' international marketing arm. The guaranteed minimum price has provided our farmers with the much needed certainty required, just as has the floor price for wool growers. It certainly illustrates this Government's lack of understanding of the needs of industry that it seeks substantially to undermine the guaranteed minimum price (GMP) in the current circumstances. We in the Opposition will be moving an amendment to maintain the 95 per cent GMP. Wheat is one of our most significant export commodities and this underwriting is a small contribution to provide some certainty to this industry at this time. I can recall the Government having to assist in meeting the guarantee only once, and the Australian Wheat Board says that it is extremely unlikely to occur again because of its better forecasting techniques.

The facts are that it is highly unlikely that the guarantee will ever be used. Nevertheless, the need to provide some certainty for growers is highlighted by the scandalous announcement yesterday by our so-called free trading United States of America allies that they are to sell $1.5m tonnes of subsidised wheat to the Soviet Union. This brings the United States subsidy on sales to the Union of the Soviet Socialist Republics over the past four years to around $670m. It is a most stupid, short-sighted, irrational policy being implemented by the United States. Whilst it is clear that Europe for some time sold subsidised products into our markets-although there are signs that the rate of subsidy is reducing in recent years-nevertheless, the United States, in upping the ante on the trade war, will do absolutely nothing to help the long-term goal of free trade.

Another amendment we propose is to increase the penalty for the illegal export of wheat-that is, exports other than those approved by the Board. Growers in my area were concerned that the penalty of $100,000 on a large illegal shipment would be peanuts. Therefore, after consultation with the wheat industry we have proposed that the penalty be a financial penalty of a percentage of the value of the wheat illegally exported or $100,000, whichever is the greater. Subsequently, the Minister, I understand, is agreeing to lift the penalty to $300,000 with which I agree. However, I urge the Government to accept the percentage penalty as well.

Another essential amendment we propose is to shore up the right of the Australian Wheat Board to trade within a State. I understand that it is a common goal of all parties to this debate that that be the case. I do not have time to deal with all the amendments proposed by the Opposition after consultation with the wheat industry, but I wish to refer to our proposed clause 88. There is no doubt that one of the greatest constraints on economic growth in this country is our antiquated industrial relations system, together with the restrictive work practices and other impediments to improvements in labour productivity. Whenever the Labor Government is pressed about its failure to deregulate the labour market, it diverts attention by claiming that it has done some work towards deregulating. More often than not, it points to the deregulation of the exchange rate, the banks and now, no doubt, it will point to the deregulation of the wheat industry. However, it continues to refuse steadfastly to act in areas such as the waterfront. Why? The answer is clearly political. The Labor Government is only too prepared to deregulate in areas where it does not affect its supporters but it has continually refused to act when the heat gets a bit closer to home. For example, the Government has done absolutely nothing about the waterfront. Not only has the Inter-State Commission report highlighted the gross inefficiency and the need for deregulation on the waterfront, but today we have received even more proof of the disastrous waterfront situation. The Australia to Europe Shipping Conference has proposed that surcharges for port congestion be applied on all exports and imports through Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane. It is reported in today's Australian:

The Australia to Europe Shipping Conference (AESC) which coordinates the sailings and freight rates of most British and European lines trading to Australia, has told exporters and the Federal Government the surcharges would be applied unless there was an immediate improvement in disastrously low productivity on the waterfront.
The Conference said it would charge up to an extra $190 a container and $10 a tonne for loose cargo, which would have a significant impact on the price of traded goods.

Urgent action is needed, and the coalition is determined to act after the next election. In the meantime, we are proposing an amendment to these Bills which will extend the Government's use of the export powers not only to blow up State rail monopolies but also to cover grain terminals and loading facilities. In other words, we are trying to get the Government to apply the same rules to the waterfront as it intends to apply to wheat farmers.

The time has come for the cosy relationship between this Labor Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) to end. It is time for the Government to put the national interest before the ACTU's interests. Even Max Walsh agrees. Recently he said in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald that the accord was `a reckless and wrecking monster'. We agree with that, and many people in the Australian community now agree with it.

What is the Government doing about it? We intend to do something about it tonight. The pressure is on the Government to respond. Our proposal is quite simple. It provides that there will be no closed shops, no preference to unions, and no artificially imposed number of people to do the work in the terminals, loading ships. In addition, we will provide for voluntary agreements to be entered into between the employers and employees, with provision for damages for any breach of the agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It sounds like a good idea.

—It is a very good idea. Any breach of the provisions of the clause-for example, an attempt to force a closed shop arrangement-generally will involve a fine of $10,000 and $1,000 a day for an individual while that individual continues to breach the provisions of the clause, and a fine of $100,000, and $10,000 a day, for a union. In other words, we are saying to the Government that it must use its export powers to implement responsible work practices on the waterfront.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposal is generally consistent with the recommendations of the Inter-State Commission. The Government should act on its own report. It has the chance to do that tonight. We are providing the Government with an opportunity to do exactly what it says it intends to do, that is, to implement micro-economic reform. The question is: does the Labor Government mean what it says or is it too scared to do the right thing because it might affect some of its mates? Tonight we will see who is pulling the strings. Is the Government in charge or is it the ACTU?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is the unions.

—My fear and the fear of the Australian community is that the honourable member is quite right-that the Government is not in charge and that it is the ACTU which is in charge. The failure of the Government to act tonight on our amendment to clause 88 will not only mean that this country will continue to lose out in the international trading stakes but also it will herald even higher charges being loaded onto our exporters because of the Government's inability to bite the bullet.

SPEECH.PARA: It is this Government that will carry the can for the extra $10 a tonne to be loaded onto our wheat growers as their wheat goes over the wharf. The challenge to the Government is clear: it must act tonight and avoid the threatened extra $10 a tonne. If it squibs that, it must carry the responsibility for the higher waterfront charges. If the Government really has the interests of wheat growers at heart, it must support the Opposition's amendment to clause 88 tonight. It is no good saying in response that it is all right, that negotiations are being undertaken between the waterfront unions, the ACTU and the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis). We know all about that. They met all day today and got nowhere. They are doing nothing, and they have no intention of acting on the Inter-State Commission report. So the Government cannot deal that up to us, because we know that nothing will happen as a result of those negotiations.

The importance of breaking the outrageous work practices on the waterfront cannot be overstated. The Inter-State Commission has stated quite clearly that we are wasting $440m each year. That is obviously reflected in lower export returns and higher import charges. Quite frankly, the problems in relation to the Victorian rail monopoly, which has had so much airplay during this debate, pale into insignificance when compared with the rorts that are occurring on the waterfront. There is no doubt that the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia has grossly abused its monopoly position, and action must be taken. We provide the Government with the opportunity to do that tonight.

Clearly it is an extraordinary abuse of power when we see gang supervisors working about 46 hours a week and being paid about $78,000 a year. The average wage of the wharf labourer is about $1,000 for a 28-hour week. I would not mind paying those high wages if they were earned. No one minds paying high wages for work done, but the problem is that the waterside workers are not earning their wages. It is quite clear that unless we remove the restrictive work practices which are fast throttling the lifeblood of this nation, as a nation we will go under.

Finally, I shall finish where I began. I cannot remember an instance in relation to a piece of legislation where the Minister in charge has managed to get everyone offside. This is not because he is right but because he has blundered into this new wheat marketing arrangement with vague, irrational proposals instead of a tight, well-argued case for change. It is only as a result of the action of the Opposition that we will have a reasonable package worth supporting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The wheat industry is a particularly valuable part of the Australian economy, and it has developed from the activities and personal endeavours of many tens of thousands of people, some of whom began to establish this industry soon after Australia was settled. It now presents to this country one of its basic means of earning export income. The industry is now very much different from what it was in years gone by. It is an industry made up of the hopes and aspirations of those people who operated in the industry previously and who were subsumed into larger organisations as the wheat industry and wheat properties were aggregated-and this has occurred ever since property was first taken up.

SPEECH.PARA: Today, wheat properties of a sizable nature consist of the many smaller properties that have been gathered together, according to the economic message that farmers have always had to face. We see today an industry which, as many have said in this debate, is sophisticated and in touch with modern technology and world events. The people who are responsible for making the decisions to manage the various properties that produce Australia's wheat crop can be counted as some of the best informed people in Australia. Whilst this is admitted and promoted in debate on both sides of this House, I am astounded that we can hold that collective view and yet we are willing to ignore the collective view which has been put to this Parliament and to the various parties involved by people in the Australian wheat industry.

I suppose that some 40,000 of the 45,000 individual operators would be against this legislation that we are considering here tonight. I therefore view with some cynicism the assertion made by honourable members in this House that they regard those who operate in the wheat industry as being up with current trends and knowing what they are about. On the one hand I suppose that this is being said to impress them, while on the other hand we throw aside the advice they give us in relation to this legislation. I can understand why they are concerned. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) brings this legislation into the House two months before it is necessary to renew the life of the Australian Wheat Board. It is the same as putting the farmers up against the wall and saying, `You will accept the legislation or I will economically shoot you'. There is no alternative in the wider terms of having a Wheat Board, of the Board handling the continued trading of wheat in Australia, and looking at the pools which will come from the next harvest. That, in itself, is an offence to those who work in and manage this industry.

But of a greater nature is the Government's absolute deceit throughout this country and in this House in maintaining that it is necessary to diminish the powers of the Wheat Board to improve the infrastructure that serves the wheat industry. It is absolute deceit. The Wheat Board could be given that power which is in this Bill without touching its capacity to handle the domestic market. The two are totally unrelated. If we wanted to, we could pass a Bill of one page giving the Board that power. We do not have to take away its other powers to do that.

The answer truly is that the infrastructure is basically in the charge of State governments, which over the years have failed to deregulate. My State, in this particular, stands out amongst all States. In the early 1960s road transport in South Australia was deregulated and operators of all industry everywhere could choose the form of transport that they desired. There was one further major move. I say this with some trepidation because on no other occasion have I been known to support any move by the Dunstan Government in South Australia. Its move in selling the South Australian railways to the Commonwealth, in addition to the freeing up of transport, was one of the best things it did for South Australian rail transport. The South Australian railways were taken out of the parochial management of the State Government and put in the hands of national management. The reforms that have occurred there have produced the best rail transport in Australia. But the basic reforms were made by the Playford non-Labor Government.

What Labor governments do about transport is quite evident. Which other governments in Australia have deregulated transport? Who governs Western Australia? A Labor government. Who governs Victoria? A Labor government. Of course, there is now the start of significant deregulation in New South Wales under a Liberal-National coalition. Labor was in government for years and did nothing. In recent years Labor has failed to meet the challenge of modern reform in infrastructure. We approach this Bill and its passage with that deceit behind us and without knowing that any State will approve internal trading for the Wheat Board.

Are we all going to sit here and pass this Bill and say how good it is when we do not know whether the Wheat Board can trade internally? We would have to be off our heads to approve that sort of thing. Do honourable members really think this Bill will go to the other place and come back here containing that amendment about the deregulation of the work force, which I will happily support? Come on, let us be realistic. It is an attempt similar to my attempt to move that this Bill be subject to a referendum. It is totally symbolic. If this Bill is to come into effect, it will come into effect with deregulation. It will give the Wheat Board power to affect the internal price of wheat in Australia. Nothing will be done about the costs that feed into the wheat grower's cost of production. He will pay the same inflated cost for Australian made vehicles to go into his operation and pay for all the other goods and services based on a regulated work force. So, his input costs will not be affected by our so-called amendments during the passage of this Bill.

I would like to see some equity between the major producing areas of agriculture and the pastoral industry. It is one thing to say that the pastoral industry can have one of the most significant price support schemes, as it has under the Australian Wool Corporation. It has one of the most admirable schemes brought in in support of the pastoral industry-one of the most significant industries in Australia. No matter what people may say, it is a significant price support structure. When the market was down, as we know, the Wool Corporation brought in, I think, well over one million-it may have been 1.7 million-bales of wool. It was a huge amount of wool. Under its legislation it was charged to support the price and it did support the price. Through the assessment of what the world market will bear through the auction system, it continued to assess what floor it can place under the market. Its operation is distinctly advantageous to the wool industry and maintains a floor under it. Under that operation all users of wool in Australia pay more for that wool than they would have paid if that mechanism was not in place.

That is fine for the wool industry, but it is no good for the wheat industry. Under this legislation the Wheat Board apparently is not allowed to fix the internal price. It is all right for the wool industry, but it is no good for the wheat industry. The wheat industry has tended to protect the interests of the grower in Australia by adopting an uncorrupted price for Australian consumers and to establish an umbrella under which all these other examples which have been given, have been obtained. Someone might get a few more dollars in some other action somewhere for their wheat, but it is all achieved under that umbrella price of the Board. That is to be diminished. We will have to have an internal price which undoubtedly will fall. One wonders why we have this disparity between the two industries. Does that mean that somehow the wool industry has a greater social standing? As someone has suggested, perhaps we should not call our wheat years `pools'; we should have vintages. As someone said, perhaps we could have a grain hermitage. The wheat industry perhaps needs a better social standing to impress on Parliament that we should have the same right to set some better standard for the price of wheat in Australia on behalf of growers. One can understand the growers' fears.

Beyond the detail of this Bill, what growers fear most of all is the `foot in the door' approach-the almost fanatical approach to deregulation today not only in politics but also in the community. Many growers are viewing this Bill as a foot in the door. Does it mean that in a few years time there will be a concerted attack on the very existence of the Board and, in that, a demand across Australia that we do away with it? I hope that that demand will not succeed. Of course, there will be such a demand. We know that there are many people in the economic world and some in this Parliament who would like to do away with the Board altogether. Certainly, that fuels the fears of growers.

I do not think that many people have considered this Bill on the basis that orderly marketing is not for good times but for bad times. One does not need anything to sell wheat in or outside Australia now. But how many years do we have to go back before we come across bad times? Not too long ago we had quotas for growing wheat-certainly in my State-and one did not get paid at all for the third tier of quota. We had two tiers of quota and after the second tier we got nothing. I would like to see what deregulation would do in those times. The value of the Board and pools is that they can always straddle the times of oversupply and the times in which growers find it difficult to survive. They can ensure that each year something is paid for the wheat crop. Orderly marketing is ingrained in the consciousness of Australian wheat growers. If anyone thinks that he can get away with threatening the existence of the Board in the future, he will come up with a great deal more opposition than he has on this occasion.

I also listened to continued loose talk about more competition in the local market. What does the Government mean? When one gets down to it, it means competition between grower and grower. That is what the Government means when one analyses it. The very existence of pools is to do away with competition on the basis of price between grower and grower. That would be a return to a most murderous situation in an industry which from time to time is bedevilled with low overseas prices and the great inequities of the Australian climate.

In closing, I ask several questions. Is it necessary to reduce the Board's powers to revamp the infrastructure which serves the industry? I have already dealt with that. The answer is a resounding no. It is a plain and simple deceit. Will the return to growers for the sale of wheat in Australia be lower? The answer will have to be yes. If we want to confirm that, we can refer to the recent sale of American wheat, an issue that was much referred to today. If one can see anything but a reduction in the price of wheat in Australia in the economic war between the United States of America and the European Community, one would have some sort of crystal ball which is not available to others.

Will the Board have the right to trade at all in Australia? How do we know? We do not know. We do not know whether the States will give that right. Will there be further demands to deregulate wheat export markets? The answer will be a resounding yes. As someone has said, one does not feed red meat to young tigers. I can assure people that this proposal is certainly feeding red meat to traders who will want to get their hands on a deregulated export market. Will the dogma of deregulation for deregulation's sake again override wheat growers' expressed interests in the future? I can only say that I do not know.

To oppose the major aspect of this Bill, which is the deregulation of the internal price, is not to set one's head in the sand or to oppose any alterations to the operation of wheat marketing, which could be advantageous to both grower and consumer. To accept lightly this move from a Labor Government which is under deep suspicion in the economic community is, I believe, to accept a position which may be a temporary one. I urge all those in the wheat industry to look to the future and make sure they take action now to maintain the export control of the Board and that they do not let the forces which will be unleashed by this legislation destroy the Board's great capacity to serve the Australian wheat grower into the long term future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join tonight my colleagues in the National Party of Australia in speaking in this debate on the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989 and cognate Bills. Of course, it will be of no great surprise to honourable members that this debate is of particular interest to the National Party and has caused great concern within our ranks. Before I commence the prepared portion of my address tonight I want to take a few moments to highlight some of the aspects of the proposed wheat marketing legislation which concern me.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, I believe that the way the Bill has been put together, the way it has been drafted, is one of the worst examples of draftsmanship and preparation, one of the sloppiest performances, that we have seen in a long time in this House. I believe that more than 40 amendments have been proposed to the Bills since they were first introduced a couple of weeks ago. That in itself is of concern to every one of us. It is not as if this Bill has been produced overnight. It was more than 12 months ago that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who is sitting opposite, announced to the world his intentions to deregulate the wheat industry. The Minister, the Government and all those concerned have had ample time to prepare the legislation without ambiguity and in such a way that it met all the concerns of the industry. Despite all of that time and opportunity for preparation, that was not achieved successfully. That is why tonight we see so many amendments being added to the original Bill. It is worth pointing out that not only has the Government put forward its amendments but we on this side of the House have our own amendments to propose to the legislation. We feel our amendments certainly add to the usefulness and workability of the legislation. We believe they are important to ensure that the wheat industry is properly serviced in the future.

We are also very concerned about the state that this leaves the Australian Wheat Board in. We know that, as this legislation goes through the House in the last few sitting weeks of this session, the life of the Wheat Board comes to a very rapid end. Unless this legislation is passed, the future of the Wheat Board is very much in doubt. What happens if there is a hitch? What happens if the Parliament rises earlier than expected? What happens if something does not go as planned? Does the Wheat Board exist after 1 July of this year? These are questions which are not being adequately answered. They are questions which should not even be asked. Had the Government organised itself properly and prepared the legislation in sufficient time, there would be no question as to the future of the Wheat Board after 1 July.

Another point worth making in this debate is that, from the view of the National Party of Australia, the legislation is crucial to the very nature of the Party. The National Party, or the Country Party of Australia as it originally was, was created from the desire to establish orderly marketing for our primary products. That is one of the very pillars upon which the Party was built. Tonight we see that very pillar being somewhat eroded. The issue we are debating tonight is terribly important to us. Just as important from the Australian Labor Party's point of view would be a piece of legislation going through this House which the Labor Party would be asked to support which did away with trade unionism in this country, because trade unionism is one of the pillars upon which the Labor Party was built.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only one.

—As the honourable member for Mayo points out, it was the only basis upon which the Labor Party was created, and still exists today. It is these very crucial aspects of the National Party's history which lead to this particular legislation being of such importance to us.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen the Government be very cunning in the way in which it has been able to reduce the position of primary industries in Australia since it took up office in 1983. Just a few weeks ago in this place, when the April mini-Budget was announced, we saw in the explanatory memorandum the fact that drought relief from the Federal Government was under review. The funding for drought relief, some $17m, was being scrapped from the Budget. It was a great time to remove drought relief when half the country seemingly was under floodwaters. The fact that these sorts of things are being done at a time when it does not seem so important for them to continue causes us concern too. The Wheat Board and the way in which the whole wheat industry has operated over the last few years has been good for the industry in both good times and bad times. As we have heard from previous speakers tonight, it is the bad times when the present system of operation within the wheat industry has gone so far to help individual growers of wheat throughout Australia. Once again we find the Government choosing a good time to change the manner in which the wheat industry operates. We find that seasons have been quite good. Prices have been improving on the world market. So we find the Government using this time as an opportunity to do away with the very basis upon which the industry has been able to survive through bad times in the past.

This legislation changes the way in which the industry operates. The present system, which we have had for a long time now, has served the industry well. It has provided, as one of the principal bases of the industry, a floor price for all wheat growers to operate under, a guaranteed minimum price scheme. Many people in this House may not understand the benefits of that. Having been a wheat grower prior to entering this place I know that it is of great security to wheat growers to know what price they are going to receive for the product they can deliver and to know that they have a market for that product. Farmers are very busy people. Farmers do not always have the time to carry out every facet of their affairs, particularly over the last few years when the high cost of wages and the necessary changes to the use of farm labour have forced farm managers to become jacks of all trades on their farms, leaving them very little time to deal with some of the business aspects of running their farms.

This Government is placing upon farmers greater responsibility for management of all of the facets of the production and sale of their products. Many people might say that that does not seem to be such a big problem. I can assure people that when one has to do everything from maintaining the tractor, driving the header, keeping the auger going, to driving the truck to the silo, one has little time to be concerned about where it is going to be delivered, what sort of price one is going to get, what the quality is and what sort of a buyer is going to be found for the product. There is a finite amount of time in which farmers have to do everything they have to do.

The present system has been a great asset to many growers throughout Australia, particularly the smaller farmers who have found the way the Wheat Board and the wheat industry have operated to be of great benefit to them. The present system has helped to protect farmers from the world corrupted markets, markets that are corrupted by the European Economic Community and by the United States. They are corrupted by the heavy subsidy programs that those two entities engage in. These are subsidy programs which we saw evidence of only yesterday when the United States Government entered into further sales of wheat at heavily subsidised rates. Yet the present system has helped to ensure that our Australian wheat farmers have had at least some small protection from some of those corrupted world markets. The present system has helped with so many of the mechanics of growing and producing wheat, such as delivery arrangements and, as I mentioned, guaranteed payments. The present system has helped to ease the minds of wheat farmers. The moment one delivers to the Wheat Board and has the docket, one can drive home knowing that eventually a cheque is going to arrive in the mail and there is no need to worry about the person who has bought the product that has just been sold being of sound financial state.

In recent times we have seen some minor changes to all that. We have seen farmers being able not only to operate under the present system but through the use of Wheat Board authorities they have been able to sell some of their grain on the domestic market to local buyers. For example, I am a piggery producer. Over the last few years we have been able to buy direct from the farmer. Purely and simply by getting the appropriate authority from the Wheat Board we have been able to purchase our grain direct from the grower. Over the last few years the Wheat Board and the wheat industry have been moving with the times, opening up for farmers the opportunity to sell to people in their local area or to the odd persons whom they find are suitable buyers. At the same time they have the security of mind that the opportunity to sell to the Board at a guaranteed minimum price and with a guaranteed payment of that price is still available to them when and where they want it.

Over the last few years we have seen some minor changes to the way the industry has operated. They were very well received changes and have been well accepted by the industry. Some people say that there is a need to change. Many members in this House over the last day or so have highlighted the differing views of wheat growers throughout Australia. Some people say that all wheat growers are opposed to the legislation. Some people say that that is not the case. There is not doubt that just because the old system has worked in the past there is not an opportunity for us to look at ways of improving it in the future. This is what the present Minister claims is the justification for this current legislation.

Only the test of time will tell, but I can assure the Minister that there are many people in the community today, many people in this Parliament and many people in the National Party who are very sceptical about the way in which the benefits from this legislation will actually flow to the individual wheat grower. Many wheat growers throughout this country believe that ultimately the net result will be that we will swap one monopoly for another. We will find that the Wheat Board, having previously been the monopoly, will be traded for some other private enterprise operation that will be a monopoly operator in the market and not necessarily working in the best interests of the industry. That is the background to this debate today. In addition to that background, when the Government first announced its intention to change the way in which the wheat industry is structured there was great scepticism among individual growers because they do not trust the Government in matters of primary industry. Over the last six and a bit years we have seen primary industry suffer badly under this Government. We have seen hundreds of millions of dollars in benefits that have been provided to the wheat industry removed by this Government. All of us can recall such things as the fuel freight equalisation subsidy scheme being scrapped. We have recently seen the superphosphate bounty go. We have seen depreciation rates for such things as grain storage, water conservation and various other aspects of life reduced since this Government got into power. We have seen the price of fuel go up. When this Government says it is going to change the way in which the wheat industry operates people say, `If you are going to change this part of the industry like you have changed other parts of the industry we are very sceptical'. That is why so much concern has been expressed and that is why so many people do not believe the words of the Minister and the members of the Government that as a result of this legislation we will see major improvements. The background has been one of scepticism. Growers have felt tremendous benefits from the present system. There are concerns all around as to what this Government really intends to do.

The Government has singled out primary industries for some major changes. It seems to be almost singularly one-eyed in the types of changes it has proposed over the last few years. Strangely enough, when this legislation was first mooted there was no talk of changing some of the aspects of high costs to the wheat industry. It has only been as a result of pressure from the Grains Council of Australia, individual wheat growers and members of my own political party that we have seen the Government moving towards the deregulation of the transport industry, changing aspects of the waterfront and talking in these last few days of looking at the coastal shipping industry to try to do away with some of the rorts there and some of the high costs that are incurred by wheat growers as a consequence of those regulated industries. We now know that from the very outset the Government did not initially intend to look at these aspects of our industries. It has only been as a result of the efforts of our party, the Grains Council of Australia and the individual wheat growers that the Government has moved down that path.

There is some comfort for those of us in our political party when we look at this legislation tonight because at least we have changed some things. From the outset there was to be no export monopoly, from what we can believe from the original utterances from the Minister, for the Wheat Board. At least that part of it has been retained. At least we have seen promises of deregulation of the transport industry. At least we have seen talk of changing things on the waterfront. This legislation tonight is seen very sceptically by wheat growers throughout Australia. It is legislation which comes to the Parliament slightly better than it would have had it not been for the efforts of the industry, the Grains Council of Australia and individual members of my party.

In conclusion, I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), for the work that he has done. Through all of his efforts we have seen some improvements to this legislation which I believe will deliver great benefits if we can add to them when hopefully we have the opportunity of being in government in a few short months. Tonight we see legislation that will go to the people which is not universally supported, which needs a lot of improvement and which we have given promises to members of the wheat industry that we will be able to improve on when we have the opportunity of being in government. I believe that from the legislation tonight and from the calls of concern from so many ordinary Australians the sooner that occurs the better Australia will be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Pratt Mr M.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I speak in this debate on the Wheat Marketing Bill 1989 and cognate Bills. This debate has been tarnished with anger and concern. We have been lobbied and we have seen emotion, hysteria, baiting, hypocrisy and cynicism on a subject which is very special to the primary producers of Australia. In this current year this industry directed economic aid worth about $2.87 billion to this struggling Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I speak from a couple of points of view. As the Federal member for Adelaide, every few months I go to the Trades Hall on South Terrace to pick up a trade union card as a paid up member of Actors Equity. Recently I was asked to strike for the benefit of actors in Australia. Last night I was encouraged by the fact that the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) inquired about how much wheat is grown in Adelaide. I hasten to point out-and I am proud to say-my stocks are etched deep in rural South Australia as I am a fourth generation wheat farmer. The honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) said last night that he has spent a lot of time on the tractor. His colleague the honourable member for Maribyrnong (Mr Griffith) suggested that he may have been conceived on one. I too have spent many a long day and long years on the tractor and on the farm. As the broadcast of this debate goes around Australia I know that my rural colleagues, relatives, friends and family will listen with interest. The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) spoke about the farmers not being able to see the wheat for the chaff. The rural producers say, `We do not want deregulation'. But if that is taken a step further and we ask `Why don't you?', they have trouble coming back with an answer.

As I have said, we will not walk away from the basic support of rural Australia-the wheat and wool industries. The Australian Wheat Board is the major player in this industry, and we will not walk away from the people who have helped to make this country as great as it is. I talk about the industry when I speak to the farmers of Bute, Baringa Gap and Blyth, and they know what I am speaking about. But these same men and women are deregulators themselves. They have the opportunity to sell their lambs at the abattoirs in Adelaide, their weaner cattle and cracker ewes at Burra, their shipping wethers, their peas for vegetable protein, their oats to the trotting and racing industry, their barley to the maltsters and their wheat to the pig and chicken vertical integrators and they sell their off-grade and their feed and seed wheat. They have the ability to sell those products on a deregulated market but when one talks to them in some sort of a debate over a cup of tea or around the kitchen table or perhaps in a silo queue, they want everyone's hands off the industry.

The myth which has been associated with the Australian wheat industry must be exposed. My colleagues talk continually about the bad old days of 1945 and the bag industry. I can remember the Bunges, the Charlicks, Southern Farmers and the other romantic names that my father spoke about when wheat cost one shilling and tenpence a ton. I think that might have been the currency; I am not sure because it is a long time ago. They spoke about a lot of bartering and trading in those bad old days of bag wheat and bad times. They spoke about the pea industry, which unfortunately in 1988 fell over in Balaclava. But there has to be some entrepreneurial skill as we drag ourselves and sometimes the rural farmers kicking and screaming towards the 1990s. To say that farmers who have the ability to handle 300 horsepower tractors, air seeders, 20-foot harvesters, combines, grain augers and weed sprays are not intelligent enough to know a bit about wheat deregulation or to be a bit more progressive is an indictment of the industry.

I believe that this myth and the image portrayed from those olden days is long behind us. I am pleased to have been associated with several South Australian members: the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and, in particular, the elder statesman of rural South Australia, the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall), who brought some very salient points to this debate in relation to the deregulation of the transport industry, which is what the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport is about.

For several years I was involved in trucking wheat out of the Blyth silo, a horizontal silo to which the railways would bring in seven rail trucks. If one filled them in a day, it was good. Us hardworking and enterprising farmers looking for a bit of extra cash used to punch those out 60 tons per truck, jack them down the line and bring in another one and we would have the job done by lunchtime. We could then go home and perform another task and get paid for two jobs as one. Overtime was not available in those days of the wheat industry.

So, I have touched on all of that. I have also been a transport operator. I started off with a Dodge Power Giant, a single drive bogie trailer, carting grain all around South Australia. South Australia is to be congratulated for being the last State to go into the bulk handling cooperative system. It has excellent superports around the State. I have spent many a long day and night at Port Pirie, Wallaroo, Port Adelaide, Ardrossan and Port Giles carting wheat, in particular, and barley.

I have a suburban seat, but I am a practising, practical farmer with 1,000 acres of wheat about to shoot out of the ground. I remember the days of wheat quotas, which were alluded to by the honourable member for Boothby. They were the dark and dim days of the industry. I remember the years when the rust came through and took out an excellent variety of wheat called halberd, which was bred in South Australia. It was my decision to go to Dubbo where I bought some condor wheat from a man by the name of Croker and brought it back. I congratulate my cousins Ross and Geoff Pratt, who have a farm. I have a cousin farming at Moree and they were among of the first people to bring back a bushel of festiguay hard wheat into South Australia. This was a long-stemmed, non-shedding variety of wheat which was able to prevent rust. Now we are getting into the new varieties of spear, dagger, warrigal and molineux, which is a cereal cyst nematode-resistant wheat.

The wheat industry is very important to Australia. This debate has raged long and hard. I reckon that if we get our people to the wire it is up to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to see whether he can come good with those amendments. Sections 7 and 88 of the Industrial Relations Act were alluded to, and the Opposition has made some commitment, as has the Minister, to deregulate the waterfront. The Inter-State Commission report makes very good reading. As the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) said today, overseas shipping in Australia is viewed as a war zone. Today on the waterfront one can get a job for 20 hours a week on good money with long overtime, five weeks paid leave and an annual leave loading of 25 per cent. Waterside workers are earning an average of $25 an hour-some earn more than $50-with generous employment conditions. I am sure that there are a few farmers-and a few politicians too-who would not mind those sorts of conditions.

I will have an opportunity during the committee stage to add further to my comments. To suggest that 45,000 farmers would be pitted against each other is a folly. It is not their way to go down that path. I support the amendments but I think that the legislation, as suggested, has been sloppily put together. There are 45 Government amendments, making approximately 90 amendments from both sides of the House. This great industry has been brought to its knees in some areas. Not only is the Government trying to pit farmers against each other, but it is trying to pit politicians against each other. As I have said, with the concessions that we have made we have been shown to be philosophically consistent and I hope that the Minister will offer Australia those same concessions when it comes to cleaning up the labour market and the waterfront.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Wheat Marketing Bill and associated Bills before the House are very important. Also, this debate is very important because when all the necessary amendments have been made to this sloppy and poorly drafted legislation-we in the Liberal Party of Australia have about 41 amendments and the Government itself has the same or an even greater number-we will have provided for a significant change in the arrangements for the industry which, I am certain, will be of lasting benefit to wheat growers.

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation is also important because, with the Government having responded-and I stress this-to pressures from the Liberal-National Party Opposition in key re- spects, it is something of a landmark in so-called micro-economic reform; that is, the potential for significant advance in that micro reform area, as the jargon has it, is there. When we talk of micro-economic reform, we are talking about the freeing up of existing restrictions on the supply of goods and services, change to enable greater productivity and lower costs, the absolutely essential reform, the central, the indispensable, key for this country to work its way out of its yawning trade deficit and frightening overseas debt problems and go on to resumed rising living standards for all Australians.

That is why this legislation is so important. It is all about deregulating-a word many fear, but, in simple terms, all about reducing restrictions on enterprise and efficiency and producers wanting to do things in the most productive way possible to everybody's benefit-for instance, not to have to send wheat to a port 100 kilometres away by rail; but at present it is regulated that it has to be sent by rail and possibly by a route up to twice the direct distance from the port, therefore costing much more. So it is about removing and reducing restrictions on enterprise and efficiency and producers wanting to do things in the most productive way-deregulating to a degree the domestic marketing of wheat, but also the transport, handling and storage of wheat. Indeed, if one of our amendments were to be passed, restrictive aspects of the conditions of people working in those areas of the activities of this great industry would be covered.

The central concern in the industry is what will happen to the domestic price of wheat under deregulation of the domestic wheat market. Given the limitation on time, I will not go over that matter again. It has been adequately dealt with by my colleagues. It has been widely canvassed. It is not a case of going back to the 1930s. The Australian Wheat Board remains in place, and its export power will remain unimpaired thanks to pressures from the Opposition.

With feed wheat already deregulated, it is the remaining 60 per cent of the domestic market that we are talking about. As the export market takes 80 per cent of the production, if one works that out it is about 15 per cent of total production and the domestic price for that which is at issue. Indeed, while there will be some pressures for the price to fall perhaps nearer the average export level, there are important offsets. There are the possibilities of entrepreneurial activities of growers specialising in particular varieties of wheat-chemical varieties, for instance-and, of course, the benefits of greater competition and efficiency in the transport, handling and storage of wheat. I stress again that it was the stand of the Opposition in calling for the implementation of reforms in transport, handling and storage as one of the conditions for coalition support-the other main condition was that the Australian Wheat Board's export powers should not be changed, and we won on that too!-of the wheat legislation that forced the Government to extend the legislation in this way.

To return to my starting point, this legislation is very important both in setting the parameters for the future of the wheat industry, including deregulating-that is officially; there is already a large measure in practice-the domestic market in wheat, and in encouraging significant change for greater competition and efficiency in the transport, handling and storage of wheat.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, it is reform in this so-called micro-economic area, the freeing up of restrictions on the supply of goods and services, change to enable greater productivity and lower costs, which is the central and indispensable key to this country working its way out of its yawning trade deficit and massive overseas debt problem. The agenda for reform is wide indeed. The central, indeed the first, item is reform of the rigid, inflexible and centralised wages and industrial relations system, further straitjacketed by the accord-and the `macro' benefits of which are debatable, and its micro, its efficiency, adverse effects are disastrous. The recent publicity about the problems in Qantas Airways Ltd in attracting and retaining engineering staff is just one of hundreds of examples one could cite. This agenda for so-called micro-economic reform also includes, related to that, the countering of the widespread incidence of restrictive work practices and it includes the key areas of the reform of the waterfront, coastal shipping, land transport and communications. It further includes privatisation for greater efficiency and growth and lower prices-like the crying need in Qantas but, of course, that is blackballed by the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. That is the sort of agenda of reform in this vital area.

A month ago we had the report of the Inter-State Commission on the waterfront which recommended changes to achieve economy-wide savings of the order of $620m and increased output of twice that to the benefit of the whole nation. It was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 7 April that even before the report had been tabled in this Parliament, Mr Tas Bull of the Waterside Workers Federation and Mr Bill Kelty of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) had conferred by telephone and `agreed to reject the package of proposals outright'.

I guess that significant reform in this area sooner or later is going to involve taking on such as the Waterside Workers Federation, and even the ACTU itself apparently. For the Australian Labor Party, that would involve taking on its own essential constituency. That causes me to ask, as I have asked before, whether this Labor Government can or will ever seriously undertake the essential micro-economic reform to get this country back onto its economic feet. By the very nature of its constituency, it is not going to be on. What the Sydney Morning Herald described the other day as `the outlandish proposals' or, again, `the nonsense' trotted out by the Government's shipping reform task force, set up by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis), underscores the point. For significant micro-economic reform, the Australian people will simply have to change the Government.

At the same time, this side of politics has to deal with its own constituencies. The wheat growers are just such a case in point. That position was not lost on Mr Tas Bull. At the time I referred to a moment ago, when some reports had it, wrongly, that the coalition was going to oppose the wheat legislation, that gentleman made a remark to the effect of quoting the then reported coalition attitude to wheat as some sort of justification for his summary rejection of the Inter-State Commission's proposals for the waterfront. But in fact the coalition is supporting this legislation, subject to a number of amendments it has previously referred to.

As I said at the outset, this legislation is very important-something of a landmark. It will free up the domestic market for wheat, to the longer term benefit, I firmly believe, of the great wheat industry and, in the context, provide potentially for a significant increase in competition and efficiency in the transport, handling and storage of wheat, again to the benefit of wheat growers-but also to the benefit of the entire Australian economy and nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I thank all honourable members who have participated in the debate. I think that some members on both sides have really put their hearts and minds into the debate and put forward some very sensible points. I particularly thank my colleagues on this side of the House, in particular, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren), who addressed the whole question of rail transport. The debate on the wheat industry and the Wheat Marketing Bill and associated Bills, here in Parliament but mainly outside, has in the past year been marked by a lot of cant, hypocrisy and double standards. All that is bad in our political system has come to the surface.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate has been bitterly divisive for the Opposition. The princes of hypocrisy, the rural populists and farm socialists-that is, the National Party of Australia, led by a dinosaur-have fought for the status quo because their farmer boss, the Grains Council of Australia (GCA), has told them to.

The ideological deregulators, the Liberal Party of Australia, under weak leadership, have had to fight their lust for inaction in matters rural because of wider imperatives. It has been only the encouragement of some backbenchers that has given any credibility to the stand of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). One of the silliest comments made in the debate was that the Government's proposals were designed to cause trouble in the Opposition. One does not have to try very hard.

A lot of the debate in the House has been about the export enhancement program (EEP) of the United States and the common agricultural policy (CAP) of the European Community (EC). Despite the protests of the US Administration and the grain farmer dominated views of the Congress and European parliaments, the EEP has seen the US share of the world wheat and flour market go up from 28.7 per cent in 1985-86 to an estimated 42.9 per cent in 1988-89, while at the same time the EC, against which the EEP is targeted, will have increased its share from 17.4 per cent to some 20 per cent. Australia's share has declined from 19.5 per cent to 11.3 per cent for the same period. The US likes to waste its taxpayers' funds, and the sort of people in the US that the National Party thinks it represents here just love it.

So at the outset let me state that it is because of the EEP, the CAP and the international conditions that the Australian Government is standing so firmly behind the Australian wheat industry. We are standing behind the whole industry with national interest cover on credit sales to the extent of $800m, which is a contingent liability. We are standing behind the whole industry with a government guarantee for the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) to finance the purchase of the crop and to enable the acquisition of the cheapest funds on world money markets. This has saved the industry hundreds of millions of dollars since 1984. We are standing behind the whole industry by not only enabling the AWB to pay a first advance of 90 per cent but also with an underwriting guarantee of 90 per cent of an estimate of the return from the season ahead, phasing down to 80 per cent in common with general government policy for other commodities.

We are standing behind the industry by now proposing a Government guarantee for the AWB to trade and market on the domestic market so that it can participate in the domestic feed wheat market without one arm tied behind its back to give growers more choice. We are standing behind the whole industry by maintaining the export monopoly, although I believe that my original proposition to allow the export of de-natured wheat by the trade posed no real threat to the monopoly. We are standing behind the wheat industry by giving it the capacity to levy itself to fund additional facilities such as marketing, financial and storage, as agreed between growers and the board.

What we are proposing is that the AWB be clothed with more powers then ever before and that the peak industry body, the Grains Council, have a larger role to play than ever before. We are standing behind the wheat industry by placing the AWB in the most powerful market position to catalyst change and savings in off-farm costs-to put more money in growers' pockets-and the growers will have more choice. Those that the National Party consider cannot make choices can do exactly what they have always done-grow the wheat, harvest it, tip it into a silo and take the pool price.

It is not often that I become involved in an ideological debate of the dimensions of this one. The strands in the debate relate to the ideologies of the Opposition political parties, the perceived self-interest or ideological views of various participants and some gutless State governments-principally Queensland. Putting aside the lies, libels and license of some, the main arguments have centred on the maintenance of the status quo, a bit each way, do not do as I do, do as I say-the classic position of the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair)-genuine unashamed hypocrisy and distortion of State's rights and the Constitution. The positions put forward really demonstrate why we are crippling ourselves as a commodity exporting nation. Little in the debate has indicated an analysis of the wheat industry and the international situation throughout this decade. Little has indicated any thought about the changes under way in the grain growing and livestock sectors of Australia. Little has indicated that it is sensible to look at Australia's overall interest, producers, consumers, exporters and service providers. Very few people see any need for the application of consistent principles or any conceptual basis to policy or a vision of where we want the wheat industry and its infrastructure to go.

It is rare for a Minister to be in the same job for two wheat plans-and I had better concede at the outset that the Grains Council of Australia was a bit better to deal with in 1988-89 than the Australian Wheatgrowers Federation (AWF) was in 1983-84. Quite frankly, there was not as much Queensland National Party influence. My experience with the wheat industry goes back to the early 1950s as a buyer of wheat. Wheat was then worth a bit over one pound a bushel f.o.b. The administered stock feed price for wheat was eight shillings a bushel-so wheat was poked down the throats of chooks and we exported eggs. We did not export a high proportion of our crop and it mainly went to the mother country.
