We got away from that and reversed the stupidity by adopting a cost of production formula on the domestic market that almost strangled our domestic industries-and eventually we got away from that.

In 1977-78 I worked in the Grains Marketing Section of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. So I thought I would see the AWF and the AWB to get some figures. I was bluntly told by an AWF spokesman that no figures were available, certainly not for the likes of me, that the Federation ran the Board and told the Government what to do, and, of course, the National Party Ministers always did as they were told. But eventually I got some figures and found out with hindsight that the Board had cost growers $150m on one deal alone-not that the growers ever knew anything about that. And a Japanese student of our grains industry drew to my attention the absolute nonsense of what was happening in grain marketing in general in Australia. Failed State boards are just one symptom of the nonsense that continues to this day.

Gradually the picture unfolded: a rail system that did not reward users as a result of efficiencies or occasional investment and one whose accountancy and work practices were Dickensian; a storage and handling system overbuilt by a factor of 3-some 43 to 45 million tonnes storage for a maximum 22 million tonnes crop-because of farmer control, and some indecision on where to place additional storage because of the blockages in the system, such as sidings being too short, but I will not go into it; and terminals crucified by demarcation disputes, hopeless management, thuggery and featherbedding. The whole system was creaking. Yet we had a marketing monopoly that never really marketed wheat but one which traded, with the United States setting the world price and where we could get some premiums because of freight and quality advantages. The growers never had to market their wheat; they had only to sell into a pool or sell on the black market-but perhaps then that was okay.

Running up the 1984 plan, the Wheatgrowers Federation wanted the status quo. Now the GCA wants the present status quo. The States wanted the status quo, and of course, the Senate only grudgingly let the Bill through. So we did not get the best-we got a bit better. We got commercial borrowing freedom, we got a permit system on the domestic market, and we got a more corporate, professional Board. The States would not move much on off-farm costs. Remuneration agreements were negotiated by the Board toughly, or there was a stand off. So I set up the royal commission in 1986 to expose the creaking system which, to be fair about it, was starting to be cleared up.

Why change is the cry. Let us look at the 1980s. The 1981 United States Farm Bill was predicated on high inflation and with the US Loan Rate in the early 80s underpinning the world price for wheat. When the price fell to a certain level US wheat went into stocks and the Canadians, EC and Australia expanded production.

In 1983 the United States started to reduce the loan rate. In 1984 the Government changed the underwriting formula because as then structured it could not be maintained without becoming a subsidy. As I said, I also put in a permit system for feed wheat to nail some of the black market trade and tried to get a more corporate Board to end the appointment of National Party hacks or favoured agripoliticians regardless of ability. In 1985, the US Farm Bill moved to keep the loan rate under the market price and thus the world price became more subject to price fluctuations. In 1985-86, with the influence of high United States stocks and the EEP and CAP export subsidies, the world price collapsed and was further corrupted by the use of the export subsidies. It was only the dollar float that saved the wheat industry. At that time; if one wants to talk about a farm crisis, it was very much a specialist cereals crisis. The EEP, despite US denials, may become a permanent feature of its highly administered system, like the EC stabiliser export subsidy system. There is another report out today from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics which shows the deficiencies in the EC system and what that means. The 90 per cent underwriting formula in this new plan will pay more than the old 95 per cent formula in the next year or two.

One of the reasons I am putting forward deregulation of the domestic market is to develop marketing skills to better equip the AWB on the more volatile international market. Many speakers from the Opposition have not demonstrated that they understand how the international market works or the role played by buyers, sellers and other governments. The Opposition has not demonstrated that it understands what is changing on the domestic market. Even in Queensland the barley growers want a permit system. The Queensland cotton growers, by a majority of 94 per cent, want to market privately. Major advances in rail systems have been made in Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria and there is even change under way in New South Wales. The Australian Wheat Board is offering new services and the Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport has put an enormous focus on the way ahead.

This Government has other parts of the whole system-shipping and coastal trade-and the wharves on the agenda. But these things do not really affect the wheat industry as a bulk commodity all that much. What we have on the agenda is something that the Opposition, when in government, never bothered with. That is a problem of 60 to 80 years standing. It is one of the major reasons we are trying to help the wheat industry. Firstly, we are setting about enabling the Wheat Board to have enough power to catalyse change in storage, transport and handling to give farmers cost savings off-farm on an ongoing basis. In other words, we will use market forces rather than administered arrangements to keep the pressure on costs off-farm. Costs for some people are 35 per cent of their gross.

We are doing this to enable the Wheat Board to be more effectively and commercially involved in domestic trading, thus allowing it to compete with private firms and traders and provide additional services and choices to farmers; to enable the Wheat Board to be in a position to trade in other grains, so that it can assist growers where there are no statutory arrangements-there is a grain legume industry growing up-and to give the Wheat Board experience in the domestic market and to give it a more pro-active role in international grain marketing, where I believe we have missed opportunities; to enable general economic efficiency gains for the cropping sector as a whole; to allow the better development of additional domestic and export industries, agricultural industries and value adding or at least to remove some of the unreasonable costs for it. I would like to read in part a letter from a major food producer in Australia, which states:

At a time when we are expanding our usage of premium soft wheats, as a result of our major test market launch in the USA and growing sales to a wide range of overseas countries, it is particularly concerning that our ability to produce should be threatened by a statutory system which encourages the sale of scarce speciality wheats for stockfeed. This year we will waste $650,000 to bring wheat from Western Australia to replace premium soft wheats used for stockfeed. Obviously we will need to recover this amount in price increases.

The producer will probably lose the export markets it has gained. That is what is happening. We are doing this to give the growers more choice through the Wheat Board and to give growers more influence through the Grains Council of Australia. What the Government is doing accords with the advice that has been given to governments for many years. It accords with advice from at least three Industries Assistance Commission reports and the Opposition's own Balderstone Working Group to Provide a Policy Discussion Paper on Agriculture, which it chartered when it was in government. What the Government is doing accords with its general policies on statutory marketing authority reform, underwriting and the particular needs of the wheat industry.

I have been listening to National Party of Australia members opposite. They do not have much capacity to make policy, only to be told what to do by farmer organisations. Every move I have made in agriculture has been opposed by the National Party unless the relevant farm organisation agreed. An awful lot of tick-tacking goes on. I was very pleased that unlike the dairy debate, people from the Grains Council were not sitting in the boxes advising the Government on its amendments, but that is what happened with the dairy matter. The Opposition in the Senate held up the dairy plan for a year and probably robbed itself of a lot of money, because it could have got a lot more advantage out of the value of the dollar for that extra year. But no-one now seriously disagrees with what I did.

We can go through the various industries-grapes or whichever one we can name-and if there is a bit of opposition we can almost count the number of days before the press release comes out. The National Party has a lot to answer for. Gunn and Vines fixed up the wool industry but look what they had to go through. The government of the day, to its credit, did respond, but unless we go through a bit of hell and put down all this rural populism, we never really get change. The rural press somehow thinks that the National Party has failed-peculiar articles are appearing-because it is not going to hold on to every aspect of the status quo. I would put it to some of these commentators that the National Party and the Liberal Party succeed when they are prepared to embrace reality and look to change that is in the farming industry's own interests. I have always said that we cannot take the Liberal Party seriously unless it takes agricultural policy more seriously. What has happened this time is that the old two card trick, with the Opposition saying one thing in the country and another thing in the cities, has been exposed. We have a lot of high cant on labour deregulation, and I will get on to that during our consideration of some of the amendments. Because we deregulate one part of the system to the advantage of an industry, does not mean we have to deregulate the world. I think the Leader of the National Party at one stage was suggesting that we had to break down the CAP. That is how nonsensical it got. If someone brought in a Bill to privatise Qantas Airways Ltd, would honourable members opposite be demanding that we privatise every government business enterprise? How are they going to handle that through the Cabinet and Ministers in government? It is nonsensical.

The Australian Democrats had a hang-up about organic wheat, durum wheat and a few other things. When we explained that the new system would allow better arrangements for those people, they fell back to some other opposition. I ask honourable members to have a look at the States and the Australian Agricultural Council. They sit on their hands. I got all the arguments back, and they were a repetition of exactly the arguments I was getting from the Grains Council that week. At least the Grains Council is more flexible. It can move week to week, but the States never could. There is a lot of nonsense about. Now the State Ministers want to have a meeting. They were not prepared to look at the intrastate question the last time I put it to them because, as they explained to me privately-not at a meeting-`We are against this on first principles because the farmers tell us they are not going to accept it yet. We will have a look at that later if you get it through'. I think governments have to make policies. I do not think the environmentalists should make environmental policy. I do not think the trade union movement should make industrial relations policy. I do not think outside forces should make policies for governments or political parties. I believe that governments have to make policies, to weigh it all up, because we are in a very privileged position, with our Public Service, to look at the whole, and that is why we have governments. If farmers run all aspects of rural policy and farm policy, we will not get good policies. That is the view I have always taken. Consultation is another thing. Of course one must consult and adapt to reality.

As I have said, I think some elements of this debate have been pretty disappointing. I will try to address some of the other more substantial matters that have been raised as we get on to the amendments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clause 1 agreed to.
Clause 2 (Commencement).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall Mr R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 2, pages 1 and 2, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:
Commencement
``2. (1) Section 1 and subsections 2 (1) and (3) commence on the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent.
``(2) Subject to subsection (3):
(a) except for Part 6, subsections 85 (1) and (2) and section 86, this Act commences on 1 July 1989;
(b) Part 6, subsections 85 (1) and (2) and section 86 commence on a day to be fixed by Proclamation;
(c) Part 6, subsections 85 (1) and (2) and section 86 are repealed on 30 June 1990 if their commencement has not been fixed by a Proclamation published in the Gazette before that day.

``(3) Except for section 1 and subsections 2 (1) and (3), no provision of this Act shall commence until after this Act has been approved by a majority of Australian wheat growers at plebiscite pursuant to the provisions of the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 (Plebiscite of Australian Wheat Growers) Act 1989, which shall be the subject of subsequent enactment by the Parliament.''.

The amendment I have circulated, because of the form necessary, appears complicated, but in effect if carried would simply make the operation of this clause subject to a plebiscite of Australian wheat growers. I have moved this amendment without any optimism. I know from the attitude of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy that he does not want to listen to the industry. In fact, he rejected it in his last few remarks. He does not think the industry is capable of making the right decisions on its own behalf. I find this a rather strange attitude. We are talking about people who make large scale decisions about investment; decisions which concern their livelihood. They make those decisions on a day to day basis or on an annual basis. They are decisions which affect their whole life. They are taken against the great background of the industry, and they are taken on the basis of all the current knowledge that is available to the agricultural and grain growing industry. As I said, they are made with comprehensive planning in mind. Many operators in the grain industry also establish off-farm investments to sustain their activities during difficult times. Beyond all else, rural producers know that there is always something unknown in their future. Because of that they do not approve lightly changes which are put forward by this Government.

A number of special pleadings are made as to why the Australian Wheat Board should be stripped of its powers to fix an internal price. Some of those pleadings can be persuasive in isolation, but they are very much in isolation. Much of the success of the price structure in Australia is due, obviously, to the umbrella price fixed by the Board. As I have said, the overseas market, with its continuing curruption, does not give long term confidence to Australian wheat growers about overseas prices. They fear the introduction of those corrupted prices into the internal Australian market.

Without repeating things that have been said previously, I believe that the orderly marketing of this industry began after much argument in the late 1940s and culminated in a vote with something like 64 per cent of grain growers approving the initial operation of the Australian Wheat Board. With the industry marketing having begun in that fashion, significant alterations should again be approved by growers. It is because of this belief that I have moved the amendment. As I said, I do not believe that the Minister will entertain it judging by the remarks that he has already made, but I want it to be known that there are a few people in this place who still regard the opinion of growers as important. We are willing to say to them, without any hypocrisy, that we believe in the good things that are said about them and in the modern technology used by the grain growing community. We believe growers are able to assess not only their individual financial position but also their position in the rest of the world, that they are aware of international politics and international price movements and that, because of this, they are capable of making decisions on their own behalf. If this amendment is carried it will establish the necessity to ask for the grain growers' approval before this legislation becomes law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Many honourable members have referred to the messy nature of the Wheat Marketing Bill. It is significantly different from the Act and the issues are complex, as the Opposition has acknowledged. The Wheat Marketing Bill was drafted against tight deadlines, and there are a number of technical drafting amendments. A large number of the amendments have resulted from representations by the Grains Council of Australia and the Australian Wheat Board. The Bill was drafted in consultation with both these organisations. Even after it was finalised and tabled, both organisations came back to the Government and sought further changes. I think honourable members would agree that it is important that the technical aspects of the Bill are right. Consequently, the Government agreed to accept some of the proposals and any consequential amendments. Some of the amendments are very similar to those being proposed by the Opposition. To add to my embarrassment, late advice from the Attorney-General's Department is also responsible for some of the amendments including all those for the Wheat Industry Fund Levy Collections Bill to which I will be moving 17 amendments on behalf of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The aim of the amendment moved by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) appears to be to hold up the legislation until there is a referendum of wheat growers on the provisions. This is a recipe for inaction and is against the interests of the wheat growers. There has been extensive consultation on these issues. As I said earlier, governments need to take decisions and act on them. The honourable member for Boothby has already argued that we should allow the States, in effect, to block the legislation, and now he wants to put it to a referendum. I do not think we can tolerate that sort of thing, so the Government rejects it.

The honourable member also says that the Australian Wool Corporation fixes the price of wool, so why cannot we let the Wheat Board do the same thing for wheat. The Wool Corporation does not fix the price of wool; it fixes the reserve price. It uses the growers' funds to maintain a buffer stock and to manipulate that stock and price to try to get the maximum from the market. But eventually the market fixes the price. This legislation actually allows the Wheat Board to pay a levy in much the same way as the Wool Corporation has for many years. Again, the market will set the price for wheat.

TALK.START.PARA: —The market does not set the price. The wool is withdrawn from the market into a stockpile.
—Eventually it is sold on a market. The Government rejects the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2, before the definition of ``Board'' insert the following definitions:
`` `authorised person' means a person appointed under section 88a for the purposes of the provision in which the expression occurs;
`authorised receiver' means a body corporate authorised to receive wheat on behalf of the Board under section 56a or under a corresponding provision of a State Act;''.

This amendment is consequential on amendment No. (4), which I will be moving in relation to the continuation of the Australian Wheat Board's current role in the acquisition of wheat from Australian wheat growers. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy speaks of consultation. However, he conducted the debate on this issue by press release. I have yet to hear of any meeting that the Minister attended at the grass roots level.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was not game to go to any.

—I am not aware of any that he went to. The amendment provides for the definition of authorised receivers, State corporations or bodies corporate contracted to the Board with respect to the storage and handling of its wheat, and it relates to authorised persons being exempted from the compulsory acquisition scheme for the purpose of gristing for use on a farm seed wheat and stock feed, and the movement of such wheat. The House should be aware that the consequences of this legislation will weaken the marketing power of the individual and the family farmer. Small businesses and family farms are the dynamo of private enterprise, but they must have a level playing field. They do not have it in this legislation. Therefore, I ask the Committee to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment. We will be opposing amendments that will be moved by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher). The amendments basically seek to reinstate the status quo-the compulsory acquisition system, the feed wheat permit system, the grower to buyer scheme and the administered price for the domestic market. It is contrary to the basic aims of the Wheat Marketing Bill. The accusation that I did not attend any grass roots meetings is incorrect. I went to a meeting of the Queensland Grain Growers Association in Caloundra. I realised after that meeting that they were the shock troops of the opposition to the proposals. When I faced that group of people with their own expressed ideology on choice and freedom, on markets and on deregulation, there seemed to be hardly any opposition. I think what the honourable member for Mallee is concerned about is one of the central things, the question of whether the domestic price will fall. We know that it will not fall in the next two years. We will not be able to measure it in the hand because if we get a cheque in the hand we do not know whether it is more or less at a certain point.

SPEECH.PARA: The measurement is always very difficult, but let us just try to calculate this figure. This relates to about 15 per cent of the wheat crop-it might be less in a big year-sold domestically. The best calculation one can make is by looking backwards, with a bit of regression analysis: take an extreme condition, with no domestic wheat sales being made through the pool, with the whole lot being involved. The estimated potential losses to the pool have been estimated, and they range between 23c a tonne in 1987-88 to $2.93 a tonne in 1986-87-and that is the year when the world price collapsed.

There is every chance that the domestic price of wheat will be above average export prices. No-one will sell below the pool price on the domestic market, unless they are crazy. No-one will be forced to pay for services any more that they never use. I keep on stressing the fact that the Australian Wheat Board will be clothed with more powers than it has ever had before. It will be a major force on the domestic market. It will use its expertise. It will have 80 per cent of crop in its hands before it starts. That is why we can catalyse savings off-farm. It can use that export grain and can be in a very powerful position.

It will use that marketing expertise and its knowledge to meet users' requirements on the domestic market to sell wheat locally to the best advantage to growers. Local millers and processors can be expected to pay a premium in order to secure the quality of wheat required-perhaps through forward sales. Those growers selling direct or through merchants will benefit from being able to avoid the pooling and bulk handling costs associated with the current grower to buyer scheme, and also from being able to organise storage and transport arrangements to suit both buyer and seller. That is why we oppose what the honourable member for Mallee is proposing.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2, lines 34 and 35, omit `by notice published in the Gazette', substitute `by regulation'.

The unexpected concern that this legislation has aroused in a very widespread manner around Australia is the use of the commerce power to override State marketing boards completely unrelated to the transport and handling of grain or the marketing of wheat. Part of that concern arises from the definition of `grain'. It is a very wide definition. I think that every possible grain that has ever been thought of is included in this definition, and in case any more need to be included there is the further option: `any product of the soil declared by the Minister, by notice published in the Gazette, to be grain for the purposes of this Act'. That provision will be somewhat Gilbertian if it is allowed to survive in that form. Consideration was given to changing that definition of `grain' to restrict it more appropriately. However, we recognise that we should not restrict the Australian Wheat Board's ability in relation not only to exports of wheat but to where it works in with other State marketing boards or other grains. Therefore, as a safeguard I think it is necessary to change the provision to stipulate that instead of a notice published in the Gazette the alteration should be done by regulation. Thus, everyone would know what the Minister was up to, and there would be the opportunity for Parliament to disallow the regulation. We will seek to amend the legislation in three other places to ensure that the Minister-or any Minister, for that matter-does not override the State marketing boards, which have been formed at the wish of the producers in those States and of those State governments, outside the use of the commerce power, to assist the Australian Wheat Board to improve the transport, storage and handling of grain and the marketing of wheat.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

Objects of the Board
``5. The Board shall perform its functions and exercise its powers:

(a) with the principal object of maximising the net return to Australian wheat growers from the marketing of wheat by securing, developing and maintaining markets for wheat and wheat products and by minimising costs as far as is practicable; and
(b) in so far as it can do so consistently with paragraph (a), with the same object as is specified in paragraph (a) in respect of grain other than wheat.''.

As currently drafted in the Bill, the objects of the Board include the provision of a choice of marketing options to Australian wheat growers. My amendment affirms the primary object of the Board as maximising the net return to Australian wheat growers and, as far as is compatible, to the growers of other grains as defined in the Bill. This Parliament should not have to search for very long to see what has happened to the reputation of some sectors of the corporate sector and to question the establishment of massive monopoly marketing in this country. I am convinced that, after deregulation, there will be fewer grain merchants than presently exist, and this can no longer represent true competition without a multitude of buyers.

No one in this debate has shown that deregulation will improve net return to growers as distinct from benefits to buyers or traders. My colleague the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), in his usual well-balanced contribution to debate, spoke about the wheat issue-unlike most members in the House-but he could not convince me that the weakest seller, selling for whatever reasons at a low price when supply and demand are in imbalance on the domestic market, will not set that price. I also remind the honourable member that there is no prohibition on growers planting any varieties that are not approved at present. However, growers must expect that these varieties will be heavily discounted if their quality is poor and demand is not available. My colleague the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) well knows the chaos in table grape marketing without lack of quality, quarantine or inspection procedures. I ask the committee to support my amendment.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

These amendments and the amendment moved by the Opposition are very similar. These amendments broaden and clarify the Australian Wheat Board's commercial operations to encompass activities involving grain as well as wheat. I would emphasise that this does not change existing marketing arrangements for other grains in the States. The primary objective of the Wheat Board is to look after interests of wheat growers, and any trading in other grains will be to assist the AWB's wheat marketing operation. As I have said, the Opposition has moved a similar amendment to broaden the scope of the AWB's objects to cover trading in other grains in the interests of all grain growers, not just wheat growers. This goes beyond the scope of the Act which deals with the Australian Wheat Board-not an overall grains corporation. Also, it should be borne in mind that the Wheat Board's commercial activities will be financed by wheat growers only. In these circumstances it would be inequitable to give it a charter to look after the interests of all grain growers. I think the Opposition is looking at the same position as the Government. There is some semanticism in this, but I would strongly adhere to the Government's amendments in this case.

``(b) to trade in wheat in Australia;
(c) to make arrangements for the growing of wheat for the purposes of:
(i) the export of wheat from Australia; or
(ii) trade and commerce in Australia;''.

Next to the initial move by the Government to weaken the Wheat Board's export power, the greatest concern is the chaos that this Government could inflict on the wheat industry and the wheatgrowers of Australia as from 1 July when the Wheat Board will be unable to trade intrastate. Some 80 per cent of the Wheat Board's domestic trading is intrastate. By the wording of this legislation, from 1 July it will actually be illegal for the Wheat Board to trade intrastate. This is in complete contradiction of the Minister's second reading speech in which, in several places, he claimed that the aim of the legislation is to strengthen the ability of the Wheat Board. The legislation does the direct opposite. This is an indictment of the Government and the Minister for misleading the wheatgrowers of this country and for months and months doing nothing about a situation which he and the Government knew was coming.

We are now well into May, and the only way that after 1 July the Wheat Board can really be allowed to trade successfully intrastate without the possibility of a legal challenge is for the States to pass complementary legislation. At this stage, not one State is prepared to pass complementary legislation. The South Australian Parliament has already risen. On Tuesday the relevant Minister, supposedly a friend of this Federal Labor Government, in the Victorian Parliament said that he would have a look at the situation when this legislation was finally passed in Canberra. By then, the Victorian Parliament will have risen. The Queensland Government rejects it. The New South Wales Government rejects it. So far, to my knowledge, the Western Australian Government has rejected it. What a hopeless situation.

What an indictment of a government that claims that it is helping the Wheat Board to be a more flexible intrastate marketer, to do this and to do that for the benefit of the wheat industry. It promises that the Board will be there as a stronger and more flexible safeguard for the wheat industry, to help the wheatgrowers of this country. Yet, with this legislation, it will be illegal for the Wheat Board to trade intrastate after 1 July. What a disastrous and treacherous situation for any government to impose on the wheatgrowers. It is in complete contradiction of what the Government promised for months and months.

As far as I am concerned, there is only one way that we can endeavour to assist, and that is by moving this amendment to allow the Board to trade if it so desires-it may not wish to, because of the possible complications-until such time as there is some sort of court challenge from a trader or the Labor States are finally bludgeoned by this Government into passing the complementary legislation. This is one of the most significant problems that we have with this legislation. The wheat industry also has this problem with this legislation because of the Government's betrayal of that industry. Therefore, we will require a division on this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept this amendment. I commented on this in my response to the contribution to this debate by the honourable member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall). The States were not prepared to move on this matter in general terms when it was put before them at the Australian Agricultural Council. The amendment attempts to provide the Australian Wheat Board with powers to trade intrastate in the absence of complementary State legislation. We cannot say very clearly that there is any problem in the Wheat Board trading intrastate, but we think there is a legal matter that needs clearing up.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no problem at all with the principle of ensuring that the Wheat Board has this power. The trouble is that the Opposition's amendment goes beyond the Commonwealth Government's constitutional power. The only way this issue can be solved is for the State governments to pass the necessary complementary legislation. All that legislation has now been sent to the States. If this legislation gets through the Senate-as I expect it will-I expect that the States will very quickly come to the party. The Grains Council of Australia is certainly one of the first organisations to put the pressure on the State governments to do just that. The creating of an additional clouded legal situation is not the answer since it puts the Wheat Board in an impossible situation. The Government cannot accept this amendment because it is not constitutional.
Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Lloyd's) be agreed to.

We are told that it is part of the Government's policy to allow the Australian Wheat Board to trade more commercially, to allow it to be more flexible to make decisions itself. Yet time after time in the legislation there are quite unnecessary restrictions because of ministerial veto or for some other reason. These amendments relate to one of those reasons. In moving the amendments I want to make the point that if the Board is to be able to operate commercially then it may have to give preference to one State over another in relation to the growing of a particular type of wheat, a special pool or some other consideration where it is sensible for the grain growers of this country and for the Wheat Board, in the exercising of its correct commercial responsibilities and its responsibilities to maximise returns to wheat growers, to have a pool which could be said to give preference to one set of growers in one State over another. SPEECH.PARA: (12) Clause 15, page 10, line 13, after ``Chairperson'' add ``who shall be a wheat grower at the time of appointment''.
(13) Clause 15, page 10, line 16, after ``members'' add ``5 of whom shall be wheat growers''.

These amendments relate to the membership of the Australian Wheat Board. There are two membership provisions which are of great importance to the wheat growers of this country. Both provisions have been very much an integral part of the Wheat Board until this legislation was introduced. The first amendment concerns the Chairperson. It has been to the advantage of the wheat industry, because of the nature of its operations and of its overseas sales, that the Chairperson of the Board should be a wheat grower at the time of his or her appointment. This requirement has served the industry well. The industry sees good reason for that to continue. I believe that it is sensible for it to continue and it forms part of my amendment.

The other amendment concerns the membership of the Board. There are eight members nominated by a selection committee and the Grains Council provides the membership of that selection committee. At present the legislation requires that five members be wheat growers, one from each of the five wheat growing States. The Opposition does not intend to persist with this requirement that the five grower members be from each of the five wheat growing States because if that is a high priority of the wheat growers of this country, they have the ability, with five out of the eight members, to determine that in relation to the selection of those nominated members. However, the Opposition believes that it is important that five out of the eight Board members be wheat growers. The Wheat Board deals with a product which remains basically as wheat-it is not processed or transformed into some other product. There is no requirement other than to have skills in finance and marketing as well as wheat growing-certainly not some of the other skills needed by some statutory marketing authorities.

We believe that it is important that the current system of membership of the Board which has proven to be successful should continue; hence, the amendments standing in my name that the Chairperson be a wheat grower at the time of appointment and that five out of the eight nominated members be wheat growers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his second reading speech the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) indicated that the Chairman would be a wheat grower, so it seems to me to be sensible and reassuring if that commitment were followed through by including it in the amendment.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I put forward the reasons why the Government cannot accept this in the concluding part of my second reading speech. Once that is done the special features of a particular industry can be taken into account. I do not think it is appropriate to include in the legislation a provision with respect to the Chairperson.

SPEECH.PARA: I have made the commitment in my second reading speech to appoint a chairperson who is a grower. In terms of interpretation before the courts, that has the power of law. I merely want to maintain consistency. As the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) said, any attempt to provide consistency was rolled in the Senate last time. As a result, I think we got a less capable Board in some ways than we may have done. Where we have applied these principles to authorities such as the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation and other statutory marketing authorities where the growers, the levy payers, have the whip hand, we have quite successful boards.

Unlike the honourable member for Maranoa, I trust the Grains Council. In relation to the Opposition's second amendment, if the Grains Council, which will have a majority on the selection committee, finds two or three outstanding people in one State while in another State there are no outstanding people, I trust it to make the decision and to have that flexibility. The Board needs to be comprised of the best people available with a balance of production, marketing and finance skills. If one cannot get five growers who have a mixture of skills State by State from an industry which has 45,000 growers, I think that the wheat industry would be in a pretty desperate situation.

The Board needs to have this expertise because it has to do a very important job. I am trying to establish boards which are based on expertise, using the best people available-not, as I said, favoured agripoliticians. I believe that the Grains Council can settle some of the industry's politics and let the Board get on with the job by appointing the best people to it. The Government cannot accept the Opposition's amendments.
Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Lloyd's) be agreed to.

The amendments relate to the ability of the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) to pay the market rate for its employees. Under legislation at present the Board is restricted in its ability to pay for employees because it is not allowed to have any employee paid more than the chief executive, the chairman or the managing director. The AWB is a major borrower and a major user of foreign currency; in fact, it is one of the major operators in Australia in respect of foreign currency. So one has only to look at the restrictions that are inherent in this legislation and then at the going price for a financial director, money market operators or employees who are essential to the Board and the well-being of wheat growers who supply the Board to realise that it is absurd that there should be such a restriction. If the Government is sincere in its claim that it wants the Board to be more commercial, as I said, it is absurd to say, on the one hand, that it wants the Board to be commercial and then, on the other hand, to unduly restrict it in this way in such an important and sensitive area. I ask the Government to seriously consider these amendments because I believe that they are of considerable importance for the better management and operation of the Board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendments, which I think are eminently sensible. This sort of flexibility should be given to the remuneration packages available to the Australian Wheat Board when it sets the salary levels and so on for employees. I hope that the Government will agree to these amendments, because the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) has put forward one example and I dare say that over the years the Board will face similar situations from time to time where it may have to pay additional amounts to gain the services of people with the necessary skills to carry out some of the functions for what is going to be one of Australia's major corporations.

The Grains Council of Australia argues that this provision is not in the current Act and therefore precludes the Wheat Board from paying an employee more than the chief executive receives. SPEECH.PARA: As it stands, clause 44 provides scope for the Board to engage a managing director as chief executive and pay him or her market rates, provided the chairperson is appointed on a non-executive basis. I understand what the Opposition is getting at here. It is a matter that I have been grappling with for quite a long time but, as I have said, the Government has broader matters to consider in this area, and at this stage it cannot accept the amendments.

``Division 1A-Delivery of, and dealings with, wheat

``56E. (1) A person who has possession of wheat in a Territory on a farm may, by notice served on the Board, notify the Board that the person wishes to deliver the wheat to a miller for gristing with the object of having the produce of the gristing return to the farm for use on the farm.

``(2) On receipt by the Board of a notice by a person under subsection (1), an authorised person may, on behalf of the Board, issue to the person a permit for the movement of the wheat from the farm to the mill and the movement of the produce of the gristing from the mill to the farm.
``(3) A person who has possession of wheat in a Territory on the farm on which the wheat was grown may, by notice service on the Board, notify the Board that the person wishes-

(b) each of them is owned, operated or controlled by a partnership and the 2 partnerships have at least one common partner;
(c) one of them is owned, operated or controlled by a person and the other is owned, operated or controlled by a partnership of which that person is a member; or

Permits for purchase of wheat for stockfeed use

``56F. (1) The Board may, on application made to it by a person and on payment of the prescribed fee, issue to the person a permit authorising the person to make, during a season, purchases of wheat from growers for a stockfeed use.
``(2) An application under subsection (1) shall be in accordance with a form approved by the Board.

``(3) A person to whom a permit has been issued under this section shall, not later than the expiration of the month immediately succeeding a month in which wheat was purchased under the permit, by notice in accordance with a form approved by the Board served on the Board, notify the Board, with respect to each such purchase during the last-mentioned month, of:

(b) the date of the purchase;

``(6) The Board shall not issue a permit under this section otherwise than in accordance with the guidelines having effect from time to time under subsection (5).
``(7) This section has effect subject to a Wheat Tax (Permit) Act 1989 and a Wheat Tax (Permit) Collection Act 1989, to be the subject of separate enactment by the Parliament.
Contracts for sale of wheat entered into on behalf of Board

``56G. ``(3) A notice under subsection (1) shall be in accordance with a form approved by the Board and shall specify-
(a) the name and address of the grower;
(b) the name and address of the offeror;
(c) the quantity of wheat to which the offer made by the offeror relates;
(d) that the wheat is proposed to be purchased for human consumption, for a stockfeed use or for an industrial use, whichever is applicable;
(e) the terms and conditions of the offer made by the offeror; and
(f) such other information as is required to be specified by the notice.

``(4) Where, on the receipt by the Board of a notice under subsection (1), an authorised person is satisfied that acceptance of the proposed offer would not detrimentally affect the orderly marketing of wheat by the Board, the authorised person may authorise the grower, in writing, to accept the offer on behalf of the Board.

``(5) On the receipt by the grower of an authorisation under subsection (4), the grower shall set aside wheat for sale in accordance with that authorisation and, thereupon, the wheat so set aside becomes the absolute property of the Board, freed from all mortgages, charges, liens, pledges, interests and trusts.

``(6) A contract for the sale of wheat entered into by the grower, on behalf of the Board, under an authorisation given under subsection (4) shall provide that the price for the wheat shall be paid directly to the Board.

``(7) A person who, after the end of a season, serves a notice on the Board under subsection (1) with respect to wheat harvested in that season shall, at the time of service of the notice, serve on the Board a declaration in writing signed by the person stating the season during which the wheat was harvested.
``(8) A person who contravenes subsection (7) is guilty of an offence punishable, on conviction, by a fine not exceeding $1,000.
Unauthorised dealings with wheat
``56h. (1) Except for the purpose of compliance with section 56b or in accordance with a permit under section 56e or 56f or an authority under section 56g or with the consent in writing of the Board:

(a) a person shall not sell or deliver to a person or transfer to a person the possession of, or take possession of, or grist or otherwise process, or mix with any other grain or substance, wheat in a Territory, other than wheat that has been sold by the Board;

(b) a person shall not move wheat in a Territory, or cause or permit wheat in a Territory to be moved, from the farm where the wheat was grown or from the farm or other place to which the wheat has been moved in accordance with a permit under section 56F;
(c) where a person has purchased wheat under a permit under section 56F the person shall not use the wheat for a use other than a stock feed use; and

(d) where wheat has been sold by the Board under a contract of sale entered into in a Territory, being a contract that specifies a purpose for which the wheat is to be used-the purchaser under the contract shall not use the wheat for any other purpose.
``(2) A person who contravenes subsection (1) is guilty of an offence punishable, on conviction, by a fine not exceeding:
(a) in the case of a person not being a body corporate-$10,000; or
(b) in the case of a body corporate-$50,000.
``(3) Paragraph (1) (a) does not prohibit the use of wheat on the farm on which the wheat was grown.''.

This amendment proposes the insertion of a new division in the Bill comprising a number of new clauses designed to restore the Wheat Board's compulsory acquisition powers in respect of the Australian domestic wheat market. Clause 56a provides for the appointment of State corporations or bodies corporate contracted for wheat storage and handling to be appointed to receive wheat on behalf of the Board. Clauses 56b and 56c relate to the delivery of wheat to the Board. Clause 56d provides that the Act does not apply to seed wheat or wheat that does not satisfy the Board's classification standards. Clauses 56e and 56f provide for the issue of permits in certain circumstances, while clause 56g provides for contracts for sale of wheat to be entered into on behalf of the Board. Clause 56h prohibits unauthorised wheat sales.

This has been an interesting debate. Almost everyone who has spoken has been a wheat lumper, a bag sewer, a truck driver or a wheat grower. I recently took the opportunity to read many of the previous debates on former wheat plans in the industry. I discovered that nothing has changed, only the players. Orderly marketing does not inhibit innovation by growers in the type of wheat produced. It is the commercial worth of the wheat variety so produced that is the barrier or stimulus to innovation. Orderly marketing provides equity and stability. It provides the same price for the same quality grain irrespective of geographical location and, importantly, does not encourage inefficiencies. A farmer's own skills and productive capacities are still paramount to his success. Downstream processors are not disadvantaged or their development inhibited by the current wheat pricing and marketing arrangements. The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics strongly supports this position.

Wheat growers should not be expected to subsidise the international competitiveness of downsteam user industries. Therefore there is a need in the debate on this legislation to distinguish between and separate out marketing competition from storage, handling and transport competition, which I totally agree with. Competition in marketing has the guarantee of reduced grower returns, while competition in storage, transport and handling produces at this time only a speculative gain for growers.

The Government's commitment to this is acknowledged, but the results are all in the future and must be challenged, given that the Australian Wheat Board in this Bill does not have the capacity to compete fully on a level playing field. I put before this chamber that none of the debate has shown that de- regulation will improve net returns to growers as distinct from benefits to buyers or traders. The Minister acknowledges that in his second reading speech. If deregulation did open up the domestic distribution system, I am convinced that any lower storage, handling and transport costs for domestic sales would flow to intermediaries and domestic end user buyers. As the Australian Wheat Board has estimated, farm gate return would be the net of the export component, storage, handling and transport costs, keeping in mind that grain can go to either domestic or export markets. The domestic buyer therefore has to pay only marginally above the Australian Wheat Board's reference price to compete, and he pockets any savings. A sole seller operating for growers and not shareholders, given the flexibility of clauses of this Bill, will allow the purchase of services from different providers and so influence costs and pass these on to the growers.

I cannot support the changes that will reduce net returns. As I have already said, the Minister has acknowledged that the only argument is about the amount. He has also acknowledged that this amount is very much dependent on the savings that may be achieved in the future with transport, handling and storage. Changes are made here without any guarantees of reductions in storage, handling and transport costs. I believe that the wheat growers face the worst possible scenario. I ask that the chamber support this important amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have pleasure in supporting this amendment. We will, of course, be calling a division on it. It is a great disappointment to me that so many members of the chamber are not supporting their constituents and the wheat growers of this nation. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) knows from meetings and from the Grains Council of Australia itself that it does not oppose many of the clauses in this Bill. It is important to understand that. I ask the Minister to withdraw this legislation and to start again. The fact that he has to put up 45 amendments tonight and that he seems to be accepting every second one that we are putting up, indicates to the growers of this country that he and his Department of Primary Industries and Energy have made a shonky, shocking job of preparing the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Vice-President of the United States of America has only just visited us. He left our shores only three or four days ago with all sorts of promises about not subsidising wheat. Yet yesterday we saw an announcement of a sale to Russia. Russia is only one of the markets that we sell to. We sell throughout the world, but obviously Europe and the United States will continue to subsidise our markets heavily through cash. I have held talks with the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, Clinton Condon, who was a constituent of mine. He grew up with me in the small wheat growing centre of Dalby in my electorate of Maranoa. He certainly is not in agreement with a lot of this legislation. Today the card price for Australian wheat is $US183 which converts to $A229. The card price relates to the Australian standard white quality wheat, the standard wheat we produce in Australia. It is not the best wheat; it is not the worst. It is an average standard quality. The average price for this wheat will be used in the so-called deregulated market. There is no such thing as a deregulated market. It is a lot of hogwash. There is nothing deregulated in business these days. There never was and never will be.

I guess Mr Peter Fisher and I cannot agree with the position the Government is taking. I believe that the legislation ought to be withdrawn in protest at the United States Government's intention to continue to subsidise. The legislation ought to be brought back into this House with some sort of support for the locally, domestically consumed wheat. I believe we ought to be able to trade our feed wheat as freely as possible. That is the only way we will be able to support the price locally for grain. I include the word `grain' because it is being included in many amendments to the wheat legislation. The word `grain' is being used in many clauses. It is quite obvious that this legislation will cover all grains, not just wheat.

It is very important to understand this industry. People compare it with the wool industry and other industries that have support prices. Growers were forced to come together as a cooperative many years ago and establish their own selling organisation. That is what the Board is; the growers own the Board, not the Government. The Government does not put a red cent into it. In actual fact, the Government put $12m a year into the Australian Wheat Board which is worth about $3 billion a year in export income. This big-hearted Government is withdrawing the support it paid last year. Poor Peter Walsh whinges and cries in Cabinet that he had to spend a lousy $175m in an industry that is earning and trying to put the balance of payments of this nation in some sort of perspective. Of course, without wheat, instead of us being $1 1/2 billion down the drain each month we would be $3 billion down the drain each month.

Wheat is a very important commodity for the total economic well-being of all Australians, not just the wheat growers of this nation. It is interesting to see the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) here. I know he is going to sleep because of what I have to say. Of course, the honourable member for Wills is listening intently to what we on this side of the House have to say. It is good to see him in the House occasionally. It is not often that he makes the effort to get here. I do not know what is grown in his electorate; it is probably carrots. Was he born a wheat-lumper? Was he born at Bordertown and did he lump wheat most of his life? I can imagine!

This Bill should be withdrawn and it ought to be re-introduced with some sort of support price arrangement. I do not mind if the growers have to pay it. I am supportive of applying a levy. I have argued this way for a number of years. We ought to pay a levy. I would like to ask the Minister whether the levy is tax free. I have contacted the Department on a number of occasions and am yet to find out whether it is tax free. The Department did not know and the Minister's office did not know. But as a wheat grower and as someone who pays taxes occasionally, and large lumps of it, I am very interested to know. If it is tax free, the setting up of a levy like this is a benefit in my mind to the industry because if we build up a fund where we can help pay our first payment we should also under this legislation be allowed to use this money as a support for our domestic price.

What people do not understand is that the reason why the Wheat Board was established was that wheat happens to be stripped all at once. It does not come off every week, every month or every six months. Cattle are held in the paddock and there is a steady flow of beef to the market. There is also a steady flow of wool to the market.

Unfortunately for wheat growers, if the sun happens to move from north to south fairly rapidly the headers rush from north to south and the crop is ripped off in about two months. All of a sudden there are 1,800 million tonnes of grain for sale. The whole of the domestic wheat requirement is dumped on the market at once, and this is what forces the price down. After the wheat industry is deregulated other grains industries will suffer because presently the price of wheat, which is held up with the support price, is the price for all grains that are traded in this country. That includes sorghum which in Queensland is traded nearly as much as wheat. A lot of sorghum is grown in Queensland. Some of it is sold on the open market and some of it is sold through a board arrangement. The domestic price of wheat controls the price of barley, oats, sunflower, sorghum, et cetera. Wheat is the grain produced most. It affects the price of all grains that we sell. Once we deregulate it, our price will become the card price for export. With the heavily subsidised world market it is obvious that the price of wheat which is consumed locally will drop substantially. No-one can convince me otherwise. If growers are prepared to put a levy on wheat, as the Government is forcing us to do, to the tune of $50m a year, we ought to be able to introduce our own support price and so help control the price of domestic wheat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious from the remarks made by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) that he has not listened to anything I have said. Obviously he believes in his own rhetoric. It is a pity the growers in his electorate believe it, too. He says that the majority of farmers are not supporting me. If I waited for the majority of farmers to support me I would never change anything. I was delighted to see in one poll that 41 per cent of farmers supported what I was doing in the wheat market. I could not believe that-I still do not believe it-but there you go. The levy will not be forced. It is tax free on the way in; the tax is paid when it is rolled out. That is what happens with wool. The honourable member is trying to get back to subsidies and to continue the domestic arrangement. We have to keep putting forward the belief that we cannot support 80 to 85 per cent of wheat production by fixing prices for 15 to 20 per cent of it. I think the honourable member for Maranoa is beyond persuasion, redemption, or even salvation.

SPEECH.PARA: I will address the more substantive comments made by the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher). He argues that market deregulation should be removed from the wheat legislation, now that the Government has taken steps to override State regulations which prevent cost savings in handling and transport being achieved. I reflect on a constant theme through speeches made by Opposition members in the second reading debate. They said that the Liberals had forced us in this whole question of transport and marketing. The timing of our decision on that was not forced. We got the advice on 30 August 1988. It was a question of working out when to exercise those powers if the States were not going to cooperate.

The approach of the honourable member for Mallee on this issue is much too simplified. Storage, handling and transport are integral parts of the overall wheat marketing process and changes in one area will inevitably affect other areas. There are benefits that arise from the deregulation of the domestic wheat market quite apart from those associated with grain storage and distribution. For example, there is a greater degree of choice for growers in disposing of wheat and there is the potential for local buyers and sellers to avoid the unnecessary costs associated with the pooling of revenues and costs which apply under existing grower to buyer arrangements. The organic wheat growers and the durum wheat growers pose a problem, as I pointed out, for a major food processor in this country.

The McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage Handling and Transport was of the view that potential resource cost savings can largely be realised under current marketing arrangements providing deregulation of transport, storage and handling costs occurs. It is also recognised that marketing reform may inject additional competitive pressures into the market environment for storage, handling and transport. The deregulation of the domestic wheat market can see the emergence of a range of new storage, handling and transport options, an increase in direct grower to end user sales, an increase in the use of on-farm storage as growers develop their own marketing strategies, the expansion in the activities of the private storage and handling agencies, and the extensions of the services provided by existing bulk handling agencies to meet the needs of private traders, millers and growers. In addition, deregulation of domestic marketing will allow downstream processors of gluten, starch and glucose to purchase wheat at market prices. That will inevitably enable an expansion of wheat sales on the domestic market. It will enable them to supply local users more cheaply and to compete more effectively with other supplies in very competitive export markets for such products as gluten and bakery pre-mixes. As honourable members know, Australia is a major gluten exporter competing directly with the European Economic Community on international markets.

I could go on, but we do have problems with the present system where costs are paid where they are not actually incurred. Any corporation which holds a monopoly over its outputs while it purchases inputs in a competitive and deregulated system is in a very favourable position. I think it is inconsistent for the honourable member for Mallee to seek deregulations in industries which supply handling and distribution services while opposing deregulation of marketing services which will produce cost savings for growers and users, especially when wheat alone amongst all exporters retains a privilege of a total export monopoly covering 80 to 85 per cent of the crop. Finally, many growers support deregulation in the domestic market and by extensive use of the parliamentary system have shown that they wish to have the option to sell wheat direct to users. They cannot be conned; they are not fools. The Government opposes the amendments.
Question put:
That the proposed new division (Mr Peter Fisher's amendment) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

The present penalty in the legislation for the illegal export of wheat is $100,000. That is clearly inadequate. The Government has recognised this, as has the Opposition, by the amendment the Government will be moving.

I wish to give a simple example of how inadequate the present penalty is. One could have a shipload of wheat of 80,000 tonnes. Even with a $10 per tonne profit, which is not a huge profit, one would have a total profit of $800,000. With a $100,000 penalty, one would still have a profit of $700,000. I make this point to the Government because its amendment proposes that the penalty be lifted to $300,000. Even with the example I have given, it still will not be an adequate deterrent to someone illegally exporting wheat. I strongly suggest to the Government that it give favourable consideration to our amendment, which gives the Board the flexibility to prescribe a percentage, so that it is made very clear that anyone who attempts to illegally export wheat will not profit from that illegal export.

While we welcome the fact that the Government will move amendments that stiffen up the penalties-they not only increase the financial penalties but also make illegal export an indictable offence-I still think that the penalty could, on some occasions, be insufficient. As the honourable member for Murray has pointed out, a ship carrying 80,000 tonnes of wheat would pay less than $4 a tonne penalty if it were illegal wheat. For someone who could make a reasonable profit on the wheat, that may be seen as a reasonable penalty to continue that practice. I urge the Government to have another look at this question of penalties because I still think they are inadequate.

``61a. The provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974 do not apply to purchases of wheat by the Board under section 60 or to pools for the marketing of wheat established by the Board under section 61.''.

The amendment relates to the exemption from the Trades Practices Act of that part of the Australian Wheat Board's domestic trading activities concerning the use of the pool for such domestic trade. The majority of the Wheat Board's domestic trading will be done by a subsidiary company which will be subject to the Trade Practices Act and all the other requirements of company law and ordinary commercial law in this country.

However, the Wheat Board is required by another proposed section of this legislation to purchase all wheat offered to it and the pool will be the basis for acceptance of that grain. As I said, almost all of it will be for export purposes. When the pool buys grain into the pool there is no certain knowledge as to the ultimate sale of that wheat from the pool. There will be a number of times when it will be very sensible from the point of view of both the Board and the customers for wheat to be sold from the pool domestically. The problem is that under the Trade Practices Act the dominant trading position of the Board's pool could be challenged, thereby preventing the Board from trading interstate domestically. This is a sensible amendment which clarifies the situation so that the Board is free to exercise the different options available to it for domestic trading using the pool.
