``(14) The appropriate percentage, for all seasons commencing on or after 1 July 1989, is 95%.''.

This is one of the most significant aspects of the legislation and also one of its major weaknesses. At present, the Government guarantee is for 95 per cent based on a three-year average. The Opposition accepts that there are advantages in changing that calculation from a three-year average to the current year, but it strongly opposes the initial reduction from the present 95 per cent to 90 per cent phasing down to 80 per cent over five years and having a 1993 sunset clause.

The requirement of the Government to actually pay out any of this guarantee on a single year basis is non-existent. In fact, as the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) indicated earlier tonight, on the calculation for each single year basis in only one year would there have been a requirement for the Government to make up the guarantee, and that was 1980-81. That was before the Board had the ability to hedge. Since then, even with the very bad year of 1986-87, when under the current arrangement there was the requirement for the Government to provide ultimately about $220m, there would have been no requirement for the Government to contribute on this new basis. However, by having an underwriting of 95 per cent it materially assists the Board to borrow-and borrow favourably-so that wheat growers can receive a better initial payment and it generally assists the industry at no cost to the Government. I believe that this is a very unfair and mean provision inserted by the Government and it is one about which the Opposition feels very strongly. We will divide on this issue to indicate our strong opposition to what we consider to be most unfair treatment of the wheat industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the words of the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) which he has put so eloquently and forcefully. This is a critical issue. It is the major issue on which the Opposition takes exception to the Government in relation to this particular section of the Bill. Subclause 13 provides that when determining the figure the Minister shall have due regard to information given by the Board or the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. I ask the Minister whether he would be prepared to disclose to the Parliament that information. Furthermore, I ask the Minister whether he is prepared to give an undertaking to the Parliament to provide information about the basis of any pool estimates that would lead from that, and things such as relevant futures prices, exchange rate forecasts and that type of thing which would form the basis of the Government's estimate of the expected price so that it could set its level of underwriting.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out to the House that, while I support entirely the amendment moved by the Opposition, it is not the preferred position of the Australian wheat growers. A 95 per cent three-year moving average would allow more effective support during a severe downturn in the industry. It would also remove from the Minister some of his capacity to direct any instructions to the Australian Wheat Board in line with political considerations. The previous arrangements allowed for adequate market signals to the industry and no more evidence of this is needed than the major change to production that has taken place over the past two seasons.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the underwriting scheme has operated exactly as it was intended. However, the minister's commitment to stand behind the industry will be of little value given the proposal to reduce the level of underwriting. Underwriting is intended to ensure and guarantee the borrowings of the Australian Wheat Board at the lowest possible cost in order to commit a high advance payment to growers on delivery of the crop. It is intended to cushion the effect of a significant collapse of international prices and to help retain resources in the industry while not making long term signals.

It is also intended that it will be triggered only in exceptional circumstances but that there will be automatic Government support in a crisis. The Grains Council of Australia considers that the existing scheme has operated exactly as was intended, having been triggered, as the shadow Minister mentioned, on only one occasion and that was in 1986-87. This, as has been pointed out already, follows the aggressive use of the export enhancement program by the United States of America. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in the May economic statement, agreed to stand behind the industry in the event of an extraordinary downward price movement, while expecting the industry to shoulder an increasing share of the price risk itself.

The cost to the industry, in 1986-87, of overseas subsidy activity was estimated in the Industries Assistance Commission report at about $420m. Given that the underwriting payments incurred by the Commonwealth in that year in which the gross national product was breached are estimated at around $200m-of which approximately $60m, it will be remembered, was interest-the industry, I believe, has already borne a considerable burden. Where downturns in the market, as a consequence of foreign subsidies, are not so dramatic, the industry simply absorbs the full price impact. I believe that underwriting to the 95 per cent level, with a moving average, and at least in line with the amendment proposed by the Opposition, is necessary to reduce uncertainty and to maintain investment and production in the industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this amendment. Let me, in doing so, ask the Minister, who has been on about the wheat industry costing taxpayers' money, to point out where this is so, other than in the case of the dollar-for-dollar subsidy for research and development-a cost of $12m a year in an industry worth roughly $3 billion a year. I would argue that the industry more than covers itself by the amount of taxation it pays to offset some of those funds that it receives for research in ongoing years. Of course, that is an advantage to the taxpayer who gets more money back in the longer term. Growers are disappointed that the percentage is being dropped from 90 per cent to 80 per cent over a period of five years, during which time the grower levy is being introduced. There does not seem to be anything in the legislation covering who is going to pay the levy in the domestic market. I have contacted the Minister's Department and I have been told that the purchaser will be licensed, but I have not seen in the legislation anything to suggest who is going to pay this levy and how it is going to be collected. I suggest that a fairly large black market will develop: people, like pig producers and chook producers-like the Minister himself-will not pay this levy because the Government will be able to keep tabs only on the larger purchasers, who will contribute up to 5 per cent, a maximum of 5 per cent-that the Government, in this legislation, is imposing.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important for growers and for the Board to have the highest possible guarantee by Government. It costs Government nothing to give the guarantee to borrow funds. It could be argued, perhaps, that the saving is a taxpayers' subsidy, but it still costs the Government nothing. Indirectly, of course, without it there would be a great cost in interest. There is a saving between 0.5 per cent and one per cent in interest borrowings, either locally or overseas. The overall average of the Board's borrowings is about 11 per cent. The local average, of course, is 15 per cent-much higher than the cost of borrowing overseas-but the Chairman of the Australian Wheat Board tells me that that is the sort of saving that is involved. Of course, it is a considerable saving. I should have thought that the Minister and his supporters, as so-called deregulators, would be as keen as mustard to give the growers as high a percentage as possible to save some funds in this economic situation, in which the cost of borrowing money is horrific. Indeed, interest is one of the growers' biggest costs. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron), I do not have chooks any more. So, unlike the honourable member for Maranoa, I do not have to declare a pecuniary interest in this matter.
—It was a foul comment!

—It was a pretty foul comment! I have never been on about the wheat industry costing the taxpayers money. The underwriting did exactly what it was intended to do: there was a complete potholing in the market and the underwriting scheme triggered the situation. Although no-one thought that that would happen, as honourable members know the wheat price collapsed under the impact of the export enhancement program, the common agricultural policy, and all the rest of it-high stocks.

SPEECH.PARA: The first advance, of course, is the most important thing for wheat growers. What we are giving by way of guarantee will allow the Australian Wheat Board to maintain a high first advance. The Government guarantee and the absolute level of underwriting, of course, is what enables the Wheat Board to borrow so well on international money markets, and an 80 per cent underwriting certainly gives the Board that capacity with a government guarantee. The reason why we cannot accept this is basically that Government's policy is to phase underwriting down, consistent with the broader policy of reducing government involvement in statutory marketing, whereby industry is taking greater responsibility for its own risk management, and greater commercialisation of the Board.

It should be remembered, of course, that the level is initially 90 per cent, phasing down to 80 per cent. The reduction in level is, therefore, very gradual. Even with underwriting at 80 per cent, the wheat industry is very favourably compared with other industries. Provision is also made for the industry to fund advances in excess of the underwritten level. I understand that the industry is not disposed to do this, and no-one is going to force it to do so. The industry is not going to do it because it does not think it is worthwhile, which undercuts the rationale being put forward by the Opposition. Incidentally, in response to the honourable member for Maranoa, the Board will collect the levy. It does not collect the levy on black market wheat now as it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a question raised about the Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics and the Board in regard to how you set the figure for underwriting. Would you be prepared to give that to the Parliament?

—Yes. I will have to check that and get back to the honourable member by way of correspondence. Off the top of my head, I do not see any problems in doing that. Basically, we accept the Wheat Board's figure, because it is a bit closer to the margin. There is only a difference by way of cents. So, if any group of intelligent people sit down and pick up the same sorts of parameters, they can easily arrive at the price. there is never any real dissent about it. I will get back to the honourable member officially.

—I would just like to question the Minister on his comment about the levy. I would still argue that there is nothing in the legislation-I agree that the Board eventually gets the money from the levy to say whether the purchaser or the seller of the grain pays the levy.
—Again, I will clarify that for the honourable member for Maranoa.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Mr Lloyd's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (36) Clause 78, page 39, lines 1-5, omit subclauses (18) and (19).

The amendment removes the sunset clause whereby the underwriting terminates at the end of the 1993 season. It is the only part of the legislation that has a sunset clause and I commend the Government for removing this restrictive arrangement elsewhere in the legislation. As it is never likely to be triggered or cost the Government any money, I would think that it is a sensible amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

SPEECH.PARA: (6) Page 39, after clause 79 insert the following new clause:
Remuneration of authorised receivers

``79a. (1) The Board and each authorised receiver shall enter into an agreement with respect to the remuneration of the receiver by the Board for services provided by the receiver, for any facilities made available by the receiver for the storage, protection, treatment, handling or transfer of wheat and for any expenses properly incurred by the receiver.
``(2) The terms of, and the conditions for, the remuneration payable under subsection (1) shall be the subject of subsequent enactment by the Parliament.''.
This amendment provides for authorised receivers to be remunerated by the Board under terms and conditions to be determined subsequently.
Proposed new clause negatived.
Clauses 80 and 81-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 82 and 83-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (37) Clause 82, page 40, after subclause (2) add the following subclause:
``(3) Regulations for the purpose of subsection (1) shall not be made without agreement by the Grains Council, after consultation with the Board.''.
(38) Clause 83, page 40, lines 39-41, omit subclause (3), substitute the following subclause:
``(3) Regulations for the purpose of subsection (1) shall not be made without agreement by the Grains Council, after consultation with the Board.''.

Both these amendments refer to making provision for the Grains Council of Australia to agree in relation to the use of the levy. I know that there is general provision for the Australian Wheat Board to consult with the Grains Council but there is no specific requirement. As it is significant amounts of growers' money that we are talking about, and a range of purposes for which the levy can be used, therefore I believe it is appropriate that with the agreement of the Grains Council, the body representing the wheat growers of Australia-and it is their money-those two clauses be inserted.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —While it is appropriate that provision has been made in clause 83 for the Grains Council of Australia to consult with the Australian Wheat Board on the operational arrangement for the Wheat Industry Fund, it would be untenable for me, as the Minister responsible to the Parliament, for the activities of the Wheat Board, to have an industry body placed in a position to exercise direct potentially conflicting control over the Board. The industry cannot have it both ways. If it wants that kind of autonomy, it can obtain it through the establishment of an independent industry funded body. While ever it chooses statutory marketing authority it has to accept that there are some limitations. The Government opposes these amendments.
—Do the levy funds that are collected become the property of the Australian Wheat Board? If so, this amendment would not apply.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no response. I stick to my position.
—I am not questioning the Minister, I am asking him to verify the fact that the funds collected from the grower levy become the property of the Wheat Board and not the Grains Council?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Sure, they become the property of the Wheat Board, because the Wheat Board is the creature of the industry, the instrument of government policy while ever the industry or the Government decides that it should be a statutory marketing authority. But that does not in any way remove the Government's opposition to these amendments, because it really does put a consultative relationship in such a position that the Grains Council exercises control beyond that of the Government, and the Government does have a heavy involvement in this industry by way of a national interest cover and massive guarantees for funding.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

(24) Clause 85, page 41, lines 21 and 22, omit ``that is to be paid during that season'', insert ``on which levy is imposed during that season that is to be paid''.

(40) Clause 88, page 44, after subclause (12) insert the following subclause:
``(12a) The regulations shall not prescribe a State or Territory enactment except in relation to the storage, handling and transport of grain or the marketing of wheat.''.

These amendments, particularly No. 40, are the same as that to clause 7, which the Minister previously agreed to. They just relate to and confirm the safeguard that the power that the Minister has through this legislation cannot be used to override the marketing functions of State marketing boards but still preserves the ability for the Wheat Board to act in relation to the transport, handling and storage of grain and the marketing of wheat.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned about this clause. I think the Minister covered this when he spoke about clause 7. I am particularly concerned about the rice industry in New South Wales and in other parts of Australia. New South Wales is covered by the New South Wales Marketing (Primary Products) Act. I would like the Minister to confirm that the legislation will not impinge upon the States, and particularly the rice industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) has stated, I have given ground here with respect to clause 7 already. In answer to his question on rice, there is a lot of nonsense put around about any product of the soil-I suppose including worms. The attention given here regarding the use of the power to override the States is consistent with the proposed amendment. The legislation has been drafted broadly to refer to grain in all respects, including marketing. This was done to ensure that, as far as possible, the Commonwealth's deregulation objectives are met. The concern is that the States could attempt to use vesting of other grains as a means to thwart the Commonwealth's objectives and to maintain sole receivership and rail monopolies. There is a bit of a double-edged sword for the Opposition in this matter. I have already indicated that I am prepared to accept clause 7 and to review this again to see whether there is a need to hold a firmer position when it goes to the Senate. I point out to the Opposition that this could be a two-edged sword; it might give an opening to the States to thwart what we are doing. Given the ratbaggery that we can expect of the Queensland Government, that is a possibility. The Government is prepared to accept these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Proposed new clause 88a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (41) Page 44, after clause 88, insert the following new clause:
Deregulation of labour practices

``(1) It is the intention of the Parliament that the Board and any corporation engaged in the storage, handling, transport or sale of grain for export shall, in regard to any matter connected with the storage, handling, transport or shipment of that grain:

(a) be entitled to take no cognisance of any agreement, undertaking or other arrangement which requires the employment of any specified number of persons who are members of a trade union or similar society or association of persons, and any such agreement and undertaking or other arrangement shall be void;

(b) be exempt from the operation of any enactment of the Commonwealth or of any State or Territory which would otherwise require the employment, or the giving of preference in employment, to persons who are members of a trade union or of a similar society or association of persons;

(c) be entitled to enter into voluntary employment agreements or undertakings with any employee or groups of employees, and such agreements or undertakings will override any awards of the Industrial Relations Commission;
(d) be entitled to enter into any agreement, undertaking or arrangement with any person or body in regard to the loading of any vessel and the manning of any loading apparatus; and

(e) be entitled to claim damages in the Federal Court of Australia or the High Court of Australia against any person, trade union or similar society of association or associations or persons for an amount equal to the amount of any loss of a financial or contractual nature caused by any action of that person, trade union, society or association of persons which disrupts the activities of the Board or corporation, as the case may be.
``(2) A natural person, trade union or similar society or association of persons contravening subsection (1) is guilty of an offence punishable upon conviction:
(a) in the case of a natural person-$10,000, and $1,000 for every day that the offence continues; or
(b) in the case of a trade union or similar society or association of persons-$100,000, and $10,000 for every day that the offence continues.''.

This proposed new clause relates to the deregulation of labour practices in the transport, storage and handling of grain. It is consistent with the Government's philosophy-at least I hope it is if one accepts what the Government is saying-to deregulate the transport, storage and handling of grain so that efficiencies can be achieved and costs to growers reduced. At present, as I see the application of that power, we will not be having any deregulation whatsoever in the transport, storage and handling of grain, particularly at the wharves. All there will be will be a managed or regulated arrangement between the Australian Wheat Board on the one hand, and the State rail authorities or port authorities on the other. That is not competition. It is not what the Grains Council was seeking when it wanted the commerce power used. It wanted to have an open, competitive situation.

Therefore, unless there is some reduction in the costs of labour in those regulated industries-in some of the very expensive work practices in the railways, on the wharves and in the general restrictions that build up the costs-there will not be any worthwhile savings achieved. If this Government is genuine in what it says about micro-economic reform and about getting some efficiency into the transport system, it should accept this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not long ago part time employees were employed at the wheat dumps throughout Australia to manage and bring in the harvest. The present labour system totally saddles the industry with costs. Employees employed on boards throughout country Australia are on salaries and receive holiday pay, leave pay and all the lurks and perks that are imposed by the ratbag union movement. The Labor Party Government in Canberra goes on with ratbaggery and hypocrisy about deregulating the grain industry. As grain growers we are very keen to see the Government follow through its keenness for deregulation and move into the union movement so that we may begin to compete worldwide. The Government will have to do something pretty soon because at the rate other countries are subsidising wheat sales we will not be able to sell any of our products. I mentioned earlier tonight the fact that the great family company John Shearer Ltd had closed down. It was not because of the quality of its product; Shearer machinery is noted in the farming community as the best quality product one could possibly buy for one's farm. Yet because of the high cost of labour and strikes by the unions in that factory we have seen a great Australian company go to the wall. It will start manufacturing machinery overseas. Australia will become an agent because of the union movement and the labour costs in this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the clause which really provides the ultimate test for the Government. In his second reading speech, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the AWB and other grain trading corporations are to realise the savings estimated by the Royal Commission, they must have the scope to use least cost methods of handling and moving grain.
We agree. One of the real concerns that the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport had was in relation to the waterfront. The Royal Commission report states at page 125:
Restrictive practices occur in all parts of the distribution system but particularly in rail transport-
and the Government has acted in relation to that-
at port terminals and on the waterfront.

Where is the action there? The Royal Commission points out that the major problem is on the waterfront, but to date the Government has squibbed on any action on the waterfront. We are providing the opportunity for the Government to act in relation to the waterfront, to reduce costs for grain growers. The following statement appears on page 128 of the Royal Commission report:
In the Commission's view, there is an urgent need to change the operating environment on the waterfront-
and I say `Hear, hear!' to that-
such that competition is encouraged between organisations whose respective work forces are dependent on the economic well-being of their employers.
Again, `Hear, hear!' to that. It continues:
Only in such an environment are real gains in efficiency improvements likely to be achieved on a continuing basis.

That is exactly what this amendment aims to achieve. It aims to achieve those improvements in efficiency on the waterfront through greater competition. As I said during the second reading debate, right now we have a situation where the shipping lines are proposing to put a surcharge on grain going over the wharves because of the lack of productivity improvements on the Australian waterfront. In fact, they are saying that it is so bad that they will not come here unless they get another $10 a tonne to cover the cost of loading their ships in Australia.

If the Government does not accept this amendment not only will it be squibbing on the action that it is taking in relation to deregulation as it concerns farmers but also it will be adding another $10 a tonne to the cost of getting wheat over the wharf. I urge the Government most strongly to accept this amendment moved by the Opposition, to show that it is genuine in its commitment to deregulation not just as it affects wheatgrowers but as it affects some of its mates in the union as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Government does not accept this amendment as proposed by the Opposition parties, the whole integrity and effectiveness of this legislation will be lost. I remind the Minister that in the past eight years the costs to growers from net returns have increased from 15 per cent of returns to 45 per cent. That clearly indicates the impact of restrictive work practices and industrial relations practices on the Australian wheat industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had actually given enough ideological savers to the Opposition-the monopoly for the National Party and the transport override for the Liberals-but they are having their self-indulgent war dance on this whole question of labour. I appreciate, of course, the acidic comments made by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) during his second reading contribution and just now, and all those nice words.

SPEECH.PARA: May I just point out to the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) that of course I know what the problem is. That is the reason why we are putting the Board in a position to catalyse savings-because we are dealing with State governments and because we are dealing with systems that are very hard to change. By putting in market pressures, we can get changes that we would never get through an administered system. I would love to get it for coal transport, but of course the Queensland Government's coal regulations for its railways are really holding back that industry. But one has a problem with State governments. This way we are doing it with a market induced approach.

It is absolutely crazy for the Opposition to propose that, because one area is deregulated in a rather complicated way to save farmers money, wages should be deregulated in a wheat Bill. As I said earlier, it is a bit like the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) moving to privatise Qantas Airways Ltd and the Opposition demanding that he privatise every Government business enterprise. The lot cannot be done at once. Other consultations have to take place. All this nonsense about--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have done nothing. You have had six years and you have done nothing.

—You had your chance, old boy. We hear all this nonsense about the wharfies and the reports before the Government. We have received them only in the last four to six weeks and we will be dealing with them this month.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us talk about all this hype about the wharfies. The wharfies are on three terminals. The wharfies are not the problem. This is a bulk trade. Opposition members talk about shipping. There is only coastal shipping to Tasmania, so forget the shipping. We are dealing with bulk trade. The taxpayers are subsidising the freight to Tasmania. Opposition members should not get into a lather about the wharfies. The dreaded wharfies operate in only three terminals. The reason they, and not the other unions, are there is that they are a lot more efficient. The wharfies have accepted more change than they are credited for. The problems have been in the terminals-in demarcation disputes and bad management there. It has nothing to do with the wharfies at all. It is a bulk trade. Wharfies do not carry every little grain across the wharf. Opposition members should not get all hyped up about shipping and wharves. That is not the problem for these bulk commodity industries.

The Government's wages policy and the accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions have already led to substantial reductions in labour costs. Other initiatives are being taken. As I said, they will be taken this month. These actions form part of a cohesive strategy for the reform of the labour market. The provisions already included in the Bill will put substantial competitive pressure on the grain distribution system, therefore putting further pressure on employment levels and conditions.

Another point is that the Commonwealth is continuing to provide assistance to the industry through the export monopolies, borrowing guarantees and national interest cover, which would offset any penalising effect. I am sure the waterside workers would like a monopoly, government guarantees, national interest cover and all the rest. So, honourable members opposite should not think that there is not a balance here. I will not accept an amendment which, in the reality of industrial relations-because we do not have slaves, as the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) wants-could jeopardise the Government's whole labour reform strategy.

We hear all this nonsense about wages deregulation. Opposition members should look at some of the realities about that. The reason why we do not have wages deregulation in the present situation is that it would be a bit like throwing a broad-based consumption tax in with inflation rising. This is another of the favourite hypes of honourable members opposite. The wage market is not a true market. It never ratchets down. Even in the Depression, in real and nominal terms it never ratcheted down. Opposition members should not think it is a real market. It is not a real market from another aspect. There is not a balance of power within the market. In other words, there is exploitation, such as in Queensland where most of the work force is non-unionised. We have awards as low as $231 a week. I know that when all the fellows opposite are going for more parliamentary pay they think $231 a week is real cream living, but they should not talk to me about wage markets and all the rest of it. We need protection and regulation in the wage market, otherwise we get massive exploitation.

The final point is that, if Opposition members get into Government and bring about wage deregulation, the only way they will escape from a massive wages blow-out-there is at least 12 per cent or 15 per cent there at present-is if they recess the economy quite massively. If that is what they propose, they will wreck this country. So, they should not get carried away with all their ideological hype and acidic comments. The Government does not accept these amendments.
Question put:
That the proposed new clause (Mr Lloyd's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that the seventh amendment that I intended to move has been negated, I withdraw it.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (28) Clause 93, page 47, lines 11 and 12, omit ``of a season that ended not later than 30 June 1989'', insert ``delivered to the Board before 1 July 1989 or in respect of which a permit was issued under the 1984 Act or under a corresponding provision of a State Act.''.

This amendment provides that the current Act will apply only to wheat delivered by the Board by 30 June 1989 and recognises that mechanisms such as administered pricing will not be in place to apply the provisions of the previous Act to any wheat received after that date regardless of the season in which it was grown.
Amendment agreed to.

Motion (by Mr Kerin) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose this legislation as it now stands. This is a fundamental issue to my grain growing constituency. I support the unanimous policy passed by the Victorian Grains Council in March, which was attended by 800 growers at Horsham. My decision to divide on the third reading supports a clearly stated policy of the National Party Federal Conference and the unanimous policy of the Victorian National Party.

SPEECH.PARA: It must be made quite clear that the measures to provide flexibility and commerciality to the Australian Wheat Board, the measures to remove unnecessary administrative costs and to impose pressures for efficiency in transport handling and storage authorities, are supported and not impeded by our earlier amendments. The report of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport was a watershed for the grain industry. His work was excellent and effective. Farmers have seen the greed of this Government and State governments plunder of farmers' returns through freight, fuel taxes and tariff costs of up to $9,000 per farm per year. While wheat industry protection stands at about 2 per cent effective protection, this sector carries a heavy protectionist burden that reduces net wheat growers' returns by some 18.4 per cent.

Finally, the Opposition parties have moved a number of amendments of great significance which have not been accepted by this Government. They relate to a satisfactory Board structure, a satisfactory underwriting level and the refusal of the Government to give any commitment to the deregulation of labour practices that have been the major cause of cost to the industry. In other words, the Government is attacking again the symptoms of our problems and not the causes. We see in this legislation further erosion of rural producers' status and support in a highly regulated economy. There is no guarantee that the opportunity will present itself again in this House to register opposition to this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: a.m.)-I also wish to oppose the full gamut of the Wheat Marketing Bill and the six associated Bills before the House tonight. I do this because not only am I opposed to the philosophy that growers have very little say on their board that is being reconstituted; I am also opposed to the fact that they are being levied to the tune of $50m a year and more as time goes by. In addition the Queensland Government's rights are being overridden by this legislation. It is interesting to note that the financial position of the Queensland Railways-this legislation wishes to interfere with the railways-was turned round by Mr Lane during his term of office. He should be praised for this. The Queensland Railways went from having an operating loss of $100m to having an operating profit.
—By taxing coal out of business.

—If the Minister withdraws the $3 per tonne export tax on coal we will get the railways in place; do not worry about that. It is all right for the Government to talk about the Queensland Railways. If he takes the $3 a tonne tax away from the coal mines that I have got in my electorate at Blackwater--
—I am waiting to hear the honourable member for Maranoa speak on the Wheat Marketing Bill.

—My own divisional council, Bulk Grains Queensland, the Queensland Wheat Board and the National Party executive council and management committee have all moved motions opposing this legislation. As a representative from the great area of Maranoa, I have much pleasure in supporting the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) in moving for a division on this Bill and in voting against it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a third time

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

Power to call for information

``11. An authorised person may, by written notice given or sent by post to a person, require the person to give to the authorised person, within a reasonable time specified in the notice, any return or information in relation to matters relevant to the operation of this Act specified in the notice.''.
Clause 12-

``(4) In this section:
`premises' includes:
(a) a structure, building, aircraft, vehicle or vessel;

Clause 13, page 5, line 30, after ``Act'' insert ``or the regulations''.
Clause 14, page 6, omit paragraph (1) (b), substitute the following paragraph:

``(b) that the issue of a warrant is reasonably required by the applicant for the purpose of ascertaining whether a person has contravened or is contravening a provision of this Act or the regulations;''.
Clause 15-
Page 6, line 31, after ``knowingly'' insert ``or recklessly''.
Page 6, line 35, omit ``1,000'', substitute ``$3,000''.
Page 6, line 37, omit ``$5,000'', substitute ``$15,000''.
Clause 16-
Page 7, omit subclause (2), substitute the following subclause:

``(2) Any conduct engaged in on behalf of a body corporate by director, servant or agent of the body corporate within the scope of his or her actual or apparent authority shall be taken, for the purposes of this Act, to have been engaged in also by the body corporate.''.
Page 7, omit subclause (4), substitute the following subclause:

``(4) Any conduct engaged in on behalf of a person other than a body corporate by a servant or agent of the person within the scope of his or her actual or apparent authority shall be taken, for the purposes of this Act, to have been engaged in also by the first-mentioned person unless the first-mentioned person establishes that he or she took reasonable precautions and exercised due diligence to avoid the conduct.''.
Page 7, at the end of the clause add the following subclauses:
``(6) Where:
(a) a person other than a body corporate is convicted of an offence, and
(b) the person would not have been convicted of the offence if subsections (3) and (4) had not been enacted;
the person is not liable to be punished by imprisonment for the offence.

``(7) A reference in this section to a director of a body corporate includes a reference to a constituent member of a body corporate incorporated for a public purpose by a law of the Commonwealth, of a State or of a Territory.
``(8) A reference in this section to engaging in conduct includes a reference to failing or refusing to engage in conduct.''.
Clause 17-
Page 7, line 39, omit ``person'', substitute ``member of the Australian Public Service''.
Page 7, line 40, omit ``persons included in a class of persons'', substitute ``a class of members of the Australian Public Service''.
Clause 18-

Page 8, line 10, omit ``occupier'', substitute ``person in charge''.
Page 8, line 11, omit ``occupier's'', substitute ``person's''.
(17) Clause 21, page 9, line 17, omit ``$500'' and ``$2,500'', substitute ``$1,000'' and ``$5,000'', respectively.

These amendments will alter the Bill to achieve the following objectives: to include as offences breaches of the regulations; to insert amended pecuniary provisions in line with updated levels; to clarify and limit the liability for actions taken on behalf of a body corporate; to limit to a specific class of persons appointments of authorised persons under the Act; to provide a number of other minor amendments to reflect established precedent. None of these amendments is expected to have any effect on the financial impact statement which appears in the explanatory memorandum of the Bill.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
